{"sarsnum_articles": "180", "sars": [{"archive_id": "8184900", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> COVID-19 update (60): animal, SARS-CoV-2-related viruses, pangolin, bat", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8184900", "date": "2012-02-10 11:31:06", "main_text": "SPOTTED FEVER RICKETTSIOSIS - CHINA: HONG KONG SAR ex SOUTH AFRICA\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 10 Feb 2012\nSource: Hong Kong New Yahoo [Trans. by submitter][edited]\nhttp://hk.news.yahoo.com/%E7%88%B6%E5%A5%B3%E5%9C%A8%E5%8D%97%E9%9D%9E%E8%A2%AB%E8%9D%A8%E5%92%AC%E6%84%9F%E6%9F%93%E6%96%91%E7%96%B9%E7%86%B1-054800787.html\n\n\nA father and his daughter have been confirmed to have spotted fever after traveling to South Africa.\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection indicated that the patients' family of 5 traveled to South Africa in December 2011. While there, the father and a daughter were bitten by ticks. On the 4th day upon returning to Hong Kong, the father complained of headache and had an eschar. The daughter was also found to have eschar[s?] and lymphadenopathy. They were seen by a private physician. Both are in stable condition after receiving treatment; no hospitalization is needed. Laboratory tests confirmed both to have been infected by spotted fever. The mother and another daughter also had similar but less severe symptoms. They have recovered after receiving treatment.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Angela Huang\n\n[Rickettsioses are causes of arthropod-borne human diseases, which can be roughly divided into typhus, scrub typhus and the spotted fever groups. In retrospect, it is surprising that, given the years that ProMED has been functioning, this is the 1st posting of a spotted fever group infection originating in Africa. This is the case despite Freedman, et al (1) reporting the spotted fever rickettsial diseases were the 2nd most common cause of fever in travelers returning from the developing world, after malaria but before dengue and typhoid fever.\n\nIn Africa, Mediterranean spotted fever had long been thought to be the predominant rickettsial disease caused by _R. conorii_. With the identification of _R. africae_ from patients with African tick bite fever in 1992 (2), it has been recognized that this disease is clearly the most prevalent cause of rickettsial infection in sub-Saharan Africa, and this disease is actually commonly reported in travelers returning from South Africa (3), particularly in those traveling to Kruger National Park. The literature contains a significant number of case reports documenting the acquisition of this infection in travelers and is represented by references 4-6. Reference 6 underscores one of the relevant physical findings of _R. africae_ infection, the presence of multiple, rather than one, eschars (lesions referred to a tache noir).\n\nThe CDC publication found at http://www.cdc.gov/otherspottedfever/ is a valuable reference listing the large number of spotted fever rickettsiae described throughout the world. The tables also include _R. aeschlimannii_ as a cause of spotted fever in southern Africa.\n\nIt is most likely that these cases described are due to _R. africae_ and are cases of African tick bite fever.\n\nReferences\n---------\n1. Freedman DO, Weld LH, Kozarsky PE, et al: Spectrum of disease and relation to place of exposure among ill returned travelers. N Engl J Med 2006;354: 119-130.\n2. Kelly P, Matthewman L, Beati L, et al: African tick-bite fever: a new spotted fever group rickettsiosis under an old name. Lancet 1992;340: 982-983.\n3. Jensenius M, Fournier PE, Vene S, et al: African tick-bite fever in travelers to rural sub-Equatorial Africa. Clin Infect Dis 2003;36: 1411-1417.\n4. Roch N, Epaulard O, Polloux I, et al: African tick bite fever in elderly patients: 8 cases in French tourists returning from South Africa. Clin Infect Dis 2008;47: e28-35.\n5. Tsai KH, Huang JH, Fournier PE, et al: African tick bite fever in a Taiwanese traveler returning from South Africa: molecular and serologic studies. Am J Trop Med Hyg 2009;81: 735-739.\n6. Althaus F, Greub G, Raoult D, Genton B: African tick-bite fever: a new entity in the differential diagnosis of multiple eschars in travelers. Description of five cases imported from South Africa to Switzerland. Int J Infect Dis 2010;14 (Suppl 3): e274-276.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1EPe.]\nSee Also\nIsraeli spotted fever - Israel 20120207.1034330\n2004\n----\nSpotted fever - Russia (Siberia) (02): background 20040514.1301\n1999\n----\nIsrael spotted fever - Portugal (Setubal) 19991228.2215\nAstrakhan spotted fever - Russia (Moscow) 1998 19990821.1461\nAstrakhan spotted fever - Russia (Astrakhan) 19990125.0118\n.................................................ll/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "malaria"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-12-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Equatorial Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Astrakhan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7565035", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> COVID-19 update (312): China, SARS-CoV2 origin, animal reservoir, WHO mission", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7565035", "date": "2012-02-10 11:31:06", "main_text": "SPOTTED FEVER RICKETTSIOSIS - While there, the father and a daughter were bitten by ticks. On the 4th day upon returning to Hong Kong, the father complained of headache and had an eschar. The daughter was also found to have eschar[s?] and lymphadenopathy. They were seen by a private physician. Both are in stable condition after receiving treatment; no hospitalization is needed. Laboratory tests confirmed both to have been infected by spotted fever. The mother and another daughter also had similar but less severe symptoms. They have recovered after receiving treatment.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Angela Huang\n\n[Rickettsioses are causes of arthropod-borne human diseases, which can be roughly divided into typhus, scrub typhus and the spotted fever groups. In retrospect, it is surprising that, given the years that ProMED has been functioning, this is the 1st posting of a spotted fever group infection originating in Africa. This is the case despite Freedman, et al (1) reporting the spotted fever rickettsial diseases were the 2nd most common cause of fever in travelers returning from the developing world, after malaria but before dengue and typhoid fever.\n\nIn Africa, Mediterranean spotted fever had long been thought to be the predominant rickettsial disease caused by _R. conorii_. With the identification of _R. africae_ from patients with African tick bite fever in 1992 (2), it has been recognized that this disease is clearly the most prevalent cause of rickettsial infection in sub-Saharan Africa, and this disease is actually commonly reported in travelers returning from South Africa (3), particularly in those traveling to Kruger National Park. The literature contains a significant number of case reports documenting the acquisition of this infection in travelers and is represented by references 4-6. Reference 6 underscores one of the relevant physical findings of _R. africae_ infection, the presence of multiple, rather than one, eschars (lesions referred to a tache noir).\n\nThe CDC publication found at http://www.cdc.gov/otherspottedfever/ is a valuable reference listing the large number of spotted fever rickettsiae described throughout the world. The tables also include _R. aeschlimannii_ as a cause of spotted fever in southern Africa.\n\nIt is most likely that these cases described are due to _R. africae_ and are cases of African tick bite fever.\n\nReferences\n---------\n1. Roch N, Epaulard O, Polloux I, et al: African tick bite fever in elderly patients: 8 cases in French tourists returning from South Africa. Clin Infect Dis 2008;47: e28-35.\n5. Description of five cases imported from South Africa to Switzerland. Reference 6 underscores one of the relevant physical findings of _R. africae_ infection, the presence of multiple, rather than one, eschars (lesions referred to a tache noir).\n\nThe CDC publication found at http://www.cdc.gov/otherspottedfever/ is a valuable reference listing the large number of spotted fever rickettsiae described throughout the world. The tables also include _R. aeschlimannii_ as a cause of spotted fever in southern Africa.\n\nIt is most likely that these cases described are due to _R. africae_ and are cases of African tick bite fever.\n\nReferences\n---------\n1. While there, the father and a daughter were bitten by ticks. On the 4th day upon returning to Hong Kong, the father complained of headache and had an eschar. The daughter was also found to have eschar[s?] and lymphadenopathy. They were seen by a private physician. Both are in stable condition after receiving treatment; no hospitalization is needed. Laboratory tests confirmed both to have been infected by spotted fever. The mother and another daughter also had similar but less severe symptoms. They have recovered after receiving treatment.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Angela Huang\n\n[Rickettsioses are causes of arthropod-borne human diseases, which can be roughly divided into typhus, scrub typhus and the spotted fever groups. In retrospect, it is surprising that, given the years that ProMED has been functioning, this is the 1st posting of a spotted fever group infection originating in Africa. This is the case despite Freedman, et al (1) reporting the spotted fever rickettsial diseases were the 2nd most common cause of fever in travelers returning from the developing world, after malaria but before dengue and typhoid fever.\n\nIn Africa, Mediterranean spotted fever had long been thought to be the predominant rickettsial disease caused by _R. conorii_. With the identification of _R. africae_ from patients with African tick bite fever in 1992 (2), it has been recognized that this disease is clearly the most prevalent cause of rickettsial infection in sub-Saharan Africa, and this disease is actually commonly reported in travelers returning from South Africa (3), particularly in those traveling to Kruger National Park. The literature contains a significant number of case reports documenting the acquisition of this infection in travelers and is represented by references 4-6. Reference 6 underscores one of the relevant physical findings of _R. africae_ infection, the presence of multiple, rather than one, eschars (lesions referred to a tache noir).\n\nThe CDC publication found at http://www.cdc.gov/otherspottedfever/ is a valuable reference listing the large number of spotted fever rickettsiae described throughout the world. The tables also include _R. aeschlimannii_ as a cause of spotted fever in southern Africa.\n\nIt is most likely that these cases described are due to _R. africae_ and are cases of African tick bite fever.\n\nReferences\n---------\n1. Freedman DO, Weld LH, Kozarsky PE, et al: Spectrum of disease and relation to place of exposure among ill returned travelers. N Engl J Med 2006;354: 119-130.\n2. Kelly P, Matthewman L, Beati L, et al: African tick-bite fever: a new spotted fever group rickettsiosis under an old name. Lancet 1992;340: 982-983.\n3. Jensenius M, Fournier PE, Vene S, et al: African tick-bite fever in travelers to rural sub-Equatorial Africa. Clin Infect Dis 2003;36: 1411-1417.\n4. Roch N, Epaulard O, Polloux I, et al: African tick bite fever in elderly patients: 8 cases in French tourists returning from South Africa. Clin Infect Dis 2008;47: e28-35.\n5. Tsai KH, Huang JH, Fournier PE, et al: African tick bite fever in a Taiwanese traveler returning from South Africa: molecular and serologic studies. Am J Trop Med Hyg 2009;81: 735-739.\n6. Althaus F, Greub G, Raoult D, Genton B: African tick-bite fever: a new entity in the differential diagnosis of multiple eschars in travelers. Description of five cases imported from South Africa to Switzerland. Int J Infect Dis 2010;14 (Suppl 3): e274-276.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1EPe.]\nSee Also\nIsraeli spotted fever - Israel 20120207.1034330\n2004\n----\nSpotted fever - Russia (Astrakhan) 19990125.0118\n.................................................ll/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "malaria"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-12-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Equatorial Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Astrakhan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2580209", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> SARS-like coronavirus - China: (YN) antigenically related to SARS-CoV", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2580209", "date": "2012-02-10 11:31:06", "main_text": "SPOTTED FEVER RICKETTSIOSIS - CHINA: HONG KONG SAR ex SOUTH AFRICA\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 10 Feb 2012\nSource: Hong Kong New Yahoo [Trans. by submitter][edited]\nhttp://hk.news.yahoo.com/%E7%88%B6%E5%A5%B3%E5%9C%A8%E5%8D%97%E9%9D%9E%E8%A2%AB%E8%9D%A8%E5%92%AC%E6%84%9F%E6%9F%93%E6%96%91%E7%96%B9%E7%86%B1-054800787.html\n\n\nA father and his daughter have been confirmed to have spotted fever after traveling to South Africa.\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection indicated that the patients' family of 5 traveled to South Africa in December 2011. While there, the father and a daughter were bitten by ticks. On the 4th day upon returning to Hong Kong, the father complained of headache and had an eschar. The daughter was also found to have eschar[s?] and lymphadenopathy. They were seen by a private physician. Both are in stable condition after receiving treatment; no hospitalization is needed. Laboratory tests confirmed both to have been infected by spotted fever. The mother and another daughter also had similar but less severe symptoms. They have recovered after receiving treatment.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Angela Huang\n\n[Rickettsioses are causes of arthropod-borne human diseases, which can be roughly divided into typhus, scrub typhus and the spotted fever groups. In retrospect, it is surprising that, given the years that ProMED has been functioning, this is the 1st posting of a spotted fever group infection originating in Africa. This is the case despite Freedman, et al (1) reporting the spotted fever rickettsial diseases were the 2nd most common cause of fever in travelers returning from the developing world, after malaria but before dengue and typhoid fever.\n\nIn Africa, Mediterranean spotted fever had long been thought to be the predominant rickettsial disease caused by _R. conorii_. With the identification of _R. africae_ from patients with African tick bite fever in 1992 (2), it has been recognized that this disease is clearly the most prevalent cause of rickettsial infection in sub-Saharan Africa, and this disease is actually commonly reported in travelers returning from South Africa (3), particularly in those traveling to Kruger National Park. The literature contains a significant number of case reports documenting the acquisition of this infection in travelers and is represented by references 4-6. Reference 6 underscores one of the relevant physical findings of _R. africae_ infection, the presence of multiple, rather than one, eschars (lesions referred to a tache noir).\n\nThe CDC publication found at http://www.cdc.gov/otherspottedfever/ is a valuable reference listing the large number of spotted fever rickettsiae described throughout the world. The tables also include _R. aeschlimannii_ as a cause of spotted fever in southern Africa.\n\nIt is most likely that these cases described are due to _R. africae_ and are cases of African tick bite fever.\n\nReferences\n---------\n1. Freedman DO, Weld LH, Kozarsky PE, et al: Spectrum of disease and relation to place of exposure among ill returned travelers. N Engl J Med 2006;354: 119-130.\n2. Kelly P, Matthewman L, Beati L, et al: African tick-bite fever: a new spotted fever group rickettsiosis under an old name. Lancet 1992;340: 982-983.\n3. Jensenius M, Fournier PE, Vene S, et al: African tick-bite fever in travelers to rural sub-Equatorial Africa. Clin Infect Dis 2003;36: 1411-1417.\n4. Roch N, Epaulard O, Polloux I, et al: African tick bite fever in elderly patients: 8 cases in French tourists returning from South Africa. Clin Infect Dis 2008;47: e28-35.\n5. Tsai KH, Huang JH, Fournier PE, et al: African tick bite fever in a Taiwanese traveler returning from South Africa: molecular and serologic studies. Am J Trop Med Hyg 2009;81: 735-739.\n6. Althaus F, Greub G, Raoult D, Genton B: African tick-bite fever: a new entity in the differential diagnosis of multiple eschars in travelers. Description of five cases imported from South Africa to Switzerland. Int J Infect Dis 2010;14 (Suppl 3): e274-276.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1EPe.]\nSee Also\nIsraeli spotted fever - Israel 20120207.1034330\n2004\n----\nSpotted fever - Russia (Siberia) (02): background 20040514.1301\n1999\n----\nIsrael spotted fever - Portugal (Setubal) 19991228.2215\nAstrakhan spotted fever - Russia (Moscow) 1998 19990821.1461\nAstrakhan spotted fever - China: (HK SAR) Indonesian women, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=911202", "date": "2007-03-20 15:00:02", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN: H9N2, CHINA (HONG KONG SAR)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 20 Mar 2007\nFrom: \"Joseph Dudley\" <fnjpd@uaf.edu>\nSource: International Herald Tribune, Associated\nPress report, Tue 20 Mar 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/03/20/asia/AS-MED-Hong-Kong-Bird-Flu.php>\n\nHuman case of H9N2 avian influenza detected in Hong Kong (SAR)\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nHONG KONG: A 9-month-old girl was infected with\nH9N2 -\ufffd a less virulent strain of avian influenza\n\ufffd- in Hong Kong and was being isolated at a\nhospital, health officials said Tuesday [20 Mar 2007].\nBefore becoming sick on 4 Mar 2007, the baby\nalmost daily visited a food market that sold live\npoultry, said Thomas Tsang Ho-fai of the Center\nfor Health Protection. Officials suspected she\nwas infected by birds at the market, he said.\nH9N2 is a mild strain [of avian influenza A\nvirus], [the H5N1 strain of avian influenza A\nvirus] has caused the deaths of at least 169\npeople worldwide. [The H9N2 virus belongs to a\ndifferent serotype of avian influenza A virus and\nshould not be described as a strain of H5N1\nvirus. These 2 avian influenza A viruses should\nbe regarded as distinct viruses differing in\nvirulence, host range and transmissibility. -\nMod.CP]. \"The baby's case is not that serious,\nand there's no serious indication that there was\nhuman-to-human infection,\" Tsang said.\nHong Kong reported 2 cases of the mild strain in\n1999 and one in 2003, he said. The patients were\nchildren who all recovered, he said. The recent\ncase returned home after spending 5 days in the\nhospital, but the child was put into isolation\nafter her samples tested positive for H9N2, said\nTsang, adding that the case was confirmed Tuesday [20 Mar 2007].\nOfficials were taking more samples from the\nmarket and family members, he said. Hong Kong\naggressively monitors bird flu because an\noutbreak [caaused by a highly pathogenic strain\nof different serotype - Mod CP.] in 1997 jumped\nto humans and killed 6 people. That prompted the\ngovernment to slaughter the entire poultry\npopulation of about 1.5 million birds.\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\nChief Scientist,\nEAI Corporation\nResearch Associate,\nInstitute of Arctic Biology - University of Alaska Fairbanks\nDepartment of Earth Science - University of Alaska Museum\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n[This case has precedents (e.g. see ProMED-mail\nposting : Influenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human -\nChina (Hong Kong) 19990407.0566 and Influenza A\n(H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong)\n19990805.1347). In 1999 an influenza A (H9N2)\nvirus was isolated from 2 patients (aged one and\n4 years old) by the Virus Unit of the Hong Kong\nDepartment of Health. Both girls recovered fully.\nThis was the 1st occasion that an H9N2 virus had\nbeen isolated from humans in Hong Kong, although\ninfluenza A (H9N2) viruses had been isolated from\nducks and chickens for several years previously.\nIn both instances the H9N2 virus was isolated\nfrom mildly ill young children and there was no\nfurther spread of infection. The circumstances\nsurrounding the exposure of these children to infection have not been reported.\nOther avian influenza viruses have been isolated\nfrom human patients, notably the H5N1 virus in\nHong Kong in 1997 and subsequently, and H9N2 (and\nH5N1) in 2003, and the H7N7 virus in the more\nextensive poultry outbreak in the Netherlands\nearlier in 2003. On these occasions only the H5N1\nviruses caused severe disease in humans. No\nevidence of transmission of H9N2 virus among humans was observed. -Mod.CP]\n[ProMED-mail would also like to thank rapporteurs\nMary Marshall and A-lan Banks for submitting similar articles. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\n2003\n----\nInfluenza A (H9N2), child - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20031210.3028\nInfluenza A (H9N2), child - China (Hong Kong) 20031209.3021\n2002\n----\nAvian influenza, transmission to humans: genetics 20020106.3179\n2001\n----\nAvian influenza - Japan: pet parakeets 20010422.0784\nInfluenza virus: new diagnostic reagents 20010109.0075\n1999\n----\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) 19990805.1347\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) 19990407.0566\nInfluenza virus vaccine (02) 19990531.0916\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (HK) (03) 19990415.0622\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Guandong) 19990409.0587\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (HK) (02) 19990409.0586\n..................cp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. pandemic (H1N1) (28): Hong Kong SAR, Norway, D222G mutation", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=407619", "date": "2007-03-20 15:00:02", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN: H9N2, CHINA (HONG KONG SAR)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 20 Mar 2007\nFrom: \"Joseph Dudley\" <fnjpd@uaf.edu>\nSource: International Herald Tribune, Associated\nPress report, Tue 20 Mar 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/03/20/asia/AS-MED-Hong-Kong-Bird-Flu.php>\n\nHuman case of H9N2 avian influenza detected in Hong Kong (SAR)\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nHONG KONG: A 9-month-old girl was infected with\nH9N2 -\ufffd a less virulent strain of avian influenza\n\ufffd- in Hong Kong and was being isolated at a\nhospital, health officials said Tuesday [20 Mar 2007].\nBefore becoming sick on 4 Mar 2007, the baby\nalmost daily visited a food market that sold live\npoultry, said Thomas Tsang Ho-fai of the Center\nfor Health Protection. Officials suspected she\nwas infected by birds at the market, he said.\nH9N2 is a mild strain [of avian influenza A\nvirus], [the H5N1 strain of avian influenza A\nvirus] has caused the deaths of at least 169\npeople worldwide. [The H9N2 virus belongs to a\ndifferent serotype of avian influenza A virus and\nshould not be described as a strain of H5N1\nvirus. These 2 avian influenza A viruses should\nbe regarded as distinct viruses differing in\nvirulence, host range and transmissibility. -\nMod.CP]. \"The baby's case is not that serious,\nand there's no serious indication that there was\nhuman-to-human infection,\" Tsang said.\nHong Kong reported 2 cases of the mild strain in\n1999 and one in 2003, he said. The patients were\nchildren who all recovered, he said. The recent\ncase returned home after spending 5 days in the\nhospital, but the child was put into isolation\nafter her samples tested positive for H9N2, said\nTsang, adding that the case was confirmed Tuesday [20 Mar 2007].\nOfficials were taking more samples from the\nmarket and family members, he said. Hong Kong\naggressively monitors bird flu because an\noutbreak [caaused by a highly pathogenic strain\nof different serotype - Mod CP.] in 1997 jumped\nto humans and killed 6 people. That prompted the\ngovernment to slaughter the entire poultry\npopulation of about 1.5 million birds.\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\nChief Scientist,\nEAI Corporation\nResearch Associate,\nInstitute of Arctic Biology - University of Alaska Fairbanks\nDepartment of Earth Science - University of Alaska Museum\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n[This case has precedents (e.g. see ProMED-mail\nposting : Influenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human -\nChina (Hong Kong) 19990407.0566 and Influenza A\n(H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong)\n19990805.1347). In 1999 an influenza A (H9N2)\nvirus was isolated from 2 patients (aged one and\n4 years old) by the Virus Unit of the Hong Kong\nDepartment of Health. Both girls recovered fully.\nThis was the 1st occasion that an H9N2 virus had\nbeen isolated from humans in Hong Kong, although\ninfluenza A (H9N2) viruses had been isolated from\nducks and chickens for several years previously.\nIn both instances the H9N2 virus was isolated\nfrom mildly ill young children and there was no\nfurther spread of infection. The circumstances\nsurrounding the exposure of these children to infection have not been reported.\nOther avian influenza viruses have been isolated\nfrom human patients, notably the H5N1 virus in\nHong Kong in 1997 and subsequently, and H9N2 (and\nH5N1) in 2003, and the H7N7 virus in the more\nextensive poultry outbreak in the Netherlands\nearlier in 2003. On these occasions only the H5N1\nviruses caused severe disease in humans. No\nevidence of transmission of H9N2 virus among humans was observed. -Mod.CP]\n[ProMED-mail would also like to thank rapporteurs\nMary Marshall and A-lan Banks for submitting similar articles. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\n2003\n----\nInfluenza A (H9N2), child - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20031210.3028\nInfluenza A (H9N2), child - China (Hong Kong) 20031209.3021\n2002\n----\nAvian influenza, transmission to humans: genetics 20020106.3179\n2001\n----\nAvian influenza - Japan: pet parakeets 20010422.0784\nInfluenza virus: new diagnostic reagents 20010109.0075\n1999\n----\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) 19990805.1347\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) 19990407.0566\nInfluenza virus vaccine (02) 19990531.0916\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (HK) (03) 19990415.0622\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Guandong) 19990409.0587\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (HK) (02) 19990409.0586\n..................cp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. China: hormone therapy, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=356281", "date": "2007-03-20 15:00:02", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN: H9N2, CHINA (HONG KONG SAR)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 20 Mar 2007\nFrom: \"Joseph Dudley\" <fnjpd@uaf.edu>\nSource: International Herald Tribune, Associated\nPress report, Tue 20 Mar 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/03/20/asia/AS-MED-Hong-Kong-Bird-Flu.php>\n\nHuman case of H9N2 avian influenza detected in Hong Kong (SAR)\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nHONG KONG: A 9-month-old girl was infected with\nH9N2 -\ufffd a less virulent strain of avian influenza\n\ufffd- in Hong Kong and was being isolated at a\nhospital, health officials said Tuesday [20 Mar 2007].\nBefore becoming sick on 4 Mar 2007, the baby\nalmost daily visited a food market that sold live\npoultry, said Thomas Tsang Ho-fai of the Center\nfor Health Protection. Officials suspected she\nwas infected by birds at the market, he said.\nH9N2 is a mild strain [of avian influenza A\nvirus], [the H5N1 strain of avian influenza A\nvirus] has caused the deaths of at least 169\npeople worldwide. [The H9N2 virus belongs to a\ndifferent serotype of avian influenza A virus and\nshould not be described as a strain of H5N1\nvirus. These 2 avian influenza A viruses should\nbe regarded as distinct viruses differing in\nvirulence, host range and transmissibility. -\nMod.CP]. \"The baby's case is not that serious,\nand there's no serious indication that there was\nhuman-to-human infection,\" Tsang said.\nHong Kong reported 2 cases of the mild strain in\n1999 and one in 2003, he said. The patients were\nchildren who all recovered, he said. The recent\ncase returned home after spending 5 days in the\nhospital, but the child was put into isolation\nafter her samples tested positive for H9N2, said\nTsang, adding that the case was confirmed Tuesday [20 Mar 2007].\nOfficials were taking more samples from the\nmarket and family members, he said. Hong Kong\naggressively monitors bird flu because an\noutbreak [caaused by a highly pathogenic strain\nof different serotype - Mod CP.] in 1997 jumped\nto humans and killed 6 people. That prompted the\ngovernment to slaughter the entire poultry\npopulation of about 1.5 million birds.\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\nChief Scientist,\nEAI Corporation\nResearch Associate,\nInstitute of Arctic Biology - University of Alaska Fairbanks\nDepartment of Earth Science - University of Alaska Museum\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n[This case has precedents (e.g. see ProMED-mail\nposting : Influenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human -\nChina (Hong Kong) 19990407.0566 and Influenza A\n(H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong)\n19990805.1347). In 1999 an influenza A (H9N2)\nvirus was isolated from 2 patients (aged one and\n4 years old) by the Virus Unit of the Hong Kong\nDepartment of Health. Both girls recovered fully.\nThis was the 1st occasion that an H9N2 virus had\nbeen isolated from humans in Hong Kong, although\ninfluenza A (H9N2) viruses had been isolated from\nducks and chickens for several years previously.\nIn both instances the H9N2 virus was isolated\nfrom mildly ill young children and there was no\nfurther spread of infection. The circumstances\nsurrounding the exposure of these children to infection have not been reported.\nOther avian influenza viruses have been isolated\nfrom human patients, notably the H5N1 virus in\nHong Kong in 1997 and subsequently, and H9N2 (and\nH5N1) in 2003, and the H7N7 virus in the more\nextensive poultry outbreak in the Netherlands\nearlier in 2003. On these occasions only the H5N1\nviruses caused severe disease in humans. No\nevidence of transmission of H9N2 virus among humans was observed. -Mod.CP]\n[ProMED-mail would also like to thank rapporteurs\nMary Marshall and A-lan Banks for submitting similar articles. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\n2003\n----\nInfluenza A (H9N2), child - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20031210.3028\nInfluenza A (H9N2), child - China (Hong Kong) 20031209.3021\n2002\n----\nAvian influenza, transmission to humans: genetics 20020106.3179\n2001\n----\nAvian influenza - Japan: pet parakeets 20010422.0784\nInfluenza virus: new diagnostic reagents 20010109.0075\n1999\n----\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) 19990805.1347\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) 19990407.0566\nInfluenza virus vaccine (02) 19990531.0916\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (HK) (03) 19990415.0622\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Guandong) 19990409.0587\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (HK) (02) 19990409.0586\n..................cp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. China: (HK SAR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=66600", "date": "2007-03-20 15:00:02", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN: H9N2, CHINA (HONG KONG SAR)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 20 Mar 2007\nFrom: \"Joseph Dudley\" <fnjpd@uaf.edu>\nSource: International Herald Tribune, Associated\nPress report, Tue 20 Mar 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/03/20/asia/AS-MED-Hong-Kong-Bird-Flu.php>\n\nHuman case of H9N2 avian influenza detected in Hong Kong (SAR)\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nHONG KONG: A 9-month-old girl was infected with\nH9N2 -\ufffd a less virulent strain of avian influenza\n\ufffd- in Hong Kong and was being isolated at a\nhospital, health officials said Tuesday [20 Mar 2007].\nBefore becoming sick on 4 Mar 2007, the baby\nalmost daily visited a food market that sold live\npoultry, said Thomas Tsang Ho-fai of the Center\nfor Health Protection. Officials suspected she\nwas infected by birds at the market, he said.\nH9N2 is a mild strain [of avian influenza A\nvirus], [the H5N1 strain of avian influenza A\nvirus] has caused the deaths of at least 169\npeople worldwide. [The H9N2 virus belongs to a\ndifferent serotype of avian influenza A virus and\nshould not be described as a strain of H5N1\nvirus. These 2 avian influenza A viruses should\nbe regarded as distinct viruses differing in\nvirulence, host range and transmissibility. -\nMod.CP]. \"The baby's case is not that serious,\nand there's no serious indication that there was\nhuman-to-human infection,\" Tsang said.\nHong Kong reported 2 cases of the mild strain in\n1999 and one in 2003, he said. The patients were\nchildren who all recovered, he said. The recent\ncase returned home after spending 5 days in the\nhospital, but the child was put into isolation\nafter her samples tested positive for H9N2, said\nTsang, adding that the case was confirmed Tuesday [20 Mar 2007].\nOfficials were taking more samples from the\nmarket and family members, he said. Hong Kong\naggressively monitors bird flu because an\noutbreak [caaused by a highly pathogenic strain\nof different serotype - Mod CP.] in 1997 jumped\nto humans and killed 6 people. That prompted the\ngovernment to slaughter the entire poultry\npopulation of about 1.5 million birds.\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\nChief Scientist,\nEAI Corporation\nResearch Associate,\nInstitute of Arctic Biology - University of Alaska Fairbanks\nDepartment of Earth Science - University of Alaska Museum\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n[This case has precedents (e.g. see ProMED-mail\nposting : Influenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human -\nChina (Hong Kong) 19990407.0566 and Influenza A\n(H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong)\n19990805.1347). In 1999 an influenza A (H9N2)\nvirus was isolated from 2 patients (aged one and\n4 years old) by the Virus Unit of the Hong Kong\nDepartment of Health. Both girls recovered fully.\nThis was the 1st occasion that an H9N2 virus had\nbeen isolated from humans in Hong Kong, although\ninfluenza A (H9N2) viruses had been isolated from\nducks and chickens for several years previously.\nIn both instances the H9N2 virus was isolated\nfrom mildly ill young children and there was no\nfurther spread of infection. The circumstances\nsurrounding the exposure of these children to infection have not been reported.\nOther avian influenza viruses have been isolated\nfrom human patients, notably the H5N1 virus in\nHong Kong in 1997 and subsequently, and H9N2 (and\nH5N1) in 2003, and the H7N7 virus in the more\nextensive poultry outbreak in the Netherlands\nearlier in 2003. On these occasions only the H5N1\nviruses caused severe disease in humans. No\nevidence of transmission of H9N2 virus among humans was observed. -Mod.CP]\n[ProMED-mail would also like to thank rapporteurs\nMary Marshall and A-lan Banks for submitting similar articles. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\n2003\n----\nInfluenza A (H9N2), child - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20031210.3028\nInfluenza A (H9N2), child - China (Hong Kong) 20031209.3021\n2002\n----\nAvian influenza, transmission to humans: genetics 20020106.3179\n2001\n----\nAvian influenza - Japan: pet parakeets 20010422.0784\nInfluenza virus: new diagnostic reagents 20010109.0075\n1999\n----\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) 19990805.1347\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) 19990407.0566\nInfluenza virus vaccine (02) 19990531.0916\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (HK) (03) 19990415.0622\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Guandong) 19990409.0587\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (HK) (02) 19990409.0586\n..................cp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Officials suspected she\nwas infected by birds at the market, he said.\nH9N2 is a mild strain [of avian influenza A\nvirus], [the H5N1 strain of avian influenza A\nvirus] has caused the deaths of at least 169\npeople worldwide. [The H9N2 virus belongs to a\ndifferent serotype of avian influenza A virus and\nshould not be described as a strain of H5N1\nvirus. These 2 avian influenza A viruses should\nbe regarded as distinct viruses differing in\nvirulence, host range and transmissibility. -\nMod.CP]. \"The baby's case is not that serious,\nand there's no serious indication that there was\nhuman-to-human infection,\" Tsang said.\nHong Kong reported 2 cases of the mild strain in\n1999 and one in 2003, he said. The recent\ncase returned home after spending 5 days in the\nhospital, but the child was put into isolation\nafter her samples tested positive for H9N2, said\nTsang, adding that the case was confirmed Tuesday [20 Mar 2007].\nOfficials were taking more samples from the\nmarket and family members, he said. Hong Kong\naggressively monitors bird flu because an\noutbreak [caaused by a highly pathogenic strain\nof different serotype - Mod CP.] in 1997 jumped\nto humans and killed 6 people. That prompted the\ngovernment to slaughter the entire poultry\npopulation of about 1.5 million birds.\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\nChief Scientist,\nEAI Corporation\nResearch Associate,\nInstitute of Arctic Biology - University of Alaska Fairbanks\nDepartment of Earth Science - University of Alaska Museum\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n[This case has precedents (e.g. see ProMED-mail\nposting : Influenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human -\nChina (Hong Kong) 19990407.0566 and Influenza A\n(H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong)\n19990805.1347). In 1999 an influenza A (H9N2)\nvirus was isolated from 2 patients (aged one and\n4 years old) by the Virus Unit of the Hong Kong\nDepartment of Health. Both girls recovered fully.\nThis was the 1st occasion that an H9N2 virus had\nbeen isolated from humans in Hong Kong, although\ninfluenza A (H9N2) viruses had been isolated from\nducks and chickens for several years previously.\nIn both instances the H9N2 virus was isolated\nfrom mildly ill young children and there was no\nfurther spread of infection. The circumstances\nsurrounding the exposure of these children to infection have not been reported.\nOther avian influenza viruses have been isolated\nfrom human patients, notably the H5N1 virus in\nHong Kong in 1997 and subsequently, and H9N2 (and\nH5N1) in 2003, and the H7N7 virus in the more\nextensive poultry outbreak in the Netherlands\nearlier in 2003. No\nevidence of transmission of H9N2 virus among humans was observed. -Mod.CP]\n[ProMED-mail would also like to thank rapporteurs\nMary Marshall and A-lan Banks for submitting similar articles. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\n2003\n----\nInfluenza A (H9N2), child - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20031210.3028\nInfluenza A (H9N2), child - China (Hong Kong) 20031209.3021\n2002\n----\nAvian influenza, transmission to humans: genetics 20020106.3179\n2001\n----\nAvian influenza - Japan: pet parakeets 20010422.0784\nInfluenza virus: new diagnostic reagents 20010109.0075\n1999\n----\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) 19990805.1347\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) 19990407.0566\nInfluenza virus vaccine (02) 19990531.0916\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (HK) (03) 19990415.0622\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Guandong) 19990409.0587\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (HK) (02) 19990409.0586\n..................cp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. SAR)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 20 Mar 2007\nFrom: \"Joseph Dudley\" <fnjpd@uaf.edu>\nSource: International Herald Tribune, Associated\nPress report, Tue 20 Mar 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/03/20/asia/AS-MED-Hong-Kong-Bird-Flu.php>\n\nHuman case of H9N2 avian influenza detected in Hong Kong (SAR)\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nHONG KONG: A 9-month-old girl was infected with\nH9N2 -\ufffd a less virulent strain of avian influenza\n\ufffd- in Hong Kong and was being isolated at a\nhospital, health officials said Tuesday [20 Mar 2007].\nBefore becoming sick on 4 Mar 2007, the baby\nalmost daily visited a food market that sold live\npoultry, said Thomas Tsang Ho-fai of the Center\nfor Health Protection. Officials suspected she\nwas infected by birds at the market, he said.\nH9N2 is a mild strain [of avian influenza A\nvirus], [the H5N1 strain of avian influenza A\nvirus] has caused the deaths of at least 169\npeople worldwide. [The H9N2 virus belongs to a\ndifferent serotype of avian influenza A virus and\nshould not be described as a strain of H5N1\nvirus. These 2 avian influenza A viruses should\nbe regarded as distinct viruses differing in\nvirulence, host range and transmissibility. -\nMod.CP]. \"The baby's case is not that serious,\nand there's no serious indication that there was\nhuman-to-human infection,\" Tsang said.\nHong Kong reported 2 cases of the mild strain in\n1999 and one in 2003, he said. The patients were\nchildren who all recovered, he said. The recent\ncase returned home after spending 5 days in the\nhospital, but the child was put into isolation\nafter her samples tested positive for H9N2, said\nTsang, adding that the case was confirmed Tuesday [20 Mar 2007].\nOfficials were taking more samples from the\nmarket and family members, he said. Hong Kong\naggressively monitors bird flu because an\noutbreak [caaused by a highly pathogenic strain\nof different serotype - Mod CP.] in 1997 jumped\nto humans and killed 6 people. That prompted the\ngovernment to slaughter the entire poultry\npopulation of about 1.5 million birds.\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\nChief Scientist,\nEAI Corporation\nResearch Associate,\nInstitute of Arctic Biology - University of Alaska Fairbanks\nDepartment of Earth Science - University of Alaska Museum\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n[This case has precedents (e.g. see ProMED-mail\nposting : Influenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human -\nChina (Hong Kong) 19990407.0566 and Influenza A\n(H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong)\n19990805.1347). In 1999 an influenza A (H9N2)\nvirus was isolated from 2 patients (aged one and\n4 years old) by the Virus Unit of the Hong Kong\nDepartment of Health. Both girls recovered fully.\nThis was the 1st occasion that an H9N2 virus had\nbeen isolated from humans in Hong Kong, although\ninfluenza A (H9N2) viruses had been isolated from\nducks and chickens for several years previously.\nIn both instances the H9N2 virus was isolated\nfrom mildly ill young children and there was no\nfurther spread of infection. The circumstances\nsurrounding the exposure of these children to infection have not been reported.\nOther avian influenza viruses have been isolated\nfrom human patients, notably the H5N1 virus in\nHong Kong in 1997 and subsequently, and H9N2 (and\nH5N1) in 2003, and the H7N7 virus in the more\nextensive poultry outbreak in the Netherlands\nearlier in 2003. No\nevidence of transmission of H9N2 virus among humans was observed. -Mod.CP]\n[ProMED-mail would also like to thank rapporteurs\nMary Marshall and A-lan Banks for submitting similar articles. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\n2003\n----\nInfluenza A (H9N2), child - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20031210.3028\nInfluenza A (H9N2), child - China (Hong Kong) 20031209.3021\n2002\n----\nAvian influenza, transmission to humans: genetics 20020106.3179\n2001\n----\nAvian influenza - Japan: pet parakeets 20010422.0784\nInfluenza virus: new diagnostic reagents 20010109.0075\n1999\n----\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) 19990805.1347\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) 19990407.0566\nInfluenza virus vaccine (02) 19990531.0916\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (HK) (03) 19990415.0622\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Guandong) 19990409.0587\nInfluenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human - China (HK) (02) 19990409.0586\n..................cp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guandong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9074", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (55): H9N2, China (Hong Kong SAR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9074", "date": "2004-05-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (28): LABORATORY INVESTIGATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 6 May 2004 11:00:05 +0800\nFrom: Tang Kin Fai, PhD <TANG_Kin_Fai@nea.gov.sg>\n\nThere are several points that I would like to highlight.\n1. For the investigation of such laboratory infection cases, the\ninvestigation team must base their investigation on BMBL [see below]\nor WHO guidelines, and not based on some never-before-recorded\ncomments of the individual team members.\n2. My concern is that when investigations are focused on lab\ninfection, other possible routes of infection will be neglected.\n3. I understand that one of the patients had not been working with\nlive SARS virus, suggesting that there may be an unknown source of\ninfection within the lab. Despite the closing of the institute, some\nstaff members are left behind to carry on routine work. This further\nincreases the risk of more infections.\n4. It is essential to perform a sero-survey of the members of the\ninstitute staff to see whether there any are asymptomatic infections.\n--\nTang Kin Fai, PhD\nResearch Scientist\nEnvironmental Health Institute\nNational Environment Agency, Singapore\n<TANG_Kin_Fai@nea.gov.sg>\n[Dr. Tang raises some interesting points. The suggestion to conduct\na serosurvey of the staff is a good one, combined with clinical\nhistories of possible mild respiratory illness that might not have\ncome to the attention of the health sector.\nThe BMBL refers to the Biosafety in Microbiological and Biomedical\nLaboratories manual. The 4th edition can be downloaded from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/ohs/biosfty/bmbl4/bmbl4toc.htm>.\nGiven the current history of 4 SARS coronavirus (CoV) infections in\nindividuals working in laboratories where research on the SARS CoV\nwas ongoing (Singapore, Taiwan and 2 cases in Beijing), it would be\nan unusual coincidence if the 2 most recent cases in Beijing were not\nassociated with transmission within the laboratory but rather through\nanother route. Again, we await further information on the findings\nof the laboratory-based investigations. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (27): China, laboratory investigation 20040505.1235\nSARS - worldwide (26): China, cases 20040504.1230\nSARS - worldwide (25): China, cases 20040430.1198\nSARS - worldwide (24): China, cases 20040429.1193\nSARS - worldwide (23): China, cases 20040428.1186\nSARS - worldwide (21): China, cases 20040426.1161\nSARS - For the investigation of such laboratory infection cases, the\ninvestigation team must base their investigation on BMBL [see below]\nor WHO guidelines, and not based on some never-before-recorded\ncomments of the individual team members.\n2. My concern is that when investigations are focused on lab\ninfection, other possible routes of infection will be neglected.\n3. I understand that one of the patients had not been working with\nlive SARS virus, suggesting that there may be an unknown source of\ninfection within the lab. Despite the closing of the institute, some\nstaff members are left behind to carry on routine work. This further\nincreases the risk of more infections.\n4. It is essential to perform a sero-survey of the members of the\ninstitute staff to see whether there any are asymptomatic infections.\n--\nTang Kin Fai, PhD\nResearch Scientist\nEnvironmental Health Institute\nNational Environment Agency, Singapore\n<TANG_Kin_Fai@nea.gov.sg>\n[Dr. Tang raises some interesting points. The suggestion to conduct\na serosurvey of the staff is a good one, combined with clinical\nhistories of possible mild respiratory illness that might not have\ncome to the attention of the health sector.\nThe BMBL refers to the Biosafety in Microbiological and Biomedical\nLaboratories manual. The 4th edition can be downloaded from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/ohs/biosfty/bmbl4/bmbl4toc.htm>.\nGiven the current history of 4 SARS coronavirus (CoV) infections in\nindividuals working in laboratories where research on the SARS CoV\nwas ongoing (Singapore, Taiwan and 2 cases in Beijing), it would be\nan unusual coincidence if the 2 most recent cases in Beijing were not\nassociated with transmission within the laboratory but rather through\nanother route. Again, we await further information on the findings\nof the laboratory-based investigations. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (27): China, laboratory investigation 20040505.1235\nSARS - worldwide (26): China, cases 20040504.1230\nSARS - For the investigation of such laboratory infection cases, the\ninvestigation team must base their investigation on BMBL [see below]\nor WHO guidelines, and not based on some never-before-recorded\ncomments of the individual team members.\n2. My concern is that when investigations are focused on lab\ninfection, other possible routes of infection will be neglected.\n3. I understand that one of the patients had not been working with\nlive SARS virus, suggesting that there may be an unknown source of\ninfection within the lab. Despite the closing of the institute, some\nstaff members are left behind to carry on routine work. This further\nincreases the risk of more infections.\n4. It is essential to perform a sero-survey of the members of the\ninstitute staff to see whether there any are asymptomatic infections.\n--\nTang Kin Fai, PhD\nResearch Scientist\nEnvironmental Health Institute\nNational Environment Agency, Singapore\n<TANG_Kin_Fai@nea.gov.sg>\n[Dr. Tang raises some interesting points. The suggestion to conduct\na serosurvey of the staff is a good one, combined with clinical\nhistories of possible mild respiratory illness that might not have\ncome to the attention of the health sector.\nThe BMBL refers to the Biosafety in Microbiological and Biomedical\nLaboratories manual. The 4th edition can be downloaded from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/ohs/biosfty/bmbl4/bmbl4toc.htm>.\nGiven the current history of 4 SARS coronavirus (CoV) infections in\nindividuals working in laboratories where research on the SARS CoV\nwas ongoing (Singapore, Taiwan and 2 cases in Beijing), it would be\nan unusual coincidence if the 2 most recent cases in Beijing were not\nassociated with transmission within the laboratory but rather through\nanother route. My concern is that when investigations are focused on lab\ninfection, other possible routes of infection will be neglected.\n3. I understand that one of the patients had not been working with\nlive SARS virus, suggesting that there may be an unknown source of\ninfection within the lab. Despite the closing of the institute, some\nstaff members are left behind to carry on routine work. This further\nincreases the risk of more infections.\n4. It is essential to perform a sero-survey of the members of the\ninstitute staff to see whether there any are asymptomatic infections.\n--\nTang Kin Fai, PhD\nResearch Scientist\nEnvironmental Health Institute\nNational Environment Agency, Singapore\n<TANG_Kin_Fai@nea.gov.sg>\n[Dr. Tang raises some interesting points. The suggestion to conduct\na serosurvey of the staff is a good one, combined with clinical\nhistories of possible mild respiratory illness that might not have\ncome to the attention of the health sector.\nThe BMBL refers to the Biosafety in Microbiological and Biomedical\nLaboratories manual. The 4th edition can be downloaded from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/ohs/biosfty/bmbl4/bmbl4toc.htm>.\nGiven the current history of 4 SARS coronavirus (CoV) infections in\nindividuals working in laboratories where research on the SARS CoV\nwas ongoing (Singapore, Taiwan and 2 cases in Beijing), it would be\nan unusual coincidence if the 2 most recent cases in Beijing were not\nassociated with transmission within the laboratory but rather through\nanother route. For the investigation of such laboratory infection cases, the\ninvestigation team must base their investigation on BMBL [see below]\nor WHO guidelines, and not based on some never-before-recorded\ncomments of the individual team members.\n2. My concern is that when investigations are focused on lab\ninfection, other possible routes of infection will be neglected.\n3. I understand that one of the patients had not been working with\nlive SARS virus, suggesting that there may be an unknown source of\ninfection within the lab. Despite the closing of the institute, some\nstaff members are left behind to carry on routine work. This further\nincreases the risk of more infections.\n4. It is essential to perform a sero-survey of the members of the\ninstitute staff to see whether there any are asymptomatic infections.\n--\nTang Kin Fai, PhD\nResearch Scientist\nEnvironmental Health Institute\nNational Environment Agency, Singapore\n<TANG_Kin_Fai@nea.gov.sg>\n[Dr. Tang raises some interesting points. The 4th edition can be downloaded from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/ohs/biosfty/bmbl4/bmbl4toc.htm>.\nGiven the current history of 4 SARS coronavirus (CoV) infections in\nindividuals working in laboratories where research on the SARS CoV\nwas ongoing (Singapore, Taiwan and 2 cases in Beijing), it would be\nan unusual coincidence if the 2 most recent cases in Beijing were not\nassociated with transmission within the laboratory but rather through\nanother route. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2004-05-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205685", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (26): China, cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205685", "date": "2004-04-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (21): - CHINA, CASES\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 26 Apr 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: World Health Organization (WHO) SARS update [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_04_26/en/>\n\nAdditional patients in China under investigation for SARS; WHO team travels\nto Beijing - update 2, 26 Apr 2004\n---------------------------------------------------------\nAt the request of the Chinese Ministry of Health, WHO is today sending the\n1st members of an international team to help investigate the source of SARS\ncases recently reported in Beijing and the eastern province of Anhui. The\nteam, which is expected to begin work on Wednesday, will include experts in\nepidemiology, virology, infection control, and laboratory biosafety.\nResults of investigations to date point to laboratory research at the\nNational Institute of Virology in Beijing as the likely source of the\noutbreak. The institute has been engaged in research with the SARS\ncoronavirus, including the development of a vaccine.\nTwo of the recently reported cases were conducting research at the\nlaboratory: a 26 year old female postgraduate student from Anhui Province,\nand a 31 year old man. The dates of symptom onset in the 2 cases were\nseparated by 23 days, suggesting that more than one opportunity for\nexposure may have occurred in the laboratory from mid-March through early\nApril 2004. Authorities have closed the virology institute and placed its\nmore than 200 employees under medical observation. Numerous environmental\nsamples from the laboratory have been taken to help assess possible sources\nof contamination, and these samples will be shared with WHO.\nUnderstanding and eliminating the source of infection are critical steps in\nbringing the outbreak under control. An equally important activity is to\nquickly detect all chains of transmission and interrupt them through rapid\ncase detection, tracing and follow-up of contacts, and infection control in\nhospitals.\nWHO is concerned about additional opportunities for exposure that may have\nalready occurred. Some patients were treated or assessed in several\ndifferent hospitals before a suspicion of SARS led to the introduction of\nadequate precautionary measures, including isolation of patients and strict\nprocedures for infection control. One patient travelled a long distance\ntwice by train within China while symptomatic.\nChinese authorities have heightened surveillance and reporting for\nSARS-like illness in health care facilities and have sent investigative\nteams to Anhui Province.\nSince 22 Apr 2004, China has reported that 8 people have been clinically\ndiagnosed as SARS cases or are under investigation for possible SARS\ninfection -- 6 in Beijing and 2, including the single fatality, in Anhui\nProvince. As of today, close to 1000 contacts of these cases are under\nmedical observation, including 640 in Beijing and 353 in Anhui.\nThe most recent cases, announced on Sunday, are 4 close contacts of a 20\nyear old nurse who treated the Anhui student at a Beijing hospital. The\ncases -\u00ad all in Beijing -\u00ad are currently under investigation. They include\nthe nurse\u0092s mother, father, aunt, and a woman who shared a hospital ward\nwith the nurse when she was undergoing treatment. Onset of symptoms for all\n4 occurred between 16 and 19 Apr 2004. The nurse\u0092s mother is in serious\ncondition following the development of pneumonia. The other 3 people are in\na stable condition.\nIn addition, health authorities have reported that 2 doctors who treated\nthe postgraduate student during her hospitalization in Hefai, Anhui, have\ndeveloped fever. A person in close contact with one of the doctors has also\ndeveloped fever.\nTo date, all diagnosed cases and cases under investigation have been linked\nto chains of transmission involving close personal contact with an\nidentified case. There is no evidence of wider transmission in the community.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the past 24 hours since the last update (20040425.1150), there are the\nadditional reports of fever in 2 physicians treating the index case in\nAnhui and in a close contact of one of these 2 physicians. According the\nChina Minstry of Health (MOH) website (<http://www.moh.gov.cn>), there has\nbeen the implementation of increased surveillance for \"atypical pneumonia\"\ncountry-wide, but no additional suspected cases have been identified.\nAs with 2003, there is an \"outbreak\" of newswire reports and speculations\non this current situation, and for this reason we have chosen to be highly\nselective of newswire information we post, preferring to rely upon the\nofficial reports available from WHO and the Chinese MOH. Lessons were\nclearly learned after the 2003 outbreak, and there is now apparent\ntransparency in reporting. We will continue to screen newswire reports for\npossible early introduction of probable SARS activity in new geographic\nregions (outside of the currently identified Beijing and Anhui provinces),\nincluding any possible international spread.\nWe are still awaiting information on the independent laboratory testing of\nspecimens from the currently identified cases in China. Until these results\nare available, the cases are being classified as probable and suspected.\nAccording to WHO guidelines for the global surveillance of SARS,\nclassification as a confirmed case at the start of an outbreak requires\nindependent verification of results by an external international reference\nlaboratory. Such procedures are considered necessary in view of the\nimplications that confirmed SARS cases can have for international public\nhealth. Irrespective of the \"tentative\" classifications, appropriate\ninvestigations and disease control measures have been implemented, under\nthe assumption that infection with SARS coronavirus has truly occurred.\nHence, it is a semantic discussion that will not delay appropriate control\nmeasures to interrupt transmission.\nFrom the information currently available, there is now evidence of 3\ngenerations of transmission. The 1st generation involved the index case\nfrom Anhui, and possibly a 2nd \"1st-generation\" case, the postdoctoral\nstudent from Beijing whose onset of illness was 23 days after the onset of\nillness of the index case from Anhui. The 2nd generation included the\nmother of the index case from Anhui and the nurse who cared for the index\ncase from Anhui while she was hospitalized in Beijing, and possibly the\nphysicians who cared for her while hospitalized in Anhui. The 3rd\ngeneration of cases are the family members of the nurse (from the 2nd\ngeneration), a patient hospitalized in the same ward as the nurse before\nSARS was identified as a possible diagnosis for the nurse's illness, and a\nclose contact of one of the physicians who treated the index patient in\nAnhui. This pattern of nosocomial spread due to lack of early\nidentification of SARS as a possible diagnosis is very reminiscent of the\noutbreak in 2003.\nConcern about possible spread outside of the current identified \"close\ncontact\" circle around these cases is warranted. It is to be hoped that the\nthreshold for suspicion of possible SARS will be lowered country-wide, so\ncases that may occur related to transmission while travelling on the trains\nbetween Anhui Province and Beijing will be identified and isolated early,\npreventing further generations of transmission.\nIn addition, there are appropriate concerns about laboratory safety\nprocedures. This is now the 3rd incident of SARS transmission within a\nlaboratory working on SARS research. The first 2 occurred in Singapore and\nTaiwan (see ProMED-mail postings SARS - worldwide (185): Taiwan, probable\nlab exposure 20031217.3081 and SARS - worldwide (174): Singapore laboratory\nexposure 20030923.2397). Since the 2003 outbreak, it seems as though\nlaboratory exposure is a higher risk factor than the possible zoonotic\nexposure. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (20): China, cases 20040425.1150\nSARS - worldwide (19): China, cases 20040424.1141\nSARS - worldwide (18): China, cases 20040423.1125\nSARS - worldwide (16): China, suspected cases 20040422.1118\nSARS - worldwide (15): animal reservoirs 20040417.1059\nSARS - worldwide (14): travel advice 20040212.0467\nSARS - worldwide (13): China, cases 20040131.0365\nSARS - Worldwide (12): molecular epidemiology, 2003 20040131.0364\nSARS - worldwide (11): molecular epidemiology, 2003 20040130.0358\nSARS - worldwide (10): China, 2004 cases 20040127.0327\nSARS - worldwide (09): China, WHO clarification 20040120.0223\nSARS - worldwide (08): China, suspected cases 20040119.0209\nSARS - worldwide (07) - China: suspected cases 20040114.0149\nSARS - worldwide (06) - China: suspected cases 20040111.0118\nSARS - worldwide (05): Taiwan lab investigation 20040109.0096\nSARS - Worldwide (04): China, new susp. case 20040108.0081\nSARS - worldwide (03): etiology 20040107.0073\nSARS - worldwide (02): China, laboratory confirmed 20040105.0046\nSARS - worldwide (01): China, susp. case 20040102.0015\n2003\n---\nSARS worldwide (179): WHO SRAC 1st report 20031024.2666\nSARS - worldwide (02): cases 20030324.0734\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02) 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide:alert 20030315.0637\n.....................mpp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail.
