If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2004-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hefai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anhui", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anhui Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205673", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (26): China, cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205673", "date": "2004-04-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (21): - CHINA, CASES\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 26 Apr 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: World Health Organization (WHO) SARS update [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_04_26/en/>\n\nAdditional patients in China under investigation for SARS; WHO team travels\nto Beijing - update 2, 26 Apr 2004\n---------------------------------------------------------\nAt the request of the Chinese Ministry of Health, WHO is today sending the\n1st members of an international team to help investigate the source of SARS\ncases recently reported in Beijing and the eastern province of Anhui. The\nteam, which is expected to begin work on Wednesday, will include experts in\nepidemiology, virology, infection control, and laboratory biosafety.\nResults of investigations to date point to laboratory research at the\nNational Institute of Virology in Beijing as the likely source of the\noutbreak. The institute has been engaged in research with the SARS\ncoronavirus, including the development of a vaccine.\nTwo of the recently reported cases were conducting research at the\nlaboratory: a 26 year old female postgraduate student from Anhui Province,\nand a 31 year old man. The dates of symptom onset in the 2 cases were\nseparated by 23 days, suggesting that more than one opportunity for\nexposure may have occurred in the laboratory from mid-March through early\nApril 2004. Authorities have closed the virology institute and placed its\nmore than 200 employees under medical observation. Numerous environmental\nsamples from the laboratory have been taken to help assess possible sources\nof contamination, and these samples will be shared with WHO.\nUnderstanding and eliminating the source of infection are critical steps in\nbringing the outbreak under control. An equally important activity is to\nquickly detect all chains of transmission and interrupt them through rapid\ncase detection, tracing and follow-up of contacts, and infection control in\nhospitals.\nWHO is concerned about additional opportunities for exposure that may have\nalready occurred. Some patients were treated or assessed in several\ndifferent hospitals before a suspicion of SARS led to the introduction of\nadequate precautionary measures, including isolation of patients and strict\nprocedures for infection control. One patient travelled a long distance\ntwice by train within China while symptomatic.\nChinese authorities have heightened surveillance and reporting for\nSARS-like illness in health care facilities and have sent investigative\nteams to Anhui Province.\nSince 22 Apr 2004, China has reported that 8 people have been clinically\ndiagnosed as SARS cases or are under investigation for possible SARS\ninfection -- 6 in Beijing and 2, including the single fatality, in Anhui\nProvince. As of today, close to 1000 contacts of these cases are under\nmedical observation, including 640 in Beijing and 353 in Anhui.\nThe most recent cases, announced on Sunday, are 4 close contacts of a 20\nyear old nurse who treated the Anhui student at a Beijing hospital. The\ncases -\u00ad all in Beijing -\u00ad are currently under investigation. They include\nthe nurse\u0092s mother, father, aunt, and a woman who shared a hospital ward\nwith the nurse when she was undergoing treatment. Onset of symptoms for all\n4 occurred between 16 and 19 Apr 2004. The nurse\u0092s mother is in serious\ncondition following the development of pneumonia. The other 3 people are in\na stable condition.\nIn addition, health authorities have reported that 2 doctors who treated\nthe postgraduate student during her hospitalization in Hefai, Anhui, have\ndeveloped fever. A person in close contact with one of the doctors has also\ndeveloped fever.\nTo date, all diagnosed cases and cases under investigation have been linked\nto chains of transmission involving close personal contact with an\nidentified case. There is no evidence of wider transmission in the community.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the past 24 hours since the last update (20040425.1150), there are the\nadditional reports of fever in 2 physicians treating the index case in\nAnhui and in a close contact of one of these 2 physicians. According the\nChina Minstry of Health (MOH) website (<http://www.moh.gov.cn>), there has\nbeen the implementation of increased surveillance for \"atypical pneumonia\"\ncountry-wide, but no additional suspected cases have been identified.\nAs with 2003, there is an \"outbreak\" of newswire reports and speculations\non this current situation, and for this reason we have chosen to be highly\nselective of newswire information we post, preferring to rely upon the\nofficial reports available from WHO and the Chinese MOH. Lessons were\nclearly learned after the 2003 outbreak, and there is now apparent\ntransparency in reporting. We will continue to screen newswire reports for\npossible early introduction of probable SARS activity in new geographic\nregions (outside of the currently identified Beijing and Anhui provinces),\nincluding any possible international spread.\nWe are still awaiting information on the independent laboratory testing of\nspecimens from the currently identified cases in China. Until these results\nare available, the cases are being classified as probable and suspected.\nAccording to WHO guidelines for the global surveillance of SARS,\nclassification as a confirmed case at the start of an outbreak requires\nindependent verification of results by an external international reference\nlaboratory. Such procedures are considered necessary in view of the\nimplications that confirmed SARS cases can have for international public\nhealth. Irrespective of the \"tentative\" classifications, appropriate\ninvestigations and disease control measures have been implemented, under\nthe assumption that infection with SARS coronavirus has truly occurred.\nHence, it is a semantic discussion that will not delay appropriate control\nmeasures to interrupt transmission.\nFrom the information currently available, there is now evidence of 3\ngenerations of transmission. The 1st generation involved the index case\nfrom Anhui, and possibly a 2nd \"1st-generation\" case, the postdoctoral\nstudent from Beijing whose onset of illness was 23 days after the onset of\nillness of the index case from Anhui. The 2nd generation included the\nmother of the index case from Anhui and the nurse who cared for the index\ncase from Anhui while she was hospitalized in Beijing, and possibly the\nphysicians who cared for her while hospitalized in Anhui. The 3rd\ngeneration of cases are the family members of the nurse (from the 2nd\ngeneration), a patient hospitalized in the same ward as the nurse before\nSARS was identified as a possible diagnosis for the nurse's illness, and a\nclose contact of one of the physicians who treated the index patient in\nAnhui. This pattern of nosocomial spread due to lack of early\nidentification of SARS as a possible diagnosis is very reminiscent of the\noutbreak in 2003.\nConcern about possible spread outside of the current identified \"close\ncontact\" circle around these cases is warranted. It is to be hoped that the\nthreshold for suspicion of possible SARS will be lowered country-wide, so\ncases that may occur related to transmission while travelling on the trains\nbetween Anhui Province and Beijing will be identified and isolated early,\npreventing further generations of transmission.\nIn addition, there are appropriate concerns about laboratory safety\nprocedures. This is now the 3rd incident of SARS transmission within a\nlaboratory working on SARS research. The first 2 occurred in Singapore and\nTaiwan (see ProMED-mail postings SARS - worldwide (185): Taiwan, probable\nlab exposure 20031217.3081 and SARS - worldwide (174): Singapore laboratory\nexposure 20030923.2397). Since the 2003 outbreak, it seems as though\nlaboratory exposure is a higher risk factor than the possible zoonotic\nexposure. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (20): China, cases 20040425.1150\nSARS - worldwide (19): China, cases 20040424.1141\nSARS - worldwide (18): China, cases 20040423.1125\nSARS - worldwide (16): China, suspected cases 20040422.1118\nSARS - worldwide (15): animal reservoirs 20040417.1059\nSARS - worldwide (14): travel advice 20040212.0467\nSARS - worldwide (13): China, cases 20040131.0365\nSARS - Worldwide (12): molecular epidemiology, 2003 20040131.0364\nSARS - worldwide (11): molecular epidemiology, 2003 20040130.0358\nSARS - worldwide (10): China, 2004 cases 20040127.0327\nSARS - worldwide (09): China, WHO clarification 20040120.0223\nSARS - worldwide (08): China, suspected cases 20040119.0209\nSARS - worldwide (07) - China: suspected cases 20040114.0149\nSARS - worldwide (06) - China: suspected cases 20040111.0118\nSARS - worldwide (05): Taiwan lab investigation 20040109.0096\nSARS - Worldwide (04): China, new susp. case 20040108.0081\nSARS - worldwide (03): etiology 20040107.0073\nSARS - worldwide (02): China, laboratory confirmed 20040105.0046\nSARS - worldwide (01): China, susp. case 20040102.0015\n2003\n---\nSARS worldwide (179): WHO SRAC 1st report 20031024.2666\nSARS - worldwide (02): cases 20030324.0734\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02) 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide:alert 20030315.0637\n.....................mpp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. WHO team travels\nto Beijing - update 2, 26 Apr 2004\n---------------------------------------------------------\nAt the request of the Chinese Ministry of Health, WHO is today sending the\n1st members of an international team to help investigate the source of SARS\ncases recently reported in Beijing and the eastern province of Anhui. Numerous environmental\nsamples from the laboratory have been taken to help assess possible sources\nof contamination, and these samples will be shared with WHO.\nUnderstanding and eliminating the source of infection are critical steps in\nbringing the outbreak under control. An equally important activity is to\nquickly detect all chains of transmission and interrupt them through rapid\ncase detection, tracing and follow-up of contacts, and infection control in\nhospitals.\nWHO is concerned about additional opportunities for exposure that may have\nalready occurred. Some patients were treated or assessed in several\ndifferent hospitals before a suspicion of SARS led to the introduction of\nadequate precautionary measures, including isolation of patients and strict\nprocedures for infection control. One patient travelled a long distance\ntwice by train within China while symptomatic.\nChinese authorities have heightened surveillance and reporting for\nSARS-like illness in health care facilities and have sent investigative\nteams to Anhui Province.\nSince 22 Apr 2004, China has reported that 8 people have been clinically\ndiagnosed as SARS cases or are under investigation for possible SARS\ninfection -- 6 in Beijing and 2, including the single fatality, in Anhui\nProvince. As of today, close to 1000 contacts of these cases are under\nmedical observation, including 640 in Beijing and 353 in Anhui.\nThe most recent cases, announced on Sunday, are 4 close contacts of a 20\nyear old nurse who treated the Anhui student at a Beijing hospital. The\ncases -\u00ad all in Beijing -\u00ad are currently under investigation. They include\nthe nurse\u0092s mother, father, aunt, and a woman who shared a hospital ward\nwith the nurse when she was undergoing treatment. Onset of symptoms for all\n4 occurred between 16 and 19 Apr 2004. The nurse\u0092s mother is in serious\ncondition following the development of pneumonia. The other 3 people are in\na stable condition.\nIn addition, health authorities have reported that 2 doctors who treated\nthe postgraduate student during her hospitalization in Hefai, Anhui, have\ndeveloped fever. A person in close contact with one of the doctors has also\ndeveloped fever.\nTo date, all diagnosed cases and cases under investigation have been linked\nto chains of transmission involving close personal contact with an\nidentified case. There is no evidence of wider transmission in the community.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the past 24 hours since the last update (20040425.1150), there are the\nadditional reports of fever in 2 physicians treating the index case in\nAnhui and in a close contact of one of these 2 physicians. According the\nChina Minstry of Health (MOH) website (<http://www.moh.gov.cn>), there has\nbeen the implementation of increased surveillance for \"atypical pneumonia\"\ncountry-wide, but no additional suspected cases have been identified.\nAs with 2003, there is an \"outbreak\" of newswire reports and speculations\non this current situation, and for this reason we have chosen to be highly\nselective of newswire information we post, preferring to rely upon the\nofficial reports available from WHO and the Chinese MOH. Lessons were\nclearly learned after the 2003 outbreak, and there is now apparent\ntransparency in reporting. We will continue to screen newswire reports for\npossible early introduction of probable SARS activity in new geographic\nregions (outside of the currently identified Beijing and Anhui provinces),\nincluding any possible international spread.\nWe are still awaiting information on the independent laboratory testing of\nspecimens from the currently identified cases in China. Until these results\nare available, the cases are being classified as probable and suspected.\nAccording to WHO guidelines for the global surveillance of SARS,\nclassification as a confirmed case at the start of an outbreak requires\nindependent verification of results by an external international reference\nlaboratory. Such procedures are considered necessary in view of the\nimplications that confirmed SARS cases can have for international public\nhealth. Irrespective of the \"tentative\" classifications, appropriate\ninvestigations and disease control measures have been implemented, under\nthe assumption that infection with SARS coronavirus has truly occurred.\nHence, it is a semantic discussion that will not delay appropriate control\nmeasures to interrupt transmission.\nFrom the information currently available, there is now evidence of 3\ngenerations of transmission. The 1st generation involved the index case\nfrom Anhui, and possibly a 2nd \"1st-generation\" case, the postdoctoral\nstudent from Beijing whose onset of illness was 23 days after the onset of\nillness of the index case from Anhui. The 2nd generation included the\nmother of the index case from Anhui and the nurse who cared for the index\ncase from Anhui while she was hospitalized in Beijing, and possibly the\nphysicians who cared for her while hospitalized in Anhui. The 3rd\ngeneration of cases are the family members of the nurse (from the 2nd\ngeneration), a patient hospitalized in the same ward as the nurse before\nSARS was identified as a possible diagnosis for the nurse's illness, and a\nclose contact of one of the physicians who treated the index patient in\nAnhui. This pattern of nosocomial spread due to lack of early\nidentification of SARS as a possible diagnosis is very reminiscent of the\noutbreak in 2003.\nConcern about possible spread outside of the current identified \"close\ncontact\" circle around these cases is warranted. It is to be hoped that the\nthreshold for suspicion of possible SARS will be lowered country-wide, so\ncases that may occur related to transmission while travelling on the trains\nbetween Anhui Province and Beijing will be identified and isolated early,\npreventing further generations of transmission.\nIn addition, there are appropriate concerns about laboratory safety\nprocedures. This is now the 3rd incident of SARS transmission within a\nlaboratory working on SARS research. The first 2 occurred in Singapore and\nTaiwan (see ProMED-mail postings SARS - worldwide (185): Taiwan, probable\nlab exposure 20031217.3081 and SARS - worldwide (174): Singapore laboratory\nexposure 20030923.2397). Since the 2003 outbreak, it seems as though\nlaboratory exposure is a higher risk factor than the possible zoonotic\nexposure. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (20): China, cases 20040425.1150\nSARS - worldwide (19): China, cases 20040424.1141\nSARS - worldwide (18): China, cases 20040423.1125\nSARS - worldwide (16): China, suspected cases 20040422.1118\nSARS - worldwide (15): animal reservoirs 20040417.1059\nSARS - worldwide (14): travel advice 20040212.0467\nSARS - worldwide (13): China, cases 20040131.0365\nSARS - Worldwide (12): molecular epidemiology, 2003 20040131.0364\nSARS - worldwide (11): molecular epidemiology, 2003 20040130.0358\nSARS - worldwide (10): China, 2004 cases 20040127.0327\nSARS - worldwide (09): China, WHO clarification 20040120.0223\nSARS - worldwide (08): China, suspected cases 20040119.0209\nSARS - worldwide (07) - China: suspected cases 20040114.0149\nSARS - worldwide (06) - China: suspected cases 20040111.0118\nSARS - worldwide (05): Taiwan lab investigation 20040109.0096\nSARS - Worldwide (04): China, new susp. case 20040108.0081\nSARS - worldwide (03): etiology 20040107.0073\nSARS - worldwide (02): China, laboratory confirmed 20040105.0046\nSARS - worldwide (01): China, susp. case 20040102.0015\n2003\n---\nSARS worldwide (179): WHO SRAC 1st report 20031024.2666\nSARS - worldwide (02): cases 20030324.0734\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02) 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide:alert 20030315.0637\n.....................mpp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2004-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hefai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anhui", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anhui Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205662", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (23): China, cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205662", "date": "2004-04-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (21): - CHINA, CASES\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 26 Apr 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: World Health Organization (WHO) SARS update [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_04_26/en/>\n\nAdditional patients in China under investigation for SARS; WHO team travels\nto Beijing - update 2, 26 Apr 2004\n---------------------------------------------------------\nAt the request of the Chinese Ministry of Health, WHO is today sending the\n1st members of an international team to help investigate the source of SARS\ncases recently reported in Beijing and the eastern province of Anhui. The\nteam, which is expected to begin work on Wednesday, will include experts in\nepidemiology, virology, infection control, and laboratory biosafety.\nResults of investigations to date point to laboratory research at the\nNational Institute of Virology in Beijing as the likely source of the\noutbreak. The institute has been engaged in research with the SARS\ncoronavirus, including the development of a vaccine.\nTwo of the recently reported cases were conducting research at the\nlaboratory: a 26 year old female postgraduate student from Anhui Province,\nand a 31 year old man. The dates of symptom onset in the 2 cases were\nseparated by 23 days, suggesting that more than one opportunity for\nexposure may have occurred in the laboratory from mid-March through early\nApril 2004. Authorities have closed the virology institute and placed its\nmore than 200 employees under medical observation. Numerous environmental\nsamples from the laboratory have been taken to help assess possible sources\nof contamination, and these samples will be shared with WHO.\nUnderstanding and eliminating the source of infection are critical steps in\nbringing the outbreak under control. An equally important activity is to\nquickly detect all chains of transmission and interrupt them through rapid\ncase detection, tracing and follow-up of contacts, and infection control in\nhospitals.\nWHO is concerned about additional opportunities for exposure that may have\nalready occurred. Some patients were treated or assessed in several\ndifferent hospitals before a suspicion of SARS led to the introduction of\nadequate precautionary measures, including isolation of patients and strict\nprocedures for infection control. One patient travelled a long distance\ntwice by train within China while symptomatic.\nChinese authorities have heightened surveillance and reporting for\nSARS-like illness in health care facilities and have sent investigative\nteams to Anhui Province.\nSince 22 Apr 2004, China has reported that 8 people have been clinically\ndiagnosed as SARS cases or are under investigation for possible SARS\ninfection -- 6 in Beijing and 2, including the single fatality, in Anhui\nProvince. As of today, close to 1000 contacts of these cases are under\nmedical observation, including 640 in Beijing and 353 in Anhui.\nThe most recent cases, announced on Sunday, are 4 close contacts of a 20\nyear old nurse who treated the Anhui student at a Beijing hospital. The\ncases -\u00ad all in Beijing -\u00ad are currently under investigation. They include\nthe nurse\u0092s mother, father, aunt, and a woman who shared a hospital ward\nwith the nurse when she was undergoing treatment. Onset of symptoms for all\n4 occurred between 16 and 19 Apr 2004. The nurse\u0092s mother is in serious\ncondition following the development of pneumonia. The other 3 people are in\na stable condition.\nIn addition, health authorities have reported that 2 doctors who treated\nthe postgraduate student during her hospitalization in Hefai, Anhui, have\ndeveloped fever. A person in close contact with one of the doctors has also\ndeveloped fever.\nTo date, all diagnosed cases and cases under investigation have been linked\nto chains of transmission involving close personal contact with an\nidentified case. There is no evidence of wider transmission in the community.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the past 24 hours since the last update (20040425.1150), there are the\nadditional reports of fever in 2 physicians treating the index case in\nAnhui and in a close contact of one of these 2 physicians. According the\nChina Minstry of Health (MOH) website (<http://www.moh.gov.cn>), there has\nbeen the implementation of increased surveillance for \"atypical pneumonia\"\ncountry-wide, but no additional suspected cases have been identified.\nAs with 2003, there is an \"outbreak\" of newswire reports and speculations\non this current situation, and for this reason we have chosen to be highly\nselective of newswire information we post, preferring to rely upon the\nofficial reports available from WHO and the Chinese MOH. Lessons were\nclearly learned after the 2003 outbreak, and there is now apparent\ntransparency in reporting. We will continue to screen newswire reports for\npossible early introduction of probable SARS activity in new geographic\nregions (outside of the currently identified Beijing and Anhui provinces),\nincluding any possible international spread.\nWe are still awaiting information on the independent laboratory testing of\nspecimens from the currently identified cases in China. Until these results\nare available, the cases are being classified as probable and suspected.\nAccording to WHO guidelines for the global surveillance of SARS,\nclassification as a confirmed case at the start of an outbreak requires\nindependent verification of results by an external international reference\nlaboratory. Such procedures are considered necessary in view of the\nimplications that confirmed SARS cases can have for international public\nhealth. Irrespective of the \"tentative\" classifications, appropriate\ninvestigations and disease control measures have been implemented, under\nthe assumption that infection with SARS coronavirus has truly occurred.\nHence, it is a semantic discussion that will not delay appropriate control\nmeasures to interrupt transmission.\nFrom the information currently available, there is now evidence of 3\ngenerations of transmission. The 1st generation involved the index case\nfrom Anhui, and possibly a 2nd \"1st-generation\" case, the postdoctoral\nstudent from Beijing whose onset of illness was 23 days after the onset of\nillness of the index case from Anhui. The 2nd generation included the\nmother of the index case from Anhui and the nurse who cared for the index\ncase from Anhui while she was hospitalized in Beijing, and possibly the\nphysicians who cared for her while hospitalized in Anhui. The 3rd\ngeneration of cases are the family members of the nurse (from the 2nd\ngeneration), a patient hospitalized in the same ward as the nurse before\nSARS was identified as a possible diagnosis for the nurse's illness, and a\nclose contact of one of the physicians who treated the index patient in\nAnhui. This pattern of nosocomial spread due to lack of early\nidentification of SARS as a possible diagnosis is very reminiscent of the\noutbreak in 2003.\nConcern about possible spread outside of the current identified \"close\ncontact\" circle around these cases is warranted. It is to be hoped that the\nthreshold for suspicion of possible SARS will be lowered country-wide, so\ncases that may occur related to transmission while travelling on the trains\nbetween Anhui Province and Beijing will be identified and isolated early,\npreventing further generations of transmission.\nIn addition, there are appropriate concerns about laboratory safety\nprocedures. This is now the 3rd incident of SARS transmission within a\nlaboratory working on SARS research. The first 2 occurred in Singapore and\nTaiwan (see ProMED-mail postings SARS - worldwide (185): Taiwan, probable\nlab exposure 20031217.3081 and SARS - worldwide (174): Singapore laboratory\nexposure 20030923.2397). Since the 2003 outbreak, it seems as though\nlaboratory exposure is a higher risk factor than the possible zoonotic\nexposure. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (20): China, cases 20040425.1150\nSARS - worldwide (19): China, cases 20040424.1141\nSARS - worldwide (18): China, cases 20040423.1125\nSARS - worldwide (16): China, suspected cases 20040422.1118\nSARS - worldwide (15): animal reservoirs 20040417.1059\nSARS - worldwide (14): travel advice 20040212.0467\nSARS - worldwide (13): China, cases 20040131.0365\nSARS - Worldwide (12): molecular epidemiology, 2003 20040131.0364\nSARS - worldwide (11): molecular epidemiology, 2003 20040130.0358\nSARS - worldwide (10): China, 2004 cases 20040127.0327\nSARS - worldwide (09): China, WHO clarification 20040120.0223\nSARS - worldwide (08): China, suspected cases 20040119.0209\nSARS - worldwide (07) - China: suspected cases 20040114.0149\nSARS - worldwide (06) - China: suspected cases 20040111.0118\nSARS - worldwide (05): Taiwan lab investigation 20040109.0096\nSARS - Worldwide (04): China, new susp. case 20040108.0081\nSARS - worldwide (03): etiology 20040107.0073\nSARS - worldwide (02): China, laboratory confirmed 20040105.0046\nSARS - worldwide (01): China, susp. case 20040102.0015\n2003\n---\nSARS worldwide (179): WHO SRAC 1st report 20031024.2666\nSARS - worldwide (02): cases 20030324.0734\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02) 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide:alert 20030315.0637\n.....................mpp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2004-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hefai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anhui", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anhui Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "609", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (22): China (HK SAR), transmission", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=609", "date": "2004-04-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (21): - CHINA, CASES\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 26 Apr 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: World Health Organization (WHO) SARS update [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_04_26/en/>\n\nAdditional patients in China under investigation for SARS; WHO team travels\nto Beijing - update 2, 26 Apr 2004\n---------------------------------------------------------\nAt the request of the Chinese Ministry of Health, WHO is today sending the\n1st members of an international team to help investigate the source of SARS\ncases recently reported in Beijing and the eastern province of Anhui. The\nteam, which is expected to begin work on Wednesday, will include experts in\nepidemiology, virology, infection control, and laboratory biosafety.\nResults of investigations to date point to laboratory research at the\nNational Institute of Virology in Beijing as the likely source of the\noutbreak. The institute has been engaged in research with the SARS\ncoronavirus, including the development of a vaccine.\nTwo of the recently reported cases were conducting research at the\nlaboratory: a 26 year old female postgraduate student from Anhui Province,\nand a 31 year old man. The dates of symptom onset in the 2 cases were\nseparated by 23 days, suggesting that more than one opportunity for\nexposure may have occurred in the laboratory from mid-March through early\nApril 2004. Authorities have closed the virology institute and placed its\nmore than 200 employees under medical observation. Numerous environmental\nsamples from the laboratory have been taken to help assess possible sources\nof contamination, and these samples will be shared with WHO.\nUnderstanding and eliminating the source of infection are critical steps in\nbringing the outbreak under control. An equally important activity is to\nquickly detect all chains of transmission and interrupt them through rapid\ncase detection, tracing and follow-up of contacts, and infection control in\nhospitals.\nWHO is concerned about additional opportunities for exposure that may have\nalready occurred. Some patients were treated or assessed in several\ndifferent hospitals before a suspicion of SARS led to the introduction of\nadequate precautionary measures, including isolation of patients and strict\nprocedures for infection control. One patient travelled a long distance\ntwice by train within China while symptomatic.\nChinese authorities have heightened surveillance and reporting for\nSARS-like illness in health care facilities and have sent investigative\nteams to Anhui Province.\nSince 22 Apr 2004, China has reported that 8 people have been clinically\ndiagnosed as SARS cases or are under investigation for possible SARS\ninfection -- 6 in Beijing and 2, including the single fatality, in Anhui\nProvince. As of today, close to 1000 contacts of these cases are under\nmedical observation, including 640 in Beijing and 353 in Anhui.\nThe most recent cases, announced on Sunday, are 4 close contacts of a 20\nyear old nurse who treated the Anhui student at a Beijing hospital. The\ncases -\u00ad all in Beijing -\u00ad are currently under investigation. They include\nthe nurse\u0092s mother, father, aunt, and a woman who shared a hospital ward\nwith the nurse when she was undergoing treatment. Onset of symptoms for all\n4 occurred between 16 and 19 Apr 2004. The nurse\u0092s mother is in serious\ncondition following the development of pneumonia. The other 3 people are in\na stable condition.\nIn addition, health authorities have reported that 2 doctors who treated\nthe postgraduate student during her hospitalization in Hefai, Anhui, have\ndeveloped fever. A person in close contact with one of the doctors has also\ndeveloped fever.\nTo date, all diagnosed cases and cases under investigation have been linked\nto chains of transmission involving close personal contact with an\nidentified case. There is no evidence of wider transmission in the community.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the past 24 hours since the last update (20040425.1150), there are the\nadditional reports of fever in 2 physicians treating the index case in\nAnhui and in a close contact of one of these 2 physicians. According the\nChina Minstry of Health (MOH) website (<http://www.moh.gov.cn>), there has\nbeen the implementation of increased surveillance for \"atypical pneumonia\"\ncountry-wide, but no additional suspected cases have been identified.\nAs with 2003, there is an \"outbreak\" of newswire reports and speculations\non this current situation, and for this reason we have chosen to be highly\nselective of newswire information we post, preferring to rely upon the\nofficial reports available from WHO and the Chinese MOH. Lessons were\nclearly learned after the 2003 outbreak, and there is now apparent\ntransparency in reporting. We will continue to screen newswire reports for\npossible early introduction of probable SARS activity in new geographic\nregions (outside of the currently identified Beijing and Anhui provinces),\nincluding any possible international spread.\nWe are still awaiting information on the independent laboratory testing of\nspecimens from the currently identified cases in China. Until these results\nare available, the cases are being classified as probable and suspected.\nAccording to WHO guidelines for the global surveillance of SARS,\nclassification as a confirmed case at the start of an outbreak requires\nindependent verification of results by an external international reference\nlaboratory. Such procedures are considered necessary in view of the\nimplications that confirmed SARS cases can have for international public\nhealth. Irrespective of the \"tentative\" classifications, appropriate\ninvestigations and disease control measures have been implemented, under\nthe assumption that infection with SARS coronavirus has truly occurred.\nHence, it is a semantic discussion that will not delay appropriate control\nmeasures to interrupt transmission.\nFrom the information currently available, there is now evidence of 3\ngenerations of transmission. The 1st generation involved the index case\nfrom Anhui, and possibly a 2nd \"1st-generation\" case, the postdoctoral\nstudent from Beijing whose onset of illness was 23 days after the onset of\nillness of the index case from Anhui. The 2nd generation included the\nmother of the index case from Anhui and the nurse who cared for the index\ncase from Anhui while she was hospitalized in Beijing, and possibly the\nphysicians who cared for her while hospitalized in Anhui. The 3rd\ngeneration of cases are the family members of the nurse (from the 2nd\ngeneration), a patient hospitalized in the same ward as the nurse before\nSARS was identified as a possible diagnosis for the nurse's illness, and a\nclose contact of one of the physicians who treated the index patient in\nAnhui. This pattern of nosocomial spread due to lack of early\nidentification of SARS as a possible diagnosis is very reminiscent of the\noutbreak in 2003.\nConcern about possible spread outside of the current identified \"close\ncontact\" circle around these cases is warranted. It is to be hoped that the\nthreshold for suspicion of possible SARS will be lowered country-wide, so\ncases that may occur related to transmission while travelling on the trains\nbetween Anhui Province and Beijing will be identified and isolated early,\npreventing further generations of transmission.\nIn addition, there are appropriate concerns about laboratory safety\nprocedures. This is now the 3rd incident of SARS transmission within a\nlaboratory working on SARS research. The first 2 occurred in Singapore and\nTaiwan (see ProMED-mail postings SARS - worldwide (185): Taiwan, probable\nlab exposure 20031217.3081 and SARS - worldwide (174): Singapore laboratory\nexposure 20030923.2397). Since the 2003 outbreak, it seems as though\nlaboratory exposure is a higher risk factor than the possible zoonotic\nexposure. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (20): China, cases 20040425.1150\nSARS - worldwide (19): China, cases 20040424.1141\nSARS - worldwide (18): China, cases 20040423.1125\nSARS - worldwide (16): China, suspected cases 20040422.1118\nSARS - worldwide (15): animal reservoirs 20040417.1059\nSARS - worldwide (14): travel advice 20040212.0467\nSARS - worldwide (13): China, cases 20040131.0365\nSARS - Worldwide (12): molecular epidemiology, 2003 20040131.0364\nSARS - worldwide (11): molecular epidemiology, 2003 20040130.0358\nSARS - worldwide (10): China, 2004 cases 20040127.0327\nSARS - worldwide (09): China, WHO clarification 20040120.0223\nSARS - worldwide (08): China, suspected cases 20040119.0209\nSARS - worldwide (07) - China: suspected cases 20040114.0149\nSARS - worldwide (06) - China: suspected cases 20040111.0118\nSARS - worldwide (05): Taiwan lab investigation 20040109.0096\nSARS - Worldwide (04): China, new susp. case 20040108.0081\nSARS - worldwide (03): etiology 20040107.0073\nSARS - worldwide (02): China, laboratory confirmed 20040105.0046\nSARS - worldwide (01): China, susp. case 20040102.0015\n2003\n---\nSARS worldwide (179): WHO SRAC 1st report 20031024.2666\nSARS - worldwide (02): cases 20030324.0734\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02) 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide:alert 20030315.0637\n.....................mpp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2004-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hefai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anhui", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anhui Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205638", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide - China (20): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205638", "date": "2003-11-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (183): ETIOLOGY\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 28 Nov 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Lancet, vol. 362, no. 9398, Fri 29 Nov 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.thelancet.com/journal/vol362/iss9398/abs/llan.362.9398.original_research.27886.1>\n\nHong Kong: Genotype of the SARS coronavirus from the Amoy Gardens outbreak\n---------------------------------------------------\n[The following is the summary of a Research Letter in the current\nissue of the Lancet, in which the authors conclude that the different\nfeatures of the hospital-based outbreak and the Amoy Gardens outbreak\nare the result of extraneous factors rather than differences in virus\ngenotype. - Mod.CP]\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) is a global health concern.\nIn Hong Kong, 2 major outbreaks, one hospital-based and the other in\nthe Amoy Gardens apartments, were identified. The frequency of\ndiarrhoea, admission to intensive care, and mortality differed\nsignificantly between the 2 outbreaks. We carried out genomic\nsequencing for viral isolates from 5 Amoy Gardens patients. The virus\nsequence was identical in 4 of these 5 patients. The sequence data\nfrom one hospital case and the 4 identical community cases had only 3\nnucleotide differences. Alterations in the SARS coronavirus genome\nare unlikely to have caused the distinctive clinical features of the\nAmoy Gardens patients, and these results highlight the importance of\nnon-viral genomic factors in this outbreak.\n(By S S C Chim, S K W Tsui, K C A Chan, T C C Au, E C W Hung, Y K\nTong, R W K Chiu, E K O Ng, P K S Chan, C M Chu, J J Y Sung, J S Tam,\nK P Fung, M M Y Waye, C Y Lee, K Y Yuen, Y M D Lo, and members of the\nCUHK Molecular SARS Research Group. From the Departments of Chemical\nPathology (S S C Chim PhD, K C A Chan MRCP, Y K Tong MPhil, R W K\nChiu MB, E K O Ng PhD, Prof Y M D Lo DM), Biochemistry (S K W Tsui\nPhD, T C C Au MPhil, K P Fung PhD, M M Y Waye PhD, Prof C Y Lee PhD),\nPaediatrics (E C W Hung MB), Microbiology (P K S Chan MRCPath, J S\nTam PhD), and Medicine and Therapeutics (Prof J J Y Sung MD), Chinese\nUniversity of Hong Kong, Prince of Wales Hospital, Hong Kong, China;\nDepartment of Medicine, United Christian Hospital, Hong Kong (C M Chu\nFRCP); and Department of Microbiology, Queen Mary Hospital,\nUniversity of Hong Kong, Hong Kong (Prof K Y Yuen MD)\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (48): etiology 20030414.0909\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0935\nSARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994\nSARS - worldwide (64): etiology 20030423.0996\nSARS - worldwide (68): etiology 20030427.1039\nSARS - worldwide (82): etiology 20030501.1086\nSARS - worldwide (90): background 20030503.1112\nSARS - worldwide (91): etiology 20030504.1114\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (98): etiology 20030509.1151\nSARS worldwide (163): etiology 20030722.1790\nSARS worldwide (164): etiology 20030723.1800\nSARS worldwide (167): etiology 20030821.2104\nSARS worldwide (179): WHO SRAC 1st report 20031024.2666\nSARS - worldwide (180): epidemiology, Guangdong 20031027.2681\nSARS - worldwide (181): host range 20031030.2701\n.......................cp/pg/lm\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The frequency of\ndiarrhoea, admission to intensive care, and mortality differed\nsignificantly between the 2 outbreaks. We carried out genomic\nsequencing for viral isolates from 5 Amoy Gardens patients. The virus\nsequence was identical in 4 of these 5 patients. The sequence data\nfrom one hospital case and the 4 identical community cases had only 3\nnucleotide differences. Alterations in the SARS coronavirus genome\nare unlikely to have caused the distinctive clinical features of the\nAmoy Gardens patients, and these results highlight the importance of\nnon-viral genomic factors in this outbreak.\n(By S S C Chim, S K W Tsui, K C A Chan, T C C Au, E C W Hung, Y K\nTong, R W K Chiu, E K O Ng, P K S Chan, C M Chu, J J Y Sung, J S Tam,\nK P Fung, M M Y Waye, C Y Lee, K Y Yuen, Y M D Lo, and members of the\nCUHK Molecular SARS Research Group. From the Departments of Chemical\nPathology (S S C Chim PhD, K C A Chan MRCP, Y K Tong MPhil, R W K\nChiu MB, E K O Ng PhD, Prof Y M D Lo DM), Biochemistry (S K W Tsui\nPhD, T C C Au MPhil, K P Fung PhD, M M Y Waye PhD, Prof C Y Lee PhD),\nPaediatrics (E C W Hung MB), Microbiology (P K S Chan MRCPath, J S\nTam PhD), and Medicine and Therapeutics (Prof J J Y Sung MD), Chinese\nUniversity of Hong Kong, Prince of Wales Hospital, Hong Kong, China;\nDepartment of Medicine, United Christian Hospital, Hong Kong (C M Chu\nFRCP); and Department of Microbiology, Queen Mary Hospital,\nUniversity of Hong Kong, Hong Kong (Prof K Y Yuen MD)\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (48): etiology 20030414.0909\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0935\nSARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994\nSARS - worldwide (64): etiology 20030423.0996\nSARS - worldwide (68): etiology 20030427.1039\nSARS - worldwide (82): etiology 20030501.1086\nSARS - worldwide (90): background 20030503.1112\nSARS - worldwide (91): etiology 20030504.1114\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (98): etiology 20030509.1151\nSARS worldwide (163): etiology 20030722.1790\nSARS worldwide (164): etiology 20030723.1800\nSARS worldwide (167): etiology 20030821.2104\nSARS worldwide (179): WHO SRAC 1st report 20031024.2666\nSARS - worldwide (180): epidemiology, Guangdong 20031027.2681\nSARS - worldwide (181): host range 20031030.2701\n.......................cp/pg/lm\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The sequence data\nfrom one hospital case and the 4 identical community cases had only 3\nnucleotide differences. The frequency of\ndiarrhoea, admission to intensive care, and mortality differed\nsignificantly between the 2 outbreaks. We carried out genomic\nsequencing for viral isolates from 5 Amoy Gardens patients. The virus\nsequence was identical in 4 of these 5 patients. The sequence data\nfrom one hospital case and the 4 identical community cases had only 3\nnucleotide differences. Alterations in the SARS coronavirus genome\nare unlikely to have caused the distinctive clinical features of the\nAmoy Gardens patients, and these results highlight the importance of\nnon-viral genomic factors in this outbreak.\n(By S S C Chim, S K W Tsui, K C A Chan, T C C Au, E C W Hung, Y K\nTong, R W K Chiu, E K O Ng, P K S Chan, C M Chu, J J Y Sung, J S Tam,\nK P Fung, M M Y Waye, C Y Lee, K Y Yuen, Y M D Lo, and members of the\nCUHK Molecular SARS Research Group. From the Departments of Chemical\nPathology (S S C Chim PhD, K C A Chan MRCP, Y K Tong MPhil, R W K\nChiu MB, E K O Ng PhD, Prof Y M D Lo DM), Biochemistry (S K W Tsui\nPhD, T C C Au MPhil, K P Fung PhD, M M Y Waye PhD, Prof C Y Lee PhD),\nPaediatrics (E C W Hung MB), Microbiology (P K S Chan MRCPath, J S\nTam PhD), and Medicine and Therapeutics (Prof J J Y Sung MD), Chinese\nUniversity of Hong Kong, Prince of Wales Hospital, Hong Kong, China;\nDepartment of Medicine, United Christian Hospital, Hong Kong (C M Chu\nFRCP); and Department of Microbiology, Queen Mary Hospital,\nUniversity of Hong Kong, Hong Kong (Prof K Y Yuen MD)\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (48): etiology 20030414.0909\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0935\nSARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994\nSARS - worldwide (64): etiology 20030423.0996\nSARS - worldwide (68): etiology 20030427.1039\nSARS - worldwide (82): etiology 20030501.1086\nSARS - worldwide (90): background 20030503.1112\nSARS - worldwide (91): etiology 20030504.1114\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (98): etiology 20030509.1151\nSARS worldwide (163): etiology 20030722.1790\nSARS worldwide (164): etiology 20030723.1800\nSARS worldwide (167): etiology 20030821.2104\nSARS worldwide (179): WHO SRAC 1st report 20031024.2666\nSARS - worldwide (180): epidemiology, Guangdong 20031027.2681\nSARS - worldwide (181): host range 20031030.2701\n.......................cp/pg/lm\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. In\nthe absence of information on the nature of the tests and the\nreagents employed, it is difficult to comment on this report in any\ndetail. Nonetheless, it provides invaluable data on the presence of a\nSARS coronavirus-like agent in asymptomatic humans approximately one\nyear before the appearance of SARS in Guangdong. However, the report\ndoes not indicate whether any of the 16 positive samples originated\nfrom Guangdong. Further information is awaited. - Mod.CP]\nBeijing Military District Air Force General Logistics Department\nstudied 1621 samples of cryopreserved blood from healthy youths in\n169 counties in China. Blood had been drawn between 2001 and 2002.\nAfter conducting 4 tests at 3 \"authoritative\" institutions, it was\ndetermined that 16 samples had a positive reaction to the SARS virus\nantigen.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (131): diagnostic testing 20030603.1359\nSARS - worldwide (87): case definitions and diagnostics 20030502.1103\nPRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nPRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (41):overview 20030411.0876\n...................cp/pg/lm\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. In\nthe absence of information on the nature of the tests and the\nreagents employed, it is difficult to comment on this report in any\ndetail. Nonetheless, it provides invaluable data on the presence of a\nSARS coronavirus-like agent in asymptomatic humans approximately one\nyear before the appearance of SARS in Guangdong. However, the report\ndoes not indicate whether any of the 16 positive samples originated\nfrom Guangdong. Further information is awaited. - Mod.CP]\nBeijing Military District Air Force General Logistics Department\nstudied 1621 samples of cryopreserved blood from healthy youths in\n169 counties in China. Blood had been drawn between 2001 and 2002.\nAfter conducting 4 tests at 3 \"authoritative\" institutions, it was\ndetermined that 16 samples had a positive reaction to the SARS virus\nantigen.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (131): diagnostic testing 20030603.1359\nSARS - worldwide (87): case definitions and diagnostics 20030502.1103\nPRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nPRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (41):overview 20030411.0876\n...................cp/pg/lm\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-09-23 00:00:00", "2003-09-24 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CHINA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204606", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - Worldwide (174): Singapore laboratory exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204606", "date": "2003-08-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (167): ETIOLOGY\n*********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 21 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: ProLog [edited]\n<http://www.ptd.net/webnews/wed/bm/Qhealth-sars-china.ROc8_DaL.html>\n\nA SARS-like virus has been found in a broad range of animals, stretching from\nsnakes and birds to mammals, a medical group said Thursday after returning\nfrom the epicenter of the virus in south China.\nThe 14 United Nations and Chinese experts visited farms and markets in\nGuangdong province in search of a possible animal carrier of the virus, and\nwere astounded to see how many different species were infected. \"What is\nsurprising is we got positive results from mammals, from birds and from\nreptiles,\" said Francois Moutou, a French expert on epidemic disease. \"This\nis very strange, because usually we don't find viruses ... affecting so many\n[different] animals,\" he told a briefing in Beijing.\nAfter a week-long trip to Guangdong, where the atypical pneumonia erupted\nlate in 2002, the search for an animal carrier remains a \"work in progress,\"\naccording to health officials.\nOne of the main findings by the expert group was the realization that finding\nthe origin and nature of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) may be a\nmuch more complex task than initially hoped.\n\"There may be many animals that are capable of being infected, but they\nmight not be capable of transmitting the virus to people,\" Hume E. Field,\nan expert from Australia's Animal Research Institute, told the briefing. The\nresearchers warned that detecting the source of the disease might take years,\nwhich means measures to curb further transmission must be undertaken before\nit is fully understood. \"Obviously we can't wait until we've got the whole\njigsaw together before action is taken,\" said Field. \"So really we have to\nlook at the best information we've got at the time in terms of risk and\nrespond according to that.\"\nCurbing further threats from SARS could result in restrictions on consumption\nof certain types of wildlife known to be infected, despite inconclusive data\non whether the species is capable of transmitting the sometimes-fatal illness\nto humans, he said.\nAfter SARS emerged in Guangdong province in 2002, it quickly spread to become\na global menace, leaving more than 800 dead from 8000 infections in 32\ncountries. Some 349 of the fatalities and 5327 of the infections were\nrecorded in China. Although China has formally declared victory over SARS\nand the last patients have been discharged from hospital, many in the world's\nmost populous country remain wary that the epidemic could bounce back. And\neven if the world has not seen the reemergence of SARS by New Year 2004, it\ndoes not mean the danger is entirely over, experts warned. \"We need to\nrecognize that if it doesn't return this year, that doesn't mean it will\nnever return,\" Field told the briefing.\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) said Thursday it would train thousands\nof medical workers in China, as fears linger that SARS could strike again\nthis year once cold weather sets in. The training program is meant to\nbetter equip health workers to prevent infectious diseases from spreading\nin hospitals, said Alan Schnur, a WHO communicable diseases expert. The\ntraining program will begin in Beijing, where 193 people died from the\nepidemic earlier in 2003, and will gradually be expanded to other parts of\nChina.\nAt the height of the SARS outbreak, many people in China were scared of\ngoing to hospitals because of fears -- in some cases well-founded -- that\nsub-standard facilities made them breeding-grounds for the virus.\nThe WHO could not conclusively rule out a SARS reappearance in late autumn\nas temperatures start plunging, and stressed steps should be taken to\nprevent any potential outbreak. \"Whether or not SARS returns, China must have\na strong surveillance network already in place,\" said Henk Bekedam, the WHO's\nChina representative.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 21 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/releases/2003/prchina2/en/>\n\nWHO Representative Office in China 21 Aug 2003\nJoint mission on SARS animal reservoir and necessary next steps\n--------------------------------------\nA joint team of specialists from the Chinese government, the World Health\nOrganization, and the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization\n(FAO), in China to investigate the animal reservoir of the SARS\ncoronavirus, has issued a series of recommendations and actions necessary\nnot only to identify the disease's animal reservoir, but to contain any\nfuture outbreaks.\n\"We did not set out this time to find the animal reservoir for SARS, but to\nmethodically piece together the jigsaw puzzle of this disease,\" says WHO's\nDr Pierre Formenty, a zoonotic disease specialist and joint leader of the\nmission. \"The fight against SARS is not over. Finding its origin will most\nlikely take years,\" says Dr Formenty, \"Right now, the need for information\nis of such urgency that even limited information will be helpful in taking\nthe right control measures. Because SARS is a global threat, international\ncollaboration is essential if we are to detect and rapidly contain any new\noutbreaks.\"\nAmong the measures recommended by the joint team of specialists include the\nstrengthening of regulations in the farming, trading, and consumption of\nwildlife. More serological monitoring of the SARS coronavirus are needed\nboth in animals and humans, as well as continued in-depth human studies of\nSARS index cases. Determining how SARS first breached the species barrier\nis crucial to controlling it.\nWhile it is still unknown whether SARS will return, WHO is continuing to\nwork closely with the Chinese government to design and implement a strategy\nusing hospitals as early detection centers of SARS. WHO is also\ncollaborating with the Chinese Ministry of Health to strengthen infection\ncontrol in health care settings. A series of training seminars on SARS\ninfection control procedures for health care workers is scheduled for\nSeptember 2003 in Beijing and Changsha.\nFollowing a meeting today with senior officials from the Ministry of\nScience and Technology, Ministry of Agriculture, Ministry of Health, and\nthe Ministry of Forestry, in which the Chinese government recognized the\nneed for increased research co-ordination, WHO is optimistic about future\nprospects for collaboration.\n\"Whether or not SARS returns, China must have a strong surveillance network\nalready in place,\" says Dr Henk Bekedam, WHO's China Representative. \"China\nhas a unique opportunity to contribute to the international understanding\nof this disease. Investing now in this safety net may be the key to\nsuccessfully combating SARS.\"\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (16): etiology 20030328.0774\nSARS - worldwide (19): etiology 20030330.0786\nSARS - worldwide (26): etiology 20030403.0819\nSARS - worldwide (31): etiology 20030405.0833\nSARS - worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - worldwide (48): etiology 20030414.0909\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0944\nSARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994\nSARS - worldwide (64): etiology 20030423.0996\nSARS - worldwide (68): etiology 20030425.1010\nSARS - worldwide (74): etiology 20030427.1039\nSARS - worldwide (82): etiology 20030429.1057\nSARS - worldwide (84): etiology 20030501.1086\nSARS - worldwide (91): etiology 20030504.1114\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (98): etiology 20030509.1151\nSARS - worldwide (101): etiology 20030510.1168\nSARS - worldwide (106): etiology 20030515.1210\nSARS - worldwide (109): etiology 20030517.1227\nSARS - worldwide (117): etiology 20030523.1267\nSARS worldwide (163): etiology 20030722.1790\nSARS worldwide (164): etiology 20030723.1800\n..................mpp/pgjw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2038-03-16 00:00:00", "2048-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2053-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "2064-03-16 00:00:00", "2068-03-16 00:00:00", "1974-03-16 00:00:00", "1991-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Changsha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204555", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (173): Singapore, laboratory conf", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204555", "date": "2003-08-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (167): ETIOLOGY\n*********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 21 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: ProLog [edited]\n<http://www.ptd.net/webnews/wed/bm/Qhealth-sars-china.ROc8_DaL.html>\n\nA SARS-like virus has been found in a broad range of animals, stretching from\nsnakes and birds to mammals, a medical group said Thursday after returning\nfrom the epicenter of the virus in south China.\nThe 14 United Nations and Chinese experts visited farms and markets in\nGuangdong province in search of a possible animal carrier of the virus, and\nwere astounded to see how many different species were infected. \"What is\nsurprising is we got positive results from mammals, from birds and from\nreptiles,\" said Francois Moutou, a French expert on epidemic disease. \"This\nis very strange, because usually we don't find viruses ... affecting so many\n[different] animals,\" he told a briefing in Beijing.\nAfter a week-long trip to Guangdong, where the atypical pneumonia erupted\nlate in 2002, the search for an animal carrier remains a \"work in progress,\"\naccording to health officials.\nOne of the main findings by the expert group was the realization that finding\nthe origin and nature of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) may be a\nmuch more complex task than initially hoped.\n\"There may be many animals that are capable of being infected, but they\nmight not be capable of transmitting the virus to people,\" Hume E. Field,\nan expert from Australia's Animal Research Institute, told the briefing. The\nresearchers warned that detecting the source of the disease might take years,\nwhich means measures to curb further transmission must be undertaken before\nit is fully understood. \"Obviously we can't wait until we've got the whole\njigsaw together before action is taken,\" said Field. \"So really we have to\nlook at the best information we've got at the time in terms of risk and\nrespond according to that.\"\nCurbing further threats from SARS could result in restrictions on consumption\nof certain types of wildlife known to be infected, despite inconclusive data\non whether the species is capable of transmitting the sometimes-fatal illness\nto humans, he said.\nAfter SARS emerged in Guangdong province in 2002, it quickly spread to become\na global menace, leaving more than 800 dead from 8000 infections in 32\ncountries. And\neven if the world has not seen the reemergence of SARS by New Year 2004, it\ndoes not mean the danger is entirely over, experts warned. \"We need to\nrecognize that if it doesn't return this year, that doesn't mean it will\nnever return,\" Field told the briefing.\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) said Thursday it would train thousands\nof medical workers in China, as fears linger that SARS could strike again\nthis year once cold weather sets in. The training program is meant to\nbetter equip health workers to prevent infectious diseases from spreading\nin hospitals, said Alan Schnur, a WHO communicable diseases expert. The\ntraining program will begin in Beijing, where 193 people died from the\nepidemic earlier in 2003, and will gradually be expanded to other parts of\nChina.\nAt the height of the SARS outbreak, many people in China were scared of\ngoing to hospitals because of fears -- in some cases well-founded -- that\nsub-standard facilities made them breeding-grounds for the virus.\nThe WHO could not conclusively rule out a SARS reappearance in late autumn\nas temperatures start plunging, and stressed steps should be taken to\nprevent any potential outbreak. \"Whether or not SARS returns, China must have\na strong surveillance network already in place,\" said Henk Bekedam, the WHO's\nChina representative.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 21 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/releases/2003/prchina2/en/>\n\nWHO Representative Office in China 21 Aug 2003\nJoint mission on SARS animal reservoir and necessary next steps\n--------------------------------------\nA joint team of specialists from the Chinese government, the World Health\nOrganization, and the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization\n(FAO), in China to investigate the animal reservoir of the SARS\ncoronavirus, has issued a series of recommendations and actions necessary\nnot only to identify the disease's animal reservoir, but to contain any\nfuture outbreaks.\n\"We did not set out this time to find the animal reservoir for SARS, but to\nmethodically piece together the jigsaw puzzle of this disease,\" says WHO's\nDr Pierre Formenty, a zoonotic disease specialist and joint leader of the\nmission. \"The fight against SARS is not over. Finding its origin will most\nlikely take years,\" says Dr Formenty, \"Right now, the need for information\nis of such urgency that even limited information will be helpful in taking\nthe right control measures. Because SARS is a global threat, international\ncollaboration is essential if we are to detect and rapidly contain any new\noutbreaks.\"\nAmong the measures recommended by the joint team of specialists include the\nstrengthening of regulations in the farming, trading, and consumption of\nwildlife. More serological monitoring of the SARS coronavirus are needed\nboth in animals and humans, as well as continued in-depth human studies of\nSARS index cases. Determining how SARS first breached the species barrier\nis crucial to controlling it.\nWhile it is still unknown whether SARS will return, WHO is continuing to\nwork closely with the Chinese government to design and implement a strategy\nusing hospitals as early detection centers of SARS. WHO is also\ncollaborating with the Chinese Ministry of Health to strengthen infection\ncontrol in health care settings. A series of training seminars on SARS\ninfection control procedures for health care workers is scheduled for\nSeptember 2003 in Beijing and Changsha.\nFollowing a meeting today with senior officials from the Ministry of\nScience and Technology, Ministry of Agriculture, Ministry of Health, and\nthe Ministry of Forestry, in which the Chinese government recognized the\nneed for increased research co-ordination, WHO is optimistic about future\nprospects for collaboration.\n\"Whether or not SARS returns, China must have a strong surveillance network\nalready in place,\" says Dr Henk Bekedam, WHO's China Representative. \"China\nhas a unique opportunity to contribute to the international understanding\nof this disease. Investing now in this safety net may be the key to\nsuccessfully combating SARS.\"\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (16): etiology 20030328.0774\nSARS - worldwide (19): etiology 20030330.0786\nSARS - worldwide (26): etiology 20030403.0819\nSARS - worldwide (31): etiology 20030405.0833\nSARS - worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - worldwide (48): etiology 20030414.0909\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0944\nSARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994\nSARS - worldwide (64): etiology 20030423.0996\nSARS - worldwide (68): etiology 20030425.1010\nSARS - worldwide (74): etiology 20030427.1039\nSARS - worldwide (82): etiology 20030429.1057\nSARS - worldwide (84): etiology 20030501.1086\nSARS - worldwide (91): etiology 20030504.1114\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (98): etiology 20030509.1151\nSARS - worldwide (101): etiology 20030510.1168\nSARS - worldwide (106): etiology 20030515.1210\nSARS - worldwide (109): etiology 20030517.1227\nSARS - worldwide (117): etiology 20030523.1267\nSARS worldwide (163): etiology 20030722.1790\nSARS worldwide (164): etiology 20030723.1800\n..................mpp/pgjw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
