For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2038-03-16 00:00:00", "2048-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2053-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "2064-03-16 00:00:00", "2068-03-16 00:00:00", "1974-03-16 00:00:00", "1991-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Changsha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204534", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (172): Singapore, probable case", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204534", "date": "2003-08-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (167): ETIOLOGY\n*********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 21 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: ProLog [edited]\n<http://www.ptd.net/webnews/wed/bm/Qhealth-sars-china.ROc8_DaL.html>\n\nA SARS-like virus has been found in a broad range of animals, stretching from\nsnakes and birds to mammals, a medical group said Thursday after returning\nfrom the epicenter of the virus in south China.\nThe 14 United Nations and Chinese experts visited farms and markets in\nGuangdong province in search of a possible animal carrier of the virus, and\nwere astounded to see how many different species were infected. \"What is\nsurprising is we got positive results from mammals, from birds and from\nreptiles,\" said Francois Moutou, a French expert on epidemic disease. \"This\nis very strange, because usually we don't find viruses ... affecting so many\n[different] animals,\" he told a briefing in Beijing.\nAfter a week-long trip to Guangdong, where the atypical pneumonia erupted\nlate in 2002, the search for an animal carrier remains a \"work in progress,\"\naccording to health officials.\nOne of the main findings by the expert group was the realization that finding\nthe origin and nature of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) may be a\nmuch more complex task than initially hoped.\n\"There may be many animals that are capable of being infected, but they\nmight not be capable of transmitting the virus to people,\" Hume E. Field,\nan expert from Australia's Animal Research Institute, told the briefing. The\nresearchers warned that detecting the source of the disease might take years,\nwhich means measures to curb further transmission must be undertaken before\nit is fully understood. \"Obviously we can't wait until we've got the whole\njigsaw together before action is taken,\" said Field. \"So really we have to\nlook at the best information we've got at the time in terms of risk and\nrespond according to that.\"\nCurbing further threats from SARS could result in restrictions on consumption\nof certain types of wildlife known to be infected, despite inconclusive data\non whether the species is capable of transmitting the sometimes-fatal illness\nto humans, he said.\nAfter SARS emerged in Guangdong province in 2002, it quickly spread to become\na global menace, leaving more than 800 dead from 8000 infections in 32\ncountries. Some 349 of the fatalities and 5327 of the infections were\nrecorded in China. Although China has formally declared victory over SARS\nand the last patients have been discharged from hospital, many in the world's\nmost populous country remain wary that the epidemic could bounce back. And\neven if the world has not seen the reemergence of SARS by New Year 2004, it\ndoes not mean the danger is entirely over, experts warned. \"We need to\nrecognize that if it doesn't return this year, that doesn't mean it will\nnever return,\" Field told the briefing.\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) said Thursday it would train thousands\nof medical workers in China, as fears linger that SARS could strike again\nthis year once cold weather sets in. The training program is meant to\nbetter equip health workers to prevent infectious diseases from spreading\nin hospitals, said Alan Schnur, a WHO communicable diseases expert. The\ntraining program will begin in Beijing, where 193 people died from the\nepidemic earlier in 2003, and will gradually be expanded to other parts of\nChina.\nAt the height of the SARS outbreak, many people in China were scared of\ngoing to hospitals because of fears -- in some cases well-founded -- that\nsub-standard facilities made them breeding-grounds for the virus.\nThe WHO could not conclusively rule out a SARS reappearance in late autumn\nas temperatures start plunging, and stressed steps should be taken to\nprevent any potential outbreak. \"Whether or not SARS returns, China must have\na strong surveillance network already in place,\" said Henk Bekedam, the WHO's\nChina representative.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 21 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/releases/2003/prchina2/en/>\n\nWHO Representative Office in China 21 Aug 2003\nJoint mission on SARS animal reservoir and necessary next steps\n--------------------------------------\nA joint team of specialists from the Chinese government, the World Health\nOrganization, and the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization\n(FAO), in China to investigate the animal reservoir of the SARS\ncoronavirus, has issued a series of recommendations and actions necessary\nnot only to identify the disease's animal reservoir, but to contain any\nfuture outbreaks.\n\"We did not set out this time to find the animal reservoir for SARS, but to\nmethodically piece together the jigsaw puzzle of this disease,\" says WHO's\nDr Pierre Formenty, a zoonotic disease specialist and joint leader of the\nmission. \"The fight against SARS is not over. Finding its origin will most\nlikely take years,\" says Dr Formenty, \"Right now, the need for information\nis of such urgency that even limited information will be helpful in taking\nthe right control measures. Because SARS is a global threat, international\ncollaboration is essential if we are to detect and rapidly contain any new\noutbreaks.\"\nAmong the measures recommended by the joint team of specialists include the\nstrengthening of regulations in the farming, trading, and consumption of\nwildlife. More serological monitoring of the SARS coronavirus are needed\nboth in animals and humans, as well as continued in-depth human studies of\nSARS index cases. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2038-03-16 00:00:00", "2048-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2053-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "2064-03-16 00:00:00", "2068-03-16 00:00:00", "1974-03-16 00:00:00", "1991-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Changsha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204522", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (170): Singapore, probable case", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204522", "date": "2003-08-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (167): ETIOLOGY\n*********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 21 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: ProLog [edited]\n<http://www.ptd.net/webnews/wed/bm/Qhealth-sars-china.ROc8_DaL.html>\n\nA SARS-like virus has been found in a broad range of animals, stretching from\nsnakes and birds to mammals, a medical group said Thursday after returning\nfrom the epicenter of the virus in south China.\nThe 14 United Nations and Chinese experts visited farms and markets in\nGuangdong province in search of a possible animal carrier of the virus, and\nwere astounded to see how many different species were infected. \"What is\nsurprising is we got positive results from mammals, from birds and from\nreptiles,\" said Francois Moutou, a French expert on epidemic disease. \"This\nis very strange, because usually we don't find viruses ... affecting so many\n[different] animals,\" he told a briefing in Beijing.\nAfter a week-long trip to Guangdong, where the atypical pneumonia erupted\nlate in 2002, the search for an animal carrier remains a \"work in progress,\"\naccording to health officials.\nOne of the main findings by the expert group was the realization that finding\nthe origin and nature of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) may be a\nmuch more complex task than initially hoped.\n\"There may be many animals that are capable of being infected, but they\nmight not be capable of transmitting the virus to people,\" Hume E. Field,\nan expert from Australia's Animal Research Institute, told the briefing. The\nresearchers warned that detecting the source of the disease might take years,\nwhich means measures to curb further transmission must be undertaken before\nit is fully understood. \"Obviously we can't wait until we've got the whole\njigsaw together before action is taken,\" said Field. \"So really we have to\nlook at the best information we've got at the time in terms of risk and\nrespond according to that.\"\nCurbing further threats from SARS could result in restrictions on consumption\nof certain types of wildlife known to be infected, despite inconclusive data\non whether the species is capable of transmitting the sometimes-fatal illness\nto humans, he said.\nAfter SARS emerged in Guangdong province in 2002, it quickly spread to become\na global menace, leaving more than 800 dead from 8000 infections in 32\ncountries. Some 349 of the fatalities and 5327 of the infections were\nrecorded in China. Although China has formally declared victory over SARS\nand the last patients have been discharged from hospital, many in the world's\nmost populous country remain wary that the epidemic could bounce back. And\neven if the world has not seen the reemergence of SARS by New Year 2004, it\ndoes not mean the danger is entirely over, experts warned. \"We need to\nrecognize that if it doesn't return this year, that doesn't mean it will\nnever return,\" Field told the briefing.\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) said Thursday it would train thousands\nof medical workers in China, as fears linger that SARS could strike again\nthis year once cold weather sets in. The training program is meant to\nbetter equip health workers to prevent infectious diseases from spreading\nin hospitals, said Alan Schnur, a WHO communicable diseases expert. The\ntraining program will begin in Beijing, where 193 people died from the\nepidemic earlier in 2003, and will gradually be expanded to other parts of\nChina.\nAt the height of the SARS outbreak, many people in China were scared of\ngoing to hospitals because of fears -- in some cases well-founded -- that\nsub-standard facilities made them breeding-grounds for the virus.\nThe WHO could not conclusively rule out a SARS reappearance in late autumn\nas temperatures start plunging, and stressed steps should be taken to\nprevent any potential outbreak. \"Whether or not SARS returns, China must have\na strong surveillance network already in place,\" said Henk Bekedam, the WHO's\nChina representative.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 21 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/releases/2003/prchina2/en/>\n\nWHO Representative Office in China 21 Aug 2003\nJoint mission on SARS animal reservoir and necessary next steps\n--------------------------------------\nA joint team of specialists from the Chinese government, the World Health\nOrganization, and the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization\n(FAO), in China to investigate the animal reservoir of the SARS\ncoronavirus, has issued a series of recommendations and actions necessary\nnot only to identify the disease's animal reservoir, but to contain any\nfuture outbreaks.\n\"We did not set out this time to find the animal reservoir for SARS, but to\nmethodically piece together the jigsaw puzzle of this disease,\" says WHO's\nDr Pierre Formenty, a zoonotic disease specialist and joint leader of the\nmission. \"The fight against SARS is not over. Finding its origin will most\nlikely take years,\" says Dr Formenty, \"Right now, the need for information\nis of such urgency that even limited information will be helpful in taking\nthe right control measures. Because SARS is a global threat, international\ncollaboration is essential if we are to detect and rapidly contain any new\noutbreaks.\"\nAmong the measures recommended by the joint team of specialists include the\nstrengthening of regulations in the farming, trading, and consumption of\nwildlife. More serological monitoring of the SARS coronavirus are needed\nboth in animals and humans, as well as continued in-depth human studies of\nSARS index cases. Determining how SARS first breached the species barrier\nis crucial to controlling it.\nWhile it is still unknown whether SARS will return, WHO is continuing to\nwork closely with the Chinese government to design and implement a strategy\nusing hospitals as early detection centers of SARS. WHO is also\ncollaborating with the Chinese Ministry of Health to strengthen infection\ncontrol in health care settings. A series of training seminars on SARS\ninfection control procedures for health care workers is scheduled for\nSeptember 2003 in Beijing and Changsha.\nFollowing a meeting today with senior officials from the Ministry of\nScience and Technology, Ministry of Agriculture, Ministry of Health, and\nthe Ministry of Forestry, in which the Chinese government recognized the\nneed for increased research co-ordination, WHO is optimistic about future\nprospects for collaboration.\n\"Whether or not SARS returns, China must have a strong surveillance network\nalready in place,\" says Dr Henk Bekedam, WHO's China Representative. \"China\nhas a unique opportunity to contribute to the international understanding\nof this disease. Investing now in this safety net may be the key to\nsuccessfully combating SARS.\"\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (16): etiology 20030328.0774\nSARS - worldwide (19): etiology 20030330.0786\nSARS - worldwide (26): etiology 20030403.0819\nSARS - worldwide (31): etiology 20030405.0833\nSARS - worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - worldwide (48): etiology 20030414.0909\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0944\nSARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994\nSARS - worldwide (64): etiology 20030423.0996\nSARS - worldwide (68): etiology 20030425.1010\nSARS - worldwide (74): etiology 20030427.1039\nSARS - worldwide (82): etiology 20030429.1057\nSARS - worldwide (84): etiology 20030501.1086\nSARS - worldwide (91): etiology 20030504.1114\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (98): etiology 20030509.1151\nSARS - worldwide (101): etiology 20030510.1168\nSARS - worldwide (106): etiology 20030515.1210\nSARS - worldwide (109): etiology 20030517.1227\nSARS - worldwide (117): etiology 20030523.1267\nSARS worldwide (163): etiology 20030722.1790\nSARS worldwide (164): etiology 20030723.1800\n..................mpp/pgjw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. worldwide (168): etiology", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204502", "date": "2003-08-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (167): ETIOLOGY\n*********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 21 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: ProLog [edited]\n<http://www.ptd.net/webnews/wed/bm/Qhealth-sars-china.ROc8_DaL.html>\n\nA SARS-like virus has been found in a broad range of animals, stretching from\nsnakes and birds to mammals, a medical group said Thursday after returning\nfrom the epicenter of the virus in south China.\nThe 14 United Nations and Chinese experts visited farms and markets in\nGuangdong province in search of a possible animal carrier of the virus, and\nwere astounded to see how many different species were infected. \"What is\nsurprising is we got positive results from mammals, from birds and from\nreptiles,\" said Francois Moutou, a French expert on epidemic disease. \"This\nis very strange, because usually we don't find viruses ... affecting so many\n[different] animals,\" he told a briefing in Beijing.\nAfter a week-long trip to Guangdong, where the atypical pneumonia erupted\nlate in 2002, the search for an animal carrier remains a \"work in progress,\"\naccording to health officials.\nOne of the main findings by the expert group was the realization that finding\nthe origin and nature of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) may be a\nmuch more complex task than initially hoped.\n\"There may be many animals that are capable of being infected, but they\nmight not be capable of transmitting the virus to people,\" Hume E. Field,\nan expert from Australia's Animal Research Institute, told the briefing. The\nresearchers warned that detecting the source of the disease might take years,\nwhich means measures to curb further transmission must be undertaken before\nit is fully understood. \"Obviously we can't wait until we've got the whole\njigsaw together before action is taken,\" said Field. \"So really we have to\nlook at the best information we've got at the time in terms of risk and\nrespond according to that.\"\nCurbing further threats from SARS could result in restrictions on consumption\nof certain types of wildlife known to be infected, despite inconclusive data\non whether the species is capable of transmitting the sometimes-fatal illness\nto humans, he said.\nAfter SARS emerged in Guangdong province in 2002, it quickly spread to become\na global menace, leaving more than 800 dead from 8000 infections in 32\ncountries. Some 349 of the fatalities and 5327 of the infections were\nrecorded in China. Although China has formally declared victory over SARS\nand the last patients have been discharged from hospital, many in the world's\nmost populous country remain wary that the epidemic could bounce back. And\neven if the world has not seen the reemergence of SARS by New Year 2004, it\ndoes not mean the danger is entirely over, experts warned. \"We need to\nrecognize that if it doesn't return this year, that doesn't mean it will\nnever return,\" Field told the briefing.\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) said Thursday it would train thousands\nof medical workers in China, as fears linger that SARS could strike again\nthis year once cold weather sets in. The training program is meant to\nbetter equip health workers to prevent infectious diseases from spreading\nin hospitals, said Alan Schnur, a WHO communicable diseases expert. The\ntraining program will begin in Beijing, where 193 people died from the\nepidemic earlier in 2003, and will gradually be expanded to other parts of\nChina.\nAt the height of the SARS outbreak, many people in China were scared of\ngoing to hospitals because of fears -- in some cases well-founded -- that\nsub-standard facilities made them breeding-grounds for the virus.\nThe WHO could not conclusively rule out a SARS reappearance in late autumn\nas temperatures start plunging, and stressed steps should be taken to\nprevent any potential outbreak. \"Whether or not SARS returns, China must have\na strong surveillance network already in place,\" said Henk Bekedam, the WHO's\nChina representative.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 21 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/releases/2003/prchina2/en/>\n\nWHO Representative Office in China 21 Aug 2003\nJoint mission on SARS animal reservoir and necessary next steps\n--------------------------------------\nA joint team of specialists from the Chinese government, the World Health\nOrganization, and the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization\n(FAO), in China to investigate the animal reservoir of the SARS\ncoronavirus, has issued a series of recommendations and actions necessary\nnot only to identify the disease's animal reservoir, but to contain any\nfuture outbreaks.\n\"We did not set out this time to find the animal reservoir for SARS, but to\nmethodically piece together the jigsaw puzzle of this disease,\" says WHO's\nDr Pierre Formenty, a zoonotic disease specialist and joint leader of the\nmission. \"The fight against SARS is not over. Finding its origin will most\nlikely take years,\" says Dr Formenty, \"Right now, the need for information\nis of such urgency that even limited information will be helpful in taking\nthe right control measures. Because SARS is a global threat, international\ncollaboration is essential if we are to detect and rapidly contain any new\noutbreaks.\"\nAmong the measures recommended by the joint team of specialists include the\nstrengthening of regulations in the farming, trading, and consumption of\nwildlife. More serological monitoring of the SARS coronavirus are needed\nboth in animals and humans, as well as continued in-depth human studies of\nSARS index cases. Determining how SARS first breached the species barrier\nis crucial to controlling it.\nWhile it is still unknown whether SARS will return, WHO is continuing to\nwork closely with the Chinese government to design and implement a strategy\nusing hospitals as early detection centers of SARS. WHO is also\ncollaborating with the Chinese Ministry of Health to strengthen infection\ncontrol in health care settings. A series of training seminars on SARS\ninfection control procedures for health care workers is scheduled for\nSeptember 2003 in Beijing and Changsha.\nFollowing a meeting today with senior officials from the Ministry of\nScience and Technology, Ministry of Agriculture, Ministry of Health, and\nthe Ministry of Forestry, in which the Chinese government recognized the\nneed for increased research co-ordination, WHO is optimistic about future\nprospects for collaboration.\n\"Whether or not SARS returns, China must have a strong surveillance network\nalready in place,\" says Dr Henk Bekedam, WHO's China Representative. \"China\nhas a unique opportunity to contribute to the international understanding\nof this disease. Investing now in this safety net may be the key to\nsuccessfully combating SARS.\"\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (16): etiology 20030328.0774\nSARS - worldwide (19): etiology 20030330.0786\nSARS - worldwide (26): etiology 20030403.0819\nSARS - worldwide (31): etiology 20030405.0833\nSARS - worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - worldwide (48): etiology 20030414.0909\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0944\nSARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994\nSARS - worldwide (64): etiology 20030423.0996\nSARS - worldwide (68): etiology 20030425.1010\nSARS - worldwide (74): etiology 20030427.1039\nSARS - worldwide (82): etiology 20030429.1057\nSARS - worldwide (84): etiology 20030501.1086\nSARS - worldwide (91): etiology 20030504.1114\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (98): etiology 20030509.1151\nSARS - worldwide (101): etiology 20030510.1168\nSARS - worldwide (106): etiology 20030515.1210\nSARS - worldwide (109): etiology 20030517.1227\nSARS - worldwide (117): etiology 20030523.1267\nSARS worldwide (163): etiology 20030722.1790\nSARS worldwide (164): etiology 20030723.1800\n..................mpp/pgjw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2038-03-16 00:00:00", "2048-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2053-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "2064-03-16 00:00:00", "2068-03-16 00:00:00", "1974-03-16 00:00:00", "1991-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Changsha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204423", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS worldwide (167): etiology", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204423", "date": "2003-08-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (167): ETIOLOGY\n*********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 21 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: ProLog [edited]\n<http://www.ptd.net/webnews/wed/bm/Qhealth-sars-china.ROc8_DaL.html>\n\nA SARS-like virus has been found in a broad range of animals, stretching from\nsnakes and birds to mammals, a medical group said Thursday after returning\nfrom the epicenter of the virus in south China.\nThe 14 United Nations and Chinese experts visited farms and markets in\nGuangdong province in search of a possible animal carrier of the virus, and\nwere astounded to see how many different species were infected. \"What is\nsurprising is we got positive results from mammals, from birds and from\nreptiles,\" said Francois Moutou, a French expert on epidemic disease. \"This\nis very strange, because usually we don't find viruses ... affecting so many\n[different] animals,\" he told a briefing in Beijing.\nAfter a week-long trip to Guangdong, where the atypical pneumonia erupted\nlate in 2002, the search for an animal carrier remains a \"work in progress,\"\naccording to health officials.\nOne of the main findings by the expert group was the realization that finding\nthe origin and nature of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) may be a\nmuch more complex task than initially hoped.\n\"There may be many animals that are capable of being infected, but they\nmight not be capable of transmitting the virus to people,\" Hume E. Field,\nan expert from Australia's Animal Research Institute, told the briefing. The\nresearchers warned that detecting the source of the disease might take years,\nwhich means measures to curb further transmission must be undertaken before\nit is fully understood. \"Obviously we can't wait until we've got the whole\njigsaw together before action is taken,\" said Field. \"So really we have to\nlook at the best information we've got at the time in terms of risk and\nrespond according to that.\"\nCurbing further threats from SARS could result in restrictions on consumption\nof certain types of wildlife known to be infected, despite inconclusive data\non whether the species is capable of transmitting the sometimes-fatal illness\nto humans, he said.\nAfter SARS emerged in Guangdong province in 2002, it quickly spread to become\na global menace, leaving more than 800 dead from 8000 infections in 32\ncountries. Some 349 of the fatalities and 5327 of the infections were\nrecorded in China. Although China has formally declared victory over SARS\nand the last patients have been discharged from hospital, many in the world's\nmost populous country remain wary that the epidemic could bounce back. And\neven if the world has not seen the reemergence of SARS by New Year 2004, it\ndoes not mean the danger is entirely over, experts warned. \"We need to\nrecognize that if it doesn't return this year, that doesn't mean it will\nnever return,\" Field told the briefing.\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) said Thursday it would train thousands\nof medical workers in China, as fears linger that SARS could strike again\nthis year once cold weather sets in. The training program is meant to\nbetter equip health workers to prevent infectious diseases from spreading\nin hospitals, said Alan Schnur, a WHO communicable diseases expert. The\ntraining program will begin in Beijing, where 193 people died from the\nepidemic earlier in 2003, and will gradually be expanded to other parts of\nChina.\nAt the height of the SARS outbreak, many people in China were scared of\ngoing to hospitals because of fears -- in some cases well-founded -- that\nsub-standard facilities made them breeding-grounds for the virus.\nThe WHO could not conclusively rule out a SARS reappearance in late autumn\nas temperatures start plunging, and stressed steps should be taken to\nprevent any potential outbreak. \"Whether or not SARS returns, China must have\na strong surveillance network already in place,\" said Henk Bekedam, the WHO's\nChina representative.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 21 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/releases/2003/prchina2/en/>\n\nWHO Representative Office in China 21 Aug 2003\nJoint mission on SARS animal reservoir and necessary next steps\n--------------------------------------\nA joint team of specialists from the Chinese government, the World Health\nOrganization, and the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization\n(FAO), in China to investigate the animal reservoir of the SARS\ncoronavirus, has issued a series of recommendations and actions necessary\nnot only to identify the disease's animal reservoir, but to contain any\nfuture outbreaks.\n\"We did not set out this time to find the animal reservoir for SARS, but to\nmethodically piece together the jigsaw puzzle of this disease,\" says WHO's\nDr Pierre Formenty, a zoonotic disease specialist and joint leader of the\nmission. \"The fight against SARS is not over. Finding its origin will most\nlikely take years,\" says Dr Formenty, \"Right now, the need for information\nis of such urgency that even limited information will be helpful in taking\nthe right control measures. Because SARS is a global threat, international\ncollaboration is essential if we are to detect and rapidly contain any new\noutbreaks.\"\nAmong the measures recommended by the joint team of specialists include the\nstrengthening of regulations in the farming, trading, and consumption of\nwildlife. More serological monitoring of the SARS coronavirus are needed\nboth in animals and humans, as well as continued in-depth human studies of\nSARS index cases. Determining how SARS first breached the species barrier\nis crucial to controlling it.\nWhile it is still unknown whether SARS will return, WHO is continuing to\nwork closely with the Chinese government to design and implement a strategy\nusing hospitals as early detection centers of SARS. WHO is also\ncollaborating with the Chinese Ministry of Health to strengthen infection\ncontrol in health care settings. A series of training seminars on SARS\ninfection control procedures for health care workers is scheduled for\nSeptember 2003 in Beijing and Changsha.\nFollowing a meeting today with senior officials from the Ministry of\nScience and Technology, Ministry of Agriculture, Ministry of Health, and\nthe Ministry of Forestry, in which the Chinese government recognized the\nneed for increased research co-ordination, WHO is optimistic about future\nprospects for collaboration.\n\"Whether or not SARS returns, China must have a strong surveillance network\nalready in place,\" says Dr Henk Bekedam, WHO's China Representative. \"China\nhas a unique opportunity to contribute to the international understanding\nof this disease. Investing now in this safety net may be the key to\nsuccessfully combating SARS.\"\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (16): etiology 20030328.0774\nSARS - worldwide (19): etiology 20030330.0786\nSARS - worldwide (26): etiology 20030403.0819\nSARS - worldwide (31): etiology 20030405.0833\nSARS - worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - worldwide (48): etiology 20030414.0909\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0944\nSARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994\nSARS - worldwide (64): etiology 20030423.0996\nSARS - worldwide (68): etiology 20030425.1010\nSARS - worldwide (74): etiology 20030427.1039\nSARS - worldwide (82): etiology 20030429.1057\nSARS - worldwide (84): etiology 20030501.1086\nSARS - worldwide (91): etiology 20030504.1114\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (98): etiology 20030509.1151\nSARS - worldwide (101): etiology 20030510.1168\nSARS - worldwide (106): etiology 20030515.1210\nSARS - worldwide (109): etiology 20030517.1227\nSARS - worldwide (117): etiology 20030523.1267\nSARS worldwide (163): etiology 20030722.1790\nSARS worldwide (164): etiology 20030723.1800\n..................mpp/pgjw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Cumulative Number of Reported Probable Cases of SARS\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/country/2003_06_30/en/>\nFrom: 1 Nov 2002 To: 30 June 2003, 16:00 GMT+2\nCountry: Cumulative no. case(s)/ no. new cases since last WHO update/ no.\ndeaths/ no. recovered/ date last probable case reported/ date for which\ncumulative no. cases is current\nAustralia: 5/ 0/ 0/ 5/ 12/May/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nBrazil: 3/ 0/ 0/ 2/ 9/Jun/2003/ 9/Jun/2003\nCanada: 252/ 1/ 37/ 192/ 27/Jun/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nChina: 5327/ 0/ 348/ 4927/ 25/Jun/2003/ 29/Jun/2003\nChina, Hong Kong SAR: 1755/ 0/ 298/ 1429/ 11/Jun/2003/\n30/Jun/2003\nChina, Macao SAR: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 21/May/2003/ 23/Jun/2003\nChina, Taiwan: 678/ 0/ 84/ 495/ 19/Jun/2003/ 30/Jun/2003\nColombia: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 5/May/2003/ 5/May/2003\nFinland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 7/May/2003/ 20/May/2003\nFrance: 7/ 0/ 0/ 6/ 9/May/2003/ 22/May/2003\nGermany: 10/ 0/ 0/ 9/ 4/Jun/2003/ 23/Jun/2003\nIndia: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 13/May/2003/ 14/May/2003\nIndonesia: 2/ 0/ 0/ 2/ 23/Apr/2003/ 19/Jun/2003\nItaly: 5/ 0/ 0/ 5/ 29/Apr/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nKuwait: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 9/Apr/2003/ 20/Apr/2003\nMalaysia: 5/ 0/ 2/ 3/ 20/May/2003/ 26/Jun/2003\nMongolia: 9/ 0/ 0/ 9/ 6/May/2003/ 2/Jun/2003\nNew Zealand: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 30/Apr/2003/ 25/Jun/2003\nPhilippines: 14/ 0/ 2/ 12/ 15/May/2003/ 30/Jun/2003\nRepublic of Ireland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 21/Mar/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nRepublic of Korea: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 14/May/2003/ 23/Jun/2003\nRomania: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 27/Mar/2003/ 22/Apr/2003\nRussian Federation: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ 31/May/2003/ 31/May/2003\nSingapore: 206/ 0/ 32/ 171/ 18/May/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nSouth Africa: 1/ 0/ 1/ 0/ 9/Apr/2003/ 3/May/2003\nSpain: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 2/Apr/2003/ 5/Jun/2003\nSweden: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 18/Apr/2003/ 13/May/2003\nSwitzerland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 17/Mar/2003/ 16/May/2003\nThailand: 9/ 0/ 2/ 7/ 7/Jun/2003/ 26/Jun/2003\nUnited Kingdom: 4/ 0/ 0/ 4/ 29/Apr/2003/ 30/Jun/2003\nUnited States: 73/ 0/ 0/ 63/ 23/Jun/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nViet Nam: 63/ 0/ 5/ 58/ 14/Apr/2003/ 7/Jun/2003\nTotal: 8447/ 1/ 811/ 7417\nNotes:\nAs of 27 Jun 2003 the cumulative number of cases [in Canada] includes one\npreviously unreported case with date of onset before 12 Jun 2003. The date\nof onset of the most recent probable SARS case in Canada was 12 Jun 2003,\nthe last date of isolation of a probable SARS case was also 12 Jun 2003.\nThe date of onset of the most recent probable SARS case in China was 3 Jun\n2003. The date of isolation of this case was 6 Jun 2003.\n[B] Update 91 SARS research: the effect of patents and patent applications\n30 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_30/en/>\nAs no new probable cases of SARS have been reported anywhere in the world\nsince 15 Jun 2003, WHO is moving from an emergency response to a\nresearch-based agenda aimed at protecting the world against any future\nresurgence of SARS.\nThe world must be considered vulnerable to a return of SARS pending better\nunderstanding of the origins of the virus and the circumstances that\nallowed it to jump from an animal host or environmental source to infect\nhumans. Without such an understanding, predictions of the future evolution\nof the outbreak including its end cannot be made with certainty.\nThe SARS coronavirus was detected within a month by a virtual network of\nlaboratories, working around the clock. The complete sequencing of the\nvirus genome followed almost immediately.\nThese breakthroughs have supported progress in the development of\ndiagnostic tests and greatly facilitated the investigation of unusual\noutbreaks, such as the Amoy Gardens housing cluster that affected more than\n320 persons in late March 2003. They also facilitated initial efforts to\nlink an animal species with the first human cases, which were detected in\nsouthern China in mid-November of last year [2002].\nFurther progress in the scientific understanding of SARS will depend on\ncontinued international collaboration. WHO is establishing an additional\nnetwork to expedite much-needed animal studies.\nWHO also intends to monitor the effects of patents and patent applications\non the speed with which SARS diagnostic tests, treatments, and vaccines are\ndeveloped and made available for use, and on the manner in which prices are\nset for these technologies.\nAt the moment, it is too early to know all the effects that the patenting\nof SARS-related discoveries will have. However, the filing of patent\napplications does not in itself erect any barriers to continued scientific\ncollaboration on SARS.\nThe defensive use of patents can be a legitimate part of a researcher's\nefforts to make a discovery, and related discoveries in the future, widely\navailable to other researchers, in the best collaborative tradition of\nbiomedical science.\nIn the longer term, the manner in which SARS patent rights are pursued\ncould have a profound effect on the willingness of researchers and public\nhealth officials to collaborate during future outbreaks of new infectious\ndiseases.\nWHO will therefore examine whether the terms of reference for such\ncollaborations need to be modified to ensure that the credit for any\nintellectual property developed is appropriately attributed, that revenues\nderived from licensing such property are devoted to suitable uses, and that\nlegitimate rewards for innovative efforts do not impose undue burdens on\nefforts to make tests, therapies, and preventive measures available to all.\nAs SARS has clearly demonstrated, the appearance of a new disease in a\nhighly mobile, interconnected, and interdependent world can have serious\nrepercussions outside the health sector and far beyond the areas worst hit\nby the outbreak. This sense of shared vulnerability is considered a strong\nmotivation for continued international collaboration.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>\n\nAs of 30 Jun 2003 there are no new reports of either suspected or probable\ncases in Canada. The cumulative number of probable and suspected cases\nreported by Health Canada has not changed from the last ProMED-mail posting.\nThe most recent date of onset of illness for a probable case is 12 Jun\n2003, and this person was quarantined on 4 Jun 2003. The most recent date\nof isolation for a probable case is 12 Jun 2003, and this person had onset\nof illness on 8 Jun 2003.\n******\n[3]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs [edited]\n[A] China from Ta Kong Pao (Hong Kong)\n<http://www.takungpao.com/news/2003-6-30/ZM-149805.htm>\nSubmitted and translated by Dan Silver <DSilver@intellibridge.com>\nThe status of SARS in the mainland, conveyed by the news office of the\nChinese Ministry of Health on the afternoon of 29 Jun 2003, showed that\nfrom 28 Jun 28 2003 at 10:00 AM to 29 Jun 2003 at 10:00 AM, mainland\nreports contained no new clinically-diagnosed cases of SARS and no\ndeaths. Guangdong Province reported one new suspected case of SARS and one\n[earlier?] case treated and discharged from the hospital.\nAt the moment, there are 33 cases of clinically-diagnosed SARS being\ntreated in hospitals in mainland China. Of these, 30 are in Beijing and 3\nin Guangdong.\n[B] Canada from BBC news <\nhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/go/em/fr/-/2/hi/americas/3031476.stm > submitted by H\n. Larry Penning <hlpenning@yahoo.com>.\nThere was a report of a death of a 51-year-old nurse today, the first death\nattributable to SARS in a health care worker in Canada.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Since the last SARS update, the cumulative total of cases has decreased by\n3 to 8447. In today's report there is the official report of the new\nprobable case in Canada (reported in a prior ProMED-mail posting). Other\nchanges since the last report include the exclusion of 3 cases in Taiwan,\nand the exclusion of one case in the United States. In addition, since the\nlast update there have been 2 new deaths reported in China. There was a\nnewswire report of the death of a health care worker in Canada. There are\nstill 15 patients listed in critical condition in Canada as of today, so\nfinal outcomes are not resolved in these cases.\n(<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>)\nNo new suspected cases have been reported in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Canada --\nthe only new suspected case is from China and is from a newswire report,\nbut not an official report. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - Worldwide (158): cases 20030627.1588\nSARS - worldwide (157): cases 20030626.1580\nSARS - worldwide (156): cases 20030625.1566\nSARS - worldwide (155): cases 20030624.1550\nSARS - worldwide (152): cases 20030619.1511\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (87): case definition and diagnostics 20030502.1103\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.......................mpp/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2002-11-01 00:00:00", "2003-06-30 00:00:00", "2003-06-27 00:00:00", "2003-06-12 00:00:00", "2003-06-12 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-06-06 00:00:00", "2003-06-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-06-04 00:00:00", "2003-06-29 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macao", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "indonesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204243", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (165): cases, China", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204243", "date": "2003-06-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (159): CASES\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn today's update:\n[1] Worldwide - WHO\n[2] Canada - Health Canada\n[3] News briefs\n\n*****\n[1]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>\n\nA. Cumulative Number of Reported Probable Cases of SARS\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/country/2003_06_30/en/>\nFrom: 1 Nov 2002 To: 30 June 2003, 16:00 GMT+2\nCountry: Cumulative no. case(s)/ no. new cases since last WHO update/ no.\ndeaths/ no. recovered/ date last probable case reported/ date for which\ncumulative no. cases is current\nAustralia: 5/ 0/ 0/ 5/ 12/May/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nBrazil: 3/ 0/ 0/ 2/ 9/Jun/2003/ 9/Jun/2003\nCanada: 252/ 1/ 37/ 192/ 27/Jun/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nChina: 5327/ 0/ 348/ 4927/ 25/Jun/2003/ 29/Jun/2003\nChina, Hong Kong SAR: 1755/ 0/ 298/ 1429/ 11/Jun/2003/\n30/Jun/2003\nChina, Macao SAR: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 21/May/2003/ 23/Jun/2003\nChina, Taiwan: 678/ 0/ 84/ 495/ 19/Jun/2003/ 30/Jun/2003\nColombia: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 5/May/2003/ 5/May/2003\nFinland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 7/May/2003/ 20/May/2003\nFrance: 7/ 0/ 0/ 6/ 9/May/2003/ 22/May/2003\nGermany: 10/ 0/ 0/ 9/ 4/Jun/2003/ 23/Jun/2003\nIndia: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 13/May/2003/ 14/May/2003\nIndonesia: 2/ 0/ 0/ 2/ 23/Apr/2003/ 19/Jun/2003\nItaly: 5/ 0/ 0/ 5/ 29/Apr/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nKuwait: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 9/Apr/2003/ 20/Apr/2003\nMalaysia: 5/ 0/ 2/ 3/ 20/May/2003/ 26/Jun/2003\nMongolia: 9/ 0/ 0/ 9/ 6/May/2003/ 2/Jun/2003\nNew Zealand: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 30/Apr/2003/ 25/Jun/2003\nPhilippines: 14/ 0/ 2/ 12/ 15/May/2003/ 30/Jun/2003\nRepublic of Ireland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 21/Mar/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nRepublic of Korea: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 14/May/2003/ 23/Jun/2003\nRomania: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 27/Mar/2003/ 22/Apr/2003\nRussian Federation: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ 31/May/2003/ 31/May/2003\nSingapore: 206/ 0/ 32/ 171/ 18/May/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nSouth Africa: 1/ 0/ 1/ 0/ 9/Apr/2003/ 3/May/2003\nSpain: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 2/Apr/2003/ 5/Jun/2003\nSweden: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 18/Apr/2003/ 13/May/2003\nSwitzerland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 17/Mar/2003/ 16/May/2003\nThailand: 9/ 0/ 2/ 7/ 7/Jun/2003/ 26/Jun/2003\nUnited Kingdom: 4/ 0/ 0/ 4/ 29/Apr/2003/ 30/Jun/2003\nUnited States: 73/ 0/ 0/ 63/ 23/Jun/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nViet Nam: 63/ 0/ 5/ 58/ 14/Apr/2003/ 7/Jun/2003\nTotal: 8447/ 1/ 811/ 7417\nNotes:\nAs of 27 Jun 2003 the cumulative number of cases [in Canada] includes one\npreviously unreported case with date of onset before 12 Jun 2003. The date\nof onset of the most recent probable SARS case in Canada was 12 Jun 2003,\nthe last date of isolation of a probable SARS case was also 12 Jun 2003.\nThe date of onset of the most recent probable SARS case in China was 3 Jun\n2003. The date of isolation of this case was 6 Jun 2003.\n[B] Update 91 SARS research: the effect of patents and patent applications\n30 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_30/en/>\nAs no new probable cases of SARS have been reported anywhere in the world\nsince 15 Jun 2003, WHO is moving from an emergency response to a\nresearch-based agenda aimed at protecting the world against any future\nresurgence of SARS.\nThe world must be considered vulnerable to a return of SARS pending better\nunderstanding of the origins of the virus and the circumstances that\nallowed it to jump from an animal host or environmental source to infect\nhumans. Without such an understanding, predictions of the future evolution\nof the outbreak including its end cannot be made with certainty.\nThe SARS coronavirus was detected within a month by a virtual network of\nlaboratories, working around the clock. The complete sequencing of the\nvirus genome followed almost immediately.\nThese breakthroughs have supported progress in the development of\ndiagnostic tests and greatly facilitated the investigation of unusual\noutbreaks, such as the Amoy Gardens housing cluster that affected more than\n320 persons in late March 2003. They also facilitated initial efforts to\nlink an animal species with the first human cases, which were detected in\nsouthern China in mid-November of last year [2002].\nFurther progress in the scientific understanding of SARS will depend on\ncontinued international collaboration. WHO is establishing an additional\nnetwork to expedite much-needed animal studies.\nWHO also intends to monitor the effects of patents and patent applications\non the speed with which SARS diagnostic tests, treatments, and vaccines are\ndeveloped and made available for use, and on the manner in which prices are\nset for these technologies.\nAt the moment, it is too early to know all the effects that the patenting\nof SARS-related discoveries will have. However, the filing of patent\napplications does not in itself erect any barriers to continued scientific\ncollaboration on SARS.\nThe defensive use of patents can be a legitimate part of a researcher's\nefforts to make a discovery, and related discoveries in the future, widely\navailable to other researchers, in the best collaborative tradition of\nbiomedical science.\nIn the longer term, the manner in which SARS patent rights are pursued\ncould have a profound effect on the willingness of researchers and public\nhealth officials to collaborate during future outbreaks of new infectious\ndiseases.\nWHO will therefore examine whether the terms of reference for such\ncollaborations need to be modified to ensure that the credit for any\nintellectual property developed is appropriately attributed, that revenues\nderived from licensing such property are devoted to suitable uses, and that\nlegitimate rewards for innovative efforts do not impose undue burdens on\nefforts to make tests, therapies, and preventive measures available to all.\nAs SARS has clearly demonstrated, the appearance of a new disease in a\nhighly mobile, interconnected, and interdependent world can have serious\nrepercussions outside the health sector and far beyond the areas worst hit\nby the outbreak. This sense of shared vulnerability is considered a strong\nmotivation for continued international collaboration.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>\n\nAs of 30 Jun 2003 there are no new reports of either suspected or probable\ncases in Canada. The cumulative number of probable and suspected cases\nreported by Health Canada has not changed from the last ProMED-mail posting.\nThe most recent date of onset of illness for a probable case is 12 Jun\n2003, and this person was quarantined on 4 Jun 2003. The most recent date\nof isolation for a probable case is 12 Jun 2003, and this person had onset\nof illness on 8 Jun 2003.\n******\n[3]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs [edited]\n[A] China from Ta Kong Pao (Hong Kong)\n<http://www.takungpao.com/news/2003-6-30/ZM-149805.htm>\nSubmitted and translated by Dan Silver <DSilver@intellibridge.com>\nThe status of SARS in the mainland, conveyed by the news office of the\nChinese Ministry of Health on the afternoon of 29 Jun 2003, showed that\nfrom 28 Jun 28 2003 at 10:00 AM to 29 Jun 2003 at 10:00 AM, mainland\nreports contained no new clinically-diagnosed cases of SARS and no\ndeaths. Guangdong Province reported one new suspected case of SARS and one\n[earlier?] case treated and discharged from the hospital.\nAt the moment, there are 33 cases of clinically-diagnosed SARS being\ntreated in hospitals in mainland China. Of these, 30 are in Beijing and 3\nin Guangdong.\n[B] Canada from BBC news <\nhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/go/em/fr/-/2/hi/americas/3031476.stm > submitted by H\n. Larry Penning <hlpenning@yahoo.com>.\nThere was a report of a death of a 51-year-old nurse today, the first death\nattributable to SARS in a health care worker in Canada.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Since the last SARS update, the cumulative total of cases has decreased by\n3 to 8447. In today's report there is the official report of the new\nprobable case in Canada (reported in a prior ProMED-mail posting). Other\nchanges since the last report include the exclusion of 3 cases in Taiwan,\nand the exclusion of one case in the United States. In addition, since the\nlast update there have been 2 new deaths reported in China. There was a\nnewswire report of the death of a health care worker in Canada. There are\nstill 15 patients listed in critical condition in Canada as of today, so\nfinal outcomes are not resolved in these cases.\n(<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>)\nNo new suspected cases have been reported in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Canada --\nthe only new suspected case is from China and is from a newswire report,\nbut not an official report. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - Worldwide (158): cases 20030627.1588\nSARS - worldwide (157): cases 20030626.1580\nSARS - worldwide (156): cases 20030625.1566\nSARS - worldwide (155): cases 20030624.1550\nSARS - worldwide (152): cases 20030619.1511\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (87): case definition and diagnostics 20030502.1103\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.......................mpp/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. 8447/ 1/ 811/ 7417\nNotes:\nAs of 27 Jun 2003 the cumulative number of cases [in Canada] includes one\npreviously unreported case with date of onset before 12 Jun 2003. The date of isolation of this case was 6 Jun 2003.\n[B] Update 91 SARS research: the effect of patents and patent applications\n30 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_30/en/>\nAs no new probable cases of SARS have been reported anywhere in the world\nsince 15 Jun 2003, WHO is moving from an emergency response to a\nresearch-based agenda aimed at protecting the world against any future\nresurgence of SARS.\nThe world must be considered vulnerable to a return of SARS pending better\nunderstanding of the origins of the virus and the circumstances that\nallowed it to jump from an animal host or environmental source to infect\nhumans. Without such an understanding, predictions of the future evolution\nof the outbreak including its end cannot be made with certainty.\nThe SARS coronavirus was detected within a month by a virtual network of\nlaboratories, working around the clock. The complete sequencing of the\nvirus genome followed almost immediately.\nThese breakthroughs have supported progress in the development of\ndiagnostic tests and greatly facilitated the investigation of unusual\noutbreaks, such as the Amoy Gardens housing cluster that affected more than\n320 persons in late March 2003. They also facilitated initial efforts to\nlink an animal species with the first human cases, which were detected in\nsouthern China in mid-November of last year [2002].\nFurther progress in the scientific understanding of SARS will depend on\ncontinued international collaboration. WHO is establishing an additional\nnetwork to expedite much-needed animal studies.\nWHO also intends to monitor the effects of patents and patent applications\non the speed with which SARS diagnostic tests, treatments, and vaccines are\ndeveloped and made available for use, and on the manner in which prices are\nset for these technologies.\nAt the moment, it is too early to know all the effects that the patenting\nof SARS-related discoveries will have. However, the filing of patent\napplications does not in itself erect any barriers to continued scientific\ncollaboration on SARS.\nThe defensive use of patents can be a legitimate part of a researcher's\nefforts to make a discovery, and related discoveries in the future, widely\navailable to other researchers, in the best collaborative tradition of\nbiomedical science.\nIn the longer term, the manner in which SARS patent rights are pursued\ncould have a profound effect on the willingness of researchers and public\nhealth officials to collaborate during future outbreaks of new infectious\ndiseases.\nWHO will therefore examine whether the terms of reference for such\ncollaborations need to be modified to ensure that the credit for any\nintellectual property developed is appropriately attributed, that revenues\nderived from licensing such property are devoted to suitable uses, and that\nlegitimate rewards for innovative efforts do not impose undue burdens on\nefforts to make tests, therapies, and preventive measures available to all.\nAs SARS has clearly demonstrated, the appearance of a new disease in a\nhighly mobile, interconnected, and interdependent world can have serious\nrepercussions outside the health sector and far beyond the areas worst hit\nby the outbreak. This sense of shared vulnerability is considered a strong\nmotivation for continued international collaboration.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>\n\nAs of 30 Jun 2003 there are no new reports of either suspected or probable\ncases in Canada. The cumulative number of probable and suspected cases\nreported by Health Canada has not changed from the last ProMED-mail posting.\nThe most recent date of onset of illness for a probable case is 12 Jun\n2003, and this person was quarantined on 4 Jun 2003. The most recent date\nof isolation for a probable case is 12 Jun 2003, and this person had onset\nof illness on 8 Jun 2003.\n******\n[3]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs [edited]\n[A] China from Ta Kong Pao (Hong Kong)\n<http://www.takungpao.com/news/2003-6-30/ZM-149805.htm>\nSubmitted and translated by Dan Silver <DSilver@intellibridge.com>\nThe status of SARS in the mainland, conveyed by the news office of the\nChinese Ministry of Health on the afternoon of 29 Jun 2003, showed that\nfrom 28 Jun 28 2003 at 10:00 AM to 29 Jun 2003 at 10:00 AM, mainland\nreports contained no new clinically-diagnosed cases of SARS and no\ndeaths. Guangdong Province reported one new suspected case of SARS and one\n[earlier?] case treated and discharged from the hospital.\nAt the moment, there are 33 cases of clinically-diagnosed SARS being\ntreated in hospitals in mainland China. Of these, 30 are in Beijing and 3\nin Guangdong.\n[B] Canada from BBC news <\nhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/go/em/fr/-/2/hi/americas/3031476.stm > submitted by H\n. Larry Penning <hlpenning@yahoo.com>.\nThere was a report of a death of a 51-year-old nurse today, the first death\nattributable to SARS in a health care worker in Canada.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Since the last SARS update, the cumulative total of cases has decreased by\n3 to 8447. In today's report there is the official report of the new\nprobable case in Canada (reported in a prior ProMED-mail posting). Other\nchanges since the last report include the exclusion of 3 cases in Taiwan,\nand the exclusion of one case in the United States. In addition, since the\nlast update there have been 2 new deaths reported in China. There was a\nnewswire report of the death of a health care worker in Canada. There are\nstill 15 patients listed in critical condition in Canada as of today, so\nfinal outcomes are not resolved in these cases.\n(<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>)\nNo new suspected cases have been reported in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Canada --\nthe only new suspected case is from China and is from a newswire report,\nbut not an official report. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - Worldwide (158): cases 20030627.1588\nSARS - worldwide (157): cases 20030626.1580\nSARS - worldwide (156): cases 20030625.1566\nSARS - worldwide (155): cases 20030624.1550\nSARS - worldwide (152): cases 20030619.1511\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (87): case definition and diagnostics 20030502.1103\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.......................mpp/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. 0/ 0/ 2/ 9/Jun/2003/ 9/Jun/2003\nCanada: 252/ 1/ 37/ 192/ 27/Jun/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nChina: 5327/ 0/ 348/ 4927/ 25/Jun/2003/ 29/Jun/2003\nChina, Hong Kong SAR: 1755/ 0/ 298/ 1429/ 11/Jun/2003/\n30/Jun/2003\nChina, Macao SAR: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 21/May/2003/ 23/Jun/2003\nChina, Taiwan: 678/ 0/ 84/ 495/ 19/Jun/2003/ 30/Jun/2003\nColombia: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 5/May/2003/ 5/May/2003\nFinland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 7/May/2003/ 20/May/2003\nFrance: 7/ 0/ 0/ 6/ 9/May/2003/ 22/May/2003\nGermany: 10/ 0/ 0/ 9/ 4/Jun/2003/ 23/Jun/2003\nIndia: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 13/May/2003/ 14/May/2003\nIndonesia: 2/ 0/ 0/ 2/ 23/Apr/2003/ 19/Jun/2003\nItaly: 5/ 0/ 0/ 5/ 29/Apr/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nKuwait: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 9/Apr/2003/ 20/Apr/2003\nMalaysia: 5/ 0/ 2/ 3/ 20/May/2003/ 26/Jun/2003\nMongolia: 9/ 0/ 0/ 9/ 6/May/2003/ 2/Jun/2003\nNew Zealand: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 30/Apr/2003/ 25/Jun/2003\nPhilippines: 14/ 0/ 2/ 12/ 15/May/2003/ 30/Jun/2003\nRepublic of Ireland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 21/Mar/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nRepublic of Korea: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 14/May/2003/ 23/Jun/2003\nRomania: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 27/Mar/2003/ 22/Apr/2003\nRussian Federation: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ 31/May/2003/ 31/May/2003\nSingapore: 206/ 0/ 32/ 171/ 18/May/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nSouth Africa: 1/ 0/ 1/ 0/ 9/Apr/2003/ 3/May/2003\nSpain: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 2/Apr/2003/ 5/Jun/2003\nSweden: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 18/Apr/2003/ 13/May/2003\nSwitzerland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 17/Mar/2003/ 16/May/2003\nThailand: 9/ 0/ 2/ 7/ 7/Jun/2003/ 26/Jun/2003\nUnited Kingdom: 4/ 0/ 0/ 4/ 29/Apr/2003/ 30/Jun/2003\nUnited States: 73/ 0/ 0/ 63/ 23/Jun/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nViet Nam: 63/ 0/ 5/ 58/ 14/Apr/2003/ 7/Jun/2003\nTotal: 8447/ 1/ 811/ 7417\nNotes:\nAs of 27 Jun 2003 the cumulative number of cases [in Canada] includes one\npreviously unreported case with date of onset before 12 Jun 2003. The date\nof onset of the most recent probable SARS case in Canada was 12 Jun 2003,\nthe last date of isolation of a probable SARS case was also 12 Jun 2003.\nThe date of onset of the most recent probable SARS case in China was 3 Jun\n2003. The date of isolation of this case was 6 Jun 2003.\n[B] Update 91 SARS research: the effect of patents and patent applications\n30 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_30/en/>\nAs no new probable cases of SARS have been reported anywhere in the world\nsince 15 Jun 2003, WHO is moving from an emergency response to a\nresearch-based agenda aimed at protecting the world against any future\nresurgence of SARS.\nThe world must be considered vulnerable to a return of SARS pending better\nunderstanding of the origins of the virus and the circumstances that\nallowed it to jump from an animal host or environmental source to infect\nhumans. Without such an understanding, predictions of the future evolution\nof the outbreak including its end cannot be made with certainty.\nThe SARS coronavirus was detected within a month by a virtual network of\nlaboratories, working around the clock. The complete sequencing of the\nvirus genome followed almost immediately.\nThese breakthroughs have supported progress in the development of\ndiagnostic tests and greatly facilitated the investigation of unusual\noutbreaks, such as the Amoy Gardens housing cluster that affected more than\n320 persons in late March 2003. They also facilitated initial efforts to\nlink an animal species with the first human cases, which were detected in\nsouthern China in mid-November of last year [2002].\nFurther progress in the scientific understanding of SARS will depend on\ncontinued international collaboration. WHO is establishing an additional\nnetwork to expedite much-needed animal studies.\nWHO also intends to monitor the effects of patents and patent applications\non the speed with which SARS diagnostic tests, treatments, and vaccines are\ndeveloped and made available for use, and on the manner in which prices are\nset for these technologies.\nAt the moment, it is too early to know all the effects that the patenting\nof SARS-related discoveries will have. However, the filing of patent\napplications does not in itself erect any barriers to continued scientific\ncollaboration on SARS.\nThe defensive use of patents can be a legitimate part of a researcher's\nefforts to make a discovery, and related discoveries in the future, widely\navailable to other researchers, in the best collaborative tradition of\nbiomedical science.\nIn the longer term, the manner in which SARS patent rights are pursued\ncould have a profound effect on the willingness of researchers and public\nhealth officials to collaborate during future outbreaks of new infectious\ndiseases.\nWHO will therefore examine whether the terms of reference for such\ncollaborations need to be modified to ensure that the credit for any\nintellectual property developed is appropriately attributed, that revenues\nderived from licensing such property are devoted to suitable uses, and that\nlegitimate rewards for innovative efforts do not impose undue burdens on\nefforts to make tests, therapies, and preventive measures available to all.\nAs SARS has clearly demonstrated, the appearance of a new disease in a\nhighly mobile, interconnected, and interdependent world can have serious\nrepercussions outside the health sector and far beyond the areas worst hit\nby the outbreak. This sense of shared vulnerability is considered a strong\nmotivation for continued international collaboration.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>\n\nAs of 30 Jun 2003 there are no new reports of either suspected or probable\ncases in Canada. The cumulative number of probable and suspected cases\nreported by Health Canada has not changed from the last ProMED-mail posting.\nThe most recent date of onset of illness for a probable case is 12 Jun\n2003, and this person was quarantined on 4 Jun 2003. The most recent date\nof isolation for a probable case is 12 Jun 2003, and this person had onset\nof illness on 8 Jun 2003.\n******\n[3]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs [edited]\n[A] China from Ta Kong Pao (Hong Kong)\n<http://www.takungpao.com/news/2003-6-30/ZM-149805.htm>\nSubmitted and translated by Dan Silver <DSilver@intellibridge.com>\nThe status of SARS in the mainland, conveyed by the news office of the\nChinese Ministry of Health on the afternoon of 29 Jun 2003, showed that\nfrom 28 Jun 28 2003 at 10:00 AM to 29 Jun 2003 at 10:00 AM, mainland\nreports contained no new clinically-diagnosed cases of SARS and no\ndeaths. Guangdong Province reported one new suspected case of SARS and one\n[earlier?] case treated and discharged from the hospital.\nAt the moment, there are 33 cases of clinically-diagnosed SARS being\ntreated in hospitals in mainland China. Of these, 30 are in Beijing and 3\nin Guangdong.\n[B] Canada from BBC news <\nhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/go/em/fr/-/2/hi/americas/3031476.stm > submitted by H\n. Larry Penning <hlpenning@yahoo.com>.\nThere was a report of a death of a 51-year-old nurse today, the first death\nattributable to SARS in a health care worker in Canada.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Since the last SARS update, the cumulative total of cases has decreased by\n3 to 8447. In today's report there is the official report of the new\nprobable case in Canada (reported in a prior ProMED-mail posting). Other\nchanges since the last report include the exclusion of 3 cases in Taiwan,\nand the exclusion of one case in the United States. In addition, since the\nlast update there have been 2 new deaths reported in China. There was a\nnewswire report of the death of a health care worker in Canada. There are\nstill 15 patients listed in critical condition in Canada as of today, so\nfinal outcomes are not resolved in these cases.\n(<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>)\nNo new suspected cases have been reported in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Canada --\nthe only new suspected case is from China and is from a newswire report,\nbut not an official report. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - Worldwide (158): cases 20030627.1588\nSARS - worldwide (157): cases 20030626.1580\nSARS - worldwide (156): cases 20030625.1566\nSARS - worldwide (155): cases 20030624.1550\nSARS - worldwide (152): cases 20030619.1511\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (87): case definition and diagnostics 20030502.1103\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.......................mpp/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
