8447/ 1/ 811/ 7417\nNotes:\nAs of 27 Jun 2003 the cumulative number of cases [in Canada] includes one\npreviously unreported case with date of onset before 12 Jun 2003. The date\nof onset of the most recent probable SARS case in Canada was 12 Jun 2003,\nthe last date of isolation of a probable SARS case was also 12 Jun 2003.\nThe date of onset of the most recent probable SARS case in China was 3 Jun\n2003. The date of isolation of this case was 6 Jun 2003.\n[B] Update 91 SARS research: the effect of patents and patent applications\n30 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_30/en/>\nAs no new probable cases of SARS have been reported anywhere in the world\nsince 15 Jun 2003, WHO is moving from an emergency response to a\nresearch-based agenda aimed at protecting the world against any future\nresurgence of SARS.\nThe world must be considered vulnerable to a return of SARS pending better\nunderstanding of the origins of the virus and the circumstances that\nallowed it to jump from an animal host or environmental source to infect\nhumans. Without such an understanding, predictions of the future evolution\nof the outbreak including its end cannot be made with certainty.\nThe SARS coronavirus was detected within a month by a virtual network of\nlaboratories, working around the clock. The complete sequencing of the\nvirus genome followed almost immediately.\nThese breakthroughs have supported progress in the development of\ndiagnostic tests and greatly facilitated the investigation of unusual\noutbreaks, such as the Amoy Gardens housing cluster that affected more than\n320 persons in late March 2003. They also facilitated initial efforts to\nlink an animal species with the first human cases, which were detected in\nsouthern China in mid-November of last year [2002].\nFurther progress in the scientific understanding of SARS will depend on\ncontinued international collaboration. WHO is establishing an additional\nnetwork to expedite much-needed animal studies.\nWHO also intends to monitor the effects of patents and patent applications\non the speed with which SARS diagnostic tests, treatments, and vaccines are\ndeveloped and made available for use, and on the manner in which prices are\nset for these technologies.\nAt the moment, it is too early to know all the effects that the patenting\nof SARS-related discoveries will have. However, the filing of patent\napplications does not in itself erect any barriers to continued scientific\ncollaboration on SARS.\nThe defensive use of patents can be a legitimate part of a researcher's\nefforts to make a discovery, and related discoveries in the future, widely\navailable to other researchers, in the best collaborative tradition of\nbiomedical science.\nIn the longer term, the manner in which SARS patent rights are pursued\ncould have a profound effect on the willingness of researchers and public\nhealth officials to collaborate during future outbreaks of new infectious\ndiseases.\nWHO will therefore examine whether the terms of reference for such\ncollaborations need to be modified to ensure that the credit for any\nintellectual property developed is appropriately attributed, that revenues\nderived from licensing such property are devoted to suitable uses, and that\nlegitimate rewards for innovative efforts do not impose undue burdens on\nefforts to make tests, therapies, and preventive measures available to all.\nAs SARS has clearly demonstrated, the appearance of a new disease in a\nhighly mobile, interconnected, and interdependent world can have serious\nrepercussions outside the health sector and far beyond the areas worst hit\nby the outbreak. This sense of shared vulnerability is considered a strong\nmotivation for continued international collaboration.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>\n\nAs of 30 Jun 2003 there are no new reports of either suspected or probable\ncases in Canada. The cumulative number of probable and suspected cases\nreported by Health Canada has not changed from the last ProMED-mail posting.\nThe most recent date of onset of illness for a probable case is 12 Jun\n2003, and this person was quarantined on 4 Jun 2003. The most recent date\nof isolation for a probable case is 12 Jun 2003, and this person had onset\nof illness on 8 Jun 2003.\n******\n[3]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs [edited]\n[A] China from Ta Kong Pao (Hong Kong)\n<http://www.takungpao.com/news/2003-6-30/ZM-149805.htm>\nSubmitted and translated by Dan Silver <DSilver@intellibridge.com>\nThe status of SARS in the mainland, conveyed by the news office of the\nChinese Ministry of Health on the afternoon of 29 Jun 2003, showed that\nfrom 28 Jun 28 2003 at 10:00 AM to 29 Jun 2003 at 10:00 AM, mainland\nreports contained no new clinically-diagnosed cases of SARS and no\ndeaths. Guangdong Province reported one new suspected case of SARS and one\n[earlier?] case treated and discharged from the hospital.\nAt the moment, there are 33 cases of clinically-diagnosed SARS being\ntreated in hospitals in mainland China. Of these, 30 are in Beijing and 3\nin Guangdong.\n[B] Canada from BBC news <\nhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/go/em/fr/-/2/hi/americas/3031476.stm > submitted by H\n. Larry Penning <hlpenning@yahoo.com>.\nThere was a report of a death of a 51-year-old nurse today, the first death\nattributable to SARS in a health care worker in Canada.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Since the last SARS update, the cumulative total of cases has decreased by\n3 to 8447. In today's report there is the official report of the new\nprobable case in Canada (reported in a prior ProMED-mail posting). Other\nchanges since the last report include the exclusion of 3 cases in Taiwan,\nand the exclusion of one case in the United States. In addition, since the\nlast update there have been 2 new deaths reported in China. There was a\nnewswire report of the death of a health care worker in Canada. There are\nstill 15 patients listed in critical condition in Canada as of today, so\nfinal outcomes are not resolved in these cases.\n(<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>)\nNo new suspected cases have been reported in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Canada --\nthe only new suspected case is from China and is from a newswire report,\nbut not an official report. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - Worldwide (158): cases 20030627.1588\nSARS - worldwide (157): cases 20030626.1580\nSARS - worldwide (156): cases 20030625.1566\nSARS - worldwide (155): cases 20030624.1550\nSARS - worldwide (152): cases 20030619.1511\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (87): case definition and diagnostics 20030502.1103\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.......................mpp/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. 23/Apr/2003/ 19/Jun/2003\nItaly: 5/ 0/ 0/ 5/ 29/Apr/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nKuwait: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 9/Apr/2003/ 20/Apr/2003\nMalaysia: 5/ 0/ 2/ 3/ 20/May/2003/ 26/Jun/2003\nMongolia: 9/ 0/ 0/ 9/ 6/May/2003/ 2/Jun/2003\nNew Zealand: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 30/Apr/2003/ 25/Jun/2003\nPhilippines: 14/ 0/ 2/ 12/ 15/May/2003/ 30/Jun/2003\nRepublic of Ireland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 21/Mar/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nRepublic of Korea: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 14/May/2003/ 23/Jun/2003\nRomania: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 27/Mar/2003/ 22/Apr/2003\nRussian Federation: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ 31/May/2003/ 31/May/2003\nSingapore: 206/ 0/ 32/ 171/ 18/May/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nSouth Africa: 1/ 0/ 1/ 0/ 9/Apr/2003/ 3/May/2003\nSpain: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 2/Apr/2003/ 5/Jun/2003\nSweden: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 18/Apr/2003/ 13/May/2003\nSwitzerland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 17/Mar/2003/ 16/May/2003\nThailand: 9/ 0/ 2/ 7/ 7/Jun/2003/ 26/Jun/2003\nUnited Kingdom: 4/ 0/ 0/ 4/ 29/Apr/2003/ 30/Jun/2003\nUnited States: 73/ 0/ 0/ 63/ 23/Jun/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nViet Nam: 63/ 0/ 5/ 58/ 14/Apr/2003/ 7/Jun/2003\nTotal: 8447/ 1/ 811/ 7417\nNotes:\nAs of 27 Jun 2003 the cumulative number of cases [in Canada] includes one\npreviously unreported case with date of onset before 12 Jun 2003. The date\nof onset of the most recent probable SARS case in Canada was 12 Jun 2003,\nthe last date of isolation of a probable SARS case was also 12 Jun 2003.\nThe date of onset of the most recent probable SARS case in China was 3 Jun\n2003. The date of isolation of this case was 6 Jun 2003.\n[B] Update 91 SARS research: the effect of patents and patent applications\n30 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_30/en/>\nAs no new probable cases of SARS have been reported anywhere in the world\nsince 15 Jun 2003, WHO is moving from an emergency response to a\nresearch-based agenda aimed at protecting the world against any future\nresurgence of SARS.\nThe world must be considered vulnerable to a return of SARS pending better\nunderstanding of the origins of the virus and the circumstances that\nallowed it to jump from an animal host or environmental source to infect\nhumans. Without such an understanding, predictions of the future evolution\nof the outbreak including its end cannot be made with certainty.\nThe SARS coronavirus was detected within a month by a virtual network of\nlaboratories, working around the clock. The complete sequencing of the\nvirus genome followed almost immediately.\nThese breakthroughs have supported progress in the development of\ndiagnostic tests and greatly facilitated the investigation of unusual\noutbreaks, such as the Amoy Gardens housing cluster that affected more than\n320 persons in late March 2003. They also facilitated initial efforts to\nlink an animal species with the first human cases, which were detected in\nsouthern China in mid-November of last year [2002].\nFurther progress in the scientific understanding of SARS will depend on\ncontinued international collaboration. WHO is establishing an additional\nnetwork to expedite much-needed animal studies.\nWHO also intends to monitor the effects of patents and patent applications\non the speed with which SARS diagnostic tests, treatments, and vaccines are\ndeveloped and made available for use, and on the manner in which prices are\nset for these technologies.\nAt the moment, it is too early to know all the effects that the patenting\nof SARS-related discoveries will have. However, the filing of patent\napplications does not in itself erect any barriers to continued scientific\ncollaboration on SARS.\nThe defensive use of patents can be a legitimate part of a researcher's\nefforts to make a discovery, and related discoveries in the future, widely\navailable to other researchers, in the best collaborative tradition of\nbiomedical science.\nIn the longer term, the manner in which SARS patent rights are pursued\ncould have a profound effect on the willingness of researchers and public\nhealth officials to collaborate during future outbreaks of new infectious\ndiseases.\nWHO will therefore examine whether the terms of reference for such\ncollaborations need to be modified to ensure that the credit for any\nintellectual property developed is appropriately attributed, that revenues\nderived from licensing such property are devoted to suitable uses, and that\nlegitimate rewards for innovative efforts do not impose undue burdens on\nefforts to make tests, therapies, and preventive measures available to all.\nAs SARS has clearly demonstrated, the appearance of a new disease in a\nhighly mobile, interconnected, and interdependent world can have serious\nrepercussions outside the health sector and far beyond the areas worst hit\nby the outbreak. This sense of shared vulnerability is considered a strong\nmotivation for continued international collaboration.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>\n\nAs of 30 Jun 2003 there are no new reports of either suspected or probable\ncases in Canada. The cumulative number of probable and suspected cases\nreported by Health Canada has not changed from the last ProMED-mail posting.\nThe most recent date of onset of illness for a probable case is 12 Jun\n2003, and this person was quarantined on 4 Jun 2003. The most recent date\nof isolation for a probable case is 12 Jun 2003, and this person had onset\nof illness on 8 Jun 2003.\n******\n[3]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs [edited]\n[A] China from Ta Kong Pao (Hong Kong)\n<http://www.takungpao.com/news/2003-6-30/ZM-149805.htm>\nSubmitted and translated by Dan Silver <DSilver@intellibridge.com>\nThe status of SARS in the mainland, conveyed by the news office of the\nChinese Ministry of Health on the afternoon of 29 Jun 2003, showed that\nfrom 28 Jun 28 2003 at 10:00 AM to 29 Jun 2003 at 10:00 AM, mainland\nreports contained no new clinically-diagnosed cases of SARS and no\ndeaths. Guangdong Province reported one new suspected case of SARS and one\n[earlier?] case treated and discharged from the hospital.\nAt the moment, there are 33 cases of clinically-diagnosed SARS being\ntreated in hospitals in mainland China. Of these, 30 are in Beijing and 3\nin Guangdong.\n[B] Canada from BBC news <\nhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/go/em/fr/-/2/hi/americas/3031476.stm > submitted by H\n. Larry Penning <hlpenning@yahoo.com>.\nThere was a report of a death of a 51-year-old nurse today, the first death\nattributable to SARS in a health care worker in Canada.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Since the last SARS update, the cumulative total of cases has decreased by\n3 to 8447. In today's report there is the official report of the new\nprobable case in Canada (reported in a prior ProMED-mail posting). Other\nchanges since the last report include the exclusion of 3 cases in Taiwan,\nand the exclusion of one case in the United States. In addition, since the\nlast update there have been 2 new deaths reported in China. There was a\nnewswire report of the death of a health care worker in Canada. There are\nstill 15 patients listed in critical condition in Canada as of today, so\nfinal outcomes are not resolved in these cases.\n(<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>)\nNo new suspected cases have been reported in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Canada --\nthe only new suspected case is from China and is from a newswire report,\nbut not an official report. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - Worldwide (158): cases 20030627.1588\nSARS - worldwide (157): cases 20030626.1580\nSARS - worldwide (156): cases 20030625.1566\nSARS - worldwide (155): cases 20030624.1550\nSARS - worldwide (152): cases 20030619.1511\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (87): case definition and diagnostics 20030502.1103\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.......................mpp/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. 8447/ 1/ 811/ 7417\nNotes:\nAs of 27 Jun 2003 the cumulative number of cases [in Canada] includes one\npreviously unreported case with date of onset before 12 Jun 2003. The date\nof onset of the most recent probable SARS case in Canada was 12 Jun 2003,\nthe last date of isolation of a probable SARS case was also 12 Jun 2003.\nThe date of onset of the most recent probable SARS case in China was 3 Jun\n2003. The date of isolation of this case was 6 Jun 2003.\n[B] Update 91 SARS research: the effect of patents and patent applications\n30 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_30/en/>\nAs no new probable cases of SARS have been reported anywhere in the world\nsince 15 Jun 2003, WHO is moving from an emergency response to a\nresearch-based agenda aimed at protecting the world against any future\nresurgence of SARS.\nThe world must be considered vulnerable to a return of SARS pending better\nunderstanding of the origins of the virus and the circumstances that\nallowed it to jump from an animal host or environmental source to infect\nhumans. Without such an understanding, predictions of the future evolution\nof the outbreak including its end cannot be made with certainty.\nThe SARS coronavirus was detected within a month by a virtual network of\nlaboratories, working around the clock. The complete sequencing of the\nvirus genome followed almost immediately.\nThese breakthroughs have supported progress in the development of\ndiagnostic tests and greatly facilitated the investigation of unusual\noutbreaks, such as the Amoy Gardens housing cluster that affected more than\n320 persons in late March 2003. They also facilitated initial efforts to\nlink an animal species with the first human cases, which were detected in\nsouthern China in mid-November of last year [2002].\nFurther progress in the scientific understanding of SARS will depend on\ncontinued international collaboration. WHO is establishing an additional\nnetwork to expedite much-needed animal studies.\nWHO also intends to monitor the effects of patents and patent applications\non the speed with which SARS diagnostic tests, treatments, and vaccines are\ndeveloped and made available for use, and on the manner in which prices are\nset for these technologies.\nAt the moment, it is too early to know all the effects that the patenting\nof SARS-related discoveries will have. However, the filing of patent\napplications does not in itself erect any barriers to continued scientific\ncollaboration on SARS.\nThe defensive use of patents can be a legitimate part of a researcher's\nefforts to make a discovery, and related discoveries in the future, widely\navailable to other researchers, in the best collaborative tradition of\nbiomedical science.\nIn the longer term, the manner in which SARS patent rights are pursued\ncould have a profound effect on the willingness of researchers and public\nhealth officials to collaborate during future outbreaks of new infectious\ndiseases.\nWHO will therefore examine whether the terms of reference for such\ncollaborations need to be modified to ensure that the credit for any\nintellectual property developed is appropriately attributed, that revenues\nderived from licensing such property are devoted to suitable uses, and that\nlegitimate rewards for innovative efforts do not impose undue burdens on\nefforts to make tests, therapies, and preventive measures available to all.\nAs SARS has clearly demonstrated, the appearance of a new disease in a\nhighly mobile, interconnected, and interdependent world can have serious\nrepercussions outside the health sector and far beyond the areas worst hit\nby the outbreak. This sense of shared vulnerability is considered a strong\nmotivation for continued international collaboration.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>\n\nAs of 30 Jun 2003 there are no new reports of either suspected or probable\ncases in Canada. The cumulative number of probable and suspected cases\nreported by Health Canada has not changed from the last ProMED-mail posting.\nThe most recent date of onset of illness for a probable case is 12 Jun\n2003, and this person was quarantined on 4 Jun 2003. The most recent date\nof isolation for a probable case is 12 Jun 2003, and this person had onset\nof illness on 8 Jun 2003.\n******\n[3]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs [edited]\n[A] China from Ta Kong Pao (Hong Kong)\n<http://www.takungpao.com/news/2003-6-30/ZM-149805.htm>\nSubmitted and translated by Dan Silver <DSilver@intellibridge.com>\nThe status of SARS in the mainland, conveyed by the news office of the\nChinese Ministry of Health on the afternoon of 29 Jun 2003, showed that\nfrom 28 Jun 28 2003 at 10:00 AM to 29 Jun 2003 at 10:00 AM, mainland\nreports contained no new clinically-diagnosed cases of SARS and no\ndeaths. Guangdong Province reported one new suspected case of SARS and one\n[earlier?] case treated and discharged from the hospital.\nAt the moment, there are 33 cases of clinically-diagnosed SARS being\ntreated in hospitals in mainland China. Of these, 30 are in Beijing and 3\nin Guangdong.\n[B] Canada from BBC news <\nhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/go/em/fr/-/2/hi/americas/3031476.stm > submitted by H\n. Larry Penning <hlpenning@yahoo.com>.\nThere was a report of a death of a 51-year-old nurse today, the first death\nattributable to SARS in a health care worker in Canada.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Since the last SARS update, the cumulative total of cases has decreased by\n3 to 8447. Other\nchanges since the last report include the exclusion of 3 cases in Taiwan,\nand the exclusion of one case in the United States. In addition, since the\nlast update there have been 2 new deaths reported in China. There was a\nnewswire report of the death of a health care worker in Canada. 2/ 7/ 7/Jun/2003/ 26/Jun/2003\nUnited Kingdom: 4/ 0/ 0/ 4/ 29/Apr/2003/ 30/Jun/2003\nUnited States: 73/ 0/ 0/ 63/ 23/Jun/2003/ 27/Jun/2003\nViet Nam: 63/ 0/ 5/ 58/ 14/Apr/2003/ 7/Jun/2003\nTotal: 8447/ 1/ 811/ 7417\nNotes:\nAs of 27 Jun 2003 the cumulative number of cases [in Canada] includes one\npreviously unreported case with date of onset before 12 Jun 2003. The date\nof onset of the most recent probable SARS case in Canada was 12 Jun 2003,\nthe last date of isolation of a probable SARS case was also 12 Jun 2003.\nThe date of onset of the most recent probable SARS case in China was 3 Jun\n2003. The date of isolation of this case was 6 Jun 2003.\n[B] Update 91 SARS research: the effect of patents and patent applications\n30 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_30/en/>\nAs no new probable cases of SARS have been reported anywhere in the world\nsince 15 Jun 2003, WHO is moving from an emergency response to a\nresearch-based agenda aimed at protecting the world against any future\nresurgence of SARS.\nThe world must be considered vulnerable to a return of SARS pending better\nunderstanding of the origins of the virus and the circumstances that\nallowed it to jump from an animal host or environmental source to infect\nhumans. Without such an understanding, predictions of the future evolution\nof the outbreak including its end cannot be made with certainty.\nThe SARS coronavirus was detected within a month by a virtual network of\nlaboratories, working around the clock. The complete sequencing of the\nvirus genome followed almost immediately.\nThese breakthroughs have supported progress in the development of\ndiagnostic tests and greatly facilitated the investigation of unusual\noutbreaks, such as the Amoy Gardens housing cluster that affected more than\n320 persons in late March 2003. They also facilitated initial efforts to\nlink an animal species with the first human cases, which were detected in\nsouthern China in mid-November of last year [2002].\nFurther progress in the scientific understanding of SARS will depend on\ncontinued international collaboration. WHO is establishing an additional\nnetwork to expedite much-needed animal studies.\nWHO also intends to monitor the effects of patents and patent applications\non the speed with which SARS diagnostic tests, treatments, and vaccines are\ndeveloped and made available for use, and on the manner in which prices are\nset for these technologies.\nAt the moment, it is too early to know all the effects that the patenting\nof SARS-related discoveries will have. However, the filing of patent\napplications does not in itself erect any barriers to continued scientific\ncollaboration on SARS.\nThe defensive use of patents can be a legitimate part of a researcher's\nefforts to make a discovery, and related discoveries in the future, widely\navailable to other researchers, in the best collaborative tradition of\nbiomedical science.\nIn the longer term, the manner in which SARS patent rights are pursued\ncould have a profound effect on the willingness of researchers and public\nhealth officials to collaborate during future outbreaks of new infectious\ndiseases.\nWHO will therefore examine whether the terms of reference for such\ncollaborations need to be modified to ensure that the credit for any\nintellectual property developed is appropriately attributed, that revenues\nderived from licensing such property are devoted to suitable uses, and that\nlegitimate rewards for innovative efforts do not impose undue burdens on\nefforts to make tests, therapies, and preventive measures available to all.\nAs SARS has clearly demonstrated, the appearance of a new disease in a\nhighly mobile, interconnected, and interdependent world can have serious\nrepercussions outside the health sector and far beyond the areas worst hit\nby the outbreak. This sense of shared vulnerability is considered a strong\nmotivation for continued international collaboration.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>\n\nAs of 30 Jun 2003 there are no new reports of either suspected or probable\ncases in Canada. The cumulative number of probable and suspected cases\nreported by Health Canada has not changed from the last ProMED-mail posting.\nThe most recent date of onset of illness for a probable case is 12 Jun\n2003, and this person was quarantined on 4 Jun 2003. The most recent date\nof isolation for a probable case is 12 Jun 2003, and this person had onset\nof illness on 8 Jun 2003.\n******\n[3]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs [edited]\n[A] China from Ta Kong Pao (Hong Kong)\n<http://www.takungpao.com/news/2003-6-30/ZM-149805.htm>\nSubmitted and translated by Dan Silver <DSilver@intellibridge.com>\nThe status of SARS in the mainland, conveyed by the news office of the\nChinese Ministry of Health on the afternoon of 29 Jun 2003, showed that\nfrom 28 Jun 28 2003 at 10:00 AM to 29 Jun 2003 at 10:00 AM, mainland\nreports contained no new clinically-diagnosed cases of SARS and no\ndeaths. Guangdong Province reported one new suspected case of SARS and one\n[earlier?] case treated and discharged from the hospital.\nAt the moment, there are 33 cases of clinically-diagnosed SARS being\ntreated in hospitals in mainland China. Of these, 30 are in Beijing and 3\nin Guangdong.\n[B] Canada from BBC news <\nhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/go/em/fr/-/2/hi/americas/3031476.stm > submitted by H\n. Larry Penning <hlpenning@yahoo.com>.\nThere was a report of a death of a 51-year-old nurse today, the first death\nattributable to SARS in a health care worker in Canada.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Since the last SARS update, the cumulative total of cases has decreased by\n3 to 8447. In today's report there is the official report of the new\nprobable case in Canada (reported in a prior ProMED-mail posting). Other\nchanges since the last report include the exclusion of 3 cases in Taiwan,\nand the exclusion of one case in the United States. In addition, since the\nlast update there have been 2 new deaths reported in China. There was a\nnewswire report of the death of a health care worker in Canada. There are\nstill 15 patients listed in critical condition in Canada as of today, so\nfinal outcomes are not resolved in these cases.\n(<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>)\nNo new suspected cases have been reported in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Canada --\nthe only new suspected case is from China and is from a newswire report,\nbut not an official report. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - Worldwide (158): cases 20030627.1588\nSARS - worldwide (157): cases 20030626.1580\nSARS - worldwide (156): cases 20030625.1566\nSARS - worldwide (155): cases 20030624.1550\nSARS - worldwide (152): cases 20030619.1511\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (87): case definition and diagnostics 20030502.1103\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.......................mpp/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2002-11-01 00:00:00", "2003-06-30 00:00:00", "2003-06-27 00:00:00", "2003-06-12 00:00:00", "2003-06-12 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-06-06 00:00:00", "2003-06-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-06-04 00:00:00", "2003-06-29 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macao", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "indonesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204056", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - Worldwide (158): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204056", "date": "2003-06-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS, CONCERNED CITIZENS IMPRISONED - CHINA\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 18 June 2300\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New Zealand Herald 16 June 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.nzherald.co.nz/storydisplay.cfm?storyID=3507534&msg=emaillink>\n\nBy early February 2003, the people of Guangdong province had begun to panic\n[over a] mysterious virus the world would come to know as SARS, but [whose]\nexistence had not even been acknowledged by the Chinese government or by\nthe media. Yet by 10 Feb 2003 news of a \"fatal flu in Guangdong\" had\nreached 120 million people through text messaging, say some reports, and an\nuntold extra number through email and internet chatrooms. Chinese\nauthorities had little choice but to acknowledge the outbreak and try to\nrestore calm. The government had been taught a painful lesson about\ncontrolling the news in a burgeoning high-tech society.\nBy mid-February 2003, officials began complaining about the use of text\nmessaging to spread \"rumours\", deeming them subversive activity and a\nthreat to stability. Then they began arresting people. By the end of May\n2003, 117 people in 17 provinces had been arrested and charged with\ndisturbing social order by spreading SARS-related rumours, the Xinhua news\nagency reported. But [it was not stated] how those rumours were spread.\nWith its control slipping, the government's response [to the situation] has\nbeen to combine cutting-edge technology with repression. Its technology\nallows it, for example, to search the country's entire volume of email\ntraffic for words such as \"Falungong\", or to monitor any individual's text\nmessages. Anyone snared in its high-tech web can expect surveillance,\nintimidation, arrest, and prison. The publicity surrounding the arrests and\nprison sentences helps the government achieve what experts say is its\nstrategy of creating a climate of fear in which the people begin censoring\nthemselves.\n\"The cyberpolice, which have tens of thousands of members, are capable of\narresting internet users anywhere in the country if they send a few\nmessages considered 'subversive' or likely to 'jeopardise the state's\nsecurity',\" wrote the watchdog group Reporters Without Borders in a report\nreleased last month. One topic subject to nearly blanket censorship in\nearly April 2003 was SARS. On 10 Apr 2003, a researcher posted a message on\na sina.com.cn forum containing the word SARS and just calling on the\nChinese government to work closely with Hong Kong to arrest the epidemic.\nThe message did not appear. A second message about SARS was submitted to\nthe site 5 days later. It met the same fate.\n\"The authorities seem to have asked the websites to add the term SARS to\nthe long list of banned words. So no criticism of the government's handling\nof the SARS crisis can be seen on the most popular sites.\"\n[byline: Henry Hoenig, in Beijing]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail supports the free exchange of information relating to\noutbreaks of infectious diseases and protests in the strongest possible\nterms the imprisonment of citizens of any country for reporting such\ninformation to the world. ProMED-mail policy is NOT to criticize any\ngovernment UNLESS it arrests and imprisons people for the above reason. Dr\nDessy Mendoza of Cuba was imprisoned in 1997 for talking to foreign news\nmedia about the epidemic of dengue in Santiago de Cuba. ProMED-mail\nprotested publicly (see references below), and our posts were picked up by\nAmnesty International and Physicians for Human Rights, who intervened on\nhis behalf. The Pope's visit to Cuba eventually got him out after 2 years,\nwith his health broken.\nIt is now evident that China's suppression of news about SARS in south\nChina helped fuel a global epidemic that could have been controlled more\nquickly, with fewer fatalities and much less economic damage, if news of\nthat outbreak had been reported rapidly and fully to the world. This\nprinciple, that rapid dissemination of accurate information on emerging\ndiseases and outbreaks will lead to better public health, is the basis of\nProMED-mail's existence.\nProMED calls on the Chinese government to immediately and unconditionally\nrelease any people imprisoned for trying to get the news on SARS out. - Mod.LM]\nSee Also\n1998\n---\nOfficial secrets and public health (02) 19980625.1180\nOfficial secrets and public health 19980622.1162\n1997\n---\nDengue/DHF - Cuba: doctor sentenced 19971125.2360\n......................jw/lm/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["dengue", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2300-06-18 00:00:00", "2003-06-16 00:00:00", "2003-02-10 00:00:00", "2003-04-10 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cuba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Falungong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand Herald", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santiago de Cuba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204050", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (157): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204050", "date": "2003-06-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS, CONCERNED CITIZENS IMPRISONED - CHINA\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 18 June 2300\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New Zealand Herald 16 June 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.nzherald.co.nz/storydisplay.cfm?storyID=3507534&msg=emaillink>\n\nBy early February 2003, the people of Guangdong province had begun to panic\n[over a] mysterious virus the world would come to know as SARS, but [whose]\nexistence had not even been acknowledged by the Chinese government or by\nthe media. Yet by 10 Feb 2003 news of a \"fatal flu in Guangdong\" had\nreached 120 million people through text messaging, say some reports, and an\nuntold extra number through email and internet chatrooms. Chinese\nauthorities had little choice but to acknowledge the outbreak and try to\nrestore calm. The government had been taught a painful lesson about\ncontrolling the news in a burgeoning high-tech society.\nBy mid-February 2003, officials began complaining about the use of text\nmessaging to spread \"rumours\", deeming them subversive activity and a\nthreat to stability. Then they began arresting people. By the end of May\n2003, 117 people in 17 provinces had been arrested and charged with\ndisturbing social order by spreading SARS-related rumours, the Xinhua news\nagency reported. But [it was not stated] how those rumours were spread.\nWith its control slipping, the government's response [to the situation] has\nbeen to combine cutting-edge technology with repression. Its technology\nallows it, for example, to search the country's entire volume of email\ntraffic for words such as \"Falungong\", or to monitor any individual's text\nmessages. Anyone snared in its high-tech web can expect surveillance,\nintimidation, arrest, and prison. The publicity surrounding the arrests and\nprison sentences helps the government achieve what experts say is its\nstrategy of creating a climate of fear in which the people begin censoring\nthemselves.\n\"The cyberpolice, which have tens of thousands of members, are capable of\narresting internet users anywhere in the country if they send a few\nmessages considered 'subversive' or likely to 'jeopardise the state's\nsecurity',\" wrote the watchdog group Reporters Without Borders in a report\nreleased last month. One topic subject to nearly blanket censorship in\nearly April 2003 was SARS. On 10 Apr 2003, a researcher posted a message on\na sina.com.cn forum containing the word SARS and just calling on the\nChinese government to work closely with Hong Kong to arrest the epidemic.\nThe message did not appear. A second message about SARS was submitted to\nthe site 5 days later. It met the same fate.\n\"The authorities seem to have asked the websites to add the term SARS to\nthe long list of banned words. So no criticism of the government's handling\nof the SARS crisis can be seen on the most popular sites.\"\n[byline: Henry Hoenig, in Beijing]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail supports the free exchange of information relating to\noutbreaks of infectious diseases and protests in the strongest possible\nterms the imprisonment of citizens of any country for reporting such\ninformation to the world. ProMED-mail policy is NOT to criticize any\ngovernment UNLESS it arrests and imprisons people for the above reason. Dr\nDessy Mendoza of Cuba was imprisoned in 1997 for talking to foreign news\nmedia about the epidemic of dengue in Santiago de Cuba. ProMED-mail\nprotested publicly (see references below), and our posts were picked up by\nAmnesty International and Physicians for Human Rights, who intervened on\nhis behalf. The Pope's visit to Cuba eventually got him out after 2 years,\nwith his health broken.\nIt is now evident that China's suppression of news about SARS in south\nChina helped fuel a global epidemic that could have been controlled more\nquickly, with fewer fatalities and much less economic damage, if news of\nthat outbreak had been reported rapidly and fully to the world. This\nprinciple, that rapid dissemination of accurate information on emerging\ndiseases and outbreaks will lead to better public health, is the basis of\nProMED-mail's existence.\nProMED calls on the Chinese government to immediately and unconditionally\nrelease any people imprisoned for trying to get the news on SARS out. - Mod.LM]\nSee Also\n1998\n---\nOfficial secrets and public health (02) 19980625.1180\nOfficial secrets and public health 19980622.1162\n1997\n---\nDengue/DHF - Cuba: doctor sentenced 19971125.2360\n......................jw/lm/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Yet by 10 Feb 2003 news of a \"fatal flu in Guangdong\" had\nreached 120 million people through text messaging, say some reports, and an\nuntold extra number through email and internet chatrooms. Chinese\nauthorities had little choice but to acknowledge the outbreak and try to\nrestore calm. The government had been taught a painful lesson about\ncontrolling the news in a burgeoning high-tech society.\nBy mid-February 2003, officials began complaining about the use of text\nmessaging to spread \"rumours\", deeming them subversive activity and a\nthreat to stability. Then they began arresting people. By the end of May\n2003, 117 people in 17 provinces had been arrested and charged with\ndisturbing social order by spreading SARS-related rumours, the Xinhua news\nagency reported. But [it was not stated] how those rumours were spread.\nWith its control slipping, the government's response [to the situation] has\nbeen to combine cutting-edge technology with repression. Its technology\nallows it, for example, to search the country's entire volume of email\ntraffic for words such as \"Falungong\", or to monitor any individual's text\nmessages. Anyone snared in its high-tech web can expect surveillance,\nintimidation, arrest, and prison. The publicity surrounding the arrests and\nprison sentences helps the government achieve what experts say is its\nstrategy of creating a climate of fear in which the people begin censoring\nthemselves.\n\"The cyberpolice, which have tens of thousands of members, are capable of\narresting internet users anywhere in the country if they send a few\nmessages considered 'subversive' or likely to 'jeopardise the state's\nsecurity',\" wrote the watchdog group Reporters Without Borders in a report\nreleased last month. One topic subject to nearly blanket censorship in\nearly April 2003 was SARS. On 10 Apr 2003, a researcher posted a message on\na sina.com.cn forum containing the word SARS and just calling on the\nChinese government to work closely with Hong Kong to arrest the epidemic.\nThe message did not appear. A second message about SARS was submitted to\nthe site 5 days later. It met the same fate.\n\"The authorities seem to have asked the websites to add the term SARS to\nthe long list of banned words. So no criticism of the government's handling\nof the SARS crisis can be seen on the most popular sites.\"\n[byline: Henry Hoenig, in Beijing]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail supports the free exchange of information relating to\noutbreaks of infectious diseases and protests in the strongest possible\nterms the imprisonment of citizens of any country for reporting such\ninformation to the world. ProMED-mail policy is NOT to criticize any\ngovernment UNLESS it arrests and imprisons people for the above reason. Dr\nDessy Mendoza of Cuba was imprisoned in 1997 for talking to foreign news\nmedia about the epidemic of dengue in Santiago de Cuba. ProMED-mail\nprotested publicly (see references below), and our posts were picked up by\nAmnesty International and Physicians for Human Rights, who intervened on\nhis behalf. The Pope's visit to Cuba eventually got him out after 2 years,\nwith his health broken.\nIt is now evident that China's suppression of news about SARS in south\nChina helped fuel a global epidemic that could have been controlled more\nquickly, with fewer fatalities and much less economic damage, if news of\nthat outbreak had been reported rapidly and fully to the world. This\nprinciple, that rapid dissemination of accurate information on emerging\ndiseases and outbreaks will lead to better public health, is the basis of\nProMED-mail's existence.\nProMED calls on the Chinese government to immediately and unconditionally\nrelease any people imprisoned for trying to get the news on SARS out. - Mod.LM]\nSee Also\n1998\n---\nOfficial secrets and public health (02) 19980625.1180\nOfficial secrets and public health 19980622.1162\n1997\n---\nDengue/DHF - Cuba: doctor sentenced 19971125.2360\n......................jw/lm/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["dengue", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2300-06-18 00:00:00", "2003-06-16 00:00:00", "2003-02-10 00:00:00", "2003-04-10 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cuba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Falungong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand Herald", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santiago de Cuba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204025", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (155): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204025", "date": "2003-06-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS, CONCERNED CITIZENS IMPRISONED - CHINA\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 18 June 2300\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New Zealand Herald 16 June 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.nzherald.co.nz/storydisplay.cfm?storyID=3507534&msg=emaillink>\n\nBy early February 2003, the people of Guangdong province had begun to panic\n[over a] mysterious virus the world would come to know as SARS, but [whose]\nexistence had not even been acknowledged by the Chinese government or by\nthe media. Yet by 10 Feb 2003 news of a \"fatal flu in Guangdong\" had\nreached 120 million people through text messaging, say some reports, and an\nuntold extra number through email and internet chatrooms. Chinese\nauthorities had little choice but to acknowledge the outbreak and try to\nrestore calm. The government had been taught a painful lesson about\ncontrolling the news in a burgeoning high-tech society.\nBy mid-February 2003, officials began complaining about the use of text\nmessaging to spread \"rumours\", deeming them subversive activity and a\nthreat to stability. Then they began arresting people. By the end of May\n2003, 117 people in 17 provinces had been arrested and charged with\ndisturbing social order by spreading SARS-related rumours, the Xinhua news\nagency reported. But [it was not stated] how those rumours were spread.\nWith its control slipping, the government's response [to the situation] has\nbeen to combine cutting-edge technology with repression. Its technology\nallows it, for example, to search the country's entire volume of email\ntraffic for words such as \"Falungong\", or to monitor any individual's text\nmessages. Anyone snared in its high-tech web can expect surveillance,\nintimidation, arrest, and prison. The publicity surrounding the arrests and\nprison sentences helps the government achieve what experts say is its\nstrategy of creating a climate of fear in which the people begin censoring\nthemselves.\n\"The cyberpolice, which have tens of thousands of members, are capable of\narresting internet users anywhere in the country if they send a few\nmessages considered 'subversive' or likely to 'jeopardise the state's\nsecurity',\" wrote the watchdog group Reporters Without Borders in a report\nreleased last month. One topic subject to nearly blanket censorship in\nearly April 2003 was SARS. On 10 Apr 2003, a researcher posted a message on\na sina.com.cn forum containing the word SARS and just calling on the\nChinese government to work closely with Hong Kong to arrest the epidemic.\nThe message did not appear. A second message about SARS was submitted to\nthe site 5 days later. It met the same fate.\n\"The authorities seem to have asked the websites to add the term SARS to\nthe long list of banned words. So no criticism of the government's handling\nof the SARS crisis can be seen on the most popular sites.\"\n[byline: Henry Hoenig, in Beijing]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail supports the free exchange of information relating to\noutbreaks of infectious diseases and protests in the strongest possible\nterms the imprisonment of citizens of any country for reporting such\ninformation to the world. ProMED-mail policy is NOT to criticize any\ngovernment UNLESS it arrests and imprisons people for the above reason. Dr\nDessy Mendoza of Cuba was imprisoned in 1997 for talking to foreign news\nmedia about the epidemic of dengue in Santiago de Cuba. ProMED-mail\nprotested publicly (see references below), and our posts were picked up by\nAmnesty International and Physicians for Human Rights, who intervened on\nhis behalf. The Pope's visit to Cuba eventually got him out after 2 years,\nwith his health broken.\nIt is now evident that China's suppression of news about SARS in south\nChina helped fuel a global epidemic that could have been controlled more\nquickly, with fewer fatalities and much less economic damage, if news of\nthat outbreak had been reported rapidly and fully to the world. This\nprinciple, that rapid dissemination of accurate information on emerging\ndiseases and outbreaks will lead to better public health, is the basis of\nProMED-mail's existence.\nProMED calls on the Chinese government to immediately and unconditionally\nrelease any people imprisoned for trying to get the news on SARS out. - Mod.LM]\nSee Also\n1998\n---\nOfficial secrets and public health (02) 19980625.1180\nOfficial secrets and public health 19980622.1162\n1997\n---\nDengue/DHF - Cuba: doctor sentenced 19971125.2360\n......................jw/lm/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["dengue", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2300-06-18 00:00:00", "2003-06-16 00:00:00", "2003-02-10 00:00:00", "2003-04-10 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cuba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Falungong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand Herald", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santiago de Cuba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204010", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (154): cases, case definition", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204010", "date": "2003-06-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS, CONCERNED CITIZENS IMPRISONED - CHINA\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 18 June 2300\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New Zealand Herald 16 June 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.nzherald.co.nz/storydisplay.cfm?storyID=3507534&msg=emaillink>\n\nBy early February 2003, the people of Guangdong province had begun to panic\n[over a] mysterious virus the world would come to know as SARS, but [whose]\nexistence had not even been acknowledged by the Chinese government or by\nthe media. Yet by 10 Feb 2003 news of a \"fatal flu in Guangdong\" had\nreached 120 million people through text messaging, say some reports, and an\nuntold extra number through email and internet chatrooms. Chinese\nauthorities had little choice but to acknowledge the outbreak and try to\nrestore calm. The government had been taught a painful lesson about\ncontrolling the news in a burgeoning high-tech society.\nBy mid-February 2003, officials began complaining about the use of text\nmessaging to spread \"rumours\", deeming them subversive activity and a\nthreat to stability. Then they began arresting people. By the end of May\n2003, 117 people in 17 provinces had been arrested and charged with\ndisturbing social order by spreading SARS-related rumours, the Xinhua news\nagency reported. But [it was not stated] how those rumours were spread.\nWith its control slipping, the government's response [to the situation] has\nbeen to combine cutting-edge technology with repression. Its technology\nallows it, for example, to search the country's entire volume of email\ntraffic for words such as \"Falungong\", or to monitor any individual's text\nmessages. Anyone snared in its high-tech web can expect surveillance,\nintimidation, arrest, and prison. The publicity surrounding the arrests and\nprison sentences helps the government achieve what experts say is its\nstrategy of creating a climate of fear in which the people begin censoring\nthemselves.\n\"The cyberpolice, which have tens of thousands of members, are capable of\narresting internet users anywhere in the country if they send a few\nmessages considered 'subversive' or likely to 'jeopardise the state's\nsecurity',\" wrote the watchdog group Reporters Without Borders in a report\nreleased last month. One topic subject to nearly blanket censorship in\nearly April 2003 was SARS. On 10 Apr 2003, a researcher posted a message on\na sina.com.cn forum containing the word SARS and just calling on the\nChinese government to work closely with Hong Kong to arrest the epidemic.\nThe message did not appear. A second message about SARS was submitted to\nthe site 5 days later. It met the same fate.\n\"The authorities seem to have asked the websites to add the term SARS to\nthe long list of banned words. So no criticism of the government's handling\nof the SARS crisis can be seen on the most popular sites.\"\n[byline: Henry Hoenig, in Beijing]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail supports the free exchange of information relating to\noutbreaks of infectious diseases and protests in the strongest possible\nterms the imprisonment of citizens of any country for reporting such\ninformation to the world. ProMED-mail policy is NOT to criticize any\ngovernment UNLESS it arrests and imprisons people for the above reason. Dr\nDessy Mendoza of Cuba was imprisoned in 1997 for talking to foreign news\nmedia about the epidemic of dengue in Santiago de Cuba. ProMED-mail\nprotested publicly (see references below), and our posts were picked up by\nAmnesty International and Physicians for Human Rights, who intervened on\nhis behalf. The Pope's visit to Cuba eventually got him out after 2 years,\nwith his health broken.\nIt is now evident that China's suppression of news about SARS in south\nChina helped fuel a global epidemic that could have been controlled more\nquickly, with fewer fatalities and much less economic damage, if news of\nthat outbreak had been reported rapidly and fully to the world. This\nprinciple, that rapid dissemination of accurate information on emerging\ndiseases and outbreaks will lead to better public health, is the basis of\nProMED-mail's existence.\nProMED calls on the Chinese government to immediately and unconditionally\nrelease any people imprisoned for trying to get the news on SARS out. - Mod.LM]\nSee Also\n1998\n---\nOfficial secrets and public health (02) 19980625.1180\nOfficial secrets and public health 19980622.1162\n1997\n---\nDengue/DHF - Cuba: doctor sentenced 19971125.2360\n......................jw/lm/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Yet by 10 Feb 2003 news of a \"fatal flu in Guangdong\" had\nreached 120 million people through text messaging, say some reports, and an\nuntold extra number through email and internet chatrooms. Chinese\nauthorities had little choice but to acknowledge the outbreak and try to\nrestore calm. The government had been taught a painful lesson about\ncontrolling the news in a burgeoning high-tech society.\nBy mid-February 2003, officials began complaining about the use of text\nmessaging to spread \"rumours\", deeming them subversive activity and a\nthreat to stability. Then they began arresting people. By the end of May\n2003, 117 people in 17 provinces had been arrested and charged with\ndisturbing social order by spreading SARS-related rumours, the Xinhua news\nagency reported. But [it was not stated] how those rumours were spread.\nWith its control slipping, the government's response [to the situation] has\nbeen to combine cutting-edge technology with repression. Its technology\nallows it, for example, to search the country's entire volume of email\ntraffic for words such as \"Falungong\", or to monitor any individual's text\nmessages. Anyone snared in its high-tech web can expect surveillance,\nintimidation, arrest, and prison. The publicity surrounding the arrests and\nprison sentences helps the government achieve what experts say is its\nstrategy of creating a climate of fear in which the people begin censoring\nthemselves.\n\"The cyberpolice, which have tens of thousands of members, are capable of\narresting internet users anywhere in the country if they send a few\nmessages considered 'subversive' or likely to 'jeopardise the state's\nsecurity',\" wrote the watchdog group Reporters Without Borders in a report\nreleased last month. One topic subject to nearly blanket censorship in\nearly April 2003 was SARS. On 10 Apr 2003, a researcher posted a message on\na sina.com.cn forum containing the word SARS and just calling on the\nChinese government to work closely with Hong Kong to arrest the epidemic.\nThe message did not appear. A second message about SARS was submitted to\nthe site 5 days later. It met the same fate.\n\"The authorities seem to have asked the websites to add the term SARS to\nthe long list of banned words. So no criticism of the government's handling\nof the SARS crisis can be seen on the most popular sites.\"\n[byline: Henry Hoenig, in Beijing]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail supports the free exchange of information relating to\noutbreaks of infectious diseases and protests in the strongest possible\nterms the imprisonment of citizens of any country for reporting such\ninformation to the world. ProMED-mail policy is NOT to criticize any\ngovernment UNLESS it arrests and imprisons people for the above reason. Dr\nDessy Mendoza of Cuba was imprisoned in 1997 for talking to foreign news\nmedia about the epidemic of dengue in Santiago de Cuba. ProMED-mail\nprotested publicly (see references below), and our posts were picked up by\nAmnesty International and Physicians for Human Rights, who intervened on\nhis behalf. The Pope's visit to Cuba eventually got him out after 2 years,\nwith his health broken.\nIt is now evident that China's suppression of news about SARS in south\nChina helped fuel a global epidemic that could have been controlled more\nquickly, with fewer fatalities and much less economic damage, if news of\nthat outbreak had been reported rapidly and fully to the world. This\nprinciple, that rapid dissemination of accurate information on emerging\ndiseases and outbreaks will lead to better public health, is the basis of\nProMED-mail's existence.\nProMED calls on the Chinese government to immediately and unconditionally\nrelease any people imprisoned for trying to get the news on SARS out. - Mod.LM]\nSee Also\n1998\n---\nOfficial secrets and public health (02) 19980625.1180\nOfficial secrets and public health 19980622.1162\n1997\n---\nDengue/DHF - Cuba: doctor sentenced 19971125.2360\n......................jw/lm/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
