This means that previously reported cases may be\ndiscarded after further investigation and follow-up.\n\n(1) These 2 new probable cases, with onsets of illness 25 and 27 Feb 2003,\nwere identified retrospectively in the United Kingdom. They both most\nlikely acquired their infection in Hong Kong SAR and became ill and\nrecovered while in the Philippines.\n\n[B] Areas with recent local transmission and travel recommendations can be\naccessed at: <http://www.who.int/csr/sars/areas/2003_06_12/en/> and\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/travel/travel2003_06_12/en/> and is unchanged\nsince the last update.\n\n[C] Update 79 \u0096 Situation in China 12 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_12/en/>\n\nChina\u0092s Executive Vice Minister of Health, Mr Gao Qiang, and Dr David\nHeymann, WHO\u0092s Executive Director for Communicable Diseases, briefed the\npress this morning on the situation of SARS control in China. Also in\nattendance were Dr Qi Ziaoqiu, Director-General of the Department of\nDisease Control in the Chinese Ministry of Health, and Dr Henk Bekedam, WHO\nRepresentative to China.\n\nThe briefing marked the first joint news conference between high-ranking\nChinese and WHO officials since the SARS outbreak began. The briefing\nfollowed a day of intensive meetings during which WHO officials reviewed\ndata and statistics from selected provinces, voiced their concerns, and\nreceived frank and detailed answers.\n\nDr Heymann praised the openness with which the WHO team was welcomed by the\nMinistry of Health, and described the measures now in place to control and\nprevent SARS as \u0093excellent\u0094. He cited the high level of commitment and\ndetermination at all levels of the health system as largely responsible for\nthe dramatic recent decline in the number of cases seen throughout mainland\nChina.\n\nOne purpose of the visit was to determine how China had succeeded in\nbringing down the number of cases so rapidly, and to encourage officials to\nshare their experiences with the rest of the world. Indications of the\neffectiveness of control measures, cited by Dr Heymann, include the very\nshort time now occurring between the onset of symptoms and the detection\nand isolation of cases, and the speed and efficiency of contact tracing.\nSuch measures are important as they limit the amount of time that an\ninfected person is capable of spreading the virus to others and thus bring\ncontrol efforts closer to the stage when the chain of person-to-person\ntransmission can be broken.\n\nOther effective measures include systems for both passive and active\nsurveillance, such as fever checks at train and bus stations and airports,\na nationwide mass media campaign to inform and educate the public, and a\nvery large number of fever clinics to assess those who suspect they may\nhave symptoms. \u0093We\u0092ve seen that there has been a massive effort to\nmobilize the population both in urban and rural areas across the country,\nencouraging people to monitor themselves for fever and to ensure that SARS\ncases are quickly identified, isolated and treated.\u0094\n\nSpecific concerns expressed by the WHO team include the lack of a\nsustainable surveillance system that can be relied on to detect the first\nhints of a resurgence of cases, some delays in meeting WHO requests for\nfurther information, and wide variations in application of the national\ncase definitions, which can lead to under-reporting of cases. Some problems\nrelated to prompt sharing and analysis of data are considered to arise from\ninstitutional and administrative problems, particularly concerning the\ninformation flow from provinces to the central level.\n\nAnother major concern is the large number of cases that have no known\nsource of exposure, thus making it extremely difficult to trace patterns of\ntransmission. In Beijing, the number of cases with no known contact with a\nSARS patient has recently increased from 50 percent to more than 70 percent.\n\nIn the interest of protecting against a further resurgence of cases, WHO\nofficials singled out strengthening of surveillance capacity as the top\npriority. Experience to date has shown that a single case, especially if\nhighly infectious, can rapidly ignite an explosive outbreak.\n\n\u0093With SARS seemingly on the decline for now, there is a great need to\nstrengthen the SARS control and surveillance system in China,\u0094 said Dr\nBekedam. \u0093The system now in place grew out of an emergency response and has\nto be strengthened for the long run.\u0094 He expressed doubt that the present\nsystem would be strong enough \u0093to hold back the tide\u0094 when confronted with\na resurgence of the disease.\n\nIn his assessment of the long-term SARS situation in China, Dr Heymann also\nstressed the need for systematic studies of the origins of SARS. \u0093We still\ndon\u0092t know exactly where SARS came from, or how it was transferred to the\nhuman population. We don\u0092t know if this disease is seasonal and will\ndecrease this year but come back next year.\u0094 Until proper research into\nthe origins of SARS has been conducted, it will be impossible to predict\nwhen the conditions that first allowed the virus to jump to humans from a\nsuspected animal reservoir might be repeated in the near or distant future.\n\nWHO initial assessments of the SARS situation in China, issued in late\nApril [2003] following a visit to Guangdong Province, expressed serious\nconcern over the lack of urgency in reporting cases of SARS in China, and\ncriticized the government for not immediately treating the outbreak as a\npublic health emergency requiring extraordinary measures for its\ncontrol. Dr Heymann and other members of the WHO team are now satisfied\nthat these measures are in place, at least for the immediate response to\nSARS. Recent visits to selected provinces, jointly conducted by the Chinese\nMinistry of Health and WHO, found a high level of public awareness of SARS,\nits symptoms and mode of transmission, and the need for twice-daily fever\nchecks.\n\nChina is regarded as the epicentre of the SARS outbreak. The country was\nhome to the first cases, detected in mid-November of last year [2002], and\npresently accounts for almost two thirds of all reported cases worldwide.\nThe WHO visit was arranged to secure reassurance that control measures in\nthis vast country are adequate to continue the downward trends in cases\nand, equally important, to ensure that a sustainable system is in place to\ndetect and contain a resurgence of cases. WHO is also anxious to ensure\nthat the considerable knowledge and experience acquired in managing the\nlargest SARS outbreak on record is shared for the benefit of all countries.\n\nThe SARS outbreak has revealed substantial weaknesses in the disease\nsurveillance system in China. When investment in health infrastructure is\nneglected, conditions are ripe for the unchecked spread of any\nepidemic-prone disease, often at tremendous cost to a nation\u0092s economy. In\nthe view of WHO, the surveillance system in China needs to be made more\nflexible and capable of a much more rapid and consistent response to any\nnew infectious disease threat.\n\nDuring the visit, Chinese officials expressed deep concern about the\ncountry\u0092s capacity to deal with the next influenza season against a\nbackground of possible SARS cases. The presence of influenza could greatly\ncomplicate the detection and accurate diagnosis of SARS cases, while also\nincreasing the caseload of suspect cases considerably.\n\nThe containment of SARS remains the overriding objective of WHO. If SARS is\nnot contained, the world will face a situation in which every case of\natypical pneumonia, and every hospital-based cluster of febrile patients\nwith respiratory systems will have the potential to rouse suspicions of\nSARS and spark widespread panic.\n\nIn an earlier report, a WHO assessment team reached the following\nconclusion: \u0093If SARS is not brought under control in China, there will be\nno chance of controlling the global threat of SARS. Achieving control of\nSARS is a major challenge especially in a country as large and diverse as\nChina. Effective disease control and reporting are the cornerstone of any\nstrategy to do this.\u0094\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC Taiwan [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov.tw/sarsen/>\n\nNo. new probable cases reported: 2\nCumulative no. cases: 688\n(cumulative no. cases in last update: 687)\nExplanation: 1 previously reported prob. case excluded by reporting MD.\n\nCumulative no. SARS probable cases, by geographic area: 12 Jun 2003 9 AM\n\nArea: Cumulative no. cases/ no. new probable cases reported/ no.\ndischarged/ total no. deaths\n\nNorth: 531/ 1/ 118/ 56\nCentral: 38/ 0/ 0/ 3\nSouth: 113/ 1/ 55/ 21 (1 previously reported prob. case excluded by\nreporting MD)\nEast: 6/ 0/ 0/ 1\n\nTotal: 688/ 2/ 173/ 81 (1 previously reported prob. case excluded by\nreporting MD)\n\nAs mentioned in earlier updates, there are graphics at the above website\nlink. According to the pie chart representation of reported cases, there\nare an additional 1455 suspected cases reported, and 759 formerly reported\ncases (suspected and probable) have been excluded. Reviewing the epidemic\ncurve on today's update page, the most recent noted date of onset is 9 Jun\n2003.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website/ Beijing Government SARS website\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/china2003_06_12.pdf>\n<http://www.beijing.gov.cn/english/englishsars/beijingen/detail.asp?ResourceID=63257>\n\n** Noteworthy, no new probable cases were reported in the past 24 hours\n\nAs of 12 Jun 2003 a cumulative total of 5328 probable cases with\n343 deaths have been reported. In the past 24 hours, one previously\nreported probable case in Inner Mongolia who died was discarded as due to\nSARS. There were no new probable cases reported. One new suspected case\nwas reported from one of the provinces not identified on the daily table,\nsuggesting it occurred in one of the provinces not having reported a\nprobable case in more than 20 days. At present there are a total of 220\nsuspected cases still pending in China.\n\nShanghai, Hubei, Guangxi, Guangdong, Tianjin, Jilin, Gansu, Jiangsu, Anhui,\nShaanxi, Zhejiang, Henan, Chongqing, Jiangxi, Ningxia, Shandong, Fujian,\nHunan, Heilongjiang and Xinjiang have not reported any new probable cases\nin more than 20 days.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong Department of Health\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/2003/03-06-12e.htm>\n\n** Noteworthy - no new probable cases reported in the past 24 hours **\n\nSituation report on Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome 12 Jun 2003\n\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\n\nThere is no new confirmed case of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)\ntoday (12 Jun 2003). This is the 4th time that Hong Kong recorded zero\ninfection (the last 3 times were on 24 May 2003, 8 and 8 Jun 2003). It is\nalso the 28th consecutive day on which the number of cases has fallen below\n5 since 16 May 2003.\n\nThe number of patients recovered and discharged from hospital is 1377. Of\nthem, 3 were discharged today. The number of SARS patients in intensive\ncare unit is 17. These cases are part of the 58 cases under treatment in\nhospitals. 29 are recovering patients in convalescence and in preparation\nfor discharge. No fatality was reported. The cumulative total of deaths\nrelating to SARS remains at 291.\n\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with SARS since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\n\nCumulative no. cases/ total no. discharged patients/ total no. deaths\n(change in past 24 hours presented in parentheses, minus used for decrease)\n\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 386 (0)/ 362\n(1)/ (n/a)\nPatients, family members & visitors: 1369 (0)/ 1015 (2) / (n/a)\n\nTotal: 1755 (0)/ 1377 (3)/ 291 (0)\n\nTotal no. in hospital: 87 (-3)\nRecovering patients in convalescence: 29\nCases under treatment: 58 (-2) (including 17 patients in Intensive Care\nUnit)\n\nSuspected cases: 1\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n\nHealth Canada\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update79.html>\n\n\"Active\" cases include those hospitalized, currently ill at home, or under\ninvestigation.\n\nActive SARS cases in Canada\n---------------------\nDate: May 30/ Jun 2/ Jun 3/ Jun 4/ Jun 5/ Jun 6/ Jun 9/ Jun 10/ Jun 11/ Jun 12\n\nProbable (Active) 43/ 62/ 64/ 67/ 68/ 70/ 66/ 64/ 65/ 60\nSuspect (Active) 15/ 12/ 15/ 14/ 15/ 11/ 9/ 9/ 7/ 4\n\nTotal: 58/ 74/ 79/ 81/ 83/ 81/ 75/73/ 72/ 64\n\nThe changes in the case count and status of the SARS cases in the recent\ncluster in Ontario since yesterday are as follows: 3 new probable and 1 new\nsuspect case have been identified, 1 suspect case has been upgraded to\nprobable. The most recent date of onset of illness is 6 Jun 2003.\n\nNo new probable or suspect cases have been reported from other provinces\nand territories.\n\nAs of 12 Jun 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 434 probable or\nsuspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Canada. There\nhave been 34 deaths in Canada. To date, transmission has been limited to\nspecific transmission settings such as households, hospitals and specific\ncommunity settings.\n\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\n\nOntario is reporting 238 probable (60 active) and 133 suspect (4 active)\ncases.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 4 probable (0 active) and 46 suspect (0\nactive) cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect (0 active) case.\nNew Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases (0 active).\nAlberta is reporting 6 suspect cases (0 active).\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases (0 active).\nTotal no. of probables discharged or at home: 150\nTotal no. of suspects discharged or at home: 186\n\nThese numbers are accurate as of 1:00 PM EDST 12 Jun 2003.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[As of 12 Jun 2003 there have been a cumulative total of 8445 probable\ncases with 790 deaths reported from 29 countries. In the past 24 hours\nthere have been 13 new probable cases reported of which 8 were reported\nfrom Canada, 2 each were reported from Taiwan and the Philippines (the\ncases in the Philippines occurred in Feb but were recently confirmed\nthrough laboratory testing conducted in the UK) and 1 was reported from\nChina. There were no new cases reported from Hong Kong.\n\nThe report on the ongoing outbreak of SARS in Toronto is a sobering\nreminder of the difficulties in detection of cases in the absence of an\nimmediately apparent epidemiologic link to other cases. It begs the\nquestion at what point in time following presumed/apparent interruption of\ntransmission in an area that had had local transmission (greater than or\nequal to 20 days, using the standard \"2 incubation periods\" for the\ndefinition) an area can presume that atypical pneumonias are most probably\nnot due to SARS and therefore SARS level infection control procedures can\nbe dropped. Not an easy question to answer given the observed recurrence\nof active transmission in Ontario. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (143): cases 20030611.1441\nSARS - worldwide (142): cases 20030610.1434\nSARS - worldwide (141): cases 20030609.1423\nSARS - worldwide (140): cases 20030608.1419\nSARS - worldwide (139): cases 20030607.1409\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (87): case definition and diagnostics 20030502.1103\nSARS - worldwide (85): clinical aspects 20030501.1094\nSARS - worldwide (69): diagnostic testing 20030425.1015\nSARS - worldwide (58): diagnostic testing 20030419.0958\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - Worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.........................mpp/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203988", "date": "2003-06-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (144): CASES\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>\n\n[A] Cumulative Number of Reported Probable Cases Of SARS\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/country/2003_06_12/en/>\n\nFrom: 1 Nov 2002 To: 12 June 2003, This means that previously reported cases may be\ndiscarded after further investigation and follow-up.\n\n(1) These 2 new probable cases, with onsets of illness 25 and 27 Feb 2003,\nwere identified retrospectively in the United Kingdom. They both most\nlikely acquired their infection in Hong Kong SAR and became ill and\nrecovered while in the Philippines.\n\n[B] Areas with recent local transmission and travel recommendations can be\naccessed at: <http://www.who.int/csr/sars/areas/2003_06_12/en/> and\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/travel/travel2003_06_12/en/> and is unchanged\nsince the last update.\n\n[C] Update 79 \u0096 Situation in China 12 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_12/en/>\n\nChina\u0092s Executive Vice Minister of Health, Mr Gao Qiang, and Dr David\nHeymann, WHO\u0092s Executive Director for Communicable Diseases, briefed the\npress this morning on the situation of SARS control in China. Also in\nattendance were Dr Qi Ziaoqiu, Director-General of the Department of\nDisease Control in the Chinese Ministry of Health, and Dr Henk Bekedam, WHO\nRepresentative to China.\n\nThe briefing marked the first joint news conference between high-ranking\nChinese and WHO officials since the SARS outbreak began. The briefing\nfollowed a day of intensive meetings during which WHO officials reviewed\ndata and statistics from selected provinces, voiced their concerns, and\nreceived frank and detailed answers.\n\nDr Heymann praised the openness with which the WHO team was welcomed by the\nMinistry of Health, and described the measures now in place to control and\nprevent SARS as \u0093excellent\u0094. He cited the high level of commitment and\ndetermination at all levels of the health system as largely responsible for\nthe dramatic recent decline in the number of cases seen throughout mainland\nChina.\n\nOne purpose of the visit was to determine how China had succeeded in\nbringing down the number of cases so rapidly, and to encourage officials to\nshare their experiences with the rest of the world. Indications of the\neffectiveness of control measures, cited by Dr Heymann, include the very\nshort time now occurring between the onset of symptoms and the detection\nand isolation of cases, and the speed and efficiency of contact tracing.\nSuch measures are important as they limit the amount of time that an\ninfected person is capable of spreading the virus to others and thus bring\ncontrol efforts closer to the stage when the chain of person-to-person\ntransmission can be broken.\n\nOther effective measures include systems for both passive and active\nsurveillance, such as fever checks at train and bus stations and airports,\na nationwide mass media campaign to inform and educate the public, and a\nvery large number of fever clinics to assess those who suspect they may\nhave symptoms. \u0093We\u0092ve seen that there has been a massive effort to\nmobilize the population both in urban and rural areas across the country,\nencouraging people to monitor themselves for fever and to ensure that SARS\ncases are quickly identified, isolated and treated.\u0094\n\nSpecific concerns expressed by the WHO team include the lack of a\nsustainable surveillance system that can be relied on to detect the first\nhints of a resurgence of cases, some delays in meeting WHO requests for\nfurther information, and wide variations in application of the national\ncase definitions, which can lead to under-reporting of cases. Some problems\nrelated to prompt sharing and analysis of data are considered to arise from\ninstitutional and administrative problems, particularly concerning the\ninformation flow from provinces to the central level.\n\nAnother major concern is the large number of cases that have no known\nsource of exposure, thus making it extremely difficult to trace patterns of\ntransmission. In Beijing, the number of cases with no known contact with a\nSARS patient has recently increased from 50 percent to more than 70 percent.\n\nIn the interest of protecting against a further resurgence of cases, WHO\nofficials singled out strengthening of surveillance capacity as the top\npriority. Experience to date has shown that a single case, especially if\nhighly infectious, can rapidly ignite an explosive outbreak.\n\n\u0093With SARS seemingly on the decline for now, there is a great need to\nstrengthen the SARS control and surveillance system in China,\u0094 said Dr\nBekedam. \u0093The system now in place grew out of an emergency response and has\nto be strengthened for the long run.\u0094 He expressed doubt that the present\nsystem would be strong enough \u0093to hold back the tide\u0094 when confronted with\na resurgence of the disease.\n\nIn his assessment of the long-term SARS situation in China, Dr Heymann also\nstressed the need for systematic studies of the origins of SARS. \u0093We still\ndon\u0092t know exactly where SARS came from, or how it was transferred to the\nhuman population. We don\u0092t know if this disease is seasonal and will\ndecrease this year but come back next year.\u0094 Until proper research into\nthe origins of SARS has been conducted, it will be impossible to predict\nwhen the conditions that first allowed the virus to jump to humans from a\nsuspected animal reservoir might be repeated in the near or distant future.\n\nWHO initial assessments of the SARS situation in China, issued in late\nApril [2003] following a visit to Guangdong Province, expressed serious\nconcern over the lack of urgency in reporting cases of SARS in China, and\ncriticized the government for not immediately treating the outbreak as a\npublic health emergency requiring extraordinary measures for its\ncontrol. Dr Heymann and other members of the WHO team are now satisfied\nthat these measures are in place, at least for the immediate response to\nSARS. Recent visits to selected provinces, jointly conducted by the Chinese\nMinistry of Health and WHO, found a high level of public awareness of SARS,\nits symptoms and mode of transmission, and the need for twice-daily fever\nchecks.\n\nChina is regarded as the epicentre of the SARS outbreak. The country was\nhome to the first cases, detected in mid-November of last year [2002], and\npresently accounts for almost two thirds of all reported cases worldwide.\nThe WHO visit was arranged to secure reassurance that control measures in\nthis vast country are adequate to continue the downward trends in cases\nand, equally important, to ensure that a sustainable system is in place to\ndetect and contain a resurgence of cases. WHO is also anxious to ensure\nthat the considerable knowledge and experience acquired in managing the\nlargest SARS outbreak on record is shared for the benefit of all countries.\n\nThe SARS outbreak has revealed substantial weaknesses in the disease\nsurveillance system in China. When investment in health infrastructure is\nneglected, conditions are ripe for the unchecked spread of any\nepidemic-prone disease, often at tremendous cost to a nation\u0092s economy. In\nthe view of WHO, the surveillance system in China needs to be made more\nflexible and capable of a much more rapid and consistent response to any\nnew infectious disease threat.\n\nDuring the visit, Chinese officials expressed deep concern about the\ncountry\u0092s capacity to deal with the next influenza season against a\nbackground of possible SARS cases. The presence of influenza could greatly\ncomplicate the detection and accurate diagnosis of SARS cases, while also\nincreasing the caseload of suspect cases considerably.\n\nThe containment of SARS remains the overriding objective of WHO. If SARS is\nnot contained, the world will face a situation in which every case of\natypical pneumonia, and every hospital-based cluster of febrile patients\nwith respiratory systems will have the potential to rouse suspicions of\nSARS and spark widespread panic.\n\nIn an earlier report, a WHO assessment team reached the following\nconclusion: \u0093If SARS is not brought under control in China, there will be\nno chance of controlling the global threat of SARS. Achieving control of\nSARS is a major challenge especially in a country as large and diverse as\nChina. Effective disease control and reporting are the cornerstone of any\nstrategy to do this.\u0094\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC Taiwan [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov.tw/sarsen/>\n\nNo. new probable cases reported: 2\nCumulative no. cases: 688\n(cumulative no. cases in last update: 687)\nExplanation: 1 previously reported prob. case excluded by reporting MD.\n\nCumulative no. SARS probable cases, by geographic area: 12 Jun 2003 9 AM\n\nArea: Cumulative no. cases/ no. new probable cases reported/ no.\ndischarged/ total no. deaths\n\nNorth: 531/ 1/ 118/ 56\nCentral: 38/ 0/ 0/ 3\nSouth: 113/ 1/ 55/ 21 (1 previously reported prob. case excluded by\nreporting MD)\nEast: 6/ 0/ 0/ 1\n\nTotal: 688/ 2/ 173/ 81 (1 previously reported prob. case excluded by\nreporting MD)\n\nAs mentioned in earlier updates, there are graphics at the above website\nlink. According to the pie chart representation of reported cases, there\nare an additional 1455 suspected cases reported, and 759 formerly reported\ncases (suspected and probable) have been excluded. Reviewing the epidemic\ncurve on today's update page, the most recent noted date of onset is 9 Jun\n2003.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website/ Beijing Government SARS website\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/china2003_06_12.pdf>\n<http://www.beijing.gov.cn/english/englishsars/beijingen/detail.asp?ResourceID=63257>\n\n** Noteworthy, no new probable cases were reported in the past 24 hours\n\nAs of 12 Jun 2003 a cumulative total of 5328 probable cases with\n343 deaths have been reported. In the past 24 hours, one previously\nreported probable case in Inner Mongolia who died was discarded as due to\nSARS. There were no new probable cases reported. One new suspected case\nwas reported from one of the provinces not identified on the daily table,\nsuggesting it occurred in one of the provinces not having reported a\nprobable case in more than 20 days. At present there are a total of 220\nsuspected cases still pending in China.\n\nShanghai, Hubei, Guangxi, Guangdong, Tianjin, Jilin, Gansu, Jiangsu, Anhui,\nShaanxi, Zhejiang, Henan, Chongqing, Jiangxi, Ningxia, Shandong, Fujian,\nHunan, Heilongjiang and Xinjiang have not reported any new probable cases\nin more than 20 days.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong Department of Health\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/2003/03-06-12e.htm>\n\n** Noteworthy - no new probable cases reported in the past 24 hours **\n\nSituation report on Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome 12 Jun 2003\n\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\n\nThere is no new confirmed case of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)\ntoday (12 Jun 2003). This is the 4th time that Hong Kong recorded zero\ninfection (the last 3 times were on 24 May 2003, 8 and 8 Jun 2003). It is\nalso the 28th consecutive day on which the number of cases has fallen below\n5 since 16 May 2003.\n\nThe number of patients recovered and discharged from hospital is 1377. Of\nthem, 3 were discharged today. The number of SARS patients in intensive\ncare unit is 17. These cases are part of the 58 cases under treatment in\nhospitals. 29 are recovering patients in convalescence and in preparation\nfor discharge. No fatality was reported. The cumulative total of deaths\nrelating to SARS remains at 291.\n\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with SARS since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\n\nCumulative no. cases/ total no. discharged patients/ total no. deaths\n(change in past 24 hours presented in parentheses, minus used for decrease)\n\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 386 (0)/ 362\n(1)/ (n/a)\nPatients, family members & visitors: 1369 (0)/ 1015 (2) / (n/a)\n\nTotal: 1755 (0)/ 1377 (3)/ 291 (0)\n\nTotal no. in hospital: 87 (-3)\nRecovering patients in convalescence: 29\nCases under treatment: 58 (-2) (including 17 patients in Intensive Care\nUnit)\n\nSuspected cases: 1\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n\nHealth Canada\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update79.html>\n\n\"Active\" cases include those hospitalized, currently ill at home, or under\ninvestigation.\n\nActive SARS cases in Canada\n---------------------\nDate: May 30/ Jun 2/ Jun 3/ Jun 4/ Jun 5/ Jun 6/ Jun 9/ Jun 10/ Jun 11/ Jun 12\n\nProbable (Active) 43/ 62/ 64/ 67/ 68/ 70/ 66/ 64/ 65/ 60\nSuspect (Active) 15/ 12/ 15/ 14/ 15/ 11/ 9/ 9/ 7/ 4\n\nTotal: 58/ 74/ 79/ 81/ 83/ 81/ 75/73/ 72/ 64\n\nThe changes in the case count and status of the SARS cases in the recent\ncluster in Ontario since yesterday are as follows: 3 new probable and 1 new\nsuspect case have been identified, 1 suspect case has been upgraded to\nprobable. The most recent date of onset of illness is 6 Jun 2003.\n\nNo new probable or suspect cases have been reported from other provinces\nand territories.\n\nAs of 12 Jun 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 434 probable or\nsuspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Canada. There\nhave been 34 deaths in Canada. To date, transmission has been limited to\nspecific transmission settings such as households, hospitals and specific\ncommunity settings.\n\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\n\nOntario is reporting 238 probable (60 active) and 133 suspect (4 active)\ncases.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 4 probable (0 active) and 46 suspect (0\nactive) cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect (0 active) case.\nNew Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases (0 active).\nAlberta is reporting 6 suspect cases (0 active).\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases (0 active).\nTotal no. of probables discharged or at home: 150\nTotal no. of suspects discharged or at home: 186\n\nThese numbers are accurate as of 1:00 PM EDST 12 Jun 2003.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[As of 12 Jun 2003 there have been a cumulative total of 8445 probable\ncases with 790 deaths reported from 29 countries. In the past 24 hours\nthere have been 13 new probable cases reported of which 8 were reported\nfrom Canada, 2 each were reported from Taiwan and the Philippines (the\ncases in the Philippines occurred in Feb but were recently confirmed\nthrough laboratory testing conducted in the UK) and 1 was reported from\nChina. There were no new cases reported from Hong Kong.\n\nThe report on the ongoing outbreak of SARS in Toronto is a sobering\nreminder of the difficulties in detection of cases in the absence of an\nimmediately apparent epidemiologic link to other cases. It begs the\nquestion at what point in time following presumed/apparent interruption of\ntransmission in an area that had had local transmission (greater than or\nequal to 20 days, using the standard \"2 incubation periods\" for the\ndefinition) an area can presume that atypical pneumonias are most probably\nnot due to SARS and therefore SARS level infection control procedures can\nbe dropped. Not an easy question to answer given the observed recurrence\nof active transmission in Ontario. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (143): cases 20030611.1441\nSARS - worldwide (142): cases 20030610.1434\nSARS - worldwide (141): cases 20030609.1423\nSARS - worldwide (140): cases 20030608.1419\nSARS - worldwide (139): cases 20030607.1409\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (87): case definition and diagnostics 20030502.1103\nSARS - worldwide (85): clinical aspects 20030501.1094\nSARS - worldwide (69): diagnostic testing 20030425.1015\nSARS - worldwide (58): diagnostic testing 20030419.0958\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - Worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.........................mpp/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203982", "date": "2003-06-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (144): CASES\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn today's update:\n[1] Worldwide - WHO\n[2] Taiwan - CDC Taiwan\n[3] China - WHO/Beijing Government\n[4] Hong Kong - DOH\n[5] Canada - Health Canada\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>\n\n[A] Cumulative Number of Reported Probable Cases Of SARS\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/country/2003_06_12/en/>\n\nFrom: 1 Nov 2002 To: 12 June 2003, 18:00 GMT+2\n\nCountry: Cumulative no. cases/ no. new cases since last WHO update/ no.\ndeaths/ no. recovered/ date last probable case reported/ date cumulative\nno. cases current\n\nAustralia: 5/ 0/ 0/ 5/ 12/May/2003/ 5/Jun/2003\nBrazil: 3/ 0/ 0/ 2/ 9/Jun/2003/ 9/Jun/2003\nCanada: 238/ 8/ 32/ 141/ 11/Jun/2003/ 11/Jun/2003\nChina: 5328/ 0/ 343/ 4457/ 11/Jun/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nChina, Hong Kong\nSAR: 1755/ 1/ 291/ 1377/ 11/Jun/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nChina, Macao SAR: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 21/May/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nChina, Taiwan: 688/ 2/ 81/ 347/ 12/Jun/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nColombia: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 5/May/2003/ 5/May/2003\nFinland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 7/May/2003/ 20/May/2003\nFrance: 7/ 0/ 0/ 6/ 9/May/2003/ 22/May/2003\nGermany: 10/ 0/ 0/ 9/ 4/Jun/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nIndia: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 13/May/2003/ 14/May/2003\nIndonesia: 2/ 0/ 0/ 2/ 23/Apr/2003/ 11/Jun/2003\nItaly: 9/ 0/ 0/ 9/ 29/Apr/2003/ 10/Jun/2003\nKuwait: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 9/Apr/2003/ 20/Apr/2003\nMalaysia: 5/ 0/ 2/ 3/ 20/May/2003/ 9/Jun/2003\nMongolia: 9/ 0/ 0/ 9/ 6/May/2003/ 2/Jun/2003\nNew Zealand: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 30/Apr/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nPhilippines (1): 14/ 2/ 2/ 10/ 15/May/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nRepublic of Ireland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 21/Mar/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nRepublic of Korea: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 14/May/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nRomania: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 27/Mar/2003/ 22/Apr/2003\nRussian Federation: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ 31/May/2003/ 31/May/2003\nSingapore: 206/ 0/ 31/ 169/ 18/May/2003/ 11/Jun/2003\nSouth Africa: 1/ 0/ 1/ 0/ 9/Apr/2003/ 3/May/2003\nSpain: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 2/Apr/2003/ 5/Jun/2003\nSweden: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 18/Apr/2003/ 13/May/2003\nSwitzerland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 17/Mar/2003/ 16/May/2003\nThailand: 9/ 0/ 2/ 6/ 7/Jun/2003/ 11/Jun/2003\nUnited Kingdom: 4/ 0/ 0/ 4/ 29/Apr/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nUnited States: 70/ 0/ 0/ 36/ 10/Jun/2003/ 11/Jun/2003\nViet Nam: 63/ 0/ 5/ 58/ 14/Apr/2003/ 7/Jun/2003\n\nTotal: 8445/ 13/ 790/ 6668\n\nNotes:\nAs SARS is a diagnosis of exclusion, the status of a reported case may\nchange over time. This means that previously reported cases may be\ndiscarded after further investigation and follow-up.\n\n(1) These 2 new probable cases, with onsets of illness 25 and 27 Feb 2003,\nwere identified retrospectively in the United Kingdom. They both most\nlikely acquired their infection in Hong Kong SAR and became ill and\nrecovered while in the Philippines.\n\n[B] Areas with recent local transmission and travel recommendations can be\naccessed at: <http://www.who.int/csr/sars/areas/2003_06_12/en/> and\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/travel/travel2003_06_12/en/> and is unchanged\nsince the last update.\n\n[C] Update 79 \u0096 Situation in China 12 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_12/en/>\n\nChina\u0092s Executive Vice Minister of Health, Mr Gao Qiang, and Dr David\nHeymann, WHO\u0092s Executive Director for Communicable Diseases, briefed the\npress this morning on the situation of SARS control in China. Also in\nattendance were Dr Qi Ziaoqiu, Director-General of the Department of\nDisease Control in the Chinese Ministry of Health, and Dr Henk Bekedam, WHO\nRepresentative to China.\n\nThe briefing marked the first joint news conference between high-ranking\nChinese and WHO officials since the SARS outbreak began. The briefing\nfollowed a day of intensive meetings during which WHO officials reviewed\ndata and statistics from selected provinces, voiced their concerns, and\nreceived frank and detailed answers.\n\nDr Heymann praised the openness with which the WHO team was welcomed by the\nMinistry of Health, and described the measures now in place to control and\nprevent SARS as \u0093excellent\u0094. He cited the high level of commitment and\ndetermination at all levels of the health system as largely responsible for\nthe dramatic recent decline in the number of cases seen throughout mainland\nChina.\n\nOne purpose of the visit was to determine how China had succeeded in\nbringing down the number of cases so rapidly, and to encourage officials to\nshare their experiences with the rest of the world. Indications of the\neffectiveness of control measures, cited by Dr Heymann, include the very\nshort time now occurring between the onset of symptoms and the detection\nand isolation of cases, and the speed and efficiency of contact tracing.\nSuch measures are important as they limit the amount of time that an\ninfected person is capable of spreading the virus to others and thus bring\ncontrol efforts closer to the stage when the chain of person-to-person\ntransmission can be broken.\n\nOther effective measures include systems for both passive and active\nsurveillance, such as fever checks at train and bus stations and airports,\na nationwide mass media campaign to inform and educate the public, and a\nvery large number of fever clinics to assess those who suspect they may\nhave symptoms. \u0093We\u0092ve seen that there has been a massive effort to\nmobilize the population both in urban and rural areas across the country,\nencouraging people to monitor themselves for fever and to ensure that SARS\ncases are quickly identified, isolated and treated.\u0094\n\nSpecific concerns expressed by the WHO team include the lack of a\nsustainable surveillance system that can be relied on to detect the first\nhints of a resurgence of cases, some delays in meeting WHO requests for\nfurther information, and wide variations in application of the national\ncase definitions, which can lead to under-reporting of cases. Some problems\nrelated to prompt sharing and analysis of data are considered to arise from\ninstitutional and administrative problems, particularly concerning the\ninformation flow from provinces to the central level.\n\nAnother major concern is the large number of cases that have no known\nsource of exposure, thus making it extremely difficult to trace patterns of\ntransmission. In Beijing, the number of cases with no known contact with a\nSARS patient has recently increased from 50 percent to more than 70 percent.\n\nIn the interest of protecting against a further resurgence of cases, WHO\nofficials singled out strengthening of surveillance capacity as the top\npriority. Experience to date has shown that a single case, especially if\nhighly infectious, can rapidly ignite an explosive outbreak.\n\n\u0093With SARS seemingly on the decline for now, there is a great need to\nstrengthen the SARS control and surveillance system in China,\u0094 said Dr\nBekedam. \u0093The system now in place grew out of an emergency response and has\nto be strengthened for the long run.\u0094 He expressed doubt that the present\nsystem would be strong enough \u0093to hold back the tide\u0094 when confronted with\na resurgence of the disease.\n\nIn his assessment of the long-term SARS situation in China, Dr Heymann also\nstressed the need for systematic studies of the origins of SARS. \u0093We still\ndon\u0092t know exactly where SARS came from, or how it was transferred to the\nhuman population. We don\u0092t know if this disease is seasonal and will\ndecrease this year but come back next year.\u0094 Until proper research into\nthe origins of SARS has been conducted, it will be impossible to predict\nwhen the conditions that first allowed the virus to jump to humans from a\nsuspected animal reservoir might be repeated in the near or distant future.\n\nWHO initial assessments of the SARS situation in China, issued in late\nApril [2003] following a visit to Guangdong Province, expressed serious\nconcern over the lack of urgency in reporting cases of SARS in China, and\ncriticized the government for not immediately treating the outbreak as a\npublic health emergency requiring extraordinary measures for its\ncontrol. Dr Heymann and other members of the WHO team are now satisfied\nthat these measures are in place, at least for the immediate response to\nSARS. Recent visits to selected provinces, jointly conducted by the Chinese\nMinistry of Health and WHO, found a high level of public awareness of SARS,\nits symptoms and mode of transmission, and the need for twice-daily fever\nchecks.\n\nChina is regarded as the epicentre of the SARS outbreak. The country was\nhome to the first cases, detected in mid-November of last year [2002], and\npresently accounts for almost two thirds of all reported cases worldwide.\nThe WHO visit was arranged to secure reassurance that control measures in\nthis vast country are adequate to continue the downward trends in cases\nand, equally important, to ensure that a sustainable system is in place to\ndetect and contain a resurgence of cases. WHO is also anxious to ensure\nthat the considerable knowledge and experience acquired in managing the\nlargest SARS outbreak on record is shared for the benefit of all countries.\n\nThe SARS outbreak has revealed substantial weaknesses in the disease\nsurveillance system in China. When investment in health infrastructure is\nneglected, conditions are ripe for the unchecked spread of any\nepidemic-prone disease, often at tremendous cost to a nation\u0092s economy. In\nthe view of WHO, the surveillance system in China needs to be made more\nflexible and capable of a much more rapid and consistent response to any\nnew infectious disease threat.\n\nDuring the visit, Chinese officials expressed deep concern about the\ncountry\u0092s capacity to deal with the next influenza season against a\nbackground of possible SARS cases. The presence of influenza could greatly\ncomplicate the detection and accurate diagnosis of SARS cases, while also\nincreasing the caseload of suspect cases considerably.\n\nThe containment of SARS remains the overriding objective of WHO. If SARS is\nnot contained, the world will face a situation in which every case of\natypical pneumonia, and every hospital-based cluster of febrile patients\nwith respiratory systems will have the potential to rouse suspicions of\nSARS and spark widespread panic.\n\nIn an earlier report, a WHO assessment team reached the following\nconclusion: \u0093If SARS is not brought under control in China, there will be\nno chance of controlling the global threat of SARS. Achieving control of\nSARS is a major challenge especially in a country as large and diverse as\nChina. Effective disease control and reporting are the cornerstone of any\nstrategy to do this.\u0094\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC Taiwan [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov.tw/sarsen/>\n\nNo. new probable cases reported: 2\nCumulative no. cases: 688\n(cumulative no. cases in last update: 687)\nExplanation: 1 previously reported prob. case excluded by reporting MD.\n\nCumulative no. SARS probable cases, by geographic area: 12 Jun 2003 9 AM\n\nArea: Cumulative no. cases/ no. new probable cases reported/ no.\ndischarged/ total no. deaths\n\nNorth: 531/ 1/ 118/ 56\nCentral: 38/ 0/ 0/ 3\nSouth: 113/ 1/ 55/ 21 (1 previously reported prob. case excluded by\nreporting MD)\nEast: 6/ 0/ 0/ 1\n\nTotal: 688/ 2/ 173/ 81 (1 previously reported prob. case excluded by\nreporting MD)\n\nAs mentioned in earlier updates, there are graphics at the above website\nlink. According to the pie chart representation of reported cases, there\nare an additional 1455 suspected cases reported, and 759 formerly reported\ncases (suspected and probable) have been excluded. Reviewing the epidemic\ncurve on today's update page, the most recent noted date of onset is 9 Jun\n2003.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website/ Beijing Government SARS website\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/china2003_06_12.pdf>\n<http://www.beijing.gov.cn/english/englishsars/beijingen/detail.asp?ResourceID=63257>\n\n** Noteworthy, no new probable cases were reported in the past 24 hours\n\nAs of 12 Jun 2003 a cumulative total of 5328 probable cases with\n343 deaths have been reported. In the past 24 hours, one previously\nreported probable case in Inner Mongolia who died was discarded as due to\nSARS. There were no new probable cases reported. One new suspected case\nwas reported from one of the provinces not identified on the daily table,\nsuggesting it occurred in one of the provinces not having reported a\nprobable case in more than 20 days. At present there are a total of 220\nsuspected cases still pending in China.\n\nShanghai, Hubei, Guangxi, Guangdong, Tianjin, Jilin, Gansu, Jiangsu, Anhui,\nShaanxi, Zhejiang, Henan, Chongqing, Jiangxi, Ningxia, Shandong, Fujian,\nHunan, Heilongjiang and Xinjiang have not reported any new probable cases\nin more than 20 days.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong Department of Health\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/2003/03-06-12e.htm>\n\n** Noteworthy - no new probable cases reported in the past 24 hours **\n\nSituation report on Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome 12 Jun 2003\n\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\n\nThere is no new confirmed case of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)\ntoday (12 Jun 2003). This is the 4th time that Hong Kong recorded zero\ninfection (the last 3 times were on 24 May 2003, 8 and 8 Jun 2003). It is\nalso the 28th consecutive day on which the number of cases has fallen below\n5 since 16 May 2003.\n\nThe number of patients recovered and discharged from hospital is 1377. Of\nthem, 3 were discharged today. The number of SARS patients in intensive\ncare unit is 17. These cases are part of the 58 cases under treatment in\nhospitals. 29 are recovering patients in convalescence and in preparation\nfor discharge. No fatality was reported. The cumulative total of deaths\nrelating to SARS remains at 291.\n\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with SARS since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\n\nCumulative no. cases/ total no. discharged patients/ total no. deaths\n(change in past 24 hours presented in parentheses, minus used for decrease)\n\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 386 (0)/ 362\n(1)/ (n/a)\nPatients, family members & visitors: 1369 (0)/ 1015 (2) / (n/a)\n\nTotal: 1755 (0)/ 1377 (3)/ 291 (0)\n\nTotal no. in hospital: 87 (-3)\nRecovering patients in convalescence: 29\nCases under treatment: 58 (-2) (including 17 patients in Intensive Care\nUnit)\n\nSuspected cases: 1\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n\nHealth Canada\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update79.html>\n\n\"Active\" cases include those hospitalized, currently ill at home, or under\ninvestigation.\n\nActive SARS cases in Canada\n---------------------\nDate: May 30/ Jun 2/ Jun 3/ Jun 4/ Jun 5/ Jun 6/ Jun 9/ Jun 10/ Jun 11/ Jun 12\n\nProbable (Active) 43/ 62/ 64/ 67/ 68/ 70/ 66/ 64/ 65/ 60\nSuspect (Active) 15/ 12/ 15/ 14/ 15/ 11/ 9/ 9/ 7/ 4\n\nTotal: 58/ 74/ 79/ 81/ 83/ 81/ 75/73/ 72/ 64\n\nThe changes in the case count and status of the SARS cases in the recent\ncluster in Ontario since yesterday are as follows: 3 new probable and 1 new\nsuspect case have been identified, 1 suspect case has been upgraded to\nprobable. The most recent date of onset of illness is 6 Jun 2003.\n\nNo new probable or suspect cases have been reported from other provinces\nand territories.\n\nAs of 12 Jun 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 434 probable or\nsuspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Canada. There\nhave been 34 deaths in Canada. To date, transmission has been limited to\nspecific transmission settings such as households, hospitals and specific\ncommunity settings.\n\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\n\nOntario is reporting 238 probable (60 active) and 133 suspect (4 active)\ncases.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 4 probable (0 active) and 46 suspect (0\nactive) cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect (0 active) case.\nNew Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases (0 active).\nAlberta is reporting 6 suspect cases (0 active).\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases (0 active).\nTotal no. of probables discharged or at home: 150\nTotal no. of suspects discharged or at home: 186\n\nThese numbers are accurate as of 1:00 PM EDST 12 Jun 2003.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[As of 12 Jun 2003 there have been a cumulative total of 8445 probable\ncases with 790 deaths reported from 29 countries. In the past 24 hours\nthere have been 13 new probable cases reported of which 8 were reported\nfrom Canada, 2 each were reported from Taiwan and the Philippines (the\ncases in the Philippines occurred in Feb but were recently confirmed\nthrough laboratory testing conducted in the UK) and 1 was reported from\nChina. There were no new cases reported from Hong Kong.\n\nThe report on the ongoing outbreak of SARS in Toronto is a sobering\nreminder of the difficulties in detection of cases in the absence of an\nimmediately apparent epidemiologic link to other cases. It begs the\nquestion at what point in time following presumed/apparent interruption of\ntransmission in an area that had had local transmission (greater than or\nequal to 20 days, using the standard \"2 incubation periods\" for the\ndefinition) an area can presume that atypical pneumonias are most probably\nnot due to SARS and therefore SARS level infection control procedures can\nbe dropped. Not an easy question to answer given the observed recurrence\nof active transmission in Ontario. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (143): cases 20030611.1441\nSARS - worldwide (142): cases 20030610.1434\nSARS - worldwide (141): cases 20030609.1423\nSARS - worldwide (140): cases 20030608.1419\nSARS - worldwide (139): cases 20030607.1409\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (87): case definition and diagnostics 20030502.1103\nSARS - worldwide (85): clinical aspects 20030501.1094\nSARS - worldwide (69): diagnostic testing 20030425.1015\nSARS - worldwide (58): diagnostic testing 20030419.0958\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - Worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.........................mpp/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203972", "date": "2003-06-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (144): CASES\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn today's update:\n[1] Worldwide - WHO\n[2] Taiwan - CDC Taiwan\n[3] China - WHO/Beijing Government\n[4] Hong Kong - DOH\n[5] Canada - Health Canada\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>\n\n[A] Cumulative Number of Reported Probable Cases Of SARS\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/country/2003_06_12/en/>\n\nFrom: 1 Nov 2002 To: 12 June 2003, 18:00 GMT+2\n\nCountry: Cumulative no. cases/ no. new cases since last WHO update/ no.\ndeaths/ no. recovered/ date last probable case reported/ date cumulative\nno. cases current\n\nAustralia: 5/ 0/ 0/ 5/ 12/May/2003/ 5/Jun/2003\nBrazil: 3/ 0/ 0/ 2/ 9/Jun/2003/ 9/Jun/2003\nCanada: 238/ 8/ 32/ 141/ 11/Jun/2003/ 11/Jun/2003\nChina: 5328/ 0/ 343/ 4457/ 11/Jun/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nChina, Hong Kong\nSAR: 1755/ 1/ 291/ 1377/ 11/Jun/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nChina, Macao SAR: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 21/May/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nChina, Taiwan: 688/ 2/ 81/ 347/ 12/Jun/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nColombia: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 5/May/2003/ 5/May/2003\nFinland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 7/May/2003/ 20/May/2003\nFrance: 7/ 0/ 0/ 6/ 9/May/2003/ 22/May/2003\nGermany: 10/ 0/ 0/ 9/ 4/Jun/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nIndia: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 13/May/2003/ 14/May/2003\nIndonesia: 2/ 0/ 0/ 2/ 23/Apr/2003/ 11/Jun/2003\nItaly: 9/ 0/ 0/ 9/ 29/Apr/2003/ 10/Jun/2003\nKuwait: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 9/Apr/2003/ 20/Apr/2003\nMalaysia: 5/ 0/ 2/ 3/ 20/May/2003/ 9/Jun/2003\nMongolia: 9/ 0/ 0/ 9/ 6/May/2003/ 2/Jun/2003\nNew Zealand: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 30/Apr/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nPhilippines (1): 14/ 2/ 2/ 10/ 15/May/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nRepublic of Ireland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 21/Mar/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nRepublic of Korea: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 14/May/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nRomania: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 27/Mar/2003/ 22/Apr/2003\nRussian Federation: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ 31/May/2003/ 31/May/2003\nSingapore: 206/ 0/ 31/ 169/ 18/May/2003/ 11/Jun/2003\nSouth Africa: 1/ 0/ 1/ 0/ 9/Apr/2003/ 3/May/2003\nSpain: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 2/Apr/2003/ 5/Jun/2003\nSweden: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ 18/Apr/2003/ 13/May/2003\nSwitzerland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ 17/Mar/2003/ 16/May/2003\nThailand: 9/ 0/ 2/ 6/ 7/Jun/2003/ 11/Jun/2003\nUnited Kingdom: 4/ 0/ 0/ 4/ 29/Apr/2003/ 12/Jun/2003\nUnited States: 70/ 0/ 0/ 36/ 10/Jun/2003/ 11/Jun/2003\nViet Nam: 63/ 0/ 5/ 58/ 14/Apr/2003/ 7/Jun/2003\n\nTotal: 8445/ 13/ 790/ 6668\n\nNotes:\nAs SARS is a diagnosis of exclusion, the status of a reported case may\nchange over time. This means that previously reported cases may be\ndiscarded after further investigation and follow-up.\n\n(1) These 2 new probable cases, with onsets of illness 25 and 27 Feb 2003,\nwere identified retrospectively in the United Kingdom. They both most\nlikely acquired their infection in Hong Kong SAR and became ill and\nrecovered while in the Philippines.\n\n[B] Areas with recent local transmission and travel recommendations can be\naccessed at: <http://www.who.int/csr/sars/areas/2003_06_12/en/> and\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/travel/travel2003_06_12/en/> and is unchanged\nsince the last update.\n\n[C] Update 79 \u0096 Situation in China 12 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_12/en/>\n\nChina\u0092s Executive Vice Minister of Health, Mr Gao Qiang, and Dr David\nHeymann, WHO\u0092s Executive Director for Communicable Diseases, briefed the\npress this morning on the situation of SARS control in China. Also in\nattendance were Dr Qi Ziaoqiu, Director-General of the Department of\nDisease Control in the Chinese Ministry of Health, and Dr Henk Bekedam, WHO\nRepresentative to China.\n\nThe briefing marked the first joint news conference between high-ranking\nChinese and WHO officials since the SARS outbreak began. The briefing\nfollowed a day of intensive meetings during which WHO officials reviewed\ndata and statistics from selected provinces, voiced their concerns, and\nreceived frank and detailed answers.\n\nDr Heymann praised the openness with which the WHO team was welcomed by the\nMinistry of Health, and described the measures now in place to control and\nprevent SARS as \u0093excellent\u0094. He cited the high level of commitment and\ndetermination at all levels of the health system as largely responsible for\nthe dramatic recent decline in the number of cases seen throughout mainland\nChina.\n\nOne purpose of the visit was to determine how China had succeeded in\nbringing down the number of cases so rapidly, and to encourage officials to\nshare their experiences with the rest of the world. Indications of the\neffectiveness of control measures, cited by Dr Heymann, include the very\nshort time now occurring between the onset of symptoms and the detection\nand isolation of cases, and the speed and efficiency of contact tracing.\nSuch measures are important as they limit the amount of time that an\ninfected person is capable of spreading the virus to others and thus bring\ncontrol efforts closer to the stage when the chain of person-to-person\ntransmission can be broken.\n\nOther effective measures include systems for both passive and active\nsurveillance, such as fever checks at train and bus stations and airports,\na nationwide mass media campaign to inform and educate the public, and a\nvery large number of fever clinics to assess those who suspect they may\nhave symptoms. \u0093We\u0092ve seen that there has been a massive effort to\nmobilize the population both in urban and rural areas across the country,\nencouraging people to monitor themselves for fever and to ensure that SARS\ncases are quickly identified, isolated and treated.\u0094\n\nSpecific concerns expressed by the WHO team include the lack of a\nsustainable surveillance system that can be relied on to detect the first\nhints of a resurgence of cases, some delays in meeting WHO requests for\nfurther information, and wide variations in application of the national\ncase definitions, which can lead to under-reporting of cases. Some problems\nrelated to prompt sharing and analysis of data are considered to arise from\ninstitutional and administrative problems, particularly concerning the\ninformation flow from provinces to the central level.\n\nAnother major concern is the large number of cases that have no known\nsource of exposure, thus making it extremely difficult to trace patterns of\ntransmission. In Beijing, the number of cases with no known contact with a\nSARS patient has recently increased from 50 percent to more than 70 percent.\n\nIn the interest of protecting against a further resurgence of cases, WHO\nofficials singled out strengthening of surveillance capacity as the top\npriority. Experience to date has shown that a single case, especially if\nhighly infectious, can rapidly ignite an explosive outbreak.\n\n\u0093With SARS seemingly on the decline for now, there is a great need to\nstrengthen the SARS control and surveillance system in China,\u0094 said Dr\nBekedam. \u0093The system now in place grew out of an emergency response and has\nto be strengthened for the long run.\u0094 He expressed doubt that the present\nsystem would be strong enough \u0093to hold back the tide\u0094 when confronted with\na resurgence of the disease.\n\nIn his assessment of the long-term SARS situation in China, Dr Heymann also\nstressed the need for systematic studies of the origins of SARS. \u0093We still\ndon\u0092t know exactly where SARS came from, or how it was transferred to the\nhuman population. We don\u0092t know if this disease is seasonal and will\ndecrease this year but come back next year.\u0094 Until proper research into\nthe origins of SARS has been conducted, it will be impossible to predict\nwhen the conditions that first allowed the virus to jump to humans from a\nsuspected animal reservoir might be repeated in the near or distant future.\n\nWHO initial assessments of the SARS situation in China, issued in late\nApril [2003] following a visit to Guangdong Province, expressed serious\nconcern over the lack of urgency in reporting cases of SARS in China, and\ncriticized the government for not immediately treating the outbreak as a\npublic health emergency requiring extraordinary measures for its\ncontrol. Dr Heymann and other members of the WHO team are now satisfied\nthat these measures are in place, at least for the immediate response to\nSARS. Recent visits to selected provinces, jointly conducted by the Chinese\nMinistry of Health and WHO, found a high level of public awareness of SARS,\nits symptoms and mode of transmission, and the need for twice-daily fever\nchecks.\n\nChina is regarded as the epicentre of the SARS outbreak. The country was\nhome to the first cases, detected in mid-November of last year [2002], and\npresently accounts for almost two thirds of all reported cases worldwide.\nThe WHO visit was arranged to secure reassurance that control measures in\nthis vast country are adequate to continue the downward trends in cases\nand, equally important, to ensure that a sustainable system is in place to\ndetect and contain a resurgence of cases. WHO is also anxious to ensure\nthat the considerable knowledge and experience acquired in managing the\nlargest SARS outbreak on record is shared for the benefit of all countries.\n\nThe SARS outbreak has revealed substantial weaknesses in the disease\nsurveillance system in China. When investment in health infrastructure is\nneglected, conditions are ripe for the unchecked spread of any\nepidemic-prone disease, often at tremendous cost to a nation\u0092s economy. In\nthe view of WHO, the surveillance system in China needs to be made more\nflexible and capable of a much more rapid and consistent response to any\nnew infectious disease threat.\n\nDuring the visit, Chinese officials expressed deep concern about the\ncountry\u0092s capacity to deal with the next influenza season against a\nbackground of possible SARS cases. The presence of influenza could greatly\ncomplicate the detection and accurate diagnosis of SARS cases, while also\nincreasing the caseload of suspect cases considerably.\n\nThe containment of SARS remains the overriding objective of WHO. If SARS is\nnot contained, the world will face a situation in which every case of\natypical pneumonia, and every hospital-based cluster of febrile patients\nwith respiratory systems will have the potential to rouse suspicions of\nSARS and spark widespread panic.\n\nIn an earlier report, a WHO assessment team reached the following\nconclusion: \u0093If SARS is not brought under control in China, there will be\nno chance of controlling the global threat of SARS. Achieving control of\nSARS is a major challenge especially in a country as large and diverse as\nChina. Effective disease control and reporting are the cornerstone of any\nstrategy to do this.\u0094\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC Taiwan [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov.tw/sarsen/>\n\nNo. new probable cases reported: 2\nCumulative no. cases: 688\n(cumulative no. cases in last update: 687)\nExplanation: 1 previously reported prob. case excluded by reporting MD.\n\nCumulative no. SARS probable cases, by geographic area: 12 Jun 2003 9 AM\n\nArea: Cumulative no. cases/ no. new probable cases reported/ no.\ndischarged/ total no. deaths\n\nNorth: 531/ 1/ 118/ 56\nCentral: 38/ 0/ 0/ 3\nSouth: 113/ 1/ 55/ 21 (1 previously reported prob. case excluded by\nreporting MD)\nEast: 6/ 0/ 0/ 1\n\nTotal: 688/ 2/ 173/ 81 (1 previously reported prob. case excluded by\nreporting MD)\n\nAs mentioned in earlier updates, there are graphics at the above website\nlink. According to the pie chart representation of reported cases, there\nare an additional 1455 suspected cases reported, and 759 formerly reported\ncases (suspected and probable) have been excluded. Reviewing the epidemic\ncurve on today's update page, the most recent noted date of onset is 9 Jun\n2003.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website/ Beijing Government SARS website\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/china2003_06_12.pdf>\n<http://www.beijing.gov.cn/english/englishsars/beijingen/detail.asp?ResourceID=63257>\n\n** Noteworthy, no new probable cases were reported in the past 24 hours\n\nAs of 12 Jun 2003 a cumulative total of 5328 probable cases with\n343 deaths have been reported. In the past 24 hours, one previously\nreported probable case in Inner Mongolia who died was discarded as due to\nSARS. There were no new probable cases reported. One new suspected case\nwas reported from one of the provinces not identified on the daily table,\nsuggesting it occurred in one of the provinces not having reported a\nprobable case in more than 20 days. At present there are a total of 220\nsuspected cases still pending in China.\n\nShanghai, Hubei, Guangxi, Guangdong, Tianjin, Jilin, Gansu, Jiangsu, Anhui,\nShaanxi, Zhejiang, Henan, Chongqing, Jiangxi, Ningxia, Shandong, Fujian,\nHunan, Heilongjiang and Xinjiang have not reported any new probable cases\nin more than 20 days.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong Department of Health\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/2003/03-06-12e.htm>\n\n** Noteworthy - no new probable cases reported in the past 24 hours **\n\nSituation report on Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome 12 Jun 2003\n\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\n\nThere is no new confirmed case of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)\ntoday (12 Jun 2003). This is the 4th time that Hong Kong recorded zero\ninfection (the last 3 times were on 24 May 2003, 8 and 8 Jun 2003). It is\nalso the 28th consecutive day on which the number of cases has fallen below\n5 since 16 May 2003.\n\nThe number of patients recovered and discharged from hospital is 1377. Of\nthem, 3 were discharged today. The number of SARS patients in intensive\ncare unit is 17. These cases are part of the 58 cases under treatment in\nhospitals. 29 are recovering patients in convalescence and in preparation\nfor discharge. No fatality was reported. The cumulative total of deaths\nrelating to SARS remains at 291.\n\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with SARS since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\n\nCumulative no. cases/ total no. discharged patients/ total no. deaths\n(change in past 24 hours presented in parentheses, minus used for decrease)\n\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 386 (0)/ 362\n(1)/ (n/a)\nPatients, family members & visitors: 1369 (0)/ 1015 (2) / (n/a)\n\nTotal: 1755 (0)/ 1377 (3)/ 291 (0)\n\nTotal no. in hospital: 87 (-3)\nRecovering patients in convalescence: 29\nCases under treatment: 58 (-2) (including 17 patients in Intensive Care\nUnit)\n\nSuspected cases: 1\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n\nHealth Canada\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update79.html>\n\n\"Active\" cases include those hospitalized, currently ill at home, or under\ninvestigation.\n\nActive SARS cases in Canada\n---------------------\nDate: May 30/ Jun 2/ Jun 3/ Jun 4/ Jun 5/ Jun 6/ Jun 9/ Jun 10/ Jun 11/ Jun 12\n\nProbable (Active) 43/ 62/ 64/ 67/ 68/ 70/ 66/ 64/ 65/ 60\nSuspect (Active) 15/ 12/ 15/ 14/ 15/ 11/ 9/ 9/ 7/ 4\n\nTotal: 58/ 74/ 79/ 81/ 83/ 81/ 75/73/ 72/ 64\n\nThe changes in the case count and status of the SARS cases in the recent\ncluster in Ontario since yesterday are as follows: 3 new probable and 1 new\nsuspect case have been identified, 1 suspect case has been upgraded to\nprobable. The most recent date of onset of illness is 6 Jun 2003.\n\nNo new probable or suspect cases have been reported from other provinces\nand territories.\n\nAs of 12 Jun 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 434 probable or\nsuspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Canada. There\nhave been 34 deaths in Canada. To date, transmission has been limited to\nspecific transmission settings such as households, hospitals and specific\ncommunity settings.\n\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\n\nOntario is reporting 238 probable (60 active) and 133 suspect (4 active)\ncases.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 4 probable (0 active) and 46 suspect (0\nactive) cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect (0 active) case.\nNew Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases (0 active).\nAlberta is reporting 6 suspect cases (0 active).\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases (0 active).\nTotal no. of probables discharged or at home: 150\nTotal no. of suspects discharged or at home: 186\n\nThese numbers are accurate as of 1:00 PM EDST 12 Jun 2003.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[As of 12 Jun 2003 there have been a cumulative total of 8445 probable\ncases with 790 deaths reported from 29 countries. In the past 24 hours\nthere have been 13 new probable cases reported of which 8 were reported\nfrom Canada, 2 each were reported from Taiwan and the Philippines (the\ncases in the Philippines occurred in Feb but were recently confirmed\nthrough laboratory testing conducted in the UK) and 1 was reported from\nChina. There were no new cases reported from Hong Kong.\n\nThe report on the ongoing outbreak of SARS in Toronto is a sobering\nreminder of the difficulties in detection of cases in the absence of an\nimmediately apparent epidemiologic link to other cases. It begs the\nquestion at what point in time following presumed/apparent interruption of\ntransmission in an area that had had local transmission (greater than or\nequal to 20 days, using the standard \"2 incubation periods\" for the\ndefinition) an area can presume that atypical pneumonias are most probably\nnot due to SARS and therefore SARS level infection control procedures can\nbe dropped. Not an easy question to answer given the observed recurrence\nof active transmission in Ontario. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (143): cases 20030611.1441\nSARS - worldwide (142): cases 20030610.1434\nSARS - worldwide (141): cases 20030609.1423\nSARS - worldwide (140): cases 20030608.1419\nSARS - worldwide (139): cases 20030607.1409\nSARS - worldwide (93): etiology 20030505.1122\nSARS - worldwide (87): case definition and diagnostics 20030502.1103\nSARS - worldwide (85): clinical aspects 20030501.1094\nSARS - worldwide (69): diagnostic testing 20030425.1015\nSARS - worldwide (58): diagnostic testing 20030419.0958\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - Worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.........................mpp/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
