For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["1976-03-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "1972-03-16 00:00:00", "1971-03-16 00:00:00", "2069-03-16 00:00:00", "2068-03-16 00:00:00", "2064-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "2058-03-16 00:00:00", "2053-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2046-03-16 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00", "2038-03-16 00:00:00", "2034-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203703", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (75): diagnostic testing", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203703", "date": "2003-04-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (68): ETIOLOGY\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Data on \"shared mutations\" among SARS virus isolates\n[2] Two sequence variants from the same patient\n******\n[1]\nDate: Thurs 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\nUpdate on Shared Mutations\n--------------------------\nThe following update on shared mutations [see: SARS - worldwide (63):\netiology 20030423.0994] has been received from Dr Henry Niman.\nYesterday I gave several examples of mutations shared between CUHK-W1 and 5\nisolates from the mainland (GZ01, BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04). Since these\nmutations were well conserved among mainland isolates, but not found in\nother isolates linked to the Metropole Hotel, I thought that the data\nsupported a Metropole source containing a mixture of variants. Although\nCUHK-W1 was isolated from a patient from the Prince of Wales Hospital, I\nhave been informed by Dennis Lo and Stephen Tsui, who were involved in the\nsequencing of this isolate, that the patient was not one of the 138\npatients linked to the visitor of the Metropole Hotel. This patient had\ntraveled to Thailand and mainland China shortly before developing SARS\nsymptoms, suggesting an origin outside of Hong Kong, consistent with the\nshared mutations found with mainland China isolates.\nIn addition to the D-to-E mutation at position 5768 in orf1ab, which is\nfound in CUHK-W1, GZ01, BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, there is another mutation\nof a T changing to I at position 244 in E2. This amino acid is found in all\n6 isolates. Thus, these 2 sets of shared mutations define 2 hot spots where\n6 of the sequenced isolates have one amino acid while the other 4 have\nanother. This distribution raises the possibility that the true mutations\nare the amino acids shared by the Tor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849\nisolates. I have not yet been able to obtain the history of the HKU-39849\nisolate. However, there is another shared mutation at position 577 of E2 in\nwhich S replaces A. This mutation is found in KYK, which is from a tourist\nwho stayed at the Metropole Hotel. However, the mutation is shared with,\nBJ01 and GZ01, isolates from the mainland. This mutation is not seen in\nTor2 or Urbani, 2 isolates closely linked to the Metropole Hotel. Thus, the\ndistribution of this mutation supports the notion that the infections at\nthe Metropole Hotel involved a number of variants. As noted above, however,\nTor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849 share amino acids found at position 5769\nin orf1ab and position 244 in E2, which supports a more closely related\nsource of the infections at the Metropole Hotel.\nThese shared mutations, especially the 2 loci that are shared by the 5\nmainland isolates and CUHK-W1, support an etiological role for SARS\ncoronavirus in SARS.\nHere is the list of shared mutations:\n(1) orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]:\n3047 V to A [Val to Ala] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, CUHK-W1\n3072 V to A [Val to Ala] in CUHK-W1*\n3196 A to V [Ala to Val} in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03\n5768 D to E [Asp to Glu] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n(2) E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]:\n77 G to D [Gly toAsp] in BJ03, CUHK-W1\n244 T to I [Thr to Ile] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n577 A to S [Ala to Ser] in KYK, BJ01, GZ01\n(3) N [putative nucleoprotein gene]\n387 N to P [Asn to Pro] in GZ01, BJ02\n* This change is only in CUHK-W1, not BJ01, BJ02, BJ03 as reported\nyesterday [see: SARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994] - the 3\nBeijing isolates have a shared mutation at position 3196, which is A to V,\nas well as V to A change at position 3047.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[For the benefit of readers, the key to the virus isolates identified above\nis the following:\nTor2 (Toronto)\nCUHK-W1 (Hong Kong)\nUrbani (Hanoi/Bangkok)\nKYK (Singapore)\nHKU-39849 (Hong Kong)\nGZ01 (Guangzhou)\nBJ01 (Beijing)\nBJ02 (Beijing)\nBJ03 (Beijing)\nBJ04 (Beijing)\n- Mod.CP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\n2 distinct SARS virus variants from the same patient\n----------------------------------------------------\nThis issue of SARS mutations will likely be viewed with increased interest.\nMore information is now available on the 5 isolates from mainland China\n<http://www.genomics.org.cn:8080/bgi/news/zhongxin/news030416-2_fasta.htm>.\nOne area of interest is a comparisons of mutations in 2 isolates (BJ01 and\nBJ03) from the same individual. The partial data have been submitted to\nGenebank, and it is possible that there are some sequencing errors, but the\ndata are quite strong for multiple variants in the same individual.\nThere are 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03. 2 of them are found in\nall 5 mainland china isolates as well as CUHK-W1, and the 4 other isolates\nmay be the true mutations. The 2 widely shared alterations are at position\n5768 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene] (D changing to E) and I\nchanging to T at position 244 in E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]. Another\nmutation shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1 (V\nchanging to A at position 3196). This change is found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1\nat position 3047 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]. The fourth\nchange shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 (A changing to V\nat position 3196 in orf1ab).\nHowever, in addition to the 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03, each\nisolate has mutations not shared. BJ01 has 3 additional mutations not\nshared with the 9 other isolates. All 3 changes are in orf1ab at positions\n1718 (L to W), 2230 (A to V), and 2770 (V to I). Since these changes have\nnot been seen elsewhere, sequencing errors remain a possibility (although\nnot likely).\nIn contrast, BJ03 also has 3 mutations not found in BJ01, but 2 of these\nmutations have been found in other isolates, reducing the likelihood that\nthey are due to sequencing errors. The mutation unique to BJ03 is also in\norf1ab at position 3426 (V to I). Of interest are the 2 other mutations in\nE2. At position 78, the change of G to D is also found in CUHK-W1, while\nthe A to S change at position 577 is also found in KYK and GZ01, which were\nfrom patients in Singapore and Guangzhou, respectively.\nThe finding of this A to S mutation in isolates from 2 other geographically\ndistinct regions, but not in another isolate from the same patient, raises\nissues of multiple variants within the same patient as well as tissue\ntropism linked to specific amino acid changes.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[All RNA viruses by their nature are inherently highly mutable; while these\nsequence comparisons of a small number of SARS coronavirus isolates are\nintriguing, it is perhaps too early to speculate on the biological\nsignificance of any of these variable sites. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (67): cases 20030424.1007\nSARS - worldwide (64): etiology 20030423.0996\nSARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994\nSARS - worldwide (58): diagnostic testing 20030419.0958\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0935\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (46): diagnostic test 20030413.0901\nSARS - worldwide (44): UK transmission suspected 20030412.0887\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (41):overview 20030411.0876\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - Worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.....................cp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2068-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "5768-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "3196-03-16 00:00:00", "3047-03-16 00:00:00", "5768-03-16 00:00:00", "3047-03-16 00:00:00", "1718-03-16 00:00:00", "2230-03-16 00:00:00", "2770-03-16 00:00:00", "3426-03-16 00:00:00", "1978-03-16 00:00:00", "2064-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "2058-03-16 00:00:00", "2053-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2046-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00", "2038-03-16 00:00:00", "2034-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HKU-39849", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Metropole", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "GZ01", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "E2", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "BJ02", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangzhou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203701", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (74): etiology", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203701", "date": "2003-04-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (68): ETIOLOGY\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Data on \"shared mutations\" among SARS virus isolates\n[2] Two sequence variants from the same patient\n******\n[1]\nDate: Thurs 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\nUpdate on Shared Mutations\n--------------------------\nThe following update on shared mutations [see: SARS - worldwide (63):\netiology 20030423.0994] has been received from Dr Henry Niman.\nYesterday I gave several examples of mutations shared between CUHK-W1 and 5\nisolates from the mainland (GZ01, BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04). Since these\nmutations were well conserved among mainland isolates, but not found in\nother isolates linked to the Metropole Hotel, I thought that the data\nsupported a Metropole source containing a mixture of variants. Although\nCUHK-W1 was isolated from a patient from the Prince of Wales Hospital, I\nhave been informed by Dennis Lo and Stephen Tsui, who were involved in the\nsequencing of this isolate, that the patient was not one of the 138\npatients linked to the visitor of the Metropole Hotel. This patient had\ntraveled to Thailand and mainland China shortly before developing SARS\nsymptoms, suggesting an origin outside of Hong Kong, consistent with the\nshared mutations found with mainland China isolates.\nIn addition to the D-to-E mutation at position 5768 in orf1ab, which is\nfound in CUHK-W1, GZ01, BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, there is another mutation\nof a T changing to I at position 244 in E2. This amino acid is found in all\n6 isolates. Thus, these 2 sets of shared mutations define 2 hot spots where\n6 of the sequenced isolates have one amino acid while the other 4 have\nanother. This distribution raises the possibility that the true mutations\nare the amino acids shared by the Tor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849\nisolates. I have not yet been able to obtain the history of the HKU-39849\nisolate. However, there is another shared mutation at position 577 of E2 in\nwhich S replaces A. This mutation is found in KYK, which is from a tourist\nwho stayed at the Metropole Hotel. However, the mutation is shared with,\nBJ01 and GZ01, isolates from the mainland. This mutation is not seen in\nTor2 or Urbani, 2 isolates closely linked to the Metropole Hotel. Thus, the\ndistribution of this mutation supports the notion that the infections at\nthe Metropole Hotel involved a number of variants. As noted above, however,\nTor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849 share amino acids found at position 5769\nin orf1ab and position 244 in E2, which supports a more closely related\nsource of the infections at the Metropole Hotel.\nThese shared mutations, especially the 2 loci that are shared by the 5\nmainland isolates and CUHK-W1, support an etiological role for SARS\ncoronavirus in SARS.\nHere is the list of shared mutations:\n(1) orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]:\n3047 V to A [Val to Ala] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, CUHK-W1\n3072 V to A [Val to Ala] in CUHK-W1*\n3196 A to V [Ala to Val} in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03\n5768 D to E [Asp to Glu] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n(2) E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]:\n77 G to D [Gly toAsp] in BJ03, CUHK-W1\n244 T to I [Thr to Ile] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n577 A to S [Ala to Ser] in KYK, BJ01, GZ01\n(3) N [putative nucleoprotein gene]\n387 N to P [Asn to Pro] in GZ01, BJ02\n* This change is only in CUHK-W1, not BJ01, BJ02, BJ03 as reported\nyesterday [see: SARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994] - the 3\nBeijing isolates have a shared mutation at position 3196, which is A to V,\nas well as V to A change at position 3047.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[For the benefit of readers, the key to the virus isolates identified above\nis the following:\nTor2 (Toronto)\nCUHK-W1 (Hong Kong)\nUrbani (Hanoi/Bangkok)\nKYK (Singapore)\nHKU-39849 (Hong Kong)\nGZ01 (Guangzhou)\nBJ01 (Beijing)\nBJ02 (Beijing)\nBJ03 (Beijing)\nBJ04 (Beijing)\n- Mod.CP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\n2 distinct SARS virus variants from the same patient\n----------------------------------------------------\nThis issue of SARS mutations will likely be viewed with increased interest.\nMore information is now available on the 5 isolates from mainland China\n<http://www.genomics.org.cn:8080/bgi/news/zhongxin/news030416-2_fasta.htm>.\nOne area of interest is a comparisons of mutations in 2 isolates (BJ01 and\nBJ03) from the same individual. The partial data have been submitted to\nGenebank, and it is possible that there are some sequencing errors, but the\ndata are quite strong for multiple variants in the same individual.\nThere are 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03. 2 of them are found in\nall 5 mainland china isolates as well as CUHK-W1, and the 4 other isolates\nmay be the true mutations. The 2 widely shared alterations are at position\n5768 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene] (D changing to E) and I\nchanging to T at position 244 in E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]. Another\nmutation shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1 (V\nchanging to A at position 3196). This change is found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1\nat position 3047 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]. The fourth\nchange shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 (A changing to V\nat position 3196 in orf1ab).\nHowever, in addition to the 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03, each\nisolate has mutations not shared. BJ01 has 3 additional mutations not\nshared with the 9 other isolates. All 3 changes are in orf1ab at positions\n1718 (L to W), 2230 (A to V), and 2770 (V to I). Since these changes have\nnot been seen elsewhere, sequencing errors remain a possibility (although\nnot likely).\nIn contrast, BJ03 also has 3 mutations not found in BJ01, but 2 of these\nmutations have been found in other isolates, reducing the likelihood that\nthey are due to sequencing errors. The mutation unique to BJ03 is also in\norf1ab at position 3426 (V to I). Of interest are the 2 other mutations in\nE2. At position 78, the change of G to D is also found in CUHK-W1, while\nthe A to S change at position 577 is also found in KYK and GZ01, which were\nfrom patients in Singapore and Guangzhou, respectively.\nThe finding of this A to S mutation in isolates from 2 other geographically\ndistinct regions, but not in another isolate from the same patient, raises\nissues of multiple variants within the same patient as well as tissue\ntropism linked to specific amino acid changes.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[All RNA viruses by their nature are inherently highly mutable; while these\nsequence comparisons of a small number of SARS coronavirus isolates are\nintriguing, it is perhaps too early to speculate on the biological\nsignificance of any of these variable sites. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (67): cases 20030424.1007\nSARS - worldwide (64): etiology 20030423.0996\nSARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994\nSARS - worldwide (58): diagnostic testing 20030419.0958\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0935\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (46): diagnostic test 20030413.0901\nSARS - worldwide (44): UK transmission suspected 20030412.0887\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (41):overview 20030411.0876\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - Worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.....................cp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. worldwide (63):\netiology 20030423.0994] has been received from Dr Henry Niman.\nYesterday I gave several examples of mutations shared between CUHK-W1 and 5\nisolates from the mainland (GZ01, BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04). This distribution raises the possibility that the true mutations\nare the amino acids shared by the Tor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849\nisolates. I have not yet been able to obtain the history of the HKU-39849\nisolate. However, there is another shared mutation at position 577 of E2 in\nwhich S replaces A. This mutation is found in KYK, which is from a tourist\nwho stayed at the Metropole Hotel. However, the mutation is shared with,\nBJ01 and GZ01, isolates from the mainland. This mutation is not seen in\nTor2 or Urbani, 2 isolates closely linked to the Metropole Hotel. Thus, the\ndistribution of this mutation supports the notion that the infections at\nthe Metropole Hotel involved a number of variants. As noted above, however,\nTor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849 share amino acids found at position 5769\nin orf1ab and position 244 in E2, which supports a more closely related\nsource of the infections at the Metropole Hotel.\nThese shared mutations, especially the 2 loci that are shared by the 5\nmainland isolates and CUHK-W1, support an etiological role for SARS\ncoronavirus in SARS.\nHere is the list of shared mutations:\n(1) orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]:\n3047 V to A [Val to Ala] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, CUHK-W1\n3072 V to A [Val to Ala] in CUHK-W1*\n3196 A to V [Ala to Val} in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03\n5768 D to E [Asp to Glu] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n(2) E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]:\n77 G to D [Gly toAsp] in BJ03, CUHK-W1\n244 T to I [Thr to Ile] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n577 A to S [Ala to Ser] in KYK, BJ01, GZ01\n(3) N [putative nucleoprotein gene]\n387 N to P [Asn to Pro] in GZ01, BJ02\n* This change is only in CUHK-W1, not BJ01, BJ02, BJ03 as reported\nyesterday [see: SARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994] - the 3\nBeijing isolates have a shared mutation at position 3196, which is A to V,\nas well as V to A change at position 3047.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[For the benefit of readers, the key to the virus isolates identified above\nis the following:\nTor2 (Toronto)\nCUHK-W1 (Hong Kong)\nUrbani (Hanoi/Bangkok)\nKYK (Singapore)\nHKU-39849 (Hong Kong)\nGZ01 (Guangzhou)\nBJ01 (Beijing)\nBJ02 (Beijing)\nBJ03 (Beijing)\nBJ04 (Beijing)\n- Mod.CP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\n2 distinct SARS virus variants from the same patient\n----------------------------------------------------\nThis issue of SARS mutations will likely be viewed with increased interest.\nMore information is now available on the 5 isolates from mainland China\n<http://www.genomics.org.cn:8080/bgi/news/zhongxin/news030416-2_fasta.htm>.\nOne area of interest is a comparisons of mutations in 2 isolates (BJ01 and\nBJ03) from the same individual. The partial data have been submitted to\nGenebank, and it is possible that there are some sequencing errors, but the\ndata are quite strong for multiple variants in the same individual.\nThere are 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03. 2 of them are found in\nall 5 mainland china isolates as well as CUHK-W1, and the 4 other isolates\nmay be the true mutations. The 2 widely shared alterations are at position\n5768 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene] (D changing to E) and I\nchanging to T at position 244 in E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]. Another\nmutation shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1 (V\nchanging to A at position 3196). This change is found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1\nat position 3047 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]. The fourth\nchange shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 (A changing to V\nat position 3196 in orf1ab).\nHowever, in addition to the 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03, each\nisolate has mutations not shared. BJ01 has 3 additional mutations not\nshared with the 9 other isolates. All 3 changes are in orf1ab at positions\n1718 (L to W), 2230 (A to V), and 2770 (V to I). Since these changes have\nnot been seen elsewhere, sequencing errors remain a possibility (although\nnot likely).\nIn contrast, BJ03 also has 3 mutations not found in BJ01, but 2 of these\nmutations have been found in other isolates, reducing the likelihood that\nthey are due to sequencing errors. The mutation unique to BJ03 is also in\norf1ab at position 3426 (V to I). Of interest are the 2 other mutations in\nE2. At position 78, the change of G to D is also found in CUHK-W1, while\nthe A to S change at position 577 is also found in KYK and GZ01, which were\nfrom patients in Singapore and Guangzhou, respectively.\nThe finding of this A to S mutation in isolates from 2 other geographically\ndistinct regions, but not in another isolate from the same patient, raises\nissues of multiple variants within the same patient as well as tissue\ntropism linked to specific amino acid changes.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[All RNA viruses by their nature are inherently highly mutable; worldwide (72): treatment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203699", "date": "2003-04-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (68): ETIOLOGY\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Data on \"shared mutations\" among SARS virus isolates\n[2] Two sequence variants from the same patient\n******\n[1]\nDate: Thurs 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\nUpdate on Shared Mutations\n--------------------------\nThe following update on shared mutations [see: SARS - worldwide (63):\netiology 20030423.0994] has been received from Dr Henry Niman.\nYesterday I gave several examples of mutations shared between CUHK-W1 and 5\nisolates from the mainland (GZ01, BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04). Since these\nmutations were well conserved among mainland isolates, but not found in\nother isolates linked to the Metropole Hotel, I thought that the data\nsupported a Metropole source containing a mixture of variants. Although\nCUHK-W1 was isolated from a patient from the Prince of Wales Hospital, I\nhave been informed by Dennis Lo and Stephen Tsui, who were involved in the\nsequencing of this isolate, that the patient was not one of the 138\npatients linked to the visitor of the Metropole Hotel. This patient had\ntraveled to Thailand and mainland China shortly before developing SARS\nsymptoms, suggesting an origin outside of Hong Kong, consistent with the\nshared mutations found with mainland China isolates.\nIn addition to the D-to-E mutation at position 5768 in orf1ab, which is\nfound in CUHK-W1, GZ01, BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, there is another mutation\nof a T changing to I at position 244 in E2. This amino acid is found in all\n6 isolates. Thus, these 2 sets of shared mutations define 2 hot spots where\n6 of the sequenced isolates have one amino acid while the other 4 have\nanother. This distribution raises the possibility that the true mutations\nare the amino acids shared by the Tor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849\nisolates. I have not yet been able to obtain the history of the HKU-39849\nisolate. However, there is another shared mutation at position 577 of E2 in\nwhich S replaces A. This mutation is found in KYK, which is from a tourist\nwho stayed at the Metropole Hotel. However, the mutation is shared with,\nBJ01 and GZ01, isolates from the mainland. This mutation is not seen in\nTor2 or Urbani, 2 isolates closely linked to the Metropole Hotel. Thus, the\ndistribution of this mutation supports the notion that the infections at\nthe Metropole Hotel involved a number of variants. As noted above, however,\nTor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849 share amino acids found at position 5769\nin orf1ab and position 244 in E2, which supports a more closely related\nsource of the infections at the Metropole Hotel.\nThese shared mutations, especially the 2 loci that are shared by the 5\nmainland isolates and CUHK-W1, support an etiological role for SARS\ncoronavirus in SARS.\nHere is the list of shared mutations:\n(1) orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]:\n3047 V to A [Val to Ala] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, CUHK-W1\n3072 V to A [Val to Ala] in CUHK-W1*\n3196 A to V [Ala to Val} in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03\n5768 D to E [Asp to Glu] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n(2) E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]:\n77 G to D [Gly toAsp] in BJ03, CUHK-W1\n244 T to I [Thr to Ile] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n577 A to S [Ala to Ser] in KYK, BJ01, GZ01\n(3) N [putative nucleoprotein gene]\n387 N to P [Asn to Pro] in GZ01, BJ02\n* This change is only in CUHK-W1, not BJ01, BJ02, BJ03 as reported\nyesterday [see: SARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994] - the 3\nBeijing isolates have a shared mutation at position 3196, which is A to V,\nas well as V to A change at position 3047.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[For the benefit of readers, the key to the virus isolates identified above\nis the following:\nTor2 (Toronto)\nCUHK-W1 (Hong Kong)\nUrbani (Hanoi/Bangkok)\nKYK (Singapore)\nHKU-39849 (Hong Kong)\nGZ01 (Guangzhou)\nBJ01 (Beijing)\nBJ02 (Beijing)\nBJ03 (Beijing)\nBJ04 (Beijing)\n- Mod.CP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\n2 distinct SARS virus variants from the same patient\n----------------------------------------------------\nThis issue of SARS mutations will likely be viewed with increased interest.\nMore information is now available on the 5 isolates from mainland China\n<http://www.genomics.org.cn:8080/bgi/news/zhongxin/news030416-2_fasta.htm>.\nOne area of interest is a comparisons of mutations in 2 isolates (BJ01 and\nBJ03) from the same individual. The partial data have been submitted to\nGenebank, and it is possible that there are some sequencing errors, but the\ndata are quite strong for multiple variants in the same individual.\nThere are 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03. 2 of them are found in\nall 5 mainland china isolates as well as CUHK-W1, and the 4 other isolates\nmay be the true mutations. The 2 widely shared alterations are at position\n5768 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene] (D changing to E) and I\nchanging to T at position 244 in E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]. Another\nmutation shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1 (V\nchanging to A at position 3196). This change is found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1\nat position 3047 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]. The fourth\nchange shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 (A changing to V\nat position 3196 in orf1ab).\nHowever, in addition to the 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03, each\nisolate has mutations not shared. BJ01 has 3 additional mutations not\nshared with the 9 other isolates. All 3 changes are in orf1ab at positions\n1718 (L to W), 2230 (A to V), and 2770 (V to I). Since these changes have\nnot been seen elsewhere, sequencing errors remain a possibility (although\nnot likely).\nIn contrast, BJ03 also has 3 mutations not found in BJ01, but 2 of these\nmutations have been found in other isolates, reducing the likelihood that\nthey are due to sequencing errors. The mutation unique to BJ03 is also in\norf1ab at position 3426 (V to I). Of interest are the 2 other mutations in\nE2. At position 78, the change of G to D is also found in CUHK-W1, while\nthe A to S change at position 577 is also found in KYK and GZ01, which were\nfrom patients in Singapore and Guangzhou, respectively.\nThe finding of this A to S mutation in isolates from 2 other geographically\ndistinct regions, but not in another isolate from the same patient, raises\nissues of multiple variants within the same patient as well as tissue\ntropism linked to specific amino acid changes.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[All RNA viruses by their nature are inherently highly mutable; while these\nsequence comparisons of a small number of SARS coronavirus isolates are\nintriguing, it is perhaps too early to speculate on the biological\nsignificance of any of these variable sites. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (67): cases 20030424.1007\nSARS - worldwide (64): etiology 20030423.0996\nSARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994\nSARS - worldwide (58): diagnostic testing 20030419.0958\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0935\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (46): diagnostic test 20030413.0901\nSARS - worldwide (44): UK transmission suspected 20030412.0887\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (41):overview 20030411.0876\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - Worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.....................cp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2068-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "5768-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "3196-03-16 00:00:00", "3047-03-16 00:00:00", "5768-03-16 00:00:00", "3047-03-16 00:00:00", "1718-03-16 00:00:00", "2230-03-16 00:00:00", "2770-03-16 00:00:00", "3426-03-16 00:00:00", "1978-03-16 00:00:00", "2064-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "2058-03-16 00:00:00", "2053-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2046-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00", "2038-03-16 00:00:00", "2034-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HKU-39849", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Metropole", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "GZ01", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "E2", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "BJ02", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangzhou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203694", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (71): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203694", "date": "2003-04-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (68): ETIOLOGY\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Data on \"shared mutations\" among SARS virus isolates\n[2] Two sequence variants from the same patient\n******\n[1]\nDate: Thurs 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\nUpdate on Shared Mutations\n--------------------------\nThe following update on shared mutations [see: SARS - worldwide (63):\netiology 20030423.0994] has been received from Dr Henry Niman.\nYesterday I gave several examples of mutations shared between CUHK-W1 and 5\nisolates from the mainland (GZ01, BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04). Since these\nmutations were well conserved among mainland isolates, but not found in\nother isolates linked to the Metropole Hotel, I thought that the data\nsupported a Metropole source containing a mixture of variants. Although\nCUHK-W1 was isolated from a patient from the Prince of Wales Hospital, I\nhave been informed by Dennis Lo and Stephen Tsui, who were involved in the\nsequencing of this isolate, that the patient was not one of the 138\npatients linked to the visitor of the Metropole Hotel. This patient had\ntraveled to Thailand and mainland China shortly before developing SARS\nsymptoms, suggesting an origin outside of Hong Kong, consistent with the\nshared mutations found with mainland China isolates.\nIn addition to the D-to-E mutation at position 5768 in orf1ab, which is\nfound in CUHK-W1, GZ01, BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, there is another mutation\nof a T changing to I at position 244 in E2. This amino acid is found in all\n6 isolates. Thus, these 2 sets of shared mutations define 2 hot spots where\n6 of the sequenced isolates have one amino acid while the other 4 have\nanother. This distribution raises the possibility that the true mutations\nare the amino acids shared by the Tor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849\nisolates. I have not yet been able to obtain the history of the HKU-39849\nisolate. However, there is another shared mutation at position 577 of E2 in\nwhich S replaces A. This mutation is found in KYK, which is from a tourist\nwho stayed at the Metropole Hotel. However, the mutation is shared with,\nBJ01 and GZ01, isolates from the mainland. This mutation is not seen in\nTor2 or Urbani, 2 isolates closely linked to the Metropole Hotel. Thus, the\ndistribution of this mutation supports the notion that the infections at\nthe Metropole Hotel involved a number of variants. As noted above, however,\nTor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849 share amino acids found at position 5769\nin orf1ab and position 244 in E2, which supports a more closely related\nsource of the infections at the Metropole Hotel.\nThese shared mutations, especially the 2 loci that are shared by the 5\nmainland isolates and CUHK-W1, support an etiological role for SARS\ncoronavirus in SARS.\nHere is the list of shared mutations:\n(1) orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]:\n3047 V to A [Val to Ala] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, CUHK-W1\n3072 V to A [Val to Ala] in CUHK-W1*\n3196 A to V [Ala to Val} in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03\n5768 D to E [Asp to Glu] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n(2) E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]:\n77 G to D [Gly toAsp] in BJ03, CUHK-W1\n244 T to I [Thr to Ile] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n577 A to S [Ala to Ser] in KYK, BJ01, GZ01\n(3) N [putative nucleoprotein gene]\n387 N to P [Asn to Pro] in GZ01, BJ02\n* This change is only in CUHK-W1, not BJ01, BJ02, BJ03 as reported\nyesterday [see: SARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994] - the 3\nBeijing isolates have a shared mutation at position 3196, which is A to V,\nas well as V to A change at position 3047.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[For the benefit of readers, the key to the virus isolates identified above\nis the following:\nTor2 (Toronto)\nCUHK-W1 (Hong Kong)\nUrbani (Hanoi/Bangkok)\nKYK (Singapore)\nHKU-39849 (Hong Kong)\nGZ01 (Guangzhou)\nBJ01 (Beijing)\nBJ02 (Beijing)\nBJ03 (Beijing)\nBJ04 (Beijing)\n- Mod.CP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\n2 distinct SARS virus variants from the same patient\n----------------------------------------------------\nThis issue of SARS mutations will likely be viewed with increased interest.\nMore information is now available on the 5 isolates from mainland China\n<http://www.genomics.org.cn:8080/bgi/news/zhongxin/news030416-2_fasta.htm>.\nOne area of interest is a comparisons of mutations in 2 isolates (BJ01 and\nBJ03) from the same individual. The partial data have been submitted to\nGenebank, and it is possible that there are some sequencing errors, but the\ndata are quite strong for multiple variants in the same individual.\nThere are 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03. 2 of them are found in\nall 5 mainland china isolates as well as CUHK-W1, and the 4 other isolates\nmay be the true mutations. The 2 widely shared alterations are at position\n5768 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene] (D changing to E) and I\nchanging to T at position 244 in E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]. Another\nmutation shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1 (V\nchanging to A at position 3196). This change is found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1\nat position 3047 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]. The fourth\nchange shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 (A changing to V\nat position 3196 in orf1ab).\nHowever, in addition to the 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03, each\nisolate has mutations not shared. BJ01 has 3 additional mutations not\nshared with the 9 other isolates. All 3 changes are in orf1ab at positions\n1718 (L to W), 2230 (A to V), and 2770 (V to I). Since these changes have\nnot been seen elsewhere, sequencing errors remain a possibility (although\nnot likely).\nIn contrast, BJ03 also has 3 mutations not found in BJ01, but 2 of these\nmutations have been found in other isolates, reducing the likelihood that\nthey are due to sequencing errors. The mutation unique to BJ03 is also in\norf1ab at position 3426 (V to I). Of interest are the 2 other mutations in\nE2. At position 78, the change of G to D is also found in CUHK-W1, while\nthe A to S change at position 577 is also found in KYK and GZ01, which were\nfrom patients in Singapore and Guangzhou, respectively.\nThe finding of this A to S mutation in isolates from 2 other geographically\ndistinct regions, but not in another isolate from the same patient, raises\nissues of multiple variants within the same patient as well as tissue\ntropism linked to specific amino acid changes.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[All RNA viruses by their nature are inherently highly mutable; while these\nsequence comparisons of a small number of SARS coronavirus isolates are\nintriguing, it is perhaps too early to speculate on the biological\nsignificance of any of these variable sites. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (67): cases 20030424.1007\nSARS - worldwide (64): etiology 20030423.0996\nSARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994\nSARS - worldwide (58): diagnostic testing 20030419.0958\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0935\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (46): diagnostic test 20030413.0901\nSARS - worldwide (44): UK transmission suspected 20030412.0887\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (41):overview 20030411.0876\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - Worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.....................cp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2068-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "5768-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "3196-03-16 00:00:00", "3047-03-16 00:00:00", "5768-03-16 00:00:00", "3047-03-16 00:00:00", "1718-03-16 00:00:00", "2230-03-16 00:00:00", "2770-03-16 00:00:00", "3426-03-16 00:00:00", "1978-03-16 00:00:00", "2064-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "2058-03-16 00:00:00", "2053-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2046-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00", "2038-03-16 00:00:00", "2034-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HKU-39849", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Metropole", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "GZ01", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "E2", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "BJ02", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangzhou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203687", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (69): diagnostic testing", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203687", "date": "2003-04-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (68): ETIOLOGY\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Data on \"shared mutations\" among SARS virus isolates\n[2] Two sequence variants from the same patient\n******\n[1]\nDate: Thurs 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\nUpdate on Shared Mutations\n--------------------------\nThe following update on shared mutations [see: SARS - worldwide (63):\netiology 20030423.0994] has been received from Dr Henry Niman.\nYesterday I gave several examples of mutations shared between CUHK-W1 and 5\nisolates from the mainland (GZ01, BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04). Since these\nmutations were well conserved among mainland isolates, but not found in\nother isolates linked to the Metropole Hotel, I thought that the data\nsupported a Metropole source containing a mixture of variants. Although\nCUHK-W1 was isolated from a patient from the Prince of Wales Hospital, I\nhave been informed by Dennis Lo and Stephen Tsui, who were involved in the\nsequencing of this isolate, that the patient was not one of the 138\npatients linked to the visitor of the Metropole Hotel. This patient had\ntraveled to Thailand and mainland China shortly before developing SARS\nsymptoms, suggesting an origin outside of Hong Kong, consistent with the\nshared mutations found with mainland China isolates.\nIn addition to the D-to-E mutation at position 5768 in orf1ab, which is\nfound in CUHK-W1, GZ01, BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, there is another mutation\nof a T changing to I at position 244 in E2. This amino acid is found in all\n6 isolates. Thus, these 2 sets of shared mutations define 2 hot spots where\n6 of the sequenced isolates have one amino acid while the other 4 have\nanother. This distribution raises the possibility that the true mutations\nare the amino acids shared by the Tor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849\nisolates. I have not yet been able to obtain the history of the HKU-39849\nisolate. However, there is another shared mutation at position 577 of E2 in\nwhich S replaces A. This mutation is found in KYK, which is from a tourist\nwho stayed at the Metropole Hotel. However, the mutation is shared with,\nBJ01 and GZ01, isolates from the mainland. This mutation is not seen in\nTor2 or Urbani, 2 isolates closely linked to the Metropole Hotel. Thus, the\ndistribution of this mutation supports the notion that the infections at\nthe Metropole Hotel involved a number of variants. As noted above, however,\nTor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849 share amino acids found at position 5769\nin orf1ab and position 244 in E2, which supports a more closely related\nsource of the infections at the Metropole Hotel.\nThese shared mutations, especially the 2 loci that are shared by the 5\nmainland isolates and CUHK-W1, support an etiological role for SARS\ncoronavirus in SARS.\nHere is the list of shared mutations:\n(1) orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]:\n3047 V to A [Val to Ala] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, CUHK-W1\n3072 V to A [Val to Ala] in CUHK-W1*\n3196 A to V [Ala to Val} in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03\n5768 D to E [Asp to Glu] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n(2) E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]:\n77 G to D [Gly toAsp] in BJ03, CUHK-W1\n244 T to I [Thr to Ile] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n577 A to S [Ala to Ser] in KYK, BJ01, GZ01\n(3) N [putative nucleoprotein gene]\n387 N to P [Asn to Pro] in GZ01, BJ02\n* This change is only in CUHK-W1, not BJ01, BJ02, BJ03 as reported\nyesterday [see: SARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994] - the 3\nBeijing isolates have a shared mutation at position 3196, which is A to V,\nas well as V to A change at position 3047.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[For the benefit of readers, the key to the virus isolates identified above\nis the following:\nTor2 (Toronto)\nCUHK-W1 (Hong Kong)\nUrbani (Hanoi/Bangkok)\nKYK (Singapore)\nHKU-39849 (Hong Kong)\nGZ01 (Guangzhou)\nBJ01 (Beijing)\nBJ02 (Beijing)\nBJ03 (Beijing)\nBJ04 (Beijing)\n- Mod.CP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\n2 distinct SARS virus variants from the same patient\n----------------------------------------------------\nThis issue of SARS mutations will likely be viewed with increased interest.\nMore information is now available on the 5 isolates from mainland China\n<http://www.genomics.org.cn:8080/bgi/news/zhongxin/news030416-2_fasta.htm>.\nOne area of interest is a comparisons of mutations in 2 isolates (BJ01 and\nBJ03) from the same individual. The partial data have been submitted to\nGenebank, and it is possible that there are some sequencing errors, but the\ndata are quite strong for multiple variants in the same individual.\nThere are 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03. 2 of them are found in\nall 5 mainland china isolates as well as CUHK-W1, and the 4 other isolates\nmay be the true mutations. The 2 widely shared alterations are at position\n5768 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene] (D changing to E) and I\nchanging to T at position 244 in E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]. Another\nmutation shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1 (V\nchanging to A at position 3196). This change is found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1\nat position 3047 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]. The fourth\nchange shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 (A changing to V\nat position 3196 in orf1ab).\nHowever, in addition to the 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03, each\nisolate has mutations not shared. BJ01 has 3 additional mutations not\nshared with the 9 other isolates. All 3 changes are in orf1ab at positions\n1718 (L to W), 2230 (A to V), and 2770 (V to I). Since these changes have\nnot been seen elsewhere, sequencing errors remain a possibility (although\nnot likely).\nIn contrast, BJ03 also has 3 mutations not found in BJ01, but 2 of these\nmutations have been found in other isolates, reducing the likelihood that\nthey are due to sequencing errors. The mutation unique to BJ03 is also in\norf1ab at position 3426 (V to I). Of interest are the 2 other mutations in\nE2. At position 78, the change of G to D is also found in CUHK-W1, while\nthe A to S change at position 577 is also found in KYK and GZ01, which were\nfrom patients in Singapore and Guangzhou, respectively.\nThe finding of this A to S mutation in isolates from 2 other geographically\ndistinct regions, but not in another isolate from the same patient, raises\nissues of multiple variants within the same patient as well as tissue\ntropism linked to specific amino acid changes.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[All RNA viruses by their nature are inherently highly mutable; while these\nsequence comparisons of a small number of SARS coronavirus isolates are\nintriguing, it is perhaps too early to speculate on the biological\nsignificance of any of these variable sites. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (67): cases 20030424.1007\nSARS - worldwide (64): etiology 20030423.0996\nSARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994\nSARS - worldwide (58): diagnostic testing 20030419.0958\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0935\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (46): diagnostic test 20030413.0901\nSARS - worldwide (44): UK transmission suspected 20030412.0887\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (41):overview 20030411.0876\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - Worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.....................cp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2068-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "5768-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "3196-03-16 00:00:00", "3047-03-16 00:00:00", "5768-03-16 00:00:00", "3047-03-16 00:00:00", "1718-03-16 00:00:00", "2230-03-16 00:00:00", "2770-03-16 00:00:00", "3426-03-16 00:00:00", "1978-03-16 00:00:00", "2064-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "2058-03-16 00:00:00", "2053-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2046-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00", "2038-03-16 00:00:00", "2034-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HKU-39849", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Metropole", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "GZ01", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "E2", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "BJ02", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangzhou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203685", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (70): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203685", "date": "2003-04-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (68): ETIOLOGY\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Data on \"shared mutations\" among SARS virus isolates\n[2] Two sequence variants from the same patient\n******\n[1]\nDate: Thurs 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\nUpdate on Shared Mutations\n--------------------------\nThe following update on shared mutations [see: SARS - worldwide (63):\netiology 20030423.0994] has been received from Dr Henry Niman.\nYesterday I gave several examples of mutations shared between CUHK-W1 and 5\nisolates from the mainland (GZ01, BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04). Since these\nmutations were well conserved among mainland isolates, but not found in\nother isolates linked to the Metropole Hotel, I thought that the data\nsupported a Metropole source containing a mixture of variants. Although\nCUHK-W1 was isolated from a patient from the Prince of Wales Hospital, I\nhave been informed by Dennis Lo and Stephen Tsui, who were involved in the\nsequencing of this isolate, that the patient was not one of the 138\npatients linked to the visitor of the Metropole Hotel. This patient had\ntraveled to Thailand and mainland China shortly before developing SARS\nsymptoms, suggesting an origin outside of Hong Kong, consistent with the\nshared mutations found with mainland China isolates.\nIn addition to the D-to-E mutation at position 5768 in orf1ab, which is\nfound in CUHK-W1, GZ01, BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, there is another mutation\nof a T changing to I at position 244 in E2. This amino acid is found in all\n6 isolates. Thus, these 2 sets of shared mutations define 2 hot spots where\n6 of the sequenced isolates have one amino acid while the other 4 have\nanother. This distribution raises the possibility that the true mutations\nare the amino acids shared by the Tor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849\nisolates. I have not yet been able to obtain the history of the HKU-39849\nisolate. However, there is another shared mutation at position 577 of E2 in\nwhich S replaces A. This mutation is found in KYK, which is from a tourist\nwho stayed at the Metropole Hotel. However, the mutation is shared with,\nBJ01 and GZ01, isolates from the mainland. This mutation is not seen in\nTor2 or Urbani, 2 isolates closely linked to the Metropole Hotel. Thus, the\ndistribution of this mutation supports the notion that the infections at\nthe Metropole Hotel involved a number of variants. As noted above, however,\nTor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849 share amino acids found at position 5769\nin orf1ab and position 244 in E2, which supports a more closely related\nsource of the infections at the Metropole Hotel.\nThese shared mutations, especially the 2 loci that are shared by the 5\nmainland isolates and CUHK-W1, support an etiological role for SARS\ncoronavirus in SARS.\nHere is the list of shared mutations:\n(1) orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]:\n3047 V to A [Val to Ala] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, CUHK-W1\n3072 V to A [Val to Ala] in CUHK-W1*\n3196 A to V [Ala to Val} in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03\n5768 D to E [Asp to Glu] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n(2) E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]:\n77 G to D [Gly toAsp] in BJ03, CUHK-W1\n244 T to I [Thr to Ile] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n577 A to S [Ala to Ser] in KYK, BJ01, GZ01\n(3) N [putative nucleoprotein gene]\n387 N to P [Asn to Pro] in GZ01, BJ02\n* This change is only in CUHK-W1, not BJ01, BJ02, BJ03 as reported\nyesterday [see: SARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994] - the 3\nBeijing isolates have a shared mutation at position 3196, which is A to V,\nas well as V to A change at position 3047.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[For the benefit of readers, the key to the virus isolates identified above\nis the following:\nTor2 (Toronto)\nCUHK-W1 (Hong Kong)\nUrbani (Hanoi/Bangkok)\nKYK (Singapore)\nHKU-39849 (Hong Kong)\nGZ01 (Guangzhou)\nBJ01 (Beijing)\nBJ02 (Beijing)\nBJ03 (Beijing)\nBJ04 (Beijing)\n- Mod.CP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\n2 distinct SARS virus variants from the same patient\n----------------------------------------------------\nThis issue of SARS mutations will likely be viewed with increased interest.\nMore information is now available on the 5 isolates from mainland China\n<http://www.genomics.org.cn:8080/bgi/news/zhongxin/news030416-2_fasta.htm>.\nOne area of interest is a comparisons of mutations in 2 isolates (BJ01 and\nBJ03) from the same individual. The partial data have been submitted to\nGenebank, and it is possible that there are some sequencing errors, but the\ndata are quite strong for multiple variants in the same individual.\nThere are 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03. 2 of them are found in\nall 5 mainland china isolates as well as CUHK-W1, and the 4 other isolates\nmay be the true mutations. The 2 widely shared alterations are at position\n5768 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene] (D changing to E) and I\nchanging to T at position 244 in E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]. Another\nmutation shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1 (V\nchanging to A at position 3196). This change is found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1\nat position 3047 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]. The fourth\nchange shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 (A changing to V\nat position 3196 in orf1ab).\nHowever, in addition to the 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03, each\nisolate has mutations not shared. BJ01 has 3 additional mutations not\nshared with the 9 other isolates. All 3 changes are in orf1ab at positions\n1718 (L to W), 2230 (A to V), and 2770 (V to I). Since these changes have\nnot been seen elsewhere, sequencing errors remain a possibility (although\nnot likely).\nIn contrast, BJ03 also has 3 mutations not found in BJ01, but 2 of these\nmutations have been found in other isolates, reducing the likelihood that\nthey are due to sequencing errors. The mutation unique to BJ03 is also in\norf1ab at position 3426 (V to I). Of interest are the 2 other mutations in\nE2. At position 78, the change of G to D is also found in CUHK-W1, while\nthe A to S change at position 577 is also found in KYK and GZ01, which were\nfrom patients in Singapore and Guangzhou, respectively.\nThe finding of this A to S mutation in isolates from 2 other geographically\ndistinct regions, but not in another isolate from the same patient, raises\nissues of multiple variants within the same patient as well as tissue\ntropism linked to specific amino acid changes.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[All RNA viruses by their nature are inherently highly mutable; while these\nsequence comparisons of a small number of SARS coronavirus isolates are\nintriguing, it is perhaps too early to speculate on the biological\nsignificance of any of these variable sites. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (67): cases 20030424.1007\nSARS - worldwide (64): etiology 20030423.0996\nSARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994\nSARS - worldwide (58): diagnostic testing 20030419.0958\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0935\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (46): diagnostic test 20030413.0901\nSARS - worldwide (44): UK transmission suspected 20030412.0887\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (41):overview 20030411.0876\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - Worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.....................cp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. worldwide (63):\netiology 20030423.0994] has been received from Dr Henry Niman.\nYesterday I gave several examples of mutations shared between CUHK-W1 and 5\nisolates from the mainland (GZ01, BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04). This distribution raises the possibility that the true mutations\nare the amino acids shared by the Tor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849\nisolates. I have not yet been able to obtain the history of the HKU-39849\nisolate. However, there is another shared mutation at position 577 of E2 in\nwhich S replaces A. This mutation is found in KYK, which is from a tourist\nwho stayed at the Metropole Hotel. However, the mutation is shared with,\nBJ01 and GZ01, isolates from the mainland. This mutation is not seen in\nTor2 or Urbani, 2 isolates closely linked to the Metropole Hotel. Thus, the\ndistribution of this mutation supports the notion that the infections at\nthe Metropole Hotel involved a number of variants. As noted above, however,\nTor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849 share amino acids found at position 5769\nin orf1ab and position 244 in E2, which supports a more closely related\nsource of the infections at the Metropole Hotel.\nThese shared mutations, especially the 2 loci that are shared by the 5\nmainland isolates and CUHK-W1, support an etiological role for SARS\ncoronavirus in SARS.\nHere is the list of shared mutations:\n(1) orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]:\n3047 V to A [Val to Ala] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, CUHK-W1\n3072 V to A [Val to Ala] in CUHK-W1*\n3196 A to V [Ala to Val} in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03\n5768 D to E [Asp to Glu] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n(2) E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]:\n77 G to D [Gly toAsp] in BJ03, CUHK-W1\n244 T to I [Thr to Ile] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n577 A to S [Ala to Ser] in KYK, BJ01, GZ01\n(3) N [putative nucleoprotein gene]\n387 N to P [Asn to Pro] in GZ01, BJ02\n* This change is only in CUHK-W1, not BJ01, BJ02, BJ03 as reported\nyesterday [see: SARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994] - the 3\nBeijing isolates have a shared mutation at position 3196, which is A to V,\nas well as V to A change at position 3047.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[For the benefit of readers, the key to the virus isolates identified above\nis the following:\nTor2 (Toronto)\nCUHK-W1 (Hong Kong)\nUrbani (Hanoi/Bangkok)\nKYK (Singapore)\nHKU-39849 (Hong Kong)\nGZ01 (Guangzhou)\nBJ01 (Beijing)\nBJ02 (Beijing)\nBJ03 (Beijing)\nBJ04 (Beijing)\n- Mod.CP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\n2 distinct SARS virus variants from the same patient\n----------------------------------------------------\nThis issue of SARS mutations will likely be viewed with increased interest.\nMore information is now available on the 5 isolates from mainland China\n<http://www.genomics.org.cn:8080/bgi/news/zhongxin/news030416-2_fasta.htm>.\nOne area of interest is a comparisons of mutations in 2 isolates (BJ01 and\nBJ03) from the same individual. The partial data have been submitted to\nGenebank, and it is possible that there are some sequencing errors, but the\ndata are quite strong for multiple variants in the same individual.\nThere are 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03. 2 of them are found in\nall 5 mainland china isolates as well as CUHK-W1, and the 4 other isolates\nmay be the true mutations. The 2 widely shared alterations are at position\n5768 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene] (D changing to E) and I\nchanging to T at position 244 in E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]. Another\nmutation shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1 (V\nchanging to A at position 3196). This change is found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1\nat position 3047 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]. The fourth\nchange shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 (A changing to V\nat position 3196 in orf1ab).\nHowever, in addition to the 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03, each\nisolate has mutations not shared. BJ01 has 3 additional mutations not\nshared with the 9 other isolates. All 3 changes are in orf1ab at positions\n1718 (L to W), 2230 (A to V), and 2770 (V to I). Since these changes have\nnot been seen elsewhere, sequencing errors remain a possibility (although\nnot likely).\nIn contrast, BJ03 also has 3 mutations not found in BJ01, but 2 of these\nmutations have been found in other isolates, reducing the likelihood that\nthey are due to sequencing errors. The mutation unique to BJ03 is also in\norf1ab at position 3426 (V to I). Of interest are the 2 other mutations in\nE2. At position 78, the change of G to D is also found in CUHK-W1, while\nthe A to S change at position 577 is also found in KYK and GZ01, which were\nfrom patients in Singapore and Guangzhou, respectively.\nThe finding of this A to S mutation in isolates from 2 other geographically\ndistinct regions, but not in another isolate from the same patient, raises\nissues of multiple variants within the same patient as well as tissue\ntropism linked to specific amino acid changes.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[All RNA viruses by their nature are inherently highly mutable; while these\nsequence comparisons of a small number of SARS coronavirus isolates are\nintriguing, it is perhaps too early to speculate on the biological\nsignificance of any of these variable sites. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (67): cases 20030424.1007\nSARS - worldwide (64): etiology 20030423.0996\nSARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994\nSARS - worldwide (58): diagnostic testing 20030419.0958\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0935\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (46): diagnostic test 20030413.0901\nSARS - worldwide (44): UK transmission suspected 20030412.0887\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (41):overview 20030411.0876\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - Worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.....................cp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
