worldwide (61): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203670", "date": "2003-04-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (60): CASES\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Hong Kong - DOH\n[2] Singapore - MOH\n[3] China - newswires **admission of major under-reporting from Beijing**\n[4] News briefs\n[A] Mongolia\n[B] Canada, Ontario\n[C] Canada, Ontario\n[D] China, Shanxi, Zhejiang, Jilin and Liaoning\n*******\n[1]\nDate: 20 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 20 Apr 2003\nAs of 1 PM 20 Apr 2003, there were an additional 22 patients confirmed to\nhave atypical pneumonia following admission to public hospitals earlier.\nThey include 4 healthcare workers (2 from Prince of Wales Hospital, one\nfrom Caritas Medical Centre, one from Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole\nHospital). The remaining 18 were other patients and contacts of patients\nwith atypical pneumonia.\nA total of 409 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 46 were discharged today.\n102 patients are receiving treatment in intensive care units.\n7 patients died among Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital (AHNH), Kwong\nWah Hospital, Princess Margaret Hospital (PMH), Queen Elizabeth Hospital\n(QEH), Tseung Kwan O Hospital (TKO)and Tuen Mun Hospital (TMH). This\nbrought to 88 the total number of deaths relating to atypical pneumonia.\nThe deceased include an 88-year-old man and 2 elderly women aged 71 and 75\nrespectively, who have a history of chronic disease. The remaining are 3\nwomen and one man, aged between 35 and 47.\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\nCumulative no. cases/ total no. discharged patients/ total no. deaths *\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 315/ 116/\nPatients, family members & visitors: 1065/ 293/\nTotal: 1380/ 409/ 88\n* Most of the deaths occurred in individuals who have a history of\nchronic diseases, or were patients who sought treatment at a relatively\nlate stage of infection.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 20 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/sar/sar0301.asp?id=1&mid=6320>\n\nSARS Situation Update 20 Apr 2003\nAs of 20 Apr 2003, 4 additional SARS patients have been discharged,\nbringing the total number of patients who have recovered from SARS to 104.\n58 SARS patients remain hospitalised. There is one additional SARS case\nreported today. She is a 28-year-old female visitor who was in contact with\na SARS patient in [National University Hospital] NUH Emergency Department.\nThe SARS patient was admitted to NUH on 8 Apr 2003, transferred to [Tan\nTock Seng Hospital] TTSH on 9 Apr 2003 and died on 12 Apr 2003.\nPasir Panjang Wholesale Market\nActive contact tracing is currently underway for persons who might have\ncome into contact with the 3 SARS cases from the Pasir Panjang Wholesale\nMarket. They include their family members, and the [General Practitioner]\nGP and sinsehs [Chinese traditional doctors] that the patients had visited.\nThey will be served home quarantine orders.\nIn addition, as a precaution, all the stallholders and employees at the\nPasir Panjang Wholesale Market will also be placed on home quarantine\norders for a period of 10 days. Persons who are served the Home Quarantine\nOrder must stay at home at all times for the duration stated in the Order.\nIf they breach the order, they will be liable for a fine or jail term. The\ngovernment would provide financial assistance to those served with the Home\nQuarantine Orders for the period of the quarantine.\nThe Ministry of Health would like to strongly urge members of the public\nwho have been to the Pasir Panjang Wholesale Market during the period from\n5 to 19 Apr 2003 and who have a fever or symptoms of muscle ache, cough, or\ndifficulty in breathing, to call the MOH Special Ambulance Hotline at\n9-178-8477 / 9-178-8478 immediately. An ambulance will be despatched to\nbring them for screening at the Emergency Department, Tan Tock Seng Hospital.\nIt is critical that we minimise the risk of community spread of SARS. The\nstrong pre-emptive measures being taken are in line with this, but we also\nneed the full cooperation of the public; those who have visited Pasir\nPanjang Wholesale Market should come forward to TTSH for assessment, as\nsoon as they have fever or feel unwell.\nIt is Safe to go to TTSH\nThe public can be assured that they will not catch SARS by coming to Tan\nTock Seng Hospital for SARS screening or follow-up. Tan Tock Seng Hospital\nis safe because of the stringent infection controls. No TTSH staff looking\nafter known SARS patients have caught the infection after the enhanced\ninfection control precautions were put in place in TTSH. Strict infection\ncontrol measures are in place at TTSH to ensure the safety of those who go\nthere for SARS screening. Masks are given to all patients. All staff wear\nmasks, gowns, and gloves so they cannot infect patients or get infected.\nSpacious waiting areas are provided. Patients with low risks of SARS are\nseen by separate doctors in separate clinics. Patients admitted for\nobservation are provided individual rooms. They are never made to stay with\nother Suspect patients or Probable SARS patients. All precautions are taken\nso that patients are protected from catching the infection.\nSummary of SARS cases\nA summary of the SARS cases to date:\nDischarged: 104\nHospitalised: 58 (including 19 in intensive care)\nDeaths: 14 + 2 (pending further post mortem test results)\nTotal: 178\nSuspected: 87 (including 7 children below 18)\nUnder home quarantine orders: 467\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 20 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: NY Times 20 Apr 2003 8:02 AM [edited]\n[A] China Admits a Tenfold Increase of SARS Cases in Beijing\n<http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/science/AP-SARS-Virus.html>\n\nChina reported a jump in SARS deaths on Sunday and a 10-fold increase of\ninfected people in the capital -- an embarrassing admission that cost the\nhealth minister and the Beijing mayor their Communist Party\nposts. Struggling to stop the spread of the disease, officials canceled a\nmajor week-long holiday in May, when tens of millions of people usually go\ntraveling.\nThe demotion of Health Minister Zhang Wenkang and Beijing Mayor Meng\nXuenong came shortly after officials held a 2-hour news conference to\nannounce the sharp increases in SARS cases. Zhang lost his post as\nsecretary of the leading party members' group of the Ministry of Health.\nMeng was removed as the deputy secretary of the party's Beijing Municipal\nCommittee.\nThe government said Sunday the flu-like illness has killed 12 more people\nand that the number of infections in Beijing has soared from 37 to\n346. The new figures raised China's total number of deaths to 79 and its\ncases to 1814, Gao Qiang, an executive vice health minister, said at a news\nconference. \"With such a situation, with more than 300 patients in\nBeijing, the situation is already very serious,\" Gao said. He added there\nwere 402 more suspected cases in the capital.\nGao also made a rare admission that his ministry was not properly prepared\nfor the outbreak. The ministry \"has not given out clear instructions or\neffective guidance,\" he said. But Gao denied reports that SARS cases were\nintentionally hidden from investigators. \"We have not discovered any\nlocality or place that has intentionally hidden these statistics,\" he said.\nIn recent weeks, several nations have urged their citizens to avoid\nunnecessary travel to China. However, the Chinese government continued to\nencourage the public to stick with plans to go on vacations during the\nweek-long May Day holiday, which was to start 1 May 2003. Marking a major\nshift in how China is viewing the SARS danger, Gao said that officials were\ncanceling the vacation period, which has been extended in recent years to\nboost the travel industry and encourage consumer spending. \"The purpose of\nsuch an act is to prevent the massive movement of people and the possible\nspread of the disease,\" Gao said. He acknowledged that the advisory could\ndeal a big blow to China's economy. \"I'm sure this measure will mean\nmassive losses in tourism revenue, but people's lives and health had to be\nput above everything else,\" Gao said.\nSo far, officials have not detected the spread of SARS in large rural\nareas, he said. He noted that farmers have lower incomes and less access to\nmedical care. If the outbreak hit the countryside, \"the consequences would\nbe grim,\" he said.\n[B] China Admits Much Higher Number of SARS Cases\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/20/international/asia/20CND-CHIN.html>\nWith bureaucratic shuffling and an apologetic, 2-hour news conference, a\nsenior health official, .... admitted to the existence of a large number of\npreviously undisclosed SARS patients in military hospitals and revealed\nwhat he called the first aggressive survey of cases in some 70 scattered\nhospitals. \"Accurate figures have not been reported to high authorities in\na timely manner,\" he added, though he later argued that incompetence rather\nthan deliberate deceit was the main problem. In an unusual move for such\nsensitive and embarrassing news, the news conference was broadcast live on\na national television channel.\nThe unveiling of markedly higher disease figures as well as the firings\n(perhaps the first of many) capped a tense week in which China's efforts to\nplay down SARS, especially in Beijing, were assailed by experts from the\nWorld Health Organization and questioned by medical whistleblowers here and\nby Beijing residents, who through word of mouth began hearing about far\nmore patients than officials had acknowledged.\nToday, Mr. Gao of the Health Ministry repeatedly tried to heap blame on the\nministry's shortcomings, and to the disarray in Beijing where several\npolitical jurisdictions, including municipal, national, military, and\nothers, overlap but have not coordinated disease-control efforts. As of\ntoday, Beijing city health officials will oversee all anti-SARS measures\nthroughout the urban area, including at military hospitals, Mr. Gao\nannounced. Mr. Gao also expressed concern about the spreading reports of\nSARS in several inland provinces, while some outside experts said the case\nreports from some distant provinces seemed too low. A major source of\nerror in previous Beijing reports was the exclusion of patients in several\nmajor hospitals that are run by the military, but which also hold civilian\npatients. The angry public assertion by a retired military surgeon that\nmore than 100 SARS patients were in the military system and being omitted\nfrom public reports was a major blow to the government's credibility and\ntoday, Mr. Gao revealed that the discrepancy was still greater. Of 353 SARS\npatients still in the hospital on Friday [18 Apr 2003], he said, 235 of\nthem were in military hospitals, a high proportion that no one has explained.\nOver the last week, Mr. Gao said, hundreds of officials were dispatched to\nall of Beijing's hospitals to check for possible SARS patients and to\nverify whether they had been reported to the city or national authorities.\nThey came up with totals that well surpassed the rough estimate of a World\nHealth Organization team, which on Wednesday [16 Apr 2003] caused\nconsternation here by declaring that Beijing had undercounted and that the\ntotal might be in the range of 100 to 200. Mr. Gao urged the public to\nunderstand that the sudden multiplication of cases did not imply a sudden\nnew surge in disease, but rather that the official numbers were catching up\nto reality. \"In days to come, more of the `suspect' cases will be\nconfirmed,\" he added. With more complete SARS data only now compiled, Mr.\nGao said, the trend in the epidemic is unclear, and he could not say\nwhether new cases each day are now rising or falling.\n[Byline: Erik Eckholm]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: 20 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs [edited]\n[A] Mongolia from VOA news 20 Apr 2003, 11:47 UTC\n<http://www.voanews.com/article.cfm?objectID=13E3640F-F168-41B2-ABB5C590DD5A9905&title=Mongolia%20Adopts%20Tough%20Anti%2DSARS%20Measures&catOID=45C9C78B-88AD-11D4-A57200A0CC5EE46C&categoryname=Asia%20Pacific>\nChina's neighbor, Mongolia, has introduced tough measures to cut the risk\nof infection after 5 people were suspected, but not confirmed, to have the\nvirus. Those being monitored had all visited a hospital in Hohhot, China.\nAlthough they had gone to China for non-SARS related ailments, 4 of the 5\ncame back with a fever.\nDoctor Udval Natsag, second in charge at the Ministry of Health, ....says\nthe Hohhot hospital had several confirmed cases of SARS, and so the\npossibility that the illness has spread north from China's Inner Mongolia\nregion is very real. \"There has been contact with their friends and\nfamily, and Mongolia is a high risk [area], because we have a border with\nInner Mongolia [in China],... many Mongolians travel to Inner Mongolia\nevery day.\" In the capital, Ulaanbaatar, public gatherings have been\nbanned, which has forced the shutdown of theaters and movies houses. And at\nnight, there is an eerie calm, as bars and restaurants have been ordered\nshut by 10 PM.\n[B] Canada from Canada.com 20 Apr 2003\n<http://www.canada.com/toronto/story.asp?id=08A84C1A-93F2-488C-B1EE-825A520429D4>\nA new cluster erupted at Sunnybrook and Women's College Health Sciences\nCentre in suburban Toronto, which has treated about half the region's SARS\npatients over the past month. As of yesterday, 4 staff members, including\nat least one doctor, a nurse, and a respiratory therapist, were in\nhospital. Another 8 hospital staff members were sent into home quarantine\nas potential SARS cases.\nOfficials said they believe the [above] infections occurred during\ndifficult intubations, including one [on 13 Apr 2003] that took 4 hours.\nIntubation involves placing a tube down a patient's throat to facilitate\nbreathing. Some staff started feeling symptoms associated with SARS on [16\nand 17 Apr 2003]. The hospital's head of infection, prevention and\ncontrol, said one worker's eye shield slipped during the Sunday intubation\nprocedure, but there is no other known breach of the staff's \"full-droplet\"\nprotection. That includes gowns, gloves, eye shields, and N-95 masks. \"We\nwere using what both Health Canada and the (Atlanta-based) Centers for\nDisease Control consider to be maximal precautions for these patients,\" she\nsaid, adding \"it's possible some potentially infected staff members were\nnot present at the intubations. We're examining everything we do and we're\nlooking at a number of different options in terms of making that particular\nprocedure safer for the health care workers,\" she said. One option is\nanesthetizing patients for intubation to reduce saliva spread.\nThe hospital's head of microbiology, in a conference call with Health\nCanada and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said a CDC\nexpert surprised the others by revealing that the virus can remain potent\non objects much longer than previously thought. \"....in their studies, they\nfound that you could still culture viable virus from surfaces after as much\nas 24 hours, which is longer than we normally expect viruses to be able to\nsurvive in the environment.\"\n[C] Canada, Ontario from CBC Canada 20 Apr 2003 16:29 EDST\n<http://www.cbc.ca/stories/2003/04/20/sars_train030420>\nA woman thought to be infected with [the virus that causes] severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome was aboard a commuter train travelling west of Toronto\nlast week, public health officials said [today 20 Apr 2003]. She took the\ntrain on 2 separate occasions. Both times she was in a 4-passenger \"pod\"\nwith 3 other people who should watch themselves for symptoms, said the\nmedical officer of health for Halton Region. The woman had symptoms of the\nillness when she took the GO Train on 14 Apr 2003, leaving Union Station at\n4:30 PM, heading to Appleby station in Burlington, said [a] Toronto public\nhealth spokesperson. The next morning, the woman took the train again at\n7:32 AM to go to work as a nurse at Mount Sinai Hospital. She had a fever\nand was \"feeling unwell,\" but was not coughing. The woman was admitted to\nMount Sinai for treatment of SARS later on [15 Apr 2003].\n[D] China, Shanxi, Zhejiang, Jilin and Liaoning from the Times of India 20\nApr 2003 10:18 PM\n<http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/cms.dll/xml/uncomp/articleshow?msid=43993118>\nSARS has spread to 3 more provinces, while 2 more deaths were reported in\nnorth China's Shanxi province, taking the national toll to 81. A total of\n7 new cases of SARS have been reported in 3 Chinese provinces -- 3 in\nZhejiang (east China), 3 in Jilin, and one in Liaoning, both in northeast\nChina, the official Xinhua news agency reported.\nZhejiang's health bureau publicised the details of the diagnostic process\nand the measures taken with regard to the 3 patients. The patients'\nfamilies and others who were exposed to the patients have been placed in\nisolation for monitoring and observation. The SARS experts in Jilin said\nthat they have 3 confirmed [probable] cases and 2 suspected cases.\nMeanwhile, a report from Taiyuan, capital of north China's Shanxi province,\nreported that [as of 19 Apr 2003] 9 people had died of SARS in the province\nand there were 112 registered SARS cases in the province. 11 of these have\nrecovered and been discharged from hospitals.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Today's update reports an additional 22 cases and 7 deaths reported in the\nprevious 24 hours by Hong Kong. Of these 7 deaths, 4 were in otherwise\nhealthy individuals less than 50 years of age. In Singapore, there has\nbeen one new case reported in the previous 24 hours, but there is concern\nabout potential exposure in a large market area. In response, the Ministry\nof Health has closed the market put all market vendors into home\nquarantine, alerted the public of the possibility of exposure, and\nrecommended they seek medical assistance at the SARS reference center (Tan\nTock Seng Hospital) if symptoms of SARS-like illness appear.\nThe news article on the political repercussions in China as a result of an\nunder-reporting of SARS cases in Beijing is highly significant [4]. It\nappears a clear signal to the international community that China is serious\nabout collaboration with the international community with respect to\ndisease surveillance and control, in this case with respect to SARS, but\nmost quite possibly with respect to disease surveillance and control in\ngeneral for the future. This was an unfortunate situation, possibly\ncontributing to increased transmission if the under-reporting and possible\n\"denial\" of the disease burden was associated with lack of implementation\nof appropriate infection control procedures in the health care setting,\ncombined with a lack of awareness of risk and need to seek early medical\nattention on the part of the general population, thereby having more\npotential contacts contributing to disease transmission. The above article\nat present denies the rumors of actual patient hiding, as was covered in\nthe CNN and Time articles mentioned in an 18 Apr 2003 ProMED-mail posting,\n(SARS - worldwide (57): cases 20030418.0952). Given this occurrence, one\nmight expect to see increases in numbers of cases SARS reported from\nelsewhere in China in the near future as well, if there has been\nintroduction and transmission of the SARS-related coronavirus. It will be\nof interest to see epidemic curves based on dates of onset of illness,\ndemonstrating the true course of the outbreak, as compared with looking at\nnumbers of cases reported each day which will reflect the \"outbreak\" of\nreporting, rather than the outbreak of disease.\nThe news article from Canada [5][B] points out continuing concerns related\nto the difficulties in interruption of transmission that are being seen in\nCanada. In spite of adherence to strict infection control procedures,\naccidents may happen that cause momentary breaks in these infection control\nprocedures, that in turn lead to transmission to the health care workers,\nat least in one of the 4 implicated in the new cluster reported. The\ndiscussion surrounding possible persistence of viable virus in the\nenvironment for 24 or more hours is another potential source of\nconcern. We await official information on this -- hopefully in the form of\nan official scientific document for review.\nThe second newswire from Canada [5][C] illustrates the challenges for\nimplementation of disease control measures. At what point does an\nindividual recognize that they may have a serious illness and therefore\nshould be limiting public exposures? - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (59): cases 20030419.0964\nSARS - worldwide (58): diagnostic testing 20030419.0958\nSARS - worldwide (57): cases 20030418.0952\nSARS - worldwide (56): cases 20030418.0951\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0935\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (46): diagnostic test 20030413.0901\nSARS - worldwide (44): UK transmission suspected 20030412.0887\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (41):overview 20030411.0876\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - Worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n..........................mpp/pg/dk\n\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-04-20 00:00:00", "2003-04-08 00:00:00", "2003-04-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "1814-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-05-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2003-04-14 00:00:00", "2003-04-18 00:00:00", "2057-03-16 00:00:00", "2059-03-16 00:00:00", "2058-03-16 00:00:00", "2057-03-16 00:00:00", "2056-03-16 00:00:00", "2053-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2046-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00", "2038-03-16 00:00:00", "2034-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sunnybrook", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burlington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jilin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Halton Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shanxi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Liaoning", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiyuan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hohhot", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong - Department of Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zhejiang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong - DOH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203668", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (60): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203668", "date": "2003-04-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (60): CASES\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Hong Kong - DOH\n[2] Singapore - MOH\n[3] China - newswires **admission of major under-reporting from Beijing**\n[4] News briefs\n[A] Mongolia\n[B] Canada, Ontario\n[C] Canada, Ontario\n[D] China, Shanxi, Zhejiang, Jilin and Liaoning\n*******\n[1]\nDate: 20 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 20 Apr 2003\nAs of 1 PM 20 Apr 2003, there were an additional 22 patients confirmed to\nhave atypical pneumonia following admission to public hospitals earlier.\nThey include 4 healthcare workers (2 from Prince of Wales Hospital, one\nfrom Caritas Medical Centre, one from Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole\nHospital). The remaining 18 were other patients and contacts of patients\nwith atypical pneumonia.\nA total of 409 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 46 were discharged today.\n102 patients are receiving treatment in intensive care units.\n7 patients died among Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital (AHNH), Kwong\nWah Hospital, Princess Margaret Hospital (PMH), Queen Elizabeth Hospital\n(QEH), Tseung Kwan O Hospital (TKO)and Tuen Mun Hospital (TMH). This\nbrought to 88 the total number of deaths relating to atypical pneumonia.\nThe deceased include an 88-year-old man and 2 elderly women aged 71 and 75\nrespectively, who have a history of chronic disease. The remaining are 3\nwomen and one man, aged between 35 and 47.\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\nCumulative no. cases/ total no. discharged patients/ total no. deaths *\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 315/ 116/\nPatients, family members & visitors: 1065/ 293/\nTotal: 1380/ 409/ 88\n* Most of the deaths occurred in individuals who have a history of\nchronic diseases, or were patients who sought treatment at a relatively\nlate stage of infection.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 20 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/sar/sar0301.asp?id=1&mid=6320>\n\nSARS Situation Update 20 Apr 2003\nAs of 20 Apr 2003, 4 additional SARS patients have been discharged,\nbringing the total number of patients who have recovered from SARS to 104.\n58 SARS patients remain hospitalised. There is one additional SARS case\nreported today. She is a 28-year-old female visitor who was in contact with\na SARS patient in [National University Hospital] NUH Emergency Department.\nThe SARS patient was admitted to NUH on 8 Apr 2003, transferred to [Tan\nTock Seng Hospital] TTSH on 9 Apr 2003 and died on 12 Apr 2003.\nPasir Panjang Wholesale Market\nActive contact tracing is currently underway for persons who might have\ncome into contact with the 3 SARS cases from the Pasir Panjang Wholesale\nMarket. They include their family members, and the [General Practitioner]\nGP and sinsehs [Chinese traditional doctors] that the patients had visited.\nThey will be served home quarantine orders.\nIn addition, as a precaution, all the stallholders and employees at the\nPasir Panjang Wholesale Market will also be placed on home quarantine\norders for a period of 10 days. Persons who are served the Home Quarantine\nOrder must stay at home at all times for the duration stated in the Order.\nIf they breach the order, they will be liable for a fine or jail term. The\ngovernment would provide financial assistance to those served with the Home\nQuarantine Orders for the period of the quarantine.\nThe Ministry of Health would like to strongly urge members of the public\nwho have been to the Pasir Panjang Wholesale Market during the period from\n5 to 19 Apr 2003 and who have a fever or symptoms of muscle ache, cough, or\ndifficulty in breathing, to call the MOH Special Ambulance Hotline at\n9-178-8477 / 9-178-8478 immediately. An ambulance will be despatched to\nbring them for screening at the Emergency Department, Tan Tock Seng Hospital.\nIt is critical that we minimise the risk of community spread of SARS. The\nstrong pre-emptive measures being taken are in line with this, but we also\nneed the full cooperation of the public; those who have visited Pasir\nPanjang Wholesale Market should come forward to TTSH for assessment, as\nsoon as they have fever or feel unwell.\nIt is Safe to go to TTSH\nThe public can be assured that they will not catch SARS by coming to Tan\nTock Seng Hospital for SARS screening or follow-up. Tan Tock Seng Hospital\nis safe because of the stringent infection controls. No TTSH staff looking\nafter known SARS patients have caught the infection after the enhanced\ninfection control precautions were put in place in TTSH. Strict infection\ncontrol measures are in place at TTSH to ensure the safety of those who go\nthere for SARS screening. Masks are given to all patients. All staff wear\nmasks, gowns, and gloves so they cannot infect patients or get infected.\nSpacious waiting areas are provided. Patients with low risks of SARS are\nseen by separate doctors in separate clinics. Patients admitted for\nobservation are provided individual rooms. They are never made to stay with\nother Suspect patients or Probable SARS patients. All precautions are taken\nso that patients are protected from catching the infection.\nSummary of SARS cases\nA summary of the SARS cases to date:\nDischarged: 104\nHospitalised: 58 (including 19 in intensive care)\nDeaths: 14 + 2 (pending further post mortem test results)\nTotal: 178\nSuspected: 87 (including 7 children below 18)\nUnder home quarantine orders: 467\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 20 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: NY Times 20 Apr 2003 8:02 AM [edited]\n[A] China Admits a Tenfold Increase of SARS Cases in Beijing\n<http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/science/AP-SARS-Virus.html>\n\nChina reported a jump in SARS deaths on Sunday and a 10-fold increase of\ninfected people in the capital -- an embarrassing admission that cost the\nhealth minister and the Beijing mayor their Communist Party\nposts. Struggling to stop the spread of the disease, officials canceled a\nmajor week-long holiday in May, when tens of millions of people usually go\ntraveling.\nThe demotion of Health Minister Zhang Wenkang and Beijing Mayor Meng\nXuenong came shortly after officials held a 2-hour news conference to\nannounce the sharp increases in SARS cases. Zhang lost his post as\nsecretary of the leading party members' group of the Ministry of Health.\nMeng was removed as the deputy secretary of the party's Beijing Municipal\nCommittee.\nThe government said Sunday the flu-like illness has killed 12 more people\nand that the number of infections in Beijing has soared from 37 to\n346. The new figures raised China's total number of deaths to 79 and its\ncases to 1814, Gao Qiang, an executive vice health minister, said at a news\nconference. \"With such a situation, with more than 300 patients in\nBeijing, the situation is already very serious,\" Gao said. He added there\nwere 402 more suspected cases in the capital.\nGao also made a rare admission that his ministry was not properly prepared\nfor the outbreak. The ministry \"has not given out clear instructions or\neffective guidance,\" he said. But Gao denied reports that SARS cases were\nintentionally hidden from investigators. \"We have not discovered any\nlocality or place that has intentionally hidden these statistics,\" he said.\nIn recent weeks, several nations have urged their citizens to avoid\nunnecessary travel to China. However, the Chinese government continued to\nencourage the public to stick with plans to go on vacations during the\nweek-long May Day holiday, which was to start 1 May 2003. Marking a major\nshift in how China is viewing the SARS danger, Gao said that officials were\ncanceling the vacation period, which has been extended in recent years to\nboost the travel industry and encourage consumer spending. \"The purpose of\nsuch an act is to prevent the massive movement of people and the possible\nspread of the disease,\" Gao said. He acknowledged that the advisory could\ndeal a big blow to China's economy. \"I'm sure this measure will mean\nmassive losses in tourism revenue, but people's lives and health had to be\nput above everything else,\" Gao said.\nSo far, officials have not detected the spread of SARS in large rural\nareas, he said. He noted that farmers have lower incomes and less access to\nmedical care. If the outbreak hit the countryside, \"the consequences would\nbe grim,\" he said.\n[B] China Admits Much Higher Number of SARS Cases\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/20/international/asia/20CND-CHIN.html>\nWith bureaucratic shuffling and an apologetic, 2-hour news conference, a\nsenior health official, .... admitted to the existence of a large number of\npreviously undisclosed SARS patients in military hospitals and revealed\nwhat he called the first aggressive survey of cases in some 70 scattered\nhospitals. \"Accurate figures have not been reported to high authorities in\na timely manner,\" he added, though he later argued that incompetence rather\nthan deliberate deceit was the main problem. In an unusual move for such\nsensitive and embarrassing news, the news conference was broadcast live on\na national television channel.\nThe unveiling of markedly higher disease figures as well as the firings\n(perhaps the first of many) capped a tense week in which China's efforts to\nplay down SARS, especially in Beijing, were assailed by experts from the\nWorld Health Organization and questioned by medical whistleblowers here and\nby Beijing residents, who through word of mouth began hearing about far\nmore patients than officials had acknowledged.\nToday, Mr. Gao of the Health Ministry repeatedly tried to heap blame on the\nministry's shortcomings, and to the disarray in Beijing where several\npolitical jurisdictions, including municipal, national, military, and\nothers, overlap but have not coordinated disease-control efforts. As of\ntoday, Beijing city health officials will oversee all anti-SARS measures\nthroughout the urban area, including at military hospitals, Mr. Gao\nannounced. Mr. Gao also expressed concern about the spreading reports of\nSARS in several inland provinces, while some outside experts said the case\nreports from some distant provinces seemed too low. A major source of\nerror in previous Beijing reports was the exclusion of patients in several\nmajor hospitals that are run by the military, but which also hold civilian\npatients. The angry public assertion by a retired military surgeon that\nmore than 100 SARS patients were in the military system and being omitted\nfrom public reports was a major blow to the government's credibility and\ntoday, Mr. Gao revealed that the discrepancy was still greater. Of 353 SARS\npatients still in the hospital on Friday [18 Apr 2003], he said, 235 of\nthem were in military hospitals, a high proportion that no one has explained.\nOver the last week, Mr. Gao said, hundreds of officials were dispatched to\nall of Beijing's hospitals to check for possible SARS patients and to\nverify whether they had been reported to the city or national authorities.\nThey came up with totals that well surpassed the rough estimate of a World\nHealth Organization team, which on Wednesday [16 Apr 2003] caused\nconsternation here by declaring that Beijing had undercounted and that the\ntotal might be in the range of 100 to 200. Mr. Gao urged the public to\nunderstand that the sudden multiplication of cases did not imply a sudden\nnew surge in disease, but rather that the official numbers were catching up\nto reality. \"In days to come, more of the `suspect' cases will be\nconfirmed,\" he added. With more complete SARS data only now compiled, Mr.\nGao said, the trend in the epidemic is unclear, and he could not say\nwhether new cases each day are now rising or falling.\n[Byline: Erik Eckholm]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: 20 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs [edited]\n[A] Mongolia from VOA news 20 Apr 2003, 11:47 UTC\n<http://www.voanews.com/article.cfm?objectID=13E3640F-F168-41B2-ABB5C590DD5A9905&title=Mongolia%20Adopts%20Tough%20Anti%2DSARS%20Measures&catOID=45C9C78B-88AD-11D4-A57200A0CC5EE46C&categoryname=Asia%20Pacific>\nChina's neighbor, Mongolia, has introduced tough measures to cut the risk\nof infection after 5 people were suspected, but not confirmed, to have the\nvirus. Those being monitored had all visited a hospital in Hohhot, China.\nAlthough they had gone to China for non-SARS related ailments, 4 of the 5\ncame back with a fever.\nDoctor Udval Natsag, second in charge at the Ministry of Health, ....says\nthe Hohhot hospital had several confirmed cases of SARS, and so the\npossibility that the illness has spread north from China's Inner Mongolia\nregion is very real. \"There has been contact with their friends and\nfamily, and Mongolia is a high risk [area], because we have a border with\nInner Mongolia [in China],... many Mongolians travel to Inner Mongolia\nevery day.\" In the capital, Ulaanbaatar, public gatherings have been\nbanned, which has forced the shutdown of theaters and movies houses. And at\nnight, there is an eerie calm, as bars and restaurants have been ordered\nshut by 10 PM.\n[B] Canada from Canada.com 20 Apr 2003\n<http://www.canada.com/toronto/story.asp?id=08A84C1A-93F2-488C-B1EE-825A520429D4>\nA new cluster erupted at Sunnybrook and Women's College Health Sciences\nCentre in suburban Toronto, which has treated about half the region's SARS\npatients over the past month. As of yesterday, 4 staff members, including\nat least one doctor, a nurse, and a respiratory therapist, were in\nhospital. Another 8 hospital staff members were sent into home quarantine\nas potential SARS cases.\nOfficials said they believe the [above] infections occurred during\ndifficult intubations, including one [on 13 Apr 2003] that took 4 hours.\nIntubation involves placing a tube down a patient's throat to facilitate\nbreathing. Some staff started feeling symptoms associated with SARS on [16\nand 17 Apr 2003]. The hospital's head of infection, prevention and\ncontrol, said one worker's eye shield slipped during the Sunday intubation\nprocedure, but there is no other known breach of the staff's \"full-droplet\"\nprotection. That includes gowns, gloves, eye shields, and N-95 masks. \"We\nwere using what both Health Canada and the (Atlanta-based) Centers for\nDisease Control consider to be maximal precautions for these patients,\" she\nsaid, adding \"it's possible some potentially infected staff members were\nnot present at the intubations. We're examining everything we do and we're\nlooking at a number of different options in terms of making that particular\nprocedure safer for the health care workers,\" she said. One option is\nanesthetizing patients for intubation to reduce saliva spread.\nThe hospital's head of microbiology, in a conference call with Health\nCanada and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said a CDC\nexpert surprised the others by revealing that the virus can remain potent\non objects much longer than previously thought. \"....in their studies, they\nfound that you could still culture viable virus from surfaces after as much\nas 24 hours, which is longer than we normally expect viruses to be able to\nsurvive in the environment.\"\n[C] Canada, Ontario from CBC Canada 20 Apr 2003 16:29 EDST\n<http://www.cbc.ca/stories/2003/04/20/sars_train030420>\nA woman thought to be infected with [the virus that causes] severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome was aboard a commuter train travelling west of Toronto\nlast week, public health officials said [today 20 Apr 2003]. She took the\ntrain on 2 separate occasions. Both times she was in a 4-passenger \"pod\"\nwith 3 other people who should watch themselves for symptoms, said the\nmedical officer of health for Halton Region. The woman had symptoms of the\nillness when she took the GO Train on 14 Apr 2003, leaving Union Station at\n4:30 PM, heading to Appleby station in Burlington, said [a] Toronto public\nhealth spokesperson. The next morning, the woman took the train again at\n7:32 AM to go to work as a nurse at Mount Sinai Hospital. She had a fever\nand was \"feeling unwell,\" but was not coughing. The woman was admitted to\nMount Sinai for treatment of SARS later on [15 Apr 2003].\n[D] China, Shanxi, Zhejiang, Jilin and Liaoning from the Times of India 20\nApr 2003 10:18 PM\n<http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/cms.dll/xml/uncomp/articleshow?msid=43993118>\nSARS has spread to 3 more provinces, while 2 more deaths were reported in\nnorth China's Shanxi province, taking the national toll to 81. A total of\n7 new cases of SARS have been reported in 3 Chinese provinces -- 3 in\nZhejiang (east China), 3 in Jilin, and one in Liaoning, both in northeast\nChina, the official Xinhua news agency reported.\nZhejiang's health bureau publicised the details of the diagnostic process\nand the measures taken with regard to the 3 patients. The patients'\nfamilies and others who were exposed to the patients have been placed in\nisolation for monitoring and observation. The SARS experts in Jilin said\nthat they have 3 confirmed [probable] cases and 2 suspected cases.\nMeanwhile, a report from Taiyuan, capital of north China's Shanxi province,\nreported that [as of 19 Apr 2003] 9 people had died of SARS in the province\nand there were 112 registered SARS cases in the province. 11 of these have\nrecovered and been discharged from hospitals.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Today's update reports an additional 22 cases and 7 deaths reported in the\nprevious 24 hours by Hong Kong. Of these 7 deaths, 4 were in otherwise\nhealthy individuals less than 50 years of age. In Singapore, there has\nbeen one new case reported in the previous 24 hours, but there is concern\nabout potential exposure in a large market area. In response, the Ministry\nof Health has closed the market put all market vendors into home\nquarantine, alerted the public of the possibility of exposure, and\nrecommended they seek medical assistance at the SARS reference center (Tan\nTock Seng Hospital) if symptoms of SARS-like illness appear.\nThe news article on the political repercussions in China as a result of an\nunder-reporting of SARS cases in Beijing is highly significant [4]. It\nappears a clear signal to the international community that China is serious\nabout collaboration with the international community with respect to\ndisease surveillance and control, in this case with respect to SARS, but\nmost quite possibly with respect to disease surveillance and control in\ngeneral for the future. This was an unfortunate situation, possibly\ncontributing to increased transmission if the under-reporting and possible\n\"denial\" of the disease burden was associated with lack of implementation\nof appropriate infection control procedures in the health care setting,\ncombined with a lack of awareness of risk and need to seek early medical\nattention on the part of the general population, thereby having more\npotential contacts contributing to disease transmission. The above article\nat present denies the rumors of actual patient hiding, as was covered in\nthe CNN and Time articles mentioned in an 18 Apr 2003 ProMED-mail posting,\n(SARS - worldwide (57): cases 20030418.0952). Given this occurrence, one\nmight expect to see increases in numbers of cases SARS reported from\nelsewhere in China in the near future as well, if there has been\nintroduction and transmission of the SARS-related coronavirus. It will be\nof interest to see epidemic curves based on dates of onset of illness,\ndemonstrating the true course of the outbreak, as compared with looking at\nnumbers of cases reported each day which will reflect the \"outbreak\" of\nreporting, rather than the outbreak of disease.\nThe news article from Canada [5][B] points out continuing concerns related\nto the difficulties in interruption of transmission that are being seen in\nCanada. In spite of adherence to strict infection control procedures,\naccidents may happen that cause momentary breaks in these infection control\nprocedures, that in turn lead to transmission to the health care workers,\nat least in one of the 4 implicated in the new cluster reported. The\ndiscussion surrounding possible persistence of viable virus in the\nenvironment for 24 or more hours is another potential source of\nconcern. We await official information on this -- hopefully in the form of\nan official scientific document for review.\nThe second newswire from Canada [5][C] illustrates the challenges for\nimplementation of disease control measures. At what point does an\nindividual recognize that they may have a serious illness and therefore\nshould be limiting public exposures? - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (59): cases 20030419.0964\nSARS - worldwide (58): diagnostic testing 20030419.0958\nSARS - worldwide (57): cases 20030418.0952\nSARS - worldwide (56): cases 20030418.0951\nSARS - worldwide (53): etiology 20030417.0935\nSARS - worldwide (51): etiology 20030416.0925\nSARS - worldwide (46): diagnostic test 20030413.0901\nSARS - worldwide (44): UK transmission suspected 20030412.0887\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (41):overview 20030411.0876\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - Worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n..........................mpp/pg/dk\n\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-04-20 00:00:00", "2003-04-08 00:00:00", "2003-04-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "1814-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-05-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2003-04-14 00:00:00", "2003-04-18 00:00:00", "2057-03-16 00:00:00", "2059-03-16 00:00:00", "2058-03-16 00:00:00", "2057-03-16 00:00:00", "2056-03-16 00:00:00", "2053-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2046-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00", "2038-03-16 00:00:00", "2034-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sunnybrook", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burlington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jilin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Halton Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shanxi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Liaoning", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiyuan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hohhot", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong - Department of Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zhejiang", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong - DOH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203665", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (59): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203665", "date": "2003-04-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (52): CASES\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Worldwide - WHO\n[2] Hong Kong - DOH\n[3] Singapore - MOH\n[4] USA - CDC\n[5] Health Canada\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: 16 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website [edited]\n\n\n[A] Cumulative number of reported probable(1) cases of severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome (SARS)\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_04_16/en/>\n\nFrom: 1 Nov 2002 To: 16 Apr 2003, 12:00 GMT+2\n\nCountry: Cumulative no.case(s)/ no. new cases since last WHO update/ No.\ndeaths/ No. recovered (2)/ Local chain(s) of transmission(3)\n\nBrazil: 2/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nCanada: 103/ 3/ 13/ 37/ Yes\nChina: 1432/ 14/ 64/ 1094/ Yes\nChina, Hong Kong SAR (4) 1268/ 36/ 61/ 257/ Yes\nChina, Taiwan: 27/ 4/ 0/ 10/ Yes\nFrance: 5/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None\nGermany: 6/ 0/ 0/ 4/ None\nIndonesia: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nItaly: 3/ 0/ 0/ 2/ None\nJapan: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nKuwait: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nMalaysia: 5/ 1/ 1/ 0/ None\nPhilippines: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None\nRepublic of Ireland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None\nRomania: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None\nSingapore: 162/ 0/ 13/ 85/ Yes\nSouth Africa: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nSpain: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nSweden: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nSwitzerland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None\nThailand: 8/ 0/ 2/ 5/ None\nUnited Kingdom: 6/ 0/ 0/ 3/ Yes\nUnited States: 193/ 0/ 0/ not available/ Yes\nViet Nam: 63/ 0/ 5/ 46/ Yes\n\nTotal: 3293/ 58/ 159/ 1548\n\nNotes:\n\nCumulative number of cases includes number of deaths.\n\n1. Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a national\nlevel, probable cases are reported by all countries except the United\nStates of America, which is reporting suspected cases under investigation.\n\n2. Includes cases who are \"discharged\" or \"recovered\" as reported by the\nnational public health authorities.\n\n3. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in which\nlocal chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are provided\non the list of (See Affected Areas ).\n\n4. One death attributed to Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China\noccurred in a case medically transferred from Viet Nam.\n\n[B] The list of affected areas can be found at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_16/en/>\nand is unchanged from prior report\n\n[C] The epidemic curves can be found at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsepicurve/epiindex/en/>\nand are current as of 14 Apr 2003.\n\n[D] There is an interesting discussion on the collaborating networks\ndeveloped as part of the operational response to SARS that can be found at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/goarn2003_4_16/en/>\n\n[E] From a press release/conference 16 Apr 2003 found at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/2003_04_16/en/>\n\n2 of the questions that were posed related to the completeness in reporting\nof cases from Beijing (and the lack of reporting of cases from the military\nhospitals), and the lay press observations of a change in profile of deaths\nin Hong Kong, where recently there have been deaths in individuals not\nolder than 60 with chronic diseases, but rather a younger/healthier group\nof people.\n\nDr. Heymann responded to these questions: ...on the age issue, it's always\nuseful to understand that this disease starts out in health workers in most\ncases, so the first patient infects health workers and they are all of a\ncertain age; they are not young people, they are middle-aged people or in\ntheir 20s to 40s or 50s, so it's natural that that would be the age that's\nfirst infected. Then as it spreads out from those workers into other\npopulations, the ages change, so it's very important to understand the\ndynamics of this disease.\n\nAs far as Beijing goes, last evening they visited the military hospital.\nThey estimated that there are at least 50 patients in this hospital with\nSARS from what they've seen. They also estimate that there are between\n100-200 probable cases in Beijing, more than has been reported, and they\nfeel that there might even be up to 1000 people who are under observation\nright now at various stages of infection; some probably are not SARS, in\nfact many are probably not SARS, but they are taking precautions in\nobserving these. It's our impression that China needs to get clear on how\nit reports these diseases and they are working very closely with the\nChinese to get better reporting. It's also the team's feeling that Beijing\nhas many resources that they can put to work on this disease and that SARS\nwill not be a problem in Beijing if they get these resources working. Their\nconcern is in the provinces, especially in the western provinces, and they\nare afraid that it will not only spread from cities into the communities\nbut into areas where there may not be health facilities that are very\nclosely accessible to people. So, the challenge now is for China to not\nonly report, but to trace infection, to do infection control in the\nhospitals, and do everything that the other countries are doing to stop the\nspread of this disease.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 16 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 16 Apr 2003\n\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\n\nAs of 3 PM 16 Apr 2003, there are an additional 36 patients confirmed to\nhave atypical pneumonia following admission to public hospitals earlier.\nThey include 7 healthcare workers (6 from Princess Margaret Hospital and\none from Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital). The remaining 29 were\nother patients and contacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.\n\nA total of 257 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 14 were discharged\ntoday. 122 patients are receiving treatment in intensive care unit.\n\n5 patients died in hospitals, bringing to 61 the total number of deaths\nrelating to atypical pneumonia. A 54-year-old female and a 73-year-old\nmale, both with a history of chronic disease, died in Queen Elizabeth\nHospital. A 44-year-old male and a 62-year-old female died in Princess\nMargaret Hospital. Another chronically ill male patient, aged 73, died in\nAlice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital.\n\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\n\nCumulative no. cases/ no. recovered/ no. deaths\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 298/ 100/ 61\nPatients, family members & visitors: 970/ 157/ 0\nTotal: 1268/ 257 /61\n\n* Most of the deaths occurred in individuals who have a history of\nchronic diseases or were patients who sought treatment at a relatively late\nstage of infection.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: 16 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health 16 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/sar/sar0301.asp?id=1&mid=6180>\n\n\nSARS Situation Update 16 Apr 2003\n\nAs of 16 Apr 2003, 6 additional SARS patients have been discharged,\nbringing the total number of patients who have recovered from SARS to 91.\n61 SARS patients remain hospitalised.\n\nThere are 5 additional SARS cases reported today. They comprise 2 staff\nmembers of National Cancer Centre (NCC), namely a radiographer who had been\nadmitted to Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) since 9 Apr 2003 for observation,\nand a porter who was admitted to TTSH on 14 Apr 2003. Both patients\ndeveloped lung changes on chest X-ray yesterday and hence were diagnosed to\nhave SARS. The third SARS case is an inpatient at Singapore General\nHospital (SGH) Ward 58 who has been observed in TTSH since 13 Apr 2003, and\nwho developed lung changes yesterday. The other 2 cases comprise the son of\na SARS patient, and a doctor at National University Hospital (NUH) who\nlooked after 2 patients prior to their diagnosis of SARS.\n\nSituation Update at NCC\nThere are 2 NCC staff members who have been diagnosed as probable SARS.\n\nThe radiographer developed a fever (37.8 deg C) on Saturday 5 Apr 2003. He\ndid not see a doctor. He was well with no fever over the next 3 days (6--8\nApr 2003). He worked in the radiology department of NCC on 7 and 8 Apr\n2003. Twice-daily temperature monitoring was performed and he was noted to\nhave no fever. During these 2 days, he performed CT scans and MRI on a\ntotal of 11 patients.\n\nIn the early hours of 9 Apr 2003, he developed fever of 38.4 deg C. He went\nto Changi General Hospital (CGH) and was transferred to TTSH on the same\nday. On admission he was classified as a low-risk suspect for SARS. CGH\nobserved all the infection control measures when the patient was there.\n\nAnother hospital staff (porter), who handles dispatch work, developed a\nlow-grade fever (37.5 deg C) on the morning of Thu 10 Apr 2003. He was not\nassigned any duties and during that time he only came into contact with the\ndepartmental staff. At noon, his temperature went up to 38.6 deg C. He was\nseen at the SGH Staff Clinic and was given 2 days MC [medical leave?] and\nasked to return for a review on 12 Apr 2003.\n\nHe had no fever on 11 Apr 2003. He did not return to the Staff Clinic on 12\nApr 2003 and instead saw his neighbourhood General Practitioner (GP). He\nwas given 2 more days MC. He continued to have low-grade [fever]. On 14 Apr\n2003, he went directly to the Staff Clinic and was referred to TTSH and\nadmitted on the same day.\n\nBesides these 2 staff members, the other NCC staff are currently well. As a\nprecaution, NCC has closed its radiology department until 20 Apr 2003.\nUrgent radiological x-rays will be done at SGH A&E Dept. Non-urgent\nappointments will be deferred. NCC has contacted 10 of the 11 patients who\nhad X-ray investigations done by the radiographer and they are well.\nAlthough the radiographer did not go into the waiting room of the X-ray\ndepartment, as a precaution, NCC has been contacting the 200 patients who\nhave had other X-rays done during the period 7--9 Apr 2003. Investigations\nare still in progress to trace the source of infection.\n\nSituation Update at NUH\nThe doctor attended to a patient who was being treated for heart failure.\nThe patient, who was admitted to NUH on 8 Apr 2003, had been a visitor at\nSGH Ward 57 in end March. He had multiple medical conditions and did not\nhave fever at that time. When he was reviewed in the ward, the possibility\nof concurrent pneumonia was recognised as his condition had deteriorated.\nThe patient was unstable and required transfer to the NUH Intensive Care\nUnit where he was intubated. The transfer to TTSH took place later on the\nsame day when the patient's condition stabilised. The patient passed away\non 12 Apr 2003.\n\nThe NUH doctor developed fever on 11 Apr 2003 evening and was sent to TTSH\nEmergency Department on the same day. She has been diagnosed as a probable\nSARS case on 16 Apr 2003.\n\nHome Quarantine for non-SARS patients with chronic conditions discharged\nfrom SGH and TTSH\nContact tracing at SGH has identified the patients and healthcare workers\nwho may have been exposed to SARS. These contacts have been quarantined or\nare being monitored. There are about 800 inpatients at present in SGH who\nhave not been exposed. However, as a precaution, patients discharged from\nSGH from 17 Apr 2003 onwards who have chronic co-morbid conditions will be\nissued Home Quarantine Orders (HQO) for 10 days. At end of 10 days, SGH\nwill recall them for review, following which they will be on phone\nsurveillance for a further 10 days. The other discharged patients who do\nnot have any chronic conditions will not be on HQO but phone surveillance\nfor 21 days. The same arrangement will be implemented for non-SARS patients\nwith chronic conditions discharged from TTSH.\n\nSummary of SARS cases\nThere was a SARS patient in intensive care who died late 15 Apr 2003. She\nwas the mother of a doctor who contracted SARS while looking after a SARS\npatient. The other deceased is the mother of a SARS patient. On 13 Apr\n2003, we reported 2 SARS deaths linked to the SGH cluster comprising an\ninpatient and the brother of an index patient. The preliminary findings of\nboth patients were that they died of other medical conditions unrelated to\nSARS. We are awaiting results of further investigations.\n\nBelow is the summary of the SARS cases to date:\n\nNumber Discharged: 85 plus 6\nHospitalised: 61 (including 16 in intensive care)\nDeaths: 13 + 2 (pending post mortem findings)\n\nTotal: 167\n\nSuspected: 91 (including 8 children below 18)\nUnder home quarantine orders: 582\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: 16 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC SARS website 16 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/sars.htm>\n\n\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome report of suspected cases under\ninvestigation in the United States\n\nThese data were reported to the World Health Organization on 15 Apr 2003.\n\nState: suspected cases under investigation\n\nAlabama: 1\nCalifornia: 42\nColorado: 6\nConnecticut: 4\nFlorida: 11\nGeorgia: 3\nHawaii: 5\nIllinois: 11\nIndiana: 1\nKansas: 1\nKentucky: 1\nMaine: 2\nMassachusetts: 8\nMichigan: 3\nMinnesota: 6\nMississippi: 1\nMissouri: 2\nNevada: 1\nNew Hampshire: 1\nNew Jersey: 3\nNew Mexico: 1\nNew York: 22\nNorth Carolina: 6\nOhio: 10\nOregon: 1\nPennsylvania: 5\nRhode Island: 1\nSouth Carolina: 1\nTexas: 7\nUtah: 5\nVermont: 2\nVirginia: 5\nWashington: 19\nWisconsin: 1\n\nTotal suspected cases under investigation: 199\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5]\nDate: 16 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update32.html>\n\n\nUpdate 32: Severe acute respiratory syndrome -- 16 Apr 2003 4:30 PM\n\nAs of 16 Apr 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 303 probable or\nsuspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Canada. There\nhave been 13 deaths in Canada. To date, transmission has been limited to\nspecific transmission settings such as households, hospitals, and specific\ncommunity settings. The information contained in this update is based on\nthe information available to Health Canada at this time.\n\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\n\nOntario is reporting 122 probable and 127 suspect cases. All cases have\noccurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS\ncases in the household or in a health-care setting.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 4 probable and 38 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 5 suspect cases.\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases.\n\nSo far, 91 people have been discharged from hospitals in Ontario. These\npeople were treated as suspect cases or as probable cases.\n\nThese numbers are accurate as of 1:00 PM EDST 16 Apr 2003.\n\n[These data do not mention the newswire reports of transmission within a\nreligious community related to attendance at a funeral of a probable SARS\ncase. The newswire reports have been varied, with some mentioning that\nmost of the cases had been previously reported, but according to this\nupdate there is no mention of community-based close contact, which appeared\nto be the mode of transmission in this generation of cases. More\ninformation on this observation from official sources would be appreciated.\n- Mod.MPP]\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of today's update there is a cumulative total of 3293 cases of SARS\nreported to the WHO, with 58 new cases reported in the preceding 24 hours;\na total of 159 deaths (case fatality rate of 4.8 percent) and 1548 patients\nhave recovered (47 percent). In the past 24 hours, Hong Kong has reported\n36 new cases and 5 deaths; in China there have been 14 new cases\nreported. Based on the information provided by Dr. Heymann in today's WHO\npress briefing, we expect to see the numbers of cases reported from Beijing\nto increase significantly once official reports from the military hospitals\nare received. In addition, there has been the suggestion of increased\ntransmission outside of Beijing and Guangdong. It would be interesting to\nsee a breakdown of reported cases by province to determine whether new\nareas of local transmission have been identified. For example, the lay\npress has reported cases in Inner Mongolia, suggesting local transmission,\nbut this area has not officially been added to the affected areas list --\nsee ProMED-mail posting SARS - worldwide (45): cases 20030412.0890.\n\nThere are now 199 suspected cases from 32 states in the United States. This\nrepresents an increase of 6 cases from the last report on 15 Apr\n2003. There has been mention in press releases (CDC press release 14 Apr\n2003 (accessible at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/transcripts/t030414.htm> and in many lay\npress reports) that the USA plans to change reporting practices, separating\nsuspected and probable cases using the WHO definitions. When that occurs,\nwe expect to see a marked decrease in the numbers of cases of SARS reported\non a daily basis to WHO. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (50): (cases) 20030415.0922\nSARS - worldwide (49): cases 20030414.0916\nSARS - worldwide (47): cases 20030413.0905\nSARS - worldwide (46): diagnostic test 20030413.0901\nSARS - worldwide (44): UK transmission suspected 20030412.0887\nSARS - worldwide (42): WHO historical overview 20030411.0878\nSARS - worldwide (41):overview 20030411.0876\nSARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869\nSARS - Worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n.................................mpp/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
