"date": "2003-04-09 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (36):CASES\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\nWorldwide - WHO\n[A] Cumulative case counts by country\n[B] Affected areas\n[C] Epidemiologic links (mapping and epidemic curves)\n[D] Update discussion\n\n******\nDate: 9 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website 9 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>\n\n\n[A] Cumulative number of reported probable(\u00a7) cases of severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome (SARS)\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_04_09/en/>\n\nFrom: 1 Nov 2002 To: 9 Apr 2003, 15:00 GMT+2\n\nCountry: Cumulative no. case(s)/ No. deaths/ Local chain(s) of\ntransmission (1)\n\nBrazil: 1/ 0/ None\nCanada: 94/ 10/ Yes\nChina: 1280/ 53/ Yes\nChina, Hong Kong SAR: 970/ 27*/ Yes\nChina, Taiwan: 19/ 0/ Yes\nFrance: 4/ 0/ None\nGermany: 5/ 0/ None\nItaly: 3/ 0/ None\nMalaysia: 1/ 1/ None\nRepublic of Ireland: 1/ 0/ None\nRomania: 1/ 0/ None\nSingapore: 118/ 9/ Yes\nSpain: 1/ 0/ None\nSwitzerland: 1/ 0/ None\nThailand: 7/ 2/ None\nUnited Kingdom: 5/ 0/ None\nUnited States: 149/ 0/ None\nViet Nam: 62/ 4/ Yes\n\nTotal: 2722/ 106\n\nNotes:\n\nCumulative number of cases includes number of deaths.\n\n1. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in which\nlocal chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are provided\non the list of Affected Areas.\n\n\u00a7Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a national level,\nprobable cases are reported by all countries except the United States of\nAmerica, which is reporting suspect cases under investigation.\n\n*One death attributed to Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China\noccurred in a case medically transferred from Viet Nam.\n\n\n[B] Affected areas 9 Apr 2003\n\nUnchanged from previous reports and can be accessed at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_09/en/>\n\n\n[C] Epidemiologic links\n\nA mapping of the cumulative number of SARS cases reported to WHO (and\ncontained in the above table [A]) as of 9 Apr 2003 can be found at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/map2003_04_09.jpg>\n\nEpidemic curves of the SARS cases reported to WHO (as of 8 Apr 2003) can be\nfound at: <http://www.who.int/csr/sarsepicurve/2003_04_08/en/>. There are\nmultiple curves, representing the global outbreak, and then outbreaks by\ncountry for Hong Kong, Viet Nam, Singapore, Canada, the United States, and\nthe European Region. Reviewing the curves, when looking at the epidemic\ncurve by date of onset, it does appear as though the global outbreak may\nhave already peaked, although this curve represents a small fraction of\nactual reported probable cases, as dates of onset were not available for\n2105 cases. The date of onset of the most recent reported cases was 1 Apr\n2003, 6 days preceding the last date of notification. In contrast, the\nepidemic curve plotting reported cases by date of report appears to be\nconsistent with ongoing transmission at a steady rate, with a marked\nincrease in numbers of cases reported on 1 Apr 2003 (representing the\ndelayed reports from China) and another significant increase in reported\ncases on 8 Apr 2003.\n\nThe epidemic curve by date of report in Hong Kong suggests that there was a\nlarge peak during the week of 29 Mar 2003, and a second smaller peak during\nthe week of 5 Apr 2003. The epidemic curve by date of onset for Viet Nam\nsuggests that there was a peak during the week of 8 Mar 2003, and apparent\ninterruption of transmission (or missed cases, or one incubation period\npending appearance of new cases) during the week of 29 Mar 2003 and the\nappearance of a few cases during the week of 5 Apr 2003. The epidemic\ncurve, by date of onset for Singapore shows a clear peak in cases during\nthe period 15-22 Mar 2003 and a significant tapering off of cases by the\nweek 5 Apr 2003. The epidemic curve, by date of onset, for Canada shows a\nclear peak during the period 15-22 Mar 2003, with continued transmission\nbut at a lower rate. There have not been any cases reported with dates of\nonset since 4 Apr 2003 in Canada. The epidemic curve, by date of onset\n(current as of 4 Apr 2003), for the United States shows several peak\nperiods of cases, during the weeks of 15 Mar 2003, 22 Mar 2003, and 29 Mar\n2003. The maximum number of cases with dates of onset on a single day was\n9 on 17 Mar 2003. (We do not have information on the dates of onset of the\nfew healthcare workers and family members that were contacts of imported\ncases, but the overwhelming majority of cases reported in the United States\nwere in individuals with a history of travel to affected areas (see section\n[B] above). There have not been any cases reported with dates of onset\nsince 30 Mar 2003, representing a 5-day period without new cases. In\ncontrast, the epidemic curve by date of onset for the European Region is\nmore consistent with sporadic case reports, with a maximum of one or 2\ncases per day. To date there have not been reports of any secondary\ntransmission in the European Region. - Mod.MPP]\n\n\n[D] Update 25 - Interim report of WHO team in China, status of the main\nSARS outbreaks in different countries 9 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_09/en/>\n\n[ProMED-mail would like to express our continuing gratitude to Marianne\nHopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com> for her daily monitoring of WHO reports. - Mod.MPP]\n\n\nChina\n------\nThe WHO team of experts presented its interim report on the SARS outbreak\nin Guangdong Province this morning to the Chinese Ministry of Health and\nVice Premier Wu Yi in Beijing. The team began its investigations in\nGuangdong on 3 Apr 2003.\n\nThe team concluded that the health system in Guangdong responded well to\nthe outbreak. The province has a health system in which every hospital at\nevery level reports any new cases of SARS. The WHO report therefore\nconcluded that virtually all probable cases of SARS presenting at a\nhospital in Guangdong Province will be detected and rapidly reported.\n\nHowever, the team found an urgent need to improve surveillance in the\ncountryside to head off new outbreaks in rural areas. The team was further\nconcerned by an increase in sporadic cases, which could not be linked to a\nparticular transmission chain, as such cases raised questions about the\nadequacy of contact tracing.\n\nIn addition, the report noted many remaining concerns about the ability of\nother provinces, where health systems are not as strong as the one in\nGuangdong, to respond promptly and effectively to the challenge of SARS.\n\nIn Beijing, for example, only a minority of hospitals make daily reports of\nSARS cases. Contact tracing is another problem in Beijing and does not\nappear to be carried out systematically. Failure to perform careful contact\ntracing will allow the disease to spread.\n\nThe team observed that many of China\u0092s poorer provinces may not have\nadequate resources, facilities, and equipment to cope with outbreaks of\nSARS, and underscored that Guangdong\u0092s capacity was exceptional among\nChina\u0092s provinces.\n\nIn Guangdong, the SARS outbreak placed an enormous strain on the health\ncare system. The Guangdong Infectious Disease Hospital (Guangzhou No. 8\nPeople\u0092s Hospital) had 150 of its 400 beds occupied by SARS patients daily\nduring the second week of February [2003]. The team noted that the response\nof the health care system has been exemplary, and commended the dedication\nand bravery of doctors, nurses, and others working in clinics and hospitals.\n\nMicrobiological findings\n----------\nLarge banks of stored specimens from suspected and probable SARS cases,\nfrom case contacts as well as from \u0093normal controls\u0094 exist at the\ninstitutions visited and are stored under suitable conditions; detailed\ninformation about the numbers and types of these specimens are available\nand were provided to members of the WHO team. Although the patient data on\neach of these is very limited, it is sufficient to allow linkage with the\nvery detailed epidemiological and clinical information held elsewhere in\nGuangdong Provincial Centers for Disease Control and the hospitals.\n\nThese specimen banks comprise different types of respiratory specimens from\nwhich the detection of agents can be attempted and serum samples, often as\npaired acute and convalescent sera (i.e., the first sample obtained during\nthe acute phase of the illness and the second during recovery), which will\nallow determination of seroconversions. The laboratory staff agreed that\nonce a causative agent for SARS was identified, these banks should be\ntested and will provide very valuable information; they seemed, however,\nless sure whether this time had come already, i.e. whether there was\nalready sufficient evidence and whether suitable tests had been developed\nelsewhere that would make such an exercise worthwhile. They requested\nassistance from the WHO team to obtain relevant information on primer\nsequences and other matters as well as access to suitable experimental\ntests such as immunofluorescence antibody assays.\n\nMain recommendations\n---------\nThe interim report made several major recommendations, including the following:\n\n- The SARS reporting system established in Guangdong is an excellent model\nthat all provinces should follow. Team members suggest that the MOH ensures\nthat all provinces are brought up to Guangdong standards by implementing\nthis system nationwide as a matter of the utmost urgency. A programme for\nevaluating and accrediting surveillance systems through evaluation by\ntechnical experts is also suggested in order to ensure that consistent\nstandards are achieved and maintained.\n\n- The Guangdong experience should be used to develop uniform standards\nthroughout all provinces for preventing the spread of SARS in health care\nfacilities.\n\n- Careful contact tracing of SARS cases is vital to bring the outbreak\nunder control. Detailed interviewing of all newly reported SARS cases by\ntrained interviewers including a full review not only of close contacts but\npotential exposure in other crowded settings, e.g. public transport, needs\nto be routinely carried out. Contacts of cases should be provided with\ndetailed preventive advice verbally and in writing.\n\n- Much better collaboration between virological laboratories in China is\nrequired, particularly to facilitate the exchange of results, specimens,\nand reagents. The following institutions should form the nucleus of a\nnational SARS laboratory network within China:\n- National Institute of Virology, China CDC, Beijing\n- Virology Unit, Beijing Provincial CDC, Beijing\n- Virology Unit, Guangdong Provincial CDC, Guangzhou\n- Department of Virology, Zhongshan University, Guangzhou\nLaboratories from other areas with experience of SARS cases should also be\nincluded. Adequate funding and human resources need to be urgently provided\nto ensure the proper functioning and sustainability of SARS surveillance\nactivities, as they are essential to controlling spread of the disease.\nChinese institutions should form a national SARS laboratory network within\nChina to speed up the exchange of results, specimens, and reagents.\n\n- Guangdong clinicians have cared for the largest number of patients in the\nworld and their experience should be shared with the international\ncommunity through publications, meetings, and in drafting guidelines for\nthe management of SARS patients.\n\nPriority actions\nPriority actions recommended in the report to contain SARS include:\n\n- early recognition and treatment of cases\n\n- stringent infection control measures in hospitals and clinics\n\n- prompt reporting of suspected cases\n\n- meticulous investigation and contact tracing in the community - public\nawareness campaigns and education.\n\n\nHong Kong: heavy burden on the health system\n---------\nWith today\u0092s cumulative total of 970 cases and 27 deaths, Hong Kong\ncontinues to have the largest SARS outbreak, second to China. The strain on\nhealth services and staff is considerable, and strengthened measures of\ninfection control may be needed.\n\nThe isolation order placed on Block E, Amory Gardens will expire at\nmidnight, 9 Apr 2003. The Hong Kong Health Department has announced that\nresidents, temporarily housed at camps, may return home after their flats\nhave been disinfected by the Food and Environmental Hygiene Department.\n\nSingapore: role of \"super-spreaders\"\n----------\nSingapore has increased measures to prevent transmission in hospitals\nfollowing an outbreak in Singapore General Hospital. Measures include\nmandatory temperature checks for all staff, limiting visitors, and\nisolation of all possible SARS cases. The Singapore General Hospital\noutbreak involved over 20 people with suspect symptoms, nearly all nurses\nand doctors. Only 7 have been diagnosed as \"probable\" SARS cases. The\ndistribution of cases over time suggests a point source. The health worker\nconsidered to be the index case in this cluster of cases may be the fourth\n\"super-spreader\" identified in Singapore.\n\nA \"super-spreader\" is a source case who has, for as yet unknown reasons,\ninfected a large number of persons. Although transmission patterns of SARS\nremain incompletely understood, evidence suggests that such\n\"super-spreaders\" may have contributed to the evolution of SARS outbreaks\naround the world.\n\nUntil recently, all cases in Singapore have had good epidemiological links\nto their source. Further work is now required to establish similar links\nfor the more recent cases. If confirmed, such linking of cases will show\nthat transmission is limited to those who are symptomatic and usually very\nill. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that health workers\ncontinue to be the main group diagnosed with SARS. To date, investigation\nof the SARS outbreak in Singapore have revealed few signs of community\nspread beyond family members in close face-to-face contact with patients.\nHowever, these findings are based on limited data on exposures.\n\nViet Nam: no asymptomatic transmission\n--------\nVietnam is now reporting a cumulative total of 62 cases. 4 of these cases\nhave been detected in the last few days following stable reporting of 58\ncases for several consecutive days. The stable number of cases raised hope\nthat the outbreak in the French hospital in Hanoi had been contained.\nHowever, a 59th case was reported on 31 Mar 2003.\n\nThis male patient had been in contact with his daughter, who was a patient\nat the French Hospital at the time of Viet Nam\u0092s index case. This contact\ncontinued when the daughter became an outpatient. The daughter\u0092s husband,\nwho attended the Hanoi French Hospital with his wife, had a mild febrile\nillness which was undiagnosed at the time and which resolved spontaneously.\nIt is presumed that he had mild SARS and passed the infection to his\nfather-in-law (case 59). Assuming this to be true, WHO epidemiologists\nmaintain the view that asymptomatic transmission does not appear to occur.\nNor does this case suggest a longer incubation period than currently\nassumed (2-7 days, with 10 days considered the rare maximum). Blood is\nbeing taken for testing of the husband. Case 60 is a doctor who cared for\ncase 59 while he was in a provincial hospital about 1.5 hours from Hanoi.\nCases 61 and 62 are young women who are part of the extended household who\nprovided considerable care for case 59.\n\nWHO continues to work with the Ministry of Health to investigate the\ncontacts of these cases. It is anticipated that a few more new cases will\nbe linked to case 59. Careful monitoring of contacts continues.\n\nOf the 62 cases, 44 have been discharged, 4 have died, and 14 remain in\nhospital. One of the hospitalized patients remains critically ill, although\nslightly improved. All other hospitalized patients are improving.\n\nCanada: one new probable case reported\n--------\nHealth Canada has reported a cumulative total of 94 probable cases and 10\ndeaths. Ontario has reported 91 probable cases. All cases have occurred in\npersons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the\nhousehold or in a health-care setting. The remaining probable cases are in\nBritish Columbia (3).\n\nUpdate on cases and countries\n-------------\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 2722 cases, with 106 deaths have been\nreported from 16 countries. This represents an increase of 51 cases and 3\ndeaths when compared with yesterday.\n\nNew cases were reported in Canada (3), China (1), Hong Kong SAR (42),\nSingapore (5), and the United States of America (1). The single case\nreported in Australia has been removed from the list. Deaths were reported\nin Hong Kong (2) and Singapore (1).\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Trying to synthesize the information contained in the above reports from\nWHO today, there are many positive points. With respect to China, the\nreports on the investigation in Guangdong are promising, and we look\nforward to seeing more epidemiologic and clinical details on the cases from\nthe outbreak. In addition, the collaboration with the Chinese MOH with\nrespect to laboratory studies is also very promising and will provide a\nbank of specimens among which to check diagnostic tests as well as to\nconduct further studies. On the negative side is the concern mentioned\nregarding other provinces' ability to manage an outbreak of SARS, both from\nthe clinical aspects as well as the public health aspects.\n\nFrom today's reported cases, it appears the predominant new case reports\nare coming from Hong Kong. In Singapore, there continues to be\ntransmission, as continuation of the original importations and further\ngenerations of transmission related to those original importations from\nHong Kong. The notion of \"super spreaders\" is further highlighted by the\nSingapore experience, and we look forward to more details from studies of\nthese reported \"super spreaders\". The experience in Viet Nam seems to\nsuggest that transmission does not occur during asymptomatic infection or\nduring the incubation period, but rather after the onset of clinical\nillness. The new cluster of cases is linked to the original outbreak in\nHanoi, with nosocomial spread to a health care worker, suggesting that\nnewly involved areas have not automatically suspected SARS and that a SARS\npatient is initially cared for in the absence of infection control\nprocedures. This begs the question: At what point should all febrile\npatients in the health care setting be initially evaluated using infection\ncontrol procedures, including respiratory barriers to transmission?\n\nThe addition of epidemic curves and geographic mapping of the ongoing SARS\noutbreak is appreciated, as \"a picture is worth 1000 words\" (as was\nevidenced by the amount of words necessary to attempt to describe the\nsignificance of the curves by this moderator). The daily case counts are\neasier to interpret when graphically represented.\n\nProf. Rod Griffiths, the Regional Director of Public Health, Prof. Rod\nGriffiths,West Midlands, UK <Rod@stonebow.demon.co.uk> inquired about\nattack rates -- what proportion of exposed individuals (contacts of\nprobable SARS cases) have gone on to develop SARS themselves. A good\nquestion, but a difficult one to answer in the absence of a definitive\ndiagnostic test for SARS at this point in time. We look forward to seeing\ncrude attack rates when available (taking liberty to refer to estimates of\nattack rates based on current clinical and epidemiologic case definitions,\nrecognizing that in the absence of a definitive diagnostic test these\ncalculations would be estimates as they would not account for asymptomatic\ninfections).\n\nThe removal of Australia from the list of countries reporting SARS cases is\na further reminder that SARS is a diagnosis of exclusion until there is a\ndefinitive diagnostic test that will allow for confirmation of cases, and\nthat there are still many other diagnoses that present with the same\nclinical syndrome as described for SARS. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (35):cases 20030408.0858\nSARS - Worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - Worldwide (33): cases 20030407.0850\nSARS - worldwide (31): etiology 20030405.0833\nSARS - worldwide (28): overview 20030403.0822\nSARS - worldwide (26): etiology 20030403.0819\nSARS - worldwide (19): etiology 20030330.0786\nSARS - Worldwide (16): Etiology 20030328.0774\nSARS - worldwide (14): overview 20030327.0769\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (10): infectious disease perspectives 20030326.0752\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n...........................mpp/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203604", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (36):cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203604", "date": "2003-04-09 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (36):CASES\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\nWorldwide - WHO\n[A] Cumulative case counts by country\n[B] Affected areas\n[C] Epidemiologic links (mapping and epidemic curves)\n[D] Update discussion\n\n******\nDate: 9 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website 9 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>\n\n\n[A] Cumulative number of reported probable(\u00a7) cases of severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome (SARS)\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_04_09/en/>\n\nFrom: 1 Nov 2002 To: 9 Apr 2003, 15:00 GMT+2\n\nCountry: Cumulative no. case(s)/ No. deaths/ Local chain(s) of\ntransmission (1)\n\nBrazil: 1/ 0/ None\nCanada: 94/ 10/ Yes\nChina: 1280/ 53/ Yes\nChina, Hong Kong SAR: 970/ 27*/ Yes\nChina, Taiwan: 19/ 0/ Yes\nFrance: 4/ 0/ None\nGermany: 5/ 0/ None\nItaly: 3/ 0/ None\nMalaysia: 1/ 1/ None\nRepublic of Ireland: 1/ 0/ None\nRomania: 1/ 0/ None\nSingapore: 118/ 9/ Yes\nSpain: 1/ 0/ None\nSwitzerland: 1/ 0/ None\nThailand: 7/ 2/ None\nUnited Kingdom: 5/ 0/ None\nUnited States: 149/ 0/ None\nViet Nam: 62/ 4/ Yes\n\nTotal: 2722/ 106\n\nNotes:\n\nCumulative number of cases includes number of deaths.\n\n1. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in which\nlocal chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are provided\non the list of Affected Areas.\n\n\u00a7Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a national level,\nprobable cases are reported by all countries except the United States of\nAmerica, which is reporting suspect cases under investigation.\n\n*One death attributed to Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China\noccurred in a case medically transferred from Viet Nam.\n\n\n[B] Affected areas 9 Apr 2003\n\nUnchanged from previous reports and can be accessed at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_09/en/>\n\n\n[C] Epidemiologic links\n\nA mapping of the cumulative number of SARS cases reported to WHO (and\ncontained in the above table [A]) as of 9 Apr 2003 can be found at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/map2003_04_09.jpg>\n\nEpidemic curves of the SARS cases reported to WHO (as of 8 Apr 2003) can be\nfound at: <http://www.who.int/csr/sarsepicurve/2003_04_08/en/>. There are\nmultiple curves, representing the global outbreak, and then outbreaks by\ncountry for Hong Kong, Viet Nam, Singapore, Canada, the United States, and\nthe European Region. Reviewing the curves, when looking at the epidemic\ncurve by date of onset, it does appear as though the global outbreak may\nhave already peaked, although this curve represents a small fraction of\nactual reported probable cases, as dates of onset were not available for\n2105 cases. The date of onset of the most recent reported cases was 1 Apr\n2003, 6 days preceding the last date of notification. In contrast, the\nepidemic curve plotting reported cases by date of report appears to be\nconsistent with ongoing transmission at a steady rate, with a marked\nincrease in numbers of cases reported on 1 Apr 2003 (representing the\ndelayed reports from China) and another significant increase in reported\ncases on 8 Apr 2003.\n\nThe epidemic curve by date of report in Hong Kong suggests that there was a\nlarge peak during the week of 29 Mar 2003, and a second smaller peak during\nthe week of 5 Apr 2003. The epidemic curve by date of onset for Viet Nam\nsuggests that there was a peak during the week of 8 Mar 2003, and apparent\ninterruption of transmission (or missed cases, or one incubation period\npending appearance of new cases) during the week of 29 Mar 2003 and the\nappearance of a few cases during the week of 5 Apr 2003. The epidemic\ncurve, by date of onset for Singapore shows a clear peak in cases during\nthe period 15-22 Mar 2003 and a significant tapering off of cases by the\nweek 5 Apr 2003. The epidemic curve, by date of onset, for Canada shows a\nclear peak during the period 15-22 Mar 2003, with continued transmission\nbut at a lower rate. There have not been any cases reported with dates of\nonset since 4 Apr 2003 in Canada. The epidemic curve, by date of onset\n(current as of 4 Apr 2003), for the United States shows several peak\nperiods of cases, during the weeks of 15 Mar 2003, 22 Mar 2003, and 29 Mar\n2003. The maximum number of cases with dates of onset on a single day was\n9 on 17 Mar 2003. (We do not have information on the dates of onset of the\nfew healthcare workers and family members that were contacts of imported\ncases, but the overwhelming majority of cases reported in the United States\nwere in individuals with a history of travel to affected areas (see section\n[B] above). There have not been any cases reported with dates of onset\nsince 30 Mar 2003, representing a 5-day period without new cases. In\ncontrast, the epidemic curve by date of onset for the European Region is\nmore consistent with sporadic case reports, with a maximum of one or 2\ncases per day. To date there have not been reports of any secondary\ntransmission in the European Region. - Mod.MPP]\n\n\n[D] Update 25 - Interim report of WHO team in China, status of the main\nSARS outbreaks in different countries 9 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_09/en/>\n\n[ProMED-mail would like to express our continuing gratitude to Marianne\nHopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com> for her daily monitoring of WHO reports. - Mod.MPP]\n\n\nChina\n------\nThe WHO team of experts presented its interim report on the SARS outbreak\nin Guangdong Province this morning to the Chinese Ministry of Health and\nVice Premier Wu Yi in Beijing. The team began its investigations in\nGuangdong on 3 Apr 2003.\n\nThe team concluded that the health system in Guangdong responded well to\nthe outbreak. The province has a health system in which every hospital at\nevery level reports any new cases of SARS. The WHO report therefore\nconcluded that virtually all probable cases of SARS presenting at a\nhospital in Guangdong Province will be detected and rapidly reported.\n\nHowever, the team found an urgent need to improve surveillance in the\ncountryside to head off new outbreaks in rural areas. The team was further\nconcerned by an increase in sporadic cases, which could not be linked to a\nparticular transmission chain, as such cases raised questions about the\nadequacy of contact tracing.\n\nIn addition, the report noted many remaining concerns about the ability of\nother provinces, where health systems are not as strong as the one in\nGuangdong, to respond promptly and effectively to the challenge of SARS.\n\nIn Beijing, for example, only a minority of hospitals make daily reports of\nSARS cases. Contact tracing is another problem in Beijing and does not\nappear to be carried out systematically. Failure to perform careful contact\ntracing will allow the disease to spread.\n\nThe team observed that many of China\u0092s poorer provinces may not have\nadequate resources, facilities, and equipment to cope with outbreaks of\nSARS, and underscored that Guangdong\u0092s capacity was exceptional among\nChina\u0092s provinces.\n\nIn Guangdong, the SARS outbreak placed an enormous strain on the health\ncare system. The Guangdong Infectious Disease Hospital (Guangzhou No. 8\nPeople\u0092s Hospital) had 150 of its 400 beds occupied by SARS patients daily\nduring the second week of February [2003]. The team noted that the response\nof the health care system has been exemplary, and commended the dedication\nand bravery of doctors, nurses, and others working in clinics and hospitals.\n\nMicrobiological findings\n----------\nLarge banks of stored specimens from suspected and probable SARS cases,\nfrom case contacts as well as from \u0093normal controls\u0094 exist at the\ninstitutions visited and are stored under suitable conditions; detailed\ninformation about the numbers and types of these specimens are available\nand were provided to members of the WHO team. Although the patient data on\neach of these is very limited, it is sufficient to allow linkage with the\nvery detailed epidemiological and clinical information held elsewhere in\nGuangdong Provincial Centers for Disease Control and the hospitals.\n\nThese specimen banks comprise different types of respiratory specimens from\nwhich the detection of agents can be attempted and serum samples, often as\npaired acute and convalescent sera (i.e., the first sample obtained during\nthe acute phase of the illness and the second during recovery), which will\nallow determination of seroconversions. The laboratory staff agreed that\nonce a causative agent for SARS was identified, these banks should be\ntested and will provide very valuable information; they seemed, however,\nless sure whether this time had come already, i.e. whether there was\nalready sufficient evidence and whether suitable tests had been developed\nelsewhere that would make such an exercise worthwhile. They requested\nassistance from the WHO team to obtain relevant information on primer\nsequences and other matters as well as access to suitable experimental\ntests such as immunofluorescence antibody assays.\n\nMain recommendations\n---------\nThe interim report made several major recommendations, including the following:\n\n- The SARS reporting system established in Guangdong is an excellent model\nthat all provinces should follow. Team members suggest that the MOH ensures\nthat all provinces are brought up to Guangdong standards by implementing\nthis system nationwide as a matter of the utmost urgency. A programme for\nevaluating and accrediting surveillance systems through evaluation by\ntechnical experts is also suggested in order to ensure that consistent\nstandards are achieved and maintained.\n\n- The Guangdong experience should be used to develop uniform standards\nthroughout all provinces for preventing the spread of SARS in health care\nfacilities.\n\n- Careful contact tracing of SARS cases is vital to bring the outbreak\nunder control. Detailed interviewing of all newly reported SARS cases by\ntrained interviewers including a full review not only of close contacts but\npotential exposure in other crowded settings, e.g. public transport, needs\nto be routinely carried out. Contacts of cases should be provided with\ndetailed preventive advice verbally and in writing.\n\n- Much better collaboration between virological laboratories in China is\nrequired, particularly to facilitate the exchange of results, specimens,\nand reagents. The following institutions should form the nucleus of a\nnational SARS laboratory network within China:\n- National Institute of Virology, China CDC, Beijing\n- Virology Unit, Beijing Provincial CDC, Beijing\n- Virology Unit, Guangdong Provincial CDC, Guangzhou\n- Department of Virology, Zhongshan University, Guangzhou\nLaboratories from other areas with experience of SARS cases should also be\nincluded. Adequate funding and human resources need to be urgently provided\nto ensure the proper functioning and sustainability of SARS surveillance\nactivities, as they are essential to controlling spread of the disease.\nChinese institutions should form a national SARS laboratory network within\nChina to speed up the exchange of results, specimens, and reagents.\n\n- Guangdong clinicians have cared for the largest number of patients in the\nworld and their experience should be shared with the international\ncommunity through publications, meetings, and in drafting guidelines for\nthe management of SARS patients.\n\nPriority actions\nPriority actions recommended in the report to contain SARS include:\n\n- early recognition and treatment of cases\n\n- stringent infection control measures in hospitals and clinics\n\n- prompt reporting of suspected cases\n\n- meticulous investigation and contact tracing in the community - public\nawareness campaigns and education.\n\n\nHong Kong: heavy burden on the health system\n---------\nWith today\u0092s cumulative total of 970 cases and 27 deaths, Hong Kong\ncontinues to have the largest SARS outbreak, second to China. The strain on\nhealth services and staff is considerable, and strengthened measures of\ninfection control may be needed.\n\nThe isolation order placed on Block E, Amory Gardens will expire at\nmidnight, 9 Apr 2003. The Hong Kong Health Department has announced that\nresidents, temporarily housed at camps, may return home after their flats\nhave been disinfected by the Food and Environmental Hygiene Department.\n\nSingapore: role of \"super-spreaders\"\n----------\nSingapore has increased measures to prevent transmission in hospitals\nfollowing an outbreak in Singapore General Hospital. Measures include\nmandatory temperature checks for all staff, limiting visitors, and\nisolation of all possible SARS cases. The Singapore General Hospital\noutbreak involved over 20 people with suspect symptoms, nearly all nurses\nand doctors. Only 7 have been diagnosed as \"probable\" SARS cases. The\ndistribution of cases over time suggests a point source. The health worker\nconsidered to be the index case in this cluster of cases may be the fourth\n\"super-spreader\" identified in Singapore.\n\nA \"super-spreader\" is a source case who has, for as yet unknown reasons,\ninfected a large number of persons. Although transmission patterns of SARS\nremain incompletely understood, evidence suggests that such\n\"super-spreaders\" may have contributed to the evolution of SARS outbreaks\naround the world.\n\nUntil recently, all cases in Singapore have had good epidemiological links\nto their source. Further work is now required to establish similar links\nfor the more recent cases. If confirmed, such linking of cases will show\nthat transmission is limited to those who are symptomatic and usually very\nill. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that health workers\ncontinue to be the main group diagnosed with SARS. To date, investigation\nof the SARS outbreak in Singapore have revealed few signs of community\nspread beyond family members in close face-to-face contact with patients.\nHowever, these findings are based on limited data on exposures.\n\nViet Nam: no asymptomatic transmission\n--------\nVietnam is now reporting a cumulative total of 62 cases. 4 of these cases\nhave been detected in the last few days following stable reporting of 58\ncases for several consecutive days. The stable number of cases raised hope\nthat the outbreak in the French hospital in Hanoi had been contained.\nHowever, a 59th case was reported on 31 Mar 2003.\n\nThis male patient had been in contact with his daughter, who was a patient\nat the French Hospital at the time of Viet Nam\u0092s index case. This contact\ncontinued when the daughter became an outpatient. The daughter\u0092s husband,\nwho attended the Hanoi French Hospital with his wife, had a mild febrile\nillness which was undiagnosed at the time and which resolved spontaneously.\nIt is presumed that he had mild SARS and passed the infection to his\nfather-in-law (case 59). Assuming this to be true, WHO epidemiologists\nmaintain the view that asymptomatic transmission does not appear to occur.\nNor does this case suggest a longer incubation period than currently\nassumed (2-7 days, with 10 days considered the rare maximum). Blood is\nbeing taken for testing of the husband. Case 60 is a doctor who cared for\ncase 59 while he was in a provincial hospital about 1.5 hours from Hanoi.\nCases 61 and 62 are young women who are part of the extended household who\nprovided considerable care for case 59.\n\nWHO continues to work with the Ministry of Health to investigate the\ncontacts of these cases. It is anticipated that a few more new cases will\nbe linked to case 59. Careful monitoring of contacts continues.\n\nOf the 62 cases, 44 have been discharged, 4 have died, and 14 remain in\nhospital. One of the hospitalized patients remains critically ill, although\nslightly improved. All other hospitalized patients are improving.\n\nCanada: one new probable case reported\n--------\nHealth Canada has reported a cumulative total of 94 probable cases and 10\ndeaths. Ontario has reported 91 probable cases. All cases have occurred in\npersons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the\nhousehold or in a health-care setting. The remaining probable cases are in\nBritish Columbia (3).\n\nUpdate on cases and countries\n-------------\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 2722 cases, with 106 deaths have been\nreported from 16 countries. This represents an increase of 51 cases and 3\ndeaths when compared with yesterday.\n\nNew cases were reported in Canada (3), China (1), Hong Kong SAR (42),\nSingapore (5), and the United States of America (1). The single case\nreported in Australia has been removed from the list. Deaths were reported\nin Hong Kong (2) and Singapore (1).\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Trying to synthesize the information contained in the above reports from\nWHO today, there are many positive points. With respect to China, the\nreports on the investigation in Guangdong are promising, and we look\nforward to seeing more epidemiologic and clinical details on the cases from\nthe outbreak. In addition, the collaboration with the Chinese MOH with\nrespect to laboratory studies is also very promising and will provide a\nbank of specimens among which to check diagnostic tests as well as to\nconduct further studies. On the negative side is the concern mentioned\nregarding other provinces' ability to manage an outbreak of SARS, both from\nthe clinical aspects as well as the public health aspects.\n\nFrom today's reported cases, it appears the predominant new case reports\nare coming from Hong Kong. In Singapore, there continues to be\ntransmission, as continuation of the original importations and further\ngenerations of transmission related to those original importations from\nHong Kong. The notion of \"super spreaders\" is further highlighted by the\nSingapore experience, and we look forward to more details from studies of\nthese reported \"super spreaders\". The experience in Viet Nam seems to\nsuggest that transmission does not occur during asymptomatic infection or\nduring the incubation period, but rather after the onset of clinical\nillness. The new cluster of cases is linked to the original outbreak in\nHanoi, with nosocomial spread to a health care worker, suggesting that\nnewly involved areas have not automatically suspected SARS and that a SARS\npatient is initially cared for in the absence of infection control\nprocedures. This begs the question: At what point should all febrile\npatients in the health care setting be initially evaluated using infection\ncontrol procedures, including respiratory barriers to transmission?\n\nThe addition of epidemic curves and geographic mapping of the ongoing SARS\noutbreak is appreciated, as \"a picture is worth 1000 words\" (as was\nevidenced by the amount of words necessary to attempt to describe the\nsignificance of the curves by this moderator). The daily case counts are\neasier to interpret when graphically represented.\n\nProf. Rod Griffiths, the Regional Director of Public Health, Prof. Rod\nGriffiths,West Midlands, UK <Rod@stonebow.demon.co.uk> inquired about\nattack rates -- what proportion of exposed individuals (contacts of\nprobable SARS cases) have gone on to develop SARS themselves. A good\nquestion, but a difficult one to answer in the absence of a definitive\ndiagnostic test for SARS at this point in time. We look forward to seeing\ncrude attack rates when available (taking liberty to refer to estimates of\nattack rates based on current clinical and epidemiologic case definitions,\nrecognizing that in the absence of a definitive diagnostic test these\ncalculations would be estimates as they would not account for asymptomatic\ninfections).\n\nThe removal of Australia from the list of countries reporting SARS cases is\na further reminder that SARS is a diagnosis of exclusion until there is a\ndefinitive diagnostic test that will allow for confirmation of cases, and\nthat there are still many other diagnoses that present with the same\nclinical syndrome as described for SARS. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (35):cases 20030408.0858\nSARS - Worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857\nSARS - Worldwide (33): cases 20030407.0850\nSARS - worldwide (31): etiology 20030405.0833\nSARS - worldwide (28): overview 20030403.0822\nSARS - worldwide (26): etiology 20030403.0819\nSARS - worldwide (19): etiology 20030330.0786\nSARS - Worldwide (16): Etiology 20030328.0774\nSARS - worldwide (14): overview 20030327.0769\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (10): infectious disease perspectives 20030326.0752\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n...........................mpp/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00", "2105-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-04-01 00:00:00", "2003-04-08 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-04-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-04-03 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-31 00:00:00", "2062-03-16 00:00:00", "2034-03-16 00:00:00", "2033-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "none", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203602", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (35):cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203602", "date": "2003-04-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (28): OVERVIEW\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Descriptive epidemiology, USA - CDC, MMWR\n[2] Worldwide overview - Eurosurveillance Weekly\n*****\n[1]\nDate: 3 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR 4 Apr 2003 / 52(13);269-272 [accessed 3 Apr 2003]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5213a1.htm>\n\nUpdate: Outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome --- Worldwide, 2003\n------------------------\nCDC and the World Health Organization (WHO) are continuing to investigate\nthe multicountry outbreak of unexplained atypical pneumonia referred to as\nsevere acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) (1). Pending development of\nconfirmatory laboratory testing capacity, CDC's interim suspected SARS case\ndefinition (2) is based on clinical criteria and epidemiologic linkage to\nother SARS cases or areas with community transmission of SARS. This case\ndefinition will be updated periodically as new information becomes\navailable. Epidemiologic and laboratory investigations of SARS are ongoing.\nAs of 2 Apr 2003, a total of 2223 suspected and/or probable SARS cases\nhave been reported to WHO from 16 countries, including the United States\n(3,4). The reported SARS cases include 78 deaths (case-fatality proportion:\n3.5 percent). This report summarizes SARS cases among U.S. residents and\nsurveillance and prevention activities in the United States.\nDescriptive Epidemiology\n----------------------\nAs of April 2, CDC had received 100 reports of suspected SARS cases [see\nFigure 1 on webpage for epidemiologic curve\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5213a1.htm>] from 28 states; 81\n(81 percent) cases occurred among adults [see table 1 below]. Of these 100\nsuspected cases, 94 (94%) persons had traveled within the 10 days before\nillness onset to the areas listed in the case definition (revised on 29 Mar\n2003 to include all of mainland China as an area with documented or\nsuspected community transmission), 4 had household contact with a person\nwith suspected SARS, and 2 were health-care workers (HCWs) who provided\nmedical care to a patient with suspected SARS.\nManifestations of SARS have been relatively less severe among patients in\nthe United States than among those reported elsewhere. A majority of U.S.\npatients had normal chest radiographs, and 23 (23 percent) were reported to\nhave pneumonia or respiratory distress syndrome on chest radiograph, thereby\nmeeting the WHO case definition of a probable case (4). As of 2 Apr 2003, of\nthe 40 (40 percent) patients who were hospitalized for greater than 24\nhours, 13 (33 percent of 40) remained hospitalized; one patient had required\nmechanical ventilatory support, and no deaths have been reported.\nReports on the clinical status of suspected SARS cases are being received\nby state health departments and CDC, and household and HCW contacts are\nbeing monitored for the possibility of secondary transmission. Since SARS\ninvestigations in the United States began, some persons believed initially\nto have suspected SARS have been excluded on the basis of more complete\nclinical histories (e.g., no documented fever or respiratory symptoms) or\nbecause of testing results that indicated other etiologies. Alternative\ndiagnoses have included infection with influenza virus, respiratory\nsyncytial virus, _Haemophilus influenzae_, _Streptococcus pneumoniae_, and\n_Staphylococcus aureus_. Community transmission of SARS has not been\nidentified in the United States; transmission to HCWs has been observed in\none cluster involving 2 HCWs, compared with numerous reports of possible\ntransmission to HCWs in other countries (5--7).\nEnhanced Surveillance for SARS Related to Travel\n---------------------------------------------\nAs a precautionary measure, WHO has recommended that persons traveling to\nHong Kong and Guangdong Province of China consider postponing all but\nessential travel. CDC has issued a travel advisory recommending that\npersons planning nonessential or elective travel to mainland China, Hong\nKong, Hanoi, or Singapore consider postponing such travel until further\nnotice.\nTo detect possible SARS cases among travelers returning to the United States\nfrom these areas, CDC and state and local health authorities have\nimplemented enhanced surveillance. Since 16 Mar 2003, notices (available in\nEnglish, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Vietnamese) have been provided to\napproximately 220 000 passengers arriving in the United States on airline\nflights originating from China, Vietnam, and Singapore to inform\ndisembarking passengers and crew about SARS. Persons disembarking from these\ncountries are urged to monitor their health for 10 days after return, to\nseek medical care if they develop fever of greater than 100.5 F (39.0 C) and\ncough or difficulty breathing within 10 days of travel, and to inform their\nhealth-care providers about recent travel to regions where SARS cases have\nbeen reported.\nLaboratory Investigations\n----------------------\nEfforts are ongoing to characterize further the role of a previously\nunrecognized coronavirus in SARS. Polymerase chain reaction-based assays,\nisolation studies, electron microscopic studies, and histologic studies are\nbeing developed to detect virus in specimens from patients with suspected\nSARS. Indirect immunoflorescence antibody assays and enzyme immunoassays to\nanti-coronavirus antibody as an indicator of infection have been developed\nand are being applied to specimens from suspected SARS patients. Laboratory\nstudies at CDC and other laboratories in the WHO-organized SARS Laboratory\nNetwork have detected this new coronavirus in SARS patients, which is\nconsistent with an etiologic role in this disease. CDC has detected human\nmetapneumovirus from one SARS patient, and other laboratories also have\ndetected metapneumovirus from SARS patients (6). The role of these viruses\nin the pathogenesis of SARS is unclear.\nMMWR Editorial Note:\n--------------------\nThe number of SARS cases, and the number of countries reporting such cases,\ncontinues to increase worldwide. Transmission within hospitals and\nhouseholds continues in some areas, and transmission within communities\n(e.g., Hong Kong) continues to be reported. In the absence of a complete\nunderstanding of how SARS is transmitted, efforts to limit transmission in\nthe United States have focused on early identification of potential cases\nthrough surveillance and implementation of infection-control measures in\nhealth-care settings and the community.\nCDC has developed interim infection-control guidelines for use in U.S.\nhealth-care and household settings (8). These recommendations are based on\nexperience in the United States to date and will be revised as more\ninformation becomes available. Infection-control practitioners and\nclinicians providing medical care for patients with suspected SARS should\nconsult these guidelines frequently to keep current with recommendations.\nTransmission in health-care settings has been documented in several\ncountries. Transmission to HCWs appears to have occurred primarily after\nclose contact with symptomatic persons before recommended infection-control\nprecautions for SARS were implemented. Because a primary strategy to reduce\ntransmission in health-care settings is early recognition and isolation of\npatients who might have SARS, triage practices in hospitals and\nambulatory-care settings might require reevaluation. CDC guidelines for\ntriage of potential SARS cases are available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/triage_interim_guidance.htm>.\nIn the United States, decisions to admit persons with suspected SARS to\nhealth-care facilities should be based on clinical criteria. Patients with\nsuspected SARS who are discharged should limit interactions outside the\nhome and not go to work, school, out-of-home child care, or other public\nareas until 10 days after resolution of fever and respiratory symptoms.\nAdditional guidance for these patients is available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/ic-closecontacts.htm>.\nThe majority of U.S. residents with SARS have recovered or stabilized\nclinically without specific antiviral therapy. The U.S. case-fatality\nproportion is lower than that reported in some other countries (3).\nPossible explanations for this include differing case definitions among\ncountries or differences in the sensitivity of surveillance, leading to\nidentification in the United States of patients with less severe or early\nmanifestations of infection or of a larger proportion of patients with\nother respiratory illnesses. Until confirmatory laboratory testing is\navailable, the case definition will include clinical criteria more likely\nto identify potentially infectious persons. Various therapies, including\nantiviral agents (e.g., oseltamivir or ribavirin) and corticosteroids, have\nbeen administered to SARS patients, but the efficacy of these therapies has\nnot been determined.\nHealth-care providers of patients whose illness is consistent with the case\ndefinition for SARS should continue diagnostic evaluation for other causes\nof respiratory illness and, when appropriate, empiric therapy that includes\nactivity against organisms associated with community-acquired pneumonia of\nuncertain etiology, including both typical and atypical respiratory\npathogens (9). Health-care providers who report suspected SARS cases should\nnotify their state health departments if these patients receive\nconfirmatory testing that indicates a diagnosis other than SARS.\nInformation on suggested diagnostic testing and evaluation for persons with\npossible SARS is available at http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/diagnosis.htm.\nAirline travel\n----------\nThe potential for transmission of SARS during airline travel is unknown.\nTransmission of other infectious agents (e.g., _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_)\nduring air travel has been demonstrated (10). When an airline flight crew\nreports a passenger with respiratory illness, quarantine officials might\nboard the aircraft on arrival in the United States to assess whether the\npassenger's symptoms match the case definition of SARS and give the\npassenger information about following up. If a passenger with suspected\nSARS is identified after passengers have disembarked, public health\nauthorities will work with the airline to contact passengers and crew for\ninformation about the development of an illness suggestive of SARS.\nAlthough ill travelers have spread SARS rapidly across international\nborders, the proportion, if any, of persons who acquired SARS during\ninternational travel as a result of in-flight transmission is unknown.\nDespite vigorous efforts to identify and isolate suspected cases, reducing\ntransmission of the etiologic agents of SARS might be difficult.\nUnderstanding the epidemiology of respiratory pathogens such as those that\ncause SARS is challenging; approximately 40-60 percent of persons with\npneumonia do not have a defined etiology, even when extensive testing for\nknown respiratory pathogens is attempted (9). Minimizing transmission will\nrequire sustained attention to infection-control interventions within\nhealth-care settings and the community. The development of laboratory\ntesting techniques to identify infected persons rapidly will be an\nimportant step toward understanding and reducing transmission of SARS.\nReferences\n--------\n1. CDC. Outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome---worldwide, 2003.\nMMWR 2003;52:226--8.\n2. CDC. Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) updated interim case\ndefinition. Available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/casedefinition.htm>.\n3. World Health Organization. Cumulative number of reported cases of severe\nacute respiratory syndrome (SARS). Available at\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_04_02/en>.\n4. World Health Organization. Case definitions for surveillance of severe\nacute respiratory syndrome (SARS). Available at\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/casedefinition/en>.\n5. Tsang KW, Ho PL, Ooi GC, et al. A cluster of cases of severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome in Hong Kong. N Eng J Med. Available at\n<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/abstract/NEJMoa030666v1>.\n6. Poutanen SM, Low DE, Henry B, et al. Identification of severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome in Canada. N Eng J Med. Available at\n<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/abstract/NEJMoa030634v1>.\n7. World Health Organization. Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).\nAvailable at <http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en>.\n8. CDC. Interim guidance on infection control precautions for patients with\nsuspected severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and close contacts in\nhouseholds. Available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/ic-closecontacts.htm>.\n9. Bartlett JG, Dowell SF, Mandell LA, File TM Jr, Musher DM, Fine MJ.\nPractice guidelines for the management of community-acquired pneumonia in\nadults. Clin Infect Dis 2000;31:347--82.\n10. Kenyon TA, Valway SE, Ihle WW, Onorato IM, Castro KG. Transmission of\nmulti-drug resistant tuberculosis during a long airplane flight. N Engl J\nMed 1996;334:933--8.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate:\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly 3 Apr 2003 Volume 7 / Issue 14\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2003/030403.asp>\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome: international update\n-------------------------\nAs of 2 Apr 2003, 2223 cases of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) and\n78 deaths have been reported to the World Health Organization (WHO), a case\nfatality rate of 3.5 percent\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_04_02/en/>. This is an increase of\n4 to 5-fold in the global totals in the last 7 days\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_03_25/en/> with the greatest\nproportionate and absolute increases being in China (Hong Kong & Guangdong\nProvince), and to a much lesser extent in Canada. There has been little\nabsolute rise in other country totals.\n18 countries have now reported cases but in most of these no transmission\nseems to have occurred. Local transmission has occurred in Hanoi (Vietnam),\nSingapore, Toronto (Canada), Taiwan, and the following parts of China:\nGuangdong Province;\nBeijing; Shanxi; and Hong Kong SAR. In the United Kingdom 3 probable SARS\ncases have been reported; all have now recovered. Indeed, the only areas\nwhere WHO feels there is evidence consistent with current transmission are\nHong Kong and Guangdong\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_02_02b/en/>, and the WHO has issued\nadvice to international travellers not to travel to or through either area.\nGuangdong and Hong Kong\n--------------------------\nInformation about the outbreaks in Guangdong is limited, but the latest\nreports give a significant increase of over 350 cases during March 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_02_02b/en/>. Detailed\ndescriptions from Hong Kong are now available. Following transmission\ncentering on a large hotel, there have been intense hospital outbreaks\ninvolving staff, patient and families of staff (1) where community\ntransmission has been established. There is now evidence of community\ntransmission within a large housing complex.\nMeasures introduced by Hong Kong, Singapore, and Canada to control the\nlocal spread of SARS have included school closures (Hong Kong and\nSingapore), the quarantine of entire residential buildings (Hong Kong), and\nthe restriction of non-essential access to hospitals -- all 3,\n<http://www.health.gov.on.ca/english/public/pub/disease/sars_6.html>.\nAlthough such precautions are not yet necessary in Europe, the experience\nin Canada is a sobering reminder of what could happen in any country\nreceiving a case.\nOntario, Canada\n---------------\nThe outbreak in Canada began with a Toronto woman who developed respiratory\nsymptoms 2 days after returning from Hong Kong. She died at home 10 days\nlater, but meanwhile appears to have transmitted infection to 4 members of\nher family. One of them, her adult son, was admitted to a local hospital\nwith respiratory symptoms. He spent some time in an open part of the\nemergency department before being transferred to the intensive care unit,\nwhere he remained until his death, 6 days after admission. It is now\napparent that transmission of SARS has occurred within the hospital. A\npatient who was in the next bed in the emergency department developed\nsymptoms of SARS 3 days after his visit to the emergency department, and\ndied 11 days later. A large number of hospital staff who worked in the\nemergency department and the intensive care unit where the son of the index\ncase was cared for have now presented with symptoms of SARS. Transmission\nin the intensive care unit may have been from the patient or from visiting\nfamily members, some of whom were symptomatic at the time they visited (2).\nThe Province of Ontario declared a health emergency on 26 Mar 2003, and on\n1 Apr 2003 a sixth death from SARS was reported from Toronto. As of 1 Apr\n2003, Ontario has reported 51 probable cases of SARS. The hospital has now\nbeen closed to new admissions.\nThe experience in Canada illustrates that highly developed countries can be\nvulnerable to transmission from imported cases of SARS, especially in\nhospitals (3,4). Most of the data have been consistent with transmission\nthrough large droplets or body fluids. Aerosol transmission cannot be\ntotally discounted, but if it occurs it is uncommon. If the causative\norganism had been readily transmissible by aerosol, many more cases would\nhave been expected, especially in the countries where transmission has\nslowed or never started. In Hong Kong there are some patterns of infection\nthat are most easily explained by environmental transmission such as\nfomites.\nIf the infection is not recognised early and appropriate infection control\nprecautions put in place, extensive transmission can occur. Those most at\nrisk seem to be family members and healthcare workers who have close\ncontact with symptomatic cases. It is worth noting that there have been no\nreported secondary cases from 2 hospitalised Canadian SARS cases where\nfamily members were not permitted to visit and healthcare workers adhered\nto strict infection control precautions.\nClinicians, accident and emergency, intensive treatment units, and\ninfectious disease staff in Europe should be alert to the possibility of\nSARS in people with fever and respiratory symptoms, IF they have recently\nreturned from areas where transmission of SARS is ongoing (currently Hong\nKong, and probably Guangdong) or who have had contact with a case of SARS\n<http://www.phls.co.uk/topics_az/SARS/management_guidance.htm>. When\npatients suspected of having SARS are admitted to hospital, it is vital\nthat infection control precautions are rapidly implemented and rigorously\nenforced <http://www.phls.co.uk/topics_az/SARS/hospital_guidance.htm>.\nUpdates on the developing situation are also available from WHO\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>) , on ProMED\n(<http://www.promedmail.org>), and at the websites of various national\npublic health organisations, including CDC\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/>), Health Canada\n(<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/index.html>), and the Health\nProtection Agency in the United Kingdom\n(<http://www.phls.org.uk/topics_az/SARS/menu.htm>)(5-7).\nEurosurveillance Weekly welcomes comments on other useful information\nsources, please send\nto elizabeth.hoile@hpa.org.uk.\nReferences:\n1. Tsang KW, Ho PL, Ooi GC, Yee WK, Wang T, Chan-Yeung M, et al. A cluster\nof cases of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome in Hong Kong. N Engl J Med\n2003; published at <http://www.nejm.org>) ahead of print, 31 March 2003.\n(10.1056/NEJMoa030666).\n(<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/reprint/NEJMoa030666v2.pdf>)\n2. Poutanen SM, Low DE, Henry B, Finkelstein S, Rose D, Green K,et al.\nIdentification of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome in Canada. N Engl J Med\n2003; published at <http://www.nejm.org> ahead of print, 31 March 2003\n(10.1056/NEJMoa030634).\n(<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/reprint/NEJMoa030634v1.pdf>)\n3. Drazen JM. Case clusters of the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome. N\nEngl J Med 2003; published at <http://www.nejm.org> ahead of print, 31\nMarch 2003 (10.1056/NEJMe030062).\n(<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/reprint/NEJMe030062v2.pdf>)\n4. Gerberding JL. Faster...but fast enough? Responding to the epidemic of\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome. N Engl J Med 2003; published at\n<http://www.nejm.org> ahead of print, 2 April 2003 (10.1056/NEJMe030067).\n(<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/reprint/NEJMe030067v1.pdf>)\n5. Eurosurveillance Weekly. Clinical descriptions of Severe Acute\nRespiratory Syndrome (SARS). Eurosurveillance Weekly 2003; 7: 030327.\n(<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2003/030327.asp>)\n6. Debenoist A-C, Boccia D. Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome - update.\nEurosurveillance Weekly 2003; 7: 030320.\n(<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2003/030320.asp>)\n7. Debenoist A-C, Boccia D. WHO initiates enhanced global surveillance in\nresponse to acute respiratory syndrome in China, Vietnam, and Hong Kong,\nspecial administrative region (SAR) of China. Eurosurveillance Weekly 2003;\n7: 030313. (<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2003/030313.asp>)\n[by:Peter Horby (peter.horby@hpa.org.uk) and Angus Nicoll, Health\nProtection Agency Communicable Disease Surveillance Centre, London, England]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[These 2 weekly updates are good descriptions of the ongoing outbreak with\ndiscussions on public health implications and recommendations. The MMWR\narticle is interesting as it presents information on suspected as well as\nprobable cases, suggesting that the suspected cases, milder forms without\npneumonia may well be part of the clinical spectrum of SARS. Once\navailable, a definitive etiologic agent with laboratory testing for\nconfirmation will help define the true spectrum of clinical disease.\nIt is also interesting to note that a human metapneumovirus was isolated\nfrom one of the patients with SARS in the USA. Clearly we await further\ninformation with respect to the etiologic agent of SARS.\nThe observation in the Eurosurveillance Weekly report that \"The experience\nin Canada illustrates that highly developed countries can be vulnerable to\ntransmission from imported cases of SARS, especially in hospitals (3,4).\"\nis an important reminder of the realities of this current outbreak. -\nMod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (27): cases 20030403.0820\nSARS - worldwide (26): etiology 20030403.0819\nSARS - worldwide (25): cases 20030402.0811\nSARS - worldwide (24): cases 20030402.0808\nSARS - worldwide (23): cases 20030401.0806\nSARS - worldwide (19): etiology 20030330.0786\nSARS - Worldwide (16): Etiology 20030328.0774\nSARS - worldwide (14): overview 20030327.0769\nSARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758\nSARS - worldwide (12): correction Shanxi not Shanghai 20030327.0756\nSARS - worldwide (10): infectious disease perspectives 20030326.0752\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - East Asia 20030314.0630\nAcute respiratory syndrome - China (HK), VietNam (03) 20030313.0624\nUndiagnosed illness - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n................................mpp/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "sars", "tuberculosis", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-04-02 00:00:00", "2021-04-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-04-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-04-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-31 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-31 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-04-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong Province of", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Valway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ooi GC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA",
