"url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203564", "date": "2003-03-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (20): CASES\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Hong Kong - DOH\n[2] Singapore - MOH\n[3] Canada - Health Canada\n******\n[1]\nDate: 30 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health 30 Mar 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\n[A] Update on atypical pneumonia 30 Mar 2003\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAn additional 60 patients with symptoms of atypical pneumonia were admitted\nto public hospitals as of 1 PM 30 Mar 2003. They include 6 healthcare\nworkers and 36 patients from Amoy Gardens. The remaining 18 were new\npatients and contacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.\n17 patients, including 12 healthcare workers and medical students of Prince\nof Wales Hospital, were discharged from hospital today. A total of 60\npatients to date have recovered from atypical pneumonia and been discharged.\nCurrently, 52 patients are receiving treatment in the intensive care unit.\nA 74-year-old female patient with a history of other diseases died in\nUnited Christian Hospital this morning. This brings to 13 the total number\nof patients died with atypical pneumonia in public hospitals.\nThe cumulative figure for patients admitted to public hospitals with\natypical pneumonia is 530, starting from 12 Mar 2003.\nThe breakdown of figures is as follows: (The numbers in bracket are those\nwith pneumonia symptoms)\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students 162 (162)\n36 of the patients were discharged\nPatients, family members & visitors 368 (368)\n24 of the patients were discharged\nTotal admission 530 (530)\n60 were discharged\n[B] Flight passengers urged to contact DH 30 Mar 2003\nThe Department of Health (DH) on 30 Mar 2003 called on passengers who had\ntravelled from Beijing to Hong Kong on flight KA 901(Dragonair) on 26 Mar\n2003 to call DH's hotline 2961 8968 for health advice on atypical pneumonia\nand surveillance. The hotline will be manned from noon to 5 PM 30 Mar 2003\nand from 9 AM to 5 PM on weekdays.\nThe plea was made as DH's investigation found that a Hong Kong man who had\ntaken the flight developed symptoms of severe acute respiratory syndrome\nduring his stay in Beijing. He was later confirmed to have contracted the\ndisease. DH has informed the Airport Authority and the airline. Advice was\nalso given to the airline concerned to disinfect the airplanes. DH is\ntracing the crew members and passengers who had taken these 2 flights, for\nsurveillance purposes.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 30 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore Ministry of Health 30 Mar 2003 [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5740>\n\nSARS: New measures at airport to curb importation of new cases; more\npatients recovering and discharged - 30 Mar 2003\nIn yesterday's Press Release, MOH had informed that the fourth imported\ncase left for Hong Kong on 14 Mar 2003 and then to Beijing on 15 Mar 2003.\nOn 19 Mar 2003, she became unwell. Between 19-23 Mar 2003, she met and\nworked with 2 Singaporean colleagues, who have since returned to Singapore\nand are well. She arrived back in Singapore on Southern China Airlines CZ\n355 at Terminal 1, Changi Airport on 26 Mar 2003 at 5.38 am. Accompanied by\nher mother, she took a taxi from the airport to the Accident & Emergency\nDepartment, Singapore General Hospital. From there, she was transferred by\nambulance and admitted to Tan Tock Seng Hospital.\nHer mother and 2 colleagues have been issued with Home Quarantine Orders.\nOthers who were served the Orders were 3 SATS officers, 2 SIR officers and\n2 relations officers from the airline. We have identified a taxi-driver who\nsaid that he had ferried 2 women from Changi Airport to the Accident &\nEmergency Department, Singapore General Hospital on the morning of 26 Mar\n2003. As a precautionary measure, a Home Quarantine Order has been issued\nto him.\nFollowing yesterday's press statement, we have been able to locate 10 more\npassengers. They are all well and quarantine orders are being served to\nthem. In total, 40 of the 48 passengers (excluding the case) have been\nidentified. There is a possibility that some of the remaining 8 passengers\nare no longer in Singapore. The names of the remaining 8 passengers who we\nhave still been unable to locate are [see\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5740> for list of names.]\nThe latest (fifth) imported case is a 17-year-old Indonesian male student\nwho left Singapore on 15 Mar 2003 with his parents and his 15-year-old\nbrother for Guangdong and Hong Kong. The family returned to Singapore on\nthe night of 23 Mar 2003. On 24 Mar 2003, he was well and attended school\nat Bowen Secondary School. On 25 Mar 2003, he developed a fever and was\nseen at TTSH as an outpatient. He was given 5 days medical leave. He was\nseen again on 27 Mar 2003 and admitted to TTSH as a suspect SARS case. He\nstayed at home all this while. He was upgraded as a SARS case on 29 Mar\n2003. His mother is also admitted to TTSH as a suspect case. His father and\nbrother are well.\nAdditional precautionary measures at Changi Airport to minimize the import\nof SARS\nTo minimize the import of SARS cases, Singapore is stepping up health\nscreening procedures for passengers arriving at Changi Airport from\naffected countries. This is in view of new index cases that are traced to\npeople who have traveled overseas.\nAdditional Precautionary Measures For Incoming Passengers\nFrom 5 PM 31 Mar 2003 onwards, for all incoming flights from affected\nareas as identified by WHO, nurses will be present to check on passengers\nwho appear unwell. Those who have fever, will be sent to TTSH for assessment.\nAdditionally, CAAS has today issued a directive that takes immediate effect\nto all airlines operating at Changi Airport requiring them to ask\npassengers the 3 questions recommended by the World Health Organisation\n(WHO) before allowing them to board the flight to Singapore. The 3\nquestions are :\n1. Do you have high fever of more than 38 degrees Celsius?\n2. Do you have one or more respiratory symptoms including cough, shortness\nof breath, difficulty breathing?\n3. Have you had close contact with a person who has been diagnosed with\nSARS or had recent history of travel to areas reporting cases of SARS?\nAny visibly unwell passenger will be asked to obtain a doctor's\ncertification before they are allowed to board the flight to Singapore.\nThe above measures are on top of the health advisory cards distributed to\nall passengers coming from Hong Kong, Hanoi, and Guangdong. MOH and CAAS\nwill scale up the operations and implement the above measures to other\naffected countries as and when WHO updates the list.\nAdditional Precautionary Measures For Outgoing Passengers\nCAAS has issued a directive to airlines in Changi Airport requiring all\nairlines to ask departing passengers the 3 questions recommended by the\nWHO. This directive takes effect immediately. This is in addition to the\nhealth advisory cards which are distributed to passengers bound for Hong\nKong, Hanoi and Guangdong when checking in for their flights.\nSARS Situation Update\nAs at 30 Mar 2003, the total number of people who have recovered from SARS\nand are discharged from hospital is 35. The remaining 53 patients are\nhospitalised.\nA total of 91 people with SARS have been reported to the Ministry of\nHealth. Of the 2 additional patients, one is a healthcare worker who is\nstill traced back to the initial 3 index cases, and the other is the new\n(fifth) imported case.\nSo far, there have been no SARS cases that are linked to the fourth and\nfifth imported cases. This brings the total number of family members,\nfriends or close contacts infected by SARS to 44, and the total number of\nhospital staff infected by SARS to 42. These 86 cases are all linked to the\nfirst 3 index cases. The number of infected children still remains at 3.\nThere are currently 36 suspected cases, 2 out of which are children.\nThere are 12 patients who are in serious condition, including the fourth\nimported case. One patient who was in intensive care passed away on 29 Mar\n2003. This patient had concurrent history of hypertension, diabetes, heart\ndisease and a bacterial pneumonia.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 30 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/2003/2003_11update15.htm>\n\nAs of 30 Mar 2003, Health Canada has received reports of approximately 98\nprobable or suspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in\nOntario, British Columbia, Alberta and New Brunswick. There have been 4\ndeaths in Canada. All Canadian cases have occurred in persons who have\ntraveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the household or in a\nhealth-care setting. The information contained in this update is based on\nthe best available information Health Canada has at this time.\nHealth Canada is changing the way it is reporting probable and suspect\ncases of SARS to ensure consistency in reporting across the country.\n\"Probable\" cases of SARS are similar to suspect cases, but often they have\na more severe illness, with progressive shortness of breath and difficulty\nbreathing, and in some cases, chest x-rays show signs of atypical pneumonia.\nA \"suspect\" case of SARS is a person who fits into one of the following 2\ncategories: a person who develops fever and one or more respiratory\nsymptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing,\nwithin 10 days of returning from travel to areas in Asia where SARS cases\nare being reported, or a person who develops fever and one or more\nrespiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty\nbreathing, within 10 days of having had close contact with a \"probable\"\ncase of SARS (i.e., within one metre).\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\nOntario is reporting approximately 81 probable and suspect cases. All cases\nhave occurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS\ncases in the household or in a health-care setting.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 2 probable and 8 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting one suspect case.\nSaskatchewan is reporting one suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 5 suspect cases.\nManitoba is no longer reporting any suspect or probable cases.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Today's reports reflect an increase in 60 cases in Hong Kong, and 2\nadditional cases in Singapore. The number of cases reported in Canada has\nincreased from 37 to 98, but the latter figure is a combination of\nsuspected and probable cases, whereas the 37 referred to only probable\ncases. Information on a global worldwide update was not available as of\nthe time of preparation of this update.\nWith the exception of the ongoing outbreak in Hong Kong (and possibly in\nmainland China), the outbreak of SARS in other areas seems to be following\na pattern consistent with a requirement of close contact with an actively\nill case of SARS for transmission to occur. One can't help but muse on the\ndefinition of close contact in different environments, and in those areas\nwith high population density, what might be a casual, non-close contact in\nother areas is close enough to allow for transmission in an area with\nhigher population density. This moderator is reminded of studies conducted\non the baseline incidence of poliomyelitis in India back in the early\n80s. It was generally accepted that polio was more of an \"urban disease\"\nwith higher incidences observed in urban areas. Results of studies on the\nbaseline incidence of polio in a highly populated state revealed that the\nrural incidence was on a par with the urban incidence. Our interpretation\nof this observation was that the standard western definition of urban vs.\nrural was based on population density, where rural areas had a markedly\nlower population density than urban areas. In the highly populated\ndistricts of India, rural areas had population densities similar to many\nwestern urban areas. Hence, rather than being an urban disease, polio was\nmore of a high population density disease. Again, food for thought here...\n- Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (19): etiology 20030330.0786\nSARS - worldwide (18): cases 20030329.0783\nSARS - worldwide (17): cases 20030328.0779\nSARS - Worldwide (16): Etiology 20030328.0774\nSARS - Between 19-23 Mar 2003, she met and\nworked with 2 Singaporean colleagues, who have since returned to Singapore\nand are well. She arrived back in Singapore on Southern China Airlines CZ\n355 at Terminal 1, Changi Airport on 26 Mar 2003 at 5.38 am. Accompanied by\nher mother, she took a taxi from the airport to the Accident & Emergency\nDepartment, Singapore General Hospital. From there, she was transferred by\nambulance and admitted to Tan Tock Seng Hospital.\nHer mother and 2 colleagues have been issued with Home Quarantine Orders.\nOthers who were served the Orders were 3 SATS officers, 2 SIR officers and\n2 relations officers from the airline. We have identified a taxi-driver who\nsaid that he had ferried 2 women from Changi Airport to the Accident &\nEmergency Department, Singapore General Hospital on the morning of 26 Mar\n2003. As a precautionary measure, a Home Quarantine Order has been issued\nto him.\nFollowing yesterday's press statement, we have been able to locate 10 more\npassengers. They are all well and quarantine orders are being served to\nthem. In total, 40 of the 48 passengers (excluding the case) have been\nidentified. There is a possibility that some of the remaining 8 passengers\nare no longer in Singapore. The names of the remaining 8 passengers who we\nhave still been unable to locate are [see\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5740> for list of names.]\nThe latest (fifth) imported case is a 17-year-old Indonesian male student\nwho left Singapore on 15 Mar 2003 with his parents and his 15-year-old\nbrother for Guangdong and Hong Kong. The family returned to Singapore on\nthe night of 23 Mar 2003. On 24 Mar 2003, he was well and attended school\nat Bowen Secondary School. On 25 Mar 2003, he developed a fever and was\nseen at TTSH as an outpatient. He was given 5 days medical leave. He was\nseen again on 27 Mar 2003 and admitted to TTSH as a suspect SARS case. He\nstayed at home all this while. He was upgraded as a SARS case on 29 Mar\n2003. His mother is also admitted to TTSH as a suspect case. His father and\nbrother are well.\nAdditional precautionary measures at Changi Airport to minimize the import\nof SARS\nTo minimize the import of SARS cases, Singapore is stepping up health\nscreening procedures for passengers arriving at Changi Airport from\naffected countries. This is in view of new index cases that are traced to\npeople who have traveled overseas.\nAdditional Precautionary Measures For Incoming Passengers\nFrom 5 PM 31 Mar 2003 onwards, for all incoming flights from affected\nareas as identified by WHO, nurses will be present to check on passengers\nwho appear unwell. Those who have fever, will be sent to TTSH for assessment.\nAdditionally, CAAS has today issued a directive that takes immediate effect\nto all airlines operating at Changi Airport requiring them to ask\npassengers the 3 questions recommended by the World Health Organisation\n(WHO) before allowing them to board the flight to Singapore. The 3\nquestions are :\n1. Do you have high fever of more than 38 degrees Celsius?\n2. Do you have one or more respiratory symptoms including cough, shortness\nof breath, difficulty breathing?\n3. Have you had close contact with a person who has been diagnosed with\nSARS or had recent history of travel to areas reporting cases of SARS?\nAny visibly unwell passenger will be asked to obtain a doctor's\ncertification before they are allowed to board the flight to Singapore.\nThe above measures are on top of the health advisory cards distributed to\nall passengers coming from Hong Kong, Hanoi, and Guangdong. MOH and CAAS\nwill scale up the operations and implement the above measures to other\naffected countries as and when WHO updates the list.\nAdditional Precautionary Measures For Outgoing Passengers\nCAAS has issued a directive to airlines in Changi Airport requiring all\nairlines to ask departing passengers the 3 questions recommended by the\nWHO. This directive takes effect immediately. This is in addition to the\nhealth advisory cards which are distributed to passengers bound for Hong\nKong, Hanoi and Guangdong when checking in for their flights.\nSARS Situation Update\nAs at 30 Mar 2003, the total number of people who have recovered from SARS\nand are discharged from hospital is 35. The remaining 53 patients are\nhospitalised.\nA total of 91 people with SARS have been reported to the Ministry of\nHealth. Of the 2 additional patients, one is a healthcare worker who is\nstill traced back to the initial 3 index cases, and the other is the new\n(fifth) imported case.\nSo far, there have been no SARS cases that are linked to the fourth and\nfifth imported cases. This brings the total number of family members,\nfriends or close contacts infected by SARS to 44, and the total number of\nhospital staff infected by SARS to 42. These 86 cases are all linked to the\nfirst 3 index cases. The number of infected children still remains at 3.\nThere are currently 36 suspected cases, 2 out of which are children.\nThere are 12 patients who are in serious condition, including the fourth\nimported case. One patient who was in intensive care passed away on 29 Mar\n2003. This patient had concurrent history of hypertension, diabetes, heart\ndisease and a bacterial pneumonia.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 30 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/2003/2003_11update15.htm>\n\nAs of 30 Mar 2003, Health Canada has received reports of approximately 98\nprobable or suspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in\nOntario, British Columbia, Alberta and New Brunswick. There have been 4\ndeaths in Canada. All Canadian cases have occurred in persons who have\ntraveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the household or in a\nhealth-care setting. The information contained in this update is based on\nthe best available information Health Canada has at this time.\nHealth Canada is changing the way it is reporting probable and suspect\ncases of SARS to ensure consistency in reporting across the country.\n\"Probable\" cases of SARS are similar to suspect cases, but often they have\na more severe illness, with progressive shortness of breath and difficulty\nbreathing, and in some cases, chest x-rays show signs of atypical pneumonia.\nA \"suspect\" case of SARS is a person who fits into one of the following 2\ncategories: a person who develops fever and one or more respiratory\nsymptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing,\nwithin 10 days of returning from travel to areas in Asia where SARS cases\nare being reported, or a person who develops fever and one or more\nrespiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty\nbreathing, within 10 days of having had close contact with a \"probable\"\ncase of SARS (i.e., within one metre).\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\nOntario is reporting approximately 81 probable and suspect cases. All cases\nhave occurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS\ncases in the household or in a health-care setting.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 2 probable and 8 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting one suspect case.\nSaskatchewan is reporting one suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 5 suspect cases.\nManitoba is no longer reporting any suspect or probable cases.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Today's reports reflect an increase in 60 cases in Hong Kong, and 2\nadditional cases in Singapore. The number of cases reported in Canada has\nincreased from 37 to 98, but the latter figure is a combination of\nsuspected and probable cases, whereas the 37 referred to only probable\ncases. Information on a global worldwide update was not available as of\nthe time of preparation of this update.\nWith the exception of the ongoing outbreak in Hong Kong (and possibly in\nmainland China), the outbreak of SARS in other areas seems to be following\na pattern consistent with a requirement of close contact with an actively\nill case of SARS for transmission to occur. One can't help but muse on the\ndefinition of close contact in different environments, and in those areas\nwith high population density, what might be a casual, non-close contact in\nother areas is close enough to allow for transmission in an area with\nhigher population density. This moderator is reminded of studies conducted\non the baseline incidence of poliomyelitis in India back in the early\n80s. It was generally accepted that polio was more of an \"urban disease\"\nwith higher incidences observed in urban areas. Results of studies on the\nbaseline incidence of polio in a highly populated state revealed that the\nrural incidence was on a par with the urban incidence. Our interpretation\nof this observation was that the standard western definition of urban vs.\nrural was based on population density, where rural areas had a markedly\nlower population density than urban areas. In the highly populated\ndistricts of India, rural areas had population densities similar to many\nwestern urban areas. Hence, rather than being an urban disease, polio was\nmore of a high population density disease. Again, food for thought here...\n- Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (19): etiology 20030330.0786\nSARS - worldwide (18): cases 20030329.0783\nSARS - worldwide (17): cases 20030328.0779\nSARS - Worldwide (16): Etiology 20030328.0774\nSARS - "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=298", "date": "2003-03-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (20): CASES\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Hong Kong - DOH\n[2] Singapore - MOH\n[3] Canada - Health Canada\n******\n[1]\nDate: 30 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health 30 Mar 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\n[A] Update on atypical pneumonia 30 Mar 2003\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAn additional 60 patients with symptoms of atypical pneumonia were admitted\nto public hospitals as of 1 PM 30 Mar 2003. They include 6 healthcare\nworkers and 36 patients from Amoy Gardens. The remaining 18 were new\npatients and contacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.\n17 patients, including 12 healthcare workers and medical students of Prince\nof Wales Hospital, were discharged from hospital today. A total of 60\npatients to date have recovered from atypical pneumonia and been discharged.\nCurrently, 52 patients are receiving treatment in the intensive care unit.\nA 74-year-old female patient with a history of other diseases died in\nUnited Christian Hospital this morning. This brings to 13 the total number\nof patients died with atypical pneumonia in public hospitals.\nThe cumulative figure for patients admitted to public hospitals with\natypical pneumonia is 530, starting from 12 Mar 2003.\nThe breakdown of figures is as follows: (The numbers in bracket are those\nwith pneumonia symptoms)\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students 162 (162)\n36 of the patients were discharged\nPatients, family members & visitors 368 (368)\n24 of the patients were discharged\nTotal admission 530 (530)\n60 were discharged\n[B] Flight passengers urged to contact DH 30 Mar 2003\nThe Department of Health (DH) on 30 Mar 2003 called on passengers who had\ntravelled from Beijing to Hong Kong on flight KA 901(Dragonair) on 26 Mar\n2003 to call DH's hotline 2961 8968 for health advice on atypical pneumonia\nand surveillance. The hotline will be manned from noon to 5 PM 30 Mar 2003\nand from 9 AM to 5 PM on weekdays.\nThe plea was made as DH's investigation found that a Hong Kong man who had\ntaken the flight developed symptoms of severe acute respiratory syndrome\nduring his stay in Beijing. He was later confirmed to have contracted the\ndisease. DH has informed the Airport Authority and the airline. Advice was\nalso given to the airline concerned to disinfect the airplanes. DH is\ntracing the crew members and passengers who had taken these 2 flights, for\nsurveillance purposes.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 30 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore Ministry of Health 30 Mar 2003 [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5740>\n\nSARS: New measures at airport to curb importation of new cases; more\npatients recovering and discharged - 30 Mar 2003\nIn yesterday's Press Release, MOH had informed that the fourth imported\ncase left for Hong Kong on 14 Mar 2003 and then to Beijing on 15 Mar 2003.\nOn 19 Mar 2003, she became unwell. Between 19-23 Mar 2003, she met and\nworked with 2 Singaporean colleagues, who have since returned to Singapore\nand are well. She arrived back in Singapore on Southern China Airlines CZ\n355 at Terminal 1, Changi Airport on 26 Mar 2003 at 5.38 am. Accompanied by\nher mother, she took a taxi from the airport to the Accident & Emergency\nDepartment, Singapore General Hospital. From there, she was transferred by\nambulance and admitted to Tan Tock Seng Hospital.\nHer mother and 2 colleagues have been issued with Home Quarantine Orders.\nOthers who were served the Orders were 3 SATS officers, 2 SIR officers and\n2 relations officers from the airline. We have identified a taxi-driver who\nsaid that he had ferried 2 women from Changi Airport to the Accident &\nEmergency Department, Singapore General Hospital on the morning of 26 Mar\n2003. As a precautionary measure, a Home Quarantine Order has been issued\nto him.\nFollowing yesterday's press statement, we have been able to locate 10 more\npassengers. They are all well and quarantine orders are being served to\nthem. In total, 40 of the 48 passengers (excluding the case) have been\nidentified. There is a possibility that some of the remaining 8 passengers\nare no longer in Singapore. The names of the remaining 8 passengers who we\nhave still been unable to locate are [see\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5740> for list of names.]\nThe latest (fifth) imported case is a 17-year-old Indonesian male student\nwho left Singapore on 15 Mar 2003 with his parents and his 15-year-old\nbrother for Guangdong and Hong Kong. The family returned to Singapore on\nthe night of 23 Mar 2003. On 24 Mar 2003, he was well and attended school\nat Bowen Secondary School. On 25 Mar 2003, he developed a fever and was\nseen at TTSH as an outpatient. He was given 5 days medical leave. He was\nseen again on 27 Mar 2003 and admitted to TTSH as a suspect SARS case. He\nstayed at home all this while. He was upgraded as a SARS case on 29 Mar\n2003. His mother is also admitted to TTSH as a suspect case. His father and\nbrother are well.\nAdditional precautionary measures at Changi Airport to minimize the import\nof SARS\nTo minimize the import of SARS cases, Singapore is stepping up health\nscreening procedures for passengers arriving at Changi Airport from\naffected countries. This is in view of new index cases that are traced to\npeople who have traveled overseas.\nAdditional Precautionary Measures For Incoming Passengers\nFrom 5 PM 31 Mar 2003 onwards, for all incoming flights from affected\nareas as identified by WHO, nurses will be present to check on passengers\nwho appear unwell. Those who have fever, will be sent to TTSH for assessment.\nAdditionally, CAAS has today issued a directive that takes immediate effect\nto all airlines operating at Changi Airport requiring them to ask\npassengers the 3 questions recommended by the World Health Organisation\n(WHO) before allowing them to board the flight to Singapore. The 3\nquestions are :\n1. Do you have high fever of more than 38 degrees Celsius?\n2. Do you have one or more respiratory symptoms including cough, shortness\nof breath, difficulty breathing?\n3. Have you had close contact with a person who has been diagnosed with\nSARS or had recent history of travel to areas reporting cases of SARS?\nAny visibly unwell passenger will be asked to obtain a doctor's\ncertification before they are allowed to board the flight to Singapore.\nThe above measures are on top of the health advisory cards distributed to\nall passengers coming from Hong Kong, Hanoi, and Guangdong. MOH and CAAS\nwill scale up the operations and implement the above measures to other\naffected countries as and when WHO updates the list.\nAdditional Precautionary Measures For Outgoing Passengers\nCAAS has issued a directive to airlines in Changi Airport requiring all\nairlines to ask departing passengers the 3 questions recommended by the\nWHO. This directive takes effect immediately. This is in addition to the\nhealth advisory cards which are distributed to passengers bound for Hong\nKong, Hanoi and Guangdong when checking in for their flights.\nSARS Situation Update\nAs at 30 Mar 2003, the total number of people who have recovered from SARS\nand are discharged from hospital is 35. The remaining 53 patients are\nhospitalised.\nA total of 91 people with SARS have been reported to the Ministry of\nHealth. Of the 2 additional patients, one is a healthcare worker who is\nstill traced back to the initial 3 index cases, and the other is the new\n(fifth) imported case.\nSo far, there have been no SARS cases that are linked to the fourth and\nfifth imported cases. This brings the total number of family members,\nfriends or close contacts infected by SARS to 44, and the total number of\nhospital staff infected by SARS to 42. These 86 cases are all linked to the\nfirst 3 index cases. The number of infected children still remains at 3.\nThere are currently 36 suspected cases, 2 out of which are children.\nThere are 12 patients who are in serious condition, including the fourth\nimported case. One patient who was in intensive care passed away on 29 Mar\n2003. This patient had concurrent history of hypertension, diabetes, heart\ndisease and a bacterial pneumonia.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 30 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/2003/2003_11update15.htm>\n\nAs of 30 Mar 2003, Health Canada has received reports of approximately 98\nprobable or suspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in\nOntario, British Columbia, Alberta and New Brunswick. There have been 4\ndeaths in Canada. All Canadian cases have occurred in persons who have\ntraveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the household or in a\nhealth-care setting. The information contained in this update is based on\nthe best available information Health Canada has at this time.\nHealth Canada is changing the way it is reporting probable and suspect\ncases of SARS to ensure consistency in reporting across the country.\n\"Probable\" cases of SARS are similar to suspect cases, but often they have\na more severe illness, with progressive shortness of breath and difficulty\nbreathing, and in some cases, chest x-rays show signs of atypical pneumonia.\nA \"suspect\" case of SARS is a person who fits into one of the following 2\ncategories: a person who develops fever and one or more respiratory\nsymptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing,\nwithin 10 days of returning from travel to areas in Asia where SARS cases\nare being reported, or a person who develops fever and one or more\nrespiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty\nbreathing, within 10 days of having had close contact with a \"probable\"\ncase of SARS (i.e., within one metre).\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\nOntario is reporting approximately 81 probable and suspect cases. All cases\nhave occurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS\ncases in the household or in a health-care setting.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 2 probable and 8 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting one suspect case.\nSaskatchewan is reporting one suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 5 suspect cases.\nManitoba is no longer reporting any suspect or probable cases.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Today's reports reflect an increase in 60 cases in Hong Kong, and 2\nadditional cases in Singapore. The number of cases reported in Canada has\nincreased from 37 to 98, but the latter figure is a combination of\nsuspected and probable cases, whereas the 37 referred to only probable\ncases. Information on a global worldwide update was not available as of\nthe time of preparation of this update.\nWith the exception of the ongoing outbreak in Hong Kong (and possibly in\nmainland China), the outbreak of SARS in other areas seems to be following\na pattern consistent with a requirement of close contact with an actively\nill case of SARS for transmission to occur. One can't help but muse on the\ndefinition of close contact in different environments, and in those areas\nwith high population density, what might be a casual, non-close contact in\nother areas is close enough to allow for transmission in an area with\nhigher population density. This moderator is reminded of studies conducted\non the baseline incidence of poliomyelitis in India back in the early\n80s. It was generally accepted that polio was more of an \"urban disease\"\nwith higher incidences observed in urban areas. Results of studies on the\nbaseline incidence of polio in a highly populated state revealed that the\nrural incidence was on a par with the urban incidence. Our interpretation\nof this observation was that the standard western definition of urban vs.\nrural was based on population density, where rural areas had a markedly\nlower population density than urban areas. In the highly populated\ndistricts of India, rural areas had population densities similar to many\nwestern urban areas. Hence, rather than being an urban disease, polio was\nmore of a high population density disease. Again, food for thought here...\n- Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (19): etiology 20030330.0786\nSARS - worldwide (18): cases 20030329.0783\nSARS - worldwide (17): cases 20030328.0779\nSARS - Worldwide (16): Etiology 20030328.0774\nSARS - "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=297", "date": "2003-03-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (20): CASES\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Hong Kong - DOH\n[2] Singapore - MOH\n[3] Canada - Health Canada\n******\n[1]\nDate: 30 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health 30 Mar 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\n[A] Update on atypical pneumonia 30 Mar 2003\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAn additional 60 patients with symptoms of atypical pneumonia were admitted\nto public hospitals as of 1 PM 30 Mar 2003. They include 6 healthcare\nworkers and 36 patients from Amoy Gardens. The remaining 18 were new\npatients and contacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.\n17 patients, including 12 healthcare workers and medical students of Prince\nof Wales Hospital, were discharged from hospital today. A total of 60\npatients to date have recovered from atypical pneumonia and been discharged.\nCurrently, 52 patients are receiving treatment in the intensive care unit.\nA 74-year-old female patient with a history of other diseases died in\nUnited Christian Hospital this morning. This brings to 13 the total number\nof patients died with atypical pneumonia in public hospitals.\nThe cumulative figure for patients admitted to public hospitals with\natypical pneumonia is 530, starting from 12 Mar 2003.\nThe breakdown of figures is as follows: (The numbers in bracket are those\nwith pneumonia symptoms)\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students 162 (162)\n36 of the patients were discharged\nPatients, family members & visitors 368 (368)\n24 of the patients were discharged\nTotal admission 530 (530)\n60 were discharged\n[B] Flight passengers urged to contact DH 30 Mar 2003\nThe Department of Health (DH) on 30 Mar 2003 called on passengers who had\ntravelled from Beijing to Hong Kong on flight KA 901(Dragonair) on 26 Mar\n2003 to call DH's hotline 2961 8968 for health advice on atypical pneumonia\nand surveillance. The hotline will be manned from noon to 5 PM 30 Mar 2003\nand from 9 AM to 5 PM on weekdays.\nThe plea was made as DH's investigation found that a Hong Kong man who had\ntaken the flight developed symptoms of severe acute respiratory syndrome\nduring his stay in Beijing. He was later confirmed to have contracted the\ndisease. DH has informed the Airport Authority and the airline. Advice was\nalso given to the airline concerned to disinfect the airplanes. DH is\ntracing the crew members and passengers who had taken these 2 flights, for\nsurveillance purposes.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 30 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore Ministry of Health 30 Mar 2003 [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5740>\n\nSARS: New measures at airport to curb importation of new cases; more\npatients recovering and discharged - 30 Mar 2003\nIn yesterday's Press Release, MOH had informed that the fourth imported\ncase left for Hong Kong on 14 Mar 2003 and then to Beijing on 15 Mar 2003.\nOn 19 Mar 2003, she became unwell. Between 19-23 Mar 2003, she met and\nworked with 2 Singaporean colleagues, who have since returned to Singapore\nand are well. She arrived back in Singapore on Southern China Airlines CZ\n355 at Terminal 1, Changi Airport on 26 Mar 2003 at 5.38 am. Accompanied by\nher mother, she took a taxi from the airport to the Accident & Emergency\nDepartment, Singapore General Hospital. From there, she was transferred by\nambulance and admitted to Tan Tock Seng Hospital.\nHer mother and 2 colleagues have been issued with Home Quarantine Orders.\nOthers who were served the Orders were 3 SATS officers, 2 SIR officers and\n2 relations officers from the airline. We have identified a taxi-driver who\nsaid that he had ferried 2 women from Changi Airport to the Accident &\nEmergency Department, Singapore General Hospital on the morning of 26 Mar\n2003. As a precautionary measure, a Home Quarantine Order has been issued\nto him.\nFollowing yesterday's press statement, we have been able to locate 10 more\npassengers. They are all well and quarantine orders are being served to\nthem. In total, 40 of the 48 passengers (excluding the case) have been\nidentified. There is a possibility that some of the remaining 8 passengers\nare no longer in Singapore. The names of the remaining 8 passengers who we\nhave still been unable to locate are [see\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5740> for list of names.]\nThe latest (fifth) imported case is a 17-year-old Indonesian male student\nwho left Singapore on 15 Mar 2003 with his parents and his 15-year-old\nbrother for Guangdong and Hong Kong. The family returned to Singapore on\nthe night of 23 Mar 2003. On 24 Mar 2003, he was well and attended school\nat Bowen Secondary School. On 25 Mar 2003, he developed a fever and was\nseen at TTSH as an outpatient. He was given 5 days medical leave. He was\nseen again on 27 Mar 2003 and admitted to TTSH as a suspect SARS case. He\nstayed at home all this while. He was upgraded as a SARS case on 29 Mar\n2003. His mother is also admitted to TTSH as a suspect case. His father and\nbrother are well.\nAdditional precautionary measures at Changi Airport to minimize the import\nof SARS\nTo minimize the import of SARS cases, Singapore is stepping up health\nscreening procedures for passengers arriving at Changi Airport from\naffected countries. This is in view of new index cases that are traced to\npeople who have traveled overseas.\nAdditional Precautionary Measures For Incoming Passengers\nFrom 5 PM 31 Mar 2003 onwards, for all incoming flights from affected\nareas as identified by WHO, nurses will be present to check on passengers\nwho appear unwell. Those who have fever, will be sent to TTSH for assessment.\nAdditionally, CAAS has today issued a directive that takes immediate effect\nto all airlines operating at Changi Airport requiring them to ask\npassengers the 3 questions recommended by the World Health Organisation\n(WHO) before allowing them to board the flight to Singapore. The 3\nquestions are :\n1. Do you have high fever of more than 38 degrees Celsius?\n2. Do you have one or more respiratory symptoms including cough, shortness\nof breath, difficulty breathing?\n3. Have you had close contact with a person who has been diagnosed with\nSARS or had recent history of travel to areas reporting cases of SARS?\nAny visibly unwell passenger will be asked to obtain a doctor's\ncertification before they are allowed to board the flight to Singapore.\nThe above measures are on top of the health advisory cards distributed to\nall passengers coming from Hong Kong, Hanoi, and Guangdong. MOH and CAAS\nwill scale up the operations and implement the above measures to other\naffected countries as and when WHO updates the list.\nAdditional Precautionary Measures For Outgoing Passengers\nCAAS has issued a directive to airlines in Changi Airport requiring all\nairlines to ask departing passengers the 3 questions recommended by the\nWHO. This directive takes effect immediately. This is in addition to the\nhealth advisory cards which are distributed to passengers bound for Hong\nKong, Hanoi and Guangdong when checking in for their flights.\nSARS Situation Update\nAs at 30 Mar 2003, the total number of people who have recovered from SARS\nand are discharged from hospital is 35. The remaining 53 patients are\nhospitalised.\nA total of 91 people with SARS have been reported to the Ministry of\nHealth. Of the 2 additional patients, one is a healthcare worker who is\nstill traced back to the initial 3 index cases, and the other is the new\n(fifth) imported case.\nSo far, there have been no SARS cases that are linked to the fourth and\nfifth imported cases. This brings the total number of family members,\nfriends or close contacts infected by SARS to 44, and the total number of\nhospital staff infected by SARS to 42. These 86 cases are all linked to the\nfirst 3 index cases. The number of infected children still remains at 3.\nThere are currently 36 suspected cases, 2 out of which are children.\nThere are 12 patients who are in serious condition, including the fourth\nimported case. One patient who was in intensive care passed away on 29 Mar\n2003. This patient had concurrent history of hypertension, diabetes, heart\ndisease and a bacterial pneumonia.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 30 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/2003/2003_11update15.htm>\n\nAs of 30 Mar 2003, Health Canada has received reports of approximately 98\nprobable or suspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in\nOntario, British Columbia, Alberta and New Brunswick. There have been 4\ndeaths in Canada. All Canadian cases have occurred in persons who have\ntraveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the household or in a\nhealth-care setting. The information contained in this update is based on\nthe best available information Health Canada has at this time.\nHealth Canada is changing the way it is reporting probable and suspect\ncases of SARS to ensure consistency in reporting across the country.\n\"Probable\" cases of SARS are similar to suspect cases, but often they have\na more severe illness, with progressive shortness of breath and difficulty\nbreathing, and in some cases, chest x-rays show signs of atypical pneumonia.\nA \"suspect\" case of SARS is a person who fits into one of the following 2\ncategories: a person who develops fever and one or more respiratory\nsymptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing,\nwithin 10 days of returning from travel to areas in Asia where SARS cases\nare being reported, or a person who develops fever and one or more\nrespiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty\nbreathing, within 10 days of having had close contact with a \"probable\"\ncase of SARS (i.e., within one metre).\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\nOntario is reporting approximately 81 probable and suspect cases. All cases\nhave occurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS\ncases in the household or in a health-care setting.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 2 probable and 8 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting one suspect case.\nSaskatchewan is reporting one suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 5 suspect cases.\nManitoba is no longer reporting any suspect or probable cases.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Today's reports reflect an increase in 60 cases in Hong Kong, and 2\nadditional cases in Singapore. The number of cases reported in Canada has\nincreased from 37 to 98, but the latter figure is a combination of\nsuspected and probable cases, whereas the 37 referred to only probable\ncases. Information on a global worldwide update was not available as of\nthe time of preparation of this update.\nWith the exception of the ongoing outbreak in Hong Kong (and possibly in\nmainland China), the outbreak of SARS in other areas seems to be following\na pattern consistent with a requirement of close contact with an actively\nill case of SARS for transmission to occur. One can't help but muse on the\ndefinition of close contact in different environments, and in those areas\nwith high population density, what might be a casual, non-close contact in\nother areas is close enough to allow for transmission in an area with\nhigher population density. This moderator is reminded of studies conducted\non the baseline incidence of poliomyelitis in India back in the early\n80s. It was generally accepted that polio was more of an \"urban disease\"\nwith higher incidences observed in urban areas. Results of studies on the\nbaseline incidence of polio in a highly populated state revealed that the\nrural incidence was on a par with the urban incidence. Our interpretation\nof this observation was that the standard western definition of urban vs.\nrural was based on population density, where rural areas had a markedly\nlower population density than urban areas. In the highly populated\ndistricts of India, rural areas had population densities similar to many\nwestern urban areas. Hence, rather than being an urban disease, polio was\nmore of a high population density disease. Again, food for thought here...\n- Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (19): etiology 20030330.0786\nSARS - worldwide (18): cases 20030329.0783\nSARS - worldwide (17): cases 20030328.0779\nSARS - Worldwide (16): Etiology 20030328.0774\nSARS - post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 27 Mar 2003 12:00:20 -0500\nFrom: \"Dan Silver\" <daniel.silver6@verizon.net>\nSubject: Shanxi vs. Shanghai\n\nWith regard to your 26 Mar 2003 newswire coverage of SARS, [SARS -\nworldwide (11): cases 20030326.0753] you have incorrectly stated that\nShanxi is Shanghai. Please note that they are completely different\nlocales. Shanxi is an inland province. The presence of SARS in Shanxi\nindicates that it has migrated to China' s interior, where reporting\nmechanisms are less sophisticated than cities such as Shanghai. Thank you.\n--\nDan Silver\n<daniel.silver6@verizon.net>\n[ProMED-mail regrets this error and is grateful to Dan Silver for pointing\nthis out. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (11): cases 20030326.0753\nSARS - Please note that they are completely different\nlocales. Shanxi is an inland province. The presence of SARS in Shanxi\nindicates that it has migrated to China' s interior, where reporting\nmechanisms are less sophisticated than cities such as Shanghai. worldwide (12): correction Shanxi not Shanghai", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203548", "date": "2003-03-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (12):CORRECTION SHANXI NOT SHANGHAI\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 27 Mar 2003 12:00:20 -0500\nFrom: \"Dan Silver\" <daniel.silver6@verizon.net>\nSubject: Shanxi vs. Shanghai\n\nWith regard to your 26 Mar 2003 newswire coverage of SARS, [SARS -\nworldwide (11): cases 20030326.0753] you have incorrectly stated that\nShanxi is Shanghai. Please note that they are completely different\nlocales. Shanxi is an inland province. The presence of SARS in Shanxi\nindicates that it has migrated to China' s interior, where reporting\nmechanisms are less sophisticated than cities such as Shanghai. Thank you.\n--\nDan Silver\n<daniel.silver6@verizon.net>\n[ProMED-mail regrets this error and is grateful to Dan Silver for pointing\nthis out. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (11): cases 20030326.0753\nSARS - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n...........................mpp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shanghai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shanxi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "285", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (12): correction Shanxi not Shanghai", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=285", "date": "2003-03-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (05): HONG KONG ADVISORY\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: 25 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong Department of Health 25 Mar 2003\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nHealth Surveillance for airline passengers\n-------------------\nA spokesman for the Department of Health (DH) 25 Mar 2003 called on members\nof the public who had travelled from Hong Kong to Beijing in flight CA 112\non 15 Mar 2003 or from Beijing to Hong Kong in flight CA 115 on 19 Mar 2003\nto call DH's hotline 2961 8968 for health advice.\nThe plea follows the detection of 9 atypical pneumonia cases among members\nof a Beijing tour organized by a Hong Kong travel agent.\nThe tour comprised 35 tour members and a staff member of the travel agent.\nThey left for Beijing in flight CA 112 on 15 Mar 2003 and returned to Hong\nKong in flight CA 115 on 19 Mar 2003.\nInvestigation revealed that a couple who joined the tour, both aged 44, had\ndeveloped symptoms during their stay in Beijing on 18 Mar 2003. They were\nadmitted to Tuen Mun Hospital on the evening of 22 Mar 2003 and are now in\nstable condition.\nOn receiving the notification on 23 Mar 2003, DH immediately contacted\nother members of the tour. Among them 3, one man and 2 women aged between\n27 and 50, were also confirmed to have developed atypical pneumonia\nsymptoms. They were admitted to Tuen Mun Hospital and Pamela Youde\nNethersole Eastern Hospital for treatment. They are in stable condition.\n6 other members of the tour who had been reported to have coughs, 3 men and\n3 women aged between 32 and 61, were admitted to hospitals for close\nsurveillance earlier. Four of them, comprising 2 men and 2 women aged\nbetween 32 and 51, were confirmed today to have infected with atypical\npneumonia. They are receiving treatment in Queen Elizabeth Hospital. The\nfifth person, a 61-year-old man, is still under observation in Tuen Mun\nHospital. The sixth person, a 48-year-old woman, was discharged yesterday.\nIt is suspected that the couple contracted the disease from a passenger, a\nman aged 73, who sat close to them on their way to Beijing. The man was\nfeeling unwell after visiting his brother in Ward 8A of Prince of Wales\nHospital earlier this month.\nDH has informed the Airport Authority, the Civil Aviation Department and\nthe airline concerned. Advice was also given to the airline concerned to\ndisinfect the airplanes.\nDH is tracing the crew members and passengers who had taken these two\nflights, for surveillance purposes.\nThe spokesman reminded members of the public who have respiratory symptoms\nincluding fever, chills, malaise and cough to avoid traveling by plane\nbefore recovery.\nIt is prudent for tourists to adopt the following precautionary measures to\nprevent atypical pneumonia:\nBuild up good body immunity by having a proper diet, regular exercise and\nadequate rest, reducing stress and avoiding smoking;\nMaintain good personal hygiene, and wash hands after sneezing, coughing or\ncleaning the nose;\nMaintain good ventilation; avoid visiting crowded places with poor ventilation;\nDo not share towels;\nConsult a doctor promptly if you develop respiratory symptoms and fever.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 25 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS update 25 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_03_25/en/>\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) multi-country outbreak - Update 9\nUpdated travel advice\nOn 15 Mar 2003, WHO issued a travel advisory in response to the growing\ninternational threat posed by Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).\nSince then, WHO has conducted daily teleconferences with health authorities\nand WHO team members on the scene in all areas affected by SARS.\nWHO also receives detailed bulletins from ministries of health in the most\nheavily affected areas reporting on any SARS-related events that might\nalter understanding of the behaviour of this new disease.\nToday's communications included a report, from the Hong Kong department of\nhealth, providing detailed preliminary data on the detection of 9 atypical\npneumonia cases among members of a Beijing tour organized by a Hong Kong\ntravel agent. Investigation of these cases, including tentative\nidentification of the index case, has progressed rapidly. The Hong Kong\ndepartment of health is tracing, for surveillance purposes, the crew\nmembers and passengers who had taken 2 flights. The general public has been\ninformed and a hot-line has been set up.\nWHO epidemiologists in Geneva, together with experts tracking outbreaks in\naffected countries, have decided today that, based on the information\navailable at present, there is no need to change previous WHO advice.\nWHO continues to recommend no travel restrictions to any destination. WHO\nadvises travellers to remain alert to the symptoms of SARS. These include\nhigh fever, respiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath, and\ndifficulty breathing, and should report these symptoms promptly.\nAs of today, 487 SARS cases have been reported from 12 countries.\nA number of persons with SARS have taken long distance flights after\nbecoming ill. Thousands of passengers who travelled in the same flights\nhave been traced in Germany, Canada, Singapore and the United States. No\ncases have been discovered among these contacts. Today's report of a\npossible transmission of SARS on board a flight is undergoing\ninvestigation. As \"close\" contact is possible during a flight, in\npassengers sitting close to an infected person, such transmission cannot be\nruled out. The evidence to date indicates that in-flight transmission is\nvery unusual.\nHealth authorities and hospital staff the world over are now alert to the\nsymptoms of SARS. Suspect cases are being quickly detected and promptly\nreported. Proper isolation and management of cases has greatly reduced the\nrisk of transmission of newly detected cases to others.\nWHO advice to travellers is being kept under constant review. SARS is an\nemerging disease. Knowledge about is clinical behaviour, response to\ntreatment, and modes and risks of transmission are continually evolving.\nWHO is confident that, in the present climate of heightened awareness and\nrapid and detailed reporting, data useful in understanding SARS and issuing\nsound public health advice are being rapidly collected and rapidly made\navailable.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank subscriber John Herbert\n<j_a_herbert@yahoo.com> for sending information following a radio\nannouncement on this advisory.\nAccording to the very thorough investigation of the cases as presented\nabove, it appears as though the transmission would still qualify as \"close\ncontact\" with the chain of transmission being sitting close to an infected\nindividual on a plane, and then being a member of a tour group that spends\nhours together on a daily basis for multiple days. We await further\ninformation from the investigation of this event. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSARS - Worldwide (03): cases 20030324.0735\nSARS - worldwide (02): cases 20030324.0734\nSARS - worldwide: cases 20030323.0722\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (17) 20030322.0713\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (16) 20030322.0711\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (15) 20030322.0707\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (14) 20030321.0704\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (13) 20030321.0703\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (12) 20030321.0702\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (11) 20030320.0698\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (10) 20030319.0689\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (09) 20030319.0688\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (08) 20030318.0679\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (07) 20030318.0678\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (06) 20030318.0677\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (05) 20030317.0669\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (04):comment 20030317.0664\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nInfluenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (05) 20030228.0500\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (06) 20030220.0447\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (05) 20030220.0446\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (04) 20030219.0427\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (03) 20030214.0390\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (02) 20030211.0369\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong): RFI 20030210.0357\n...................mpp/dk\n\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-18 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "284", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - They were\nadmitted to Tuen Mun Hospital on the evening of 22 Mar 2003 and are now in\nstable condition.\nOn receiving the notification on 23 Mar 2003, DH immediately contacted\nother members of the tour. Among them 3, one man and 2 women aged between\n27 and 50, were also confirmed to have developed atypical pneumonia\nsymptoms. They were admitted to Tuen Mun Hospital and Pamela Youde\nNethersole Eastern Hospital for treatment. They are in stable condition.\n6 other members of the tour who had been reported to have coughs, 3 men and\n3 women aged between 32 and 61, were admitted to hospitals for close\nsurveillance earlier. Four of them, comprising 2 men and 2 women aged\nbetween 32 and 51, were confirmed today to have infected with atypical\npneumonia. They are receiving treatment in Queen Elizabeth Hospital. The\nfifth person, a 61-year-old man, is still under observation in Tuen Mun\nHospital. The sixth person, a 48-year-old woman, was discharged yesterday.\nIt is suspected that the couple contracted the disease from a passenger, a\nman aged 73, who sat close to them on their way to Beijing. The man was\nfeeling unwell after visiting his brother in Ward 8A of Prince of Wales\nHospital earlier this month.\nDH has informed the Airport Authority, the Civil Aviation Department and\nthe airline concerned. Advice was also given to the airline concerned to\ndisinfect the airplanes.\nDH is tracing the crew members and passengers who had taken these two\nflights, for surveillance purposes.\nThe spokesman reminded members of the public who have respiratory symptoms\nincluding fever, chills, malaise and cough to avoid traveling by plane\nbefore recovery.\nIt is prudent for tourists to adopt the following precautionary measures to\nprevent atypical pneumonia:\nBuild up good body immunity by having a proper diet, regular exercise and\nadequate rest, reducing stress and avoiding smoking;\nMaintain good personal hygiene, and wash hands after sneezing, coughing or\ncleaning the nose;\nMaintain good ventilation; avoid visiting crowded places with poor ventilation;\nDo not share towels;\nConsult a doctor promptly if you develop respiratory symptoms and fever.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 25 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS update 25 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_03_25/en/>\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) multi-country outbreak - Update 9\nUpdated travel advice\nOn 15 Mar 2003, WHO issued a travel advisory in response to the growing\ninternational threat posed by Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).\nSince then, WHO has conducted daily teleconferences with health authorities\nand WHO team members on the scene in all areas affected by SARS.\nWHO also receives detailed bulletins from ministries of health in the most\nheavily affected areas reporting on any SARS-related events that might\nalter understanding of the behaviour of this new disease.\nToday's communications included a report, from the Hong Kong department of\nhealth, providing detailed preliminary data on the detection of 9 atypical\npneumonia cases among members of a Beijing tour organized by a Hong Kong\ntravel agent. Investigation of these cases, including tentative\nidentification of the index case, has progressed rapidly. The Hong Kong\ndepartment of health is tracing, for surveillance purposes, the crew\nmembers and passengers who had taken 2 flights. The general public has been\ninformed and a hot-line has been set up.\nWHO epidemiologists in Geneva, together with experts tracking outbreaks in\naffected countries, have decided today that, based on the information\navailable at present, there is no need to change previous WHO advice.\nWHO continues to recommend no travel restrictions to any destination. WHO\nadvises travellers to remain alert to the symptoms of SARS. These include\nhigh fever, respiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath, and\ndifficulty breathing, and should report these symptoms promptly.\nAs of today, 487 SARS cases have been reported from 12 countries.\nA number of persons with SARS have taken long distance flights after\nbecoming ill. Thousands of passengers who travelled in the same flights\nhave been traced in Germany, Canada, Singapore and the United States. No\ncases have been discovered among these contacts. Today's report of a\npossible transmission of SARS on board a flight is undergoing\ninvestigation. As \"close\" contact is possible during a flight, in\npassengers sitting close to an infected person, such transmission cannot be\nruled out. The evidence to date indicates that in-flight transmission is\nvery unusual.\nHealth authorities and hospital staff the world over are now alert to the\nsymptoms of SARS. Suspect cases are being quickly detected and promptly\nreported. Proper isolation and management of cases has greatly reduced the\nrisk of transmission of newly detected cases to others.\nWHO advice to travellers is being kept under constant review. SARS is an\nemerging disease. Knowledge about is clinical behaviour, response to\ntreatment, and modes and risks of transmission are continually evolving.\nWHO is confident that, in the present climate of heightened awareness and\nrapid and detailed reporting, data useful in understanding SARS and issuing\nsound public health advice are being rapidly collected and rapidly made\navailable.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank subscriber John Herbert\n<j_a_herbert@yahoo.com> for sending information following a radio\nannouncement on this advisory.\nAccording to the very thorough investigation of the cases as presented\nabove, it appears as though the transmission would still qualify as \"close\ncontact\" with the chain of transmission being sitting close to an infected\nindividual on a plane, and then being a member of a tour group that spends\nhours together on a daily basis for multiple days. We await further\ninformation from the investigation of this event. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSARS - Worldwide (03): cases 20030324.0735\nSARS - worldwide (02): cases 20030324.0734\nSARS - If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-18 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "283", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (10): infectious disease perspectives", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=283", "date": "2003-03-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (05): HONG KONG ADVISORY\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: 25 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong Department of Health 25 Mar 2003\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nHealth Surveillance for airline passengers\n-------------------\nA spokesman for the Department of Health (DH) 25 Mar 2003 called on members\nof the public who had travelled from Hong Kong to Beijing in flight CA 112\non 15 Mar 2003 or from Beijing to Hong Kong in flight CA 115 on 19 Mar 2003\nto call DH's hotline 2961 8968 for health advice.\nThe plea follows the detection of 9 atypical pneumonia cases among members\nof a Beijing tour organized by a Hong Kong travel agent.\nThe tour comprised 35 tour members and a staff member of the travel agent.\nThey left for Beijing in flight CA 112 on 15 Mar 2003 and returned to Hong\nKong in flight CA 115 on 19 Mar 2003.\nInvestigation revealed that a couple who joined the tour, both aged 44, had\ndeveloped symptoms during their stay in Beijing on 18 Mar 2003. They were\nadmitted to Tuen Mun Hospital on the evening of 22 Mar 2003 and are now in\nstable condition.\nOn receiving the notification on 23 Mar 2003, DH immediately contacted\nother members of the tour. Among them 3, one man and 2 women aged between\n27 and 50, were also confirmed to have developed atypical pneumonia\nsymptoms. They were admitted to Tuen Mun Hospital and Pamela Youde\nNethersole Eastern Hospital for treatment. They are in stable condition.\n6 other members of the tour who had been reported to have coughs, 3 men and\n3 women aged between 32 and 61, were admitted to hospitals for close\nsurveillance earlier. Four of them, comprising 2 men and 2 women aged\nbetween 32 and 51, were confirmed today to have infected with atypical\npneumonia. They are receiving treatment in Queen Elizabeth Hospital. The\nfifth person, a 61-year-old man, is still under observation in Tuen Mun\nHospital. The sixth person, a 48-year-old woman, was discharged yesterday.\nIt is suspected that the couple contracted the disease from a passenger, a\nman aged 73, who sat close to them on their way to Beijing. The man was\nfeeling unwell after visiting his brother in Ward 8A of Prince of Wales\nHospital earlier this month.\nDH has informed the Airport Authority, the Civil Aviation Department and\nthe airline concerned. Advice was also given to the airline concerned to\ndisinfect the airplanes.\nDH is tracing the crew members and passengers who had taken these two\nflights, for surveillance purposes.\nThe spokesman reminded members of the public who have respiratory symptoms\nincluding fever, chills, malaise and cough to avoid traveling by plane\nbefore recovery.\nIt is prudent for tourists to adopt the following precautionary measures to\nprevent atypical pneumonia:\nBuild up good body immunity by having a proper diet, regular exercise and\nadequate rest, reducing stress and avoiding smoking;\nMaintain good personal hygiene, and wash hands after sneezing, coughing or\ncleaning the nose;\nMaintain good ventilation; avoid visiting crowded places with poor ventilation;\nDo not share towels;\nConsult a doctor promptly if you develop respiratory symptoms and fever.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 25 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS update 25 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_03_25/en/>\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) multi-country outbreak - Update 9\nUpdated travel advice\nOn 15 Mar 2003, WHO issued a travel advisory in response to the growing\ninternational threat posed by Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).\nSince then, WHO has conducted daily teleconferences with health authorities\nand WHO team members on the scene in all areas affected by SARS.\nWHO also receives detailed bulletins from ministries of health in the most\nheavily affected areas reporting on any SARS-related events that might\nalter understanding of the behaviour of this new disease.\nToday's communications included a report, from the Hong Kong department of\nhealth, providing detailed preliminary data on the detection of 9 atypical\npneumonia cases among members of a Beijing tour organized by a Hong Kong\ntravel agent. Investigation of these cases, including tentative\nidentification of the index case, has progressed rapidly. The Hong Kong\ndepartment of health is tracing, for surveillance purposes, the crew\nmembers and passengers who had taken 2 flights. The general public has been\ninformed and a hot-line has been set up.\nWHO epidemiologists in Geneva, together with experts tracking outbreaks in\naffected countries, have decided today that, based on the information\navailable at present, there is no need to change previous WHO advice.\nWHO continues to recommend no travel restrictions to any destination. WHO\nadvises travellers to remain alert to the symptoms of SARS. These include\nhigh fever, respiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath, and\ndifficulty breathing, and should report these symptoms promptly.\nAs of today, 487 SARS cases have been reported from 12 countries.\nA number of persons with SARS have taken long distance flights after\nbecoming ill. Thousands of passengers who travelled in the same flights\nhave been traced in Germany, Canada, Singapore and the United States. No\ncases have been discovered among these contacts. Today's report of a\npossible transmission of SARS on board a flight is undergoing\ninvestigation. As \"close\" contact is possible during a flight, in\npassengers sitting close to an infected person, such transmission cannot be\nruled out. The evidence to date indicates that in-flight transmission is\nvery unusual.\nHealth authorities and hospital staff the world over are now alert to the\nsymptoms of SARS. Suspect cases are being quickly detected and promptly\nreported. Proper isolation and management of cases has greatly reduced the\nrisk of transmission of newly detected cases to others.\nWHO advice to travellers is being kept under constant review. SARS is an\nemerging disease. Knowledge about is clinical behaviour, response to\ntreatment, and modes and risks of transmission are continually evolving.\nWHO is confident that, in the present climate of heightened awareness and\nrapid and detailed reporting, data useful in understanding SARS and issuing\nsound public health advice are being rapidly collected and rapidly made\navailable.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank subscriber John Herbert\n<j_a_herbert@yahoo.com> for sending information following a radio\nannouncement on this advisory.\nAccording to the very thorough investigation of the cases as presented\nabove, it appears as though the transmission would still qualify as \"close\ncontact\" with the chain of transmission being sitting close to an infected\nindividual on a plane, and then being a member of a tour group that spends\nhours together on a daily basis for multiple days. We await further\ninformation from the investigation of this event. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSARS - Worldwide (03): cases 20030324.0735\nSARS - worldwide (02): cases 20030324.0734\nSARS - worldwide (15) 20030322.0707\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (14) 20030321.0704\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (13) 20030321.0703\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (12) 20030321.0702\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (11) 20030320.0698\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (10) 20030319.0689\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (09) 20030319.0688\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (08) 20030318.0679\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (07) 20030318.0678\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (06) 20030318.0677\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (05) 20030317.0669\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (04):comment 20030317.0664\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nInfluenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (05) 20030228.0500\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (06) 20030220.0447\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (05) 20030220.0446\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (04) 20030219.0427\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (03) 20030214.0390\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (02) 20030211.0369\nPneumonia -
