For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-18 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "281", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (08): China", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=281", "date": "2003-03-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (05): HONG KONG ADVISORY\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: 25 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong Department of Health 25 Mar 2003\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nHealth Surveillance for airline passengers\n-------------------\nA spokesman for the Department of Health (DH) 25 Mar 2003 called on members\nof the public who had travelled from Hong Kong to Beijing in flight CA 112\non 15 Mar 2003 or from Beijing to Hong Kong in flight CA 115 on 19 Mar 2003\nto call DH's hotline 2961 8968 for health advice.\nThe plea follows the detection of 9 atypical pneumonia cases among members\nof a Beijing tour organized by a Hong Kong travel agent.\nThe tour comprised 35 tour members and a staff member of the travel agent.\nThey left for Beijing in flight CA 112 on 15 Mar 2003 and returned to Hong\nKong in flight CA 115 on 19 Mar 2003.\nInvestigation revealed that a couple who joined the tour, both aged 44, had\ndeveloped symptoms during their stay in Beijing on 18 Mar 2003. They were\nadmitted to Tuen Mun Hospital on the evening of 22 Mar 2003 and are now in\nstable condition.\nOn receiving the notification on 23 Mar 2003, DH immediately contacted\nother members of the tour. Among them 3, one man and 2 women aged between\n27 and 50, were also confirmed to have developed atypical pneumonia\nsymptoms. They were admitted to Tuen Mun Hospital and Pamela Youde\nNethersole Eastern Hospital for treatment. They are in stable condition.\n6 other members of the tour who had been reported to have coughs, 3 men and\n3 women aged between 32 and 61, were admitted to hospitals for close\nsurveillance earlier. Four of them, comprising 2 men and 2 women aged\nbetween 32 and 51, were confirmed today to have infected with atypical\npneumonia. They are receiving treatment in Queen Elizabeth Hospital. The\nfifth person, a 61-year-old man, is still under observation in Tuen Mun\nHospital. The sixth person, a 48-year-old woman, was discharged yesterday.\nIt is suspected that the couple contracted the disease from a passenger, a\nman aged 73, who sat close to them on their way to Beijing. The man was\nfeeling unwell after visiting his brother in Ward 8A of Prince of Wales\nHospital earlier this month.\nDH has informed the Airport Authority, the Civil Aviation Department and\nthe airline concerned. Advice was also given to the airline concerned to\ndisinfect the airplanes.\nDH is tracing the crew members and passengers who had taken these two\nflights, for surveillance purposes.\nThe spokesman reminded members of the public who have respiratory symptoms\nincluding fever, chills, malaise and cough to avoid traveling by plane\nbefore recovery.\nIt is prudent for tourists to adopt the following precautionary measures to\nprevent atypical pneumonia:\nBuild up good body immunity by having a proper diet, regular exercise and\nadequate rest, reducing stress and avoiding smoking;\nMaintain good personal hygiene, and wash hands after sneezing, coughing or\ncleaning the nose;\nMaintain good ventilation; avoid visiting crowded places with poor ventilation;\nDo not share towels;\nConsult a doctor promptly if you develop respiratory symptoms and fever.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 25 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS update 25 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_03_25/en/>\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) multi-country outbreak - Update 9\nUpdated travel advice\nOn 15 Mar 2003, WHO issued a travel advisory in response to the growing\ninternational threat posed by Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).\nSince then, WHO has conducted daily teleconferences with health authorities\nand WHO team members on the scene in all areas affected by SARS.\nWHO also receives detailed bulletins from ministries of health in the most\nheavily affected areas reporting on any SARS-related events that might\nalter understanding of the behaviour of this new disease.\nToday's communications included a report, from the Hong Kong department of\nhealth, providing detailed preliminary data on the detection of 9 atypical\npneumonia cases among members of a Beijing tour organized by a Hong Kong\ntravel agent. Investigation of these cases, including tentative\nidentification of the index case, has progressed rapidly. The Hong Kong\ndepartment of health is tracing, for surveillance purposes, the crew\nmembers and passengers who had taken 2 flights. The general public has been\ninformed and a hot-line has been set up.\nWHO epidemiologists in Geneva, together with experts tracking outbreaks in\naffected countries, have decided today that, based on the information\navailable at present, there is no need to change previous WHO advice.\nWHO continues to recommend no travel restrictions to any destination. WHO\nadvises travellers to remain alert to the symptoms of SARS. These include\nhigh fever, respiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath, and\ndifficulty breathing, and should report these symptoms promptly.\nAs of today, 487 SARS cases have been reported from 12 countries.\nA number of persons with SARS have taken long distance flights after\nbecoming ill. Thousands of passengers who travelled in the same flights\nhave been traced in Germany, Canada, Singapore and the United States. No\ncases have been discovered among these contacts. Today's report of a\npossible transmission of SARS on board a flight is undergoing\ninvestigation. As \"close\" contact is possible during a flight, in\npassengers sitting close to an infected person, such transmission cannot be\nruled out. The evidence to date indicates that in-flight transmission is\nvery unusual.\nHealth authorities and hospital staff the world over are now alert to the\nsymptoms of SARS. Suspect cases are being quickly detected and promptly\nreported. Proper isolation and management of cases has greatly reduced the\nrisk of transmission of newly detected cases to others.\nWHO advice to travellers is being kept under constant review. SARS is an\nemerging disease. Knowledge about is clinical behaviour, response to\ntreatment, and modes and risks of transmission are continually evolving.\nWHO is confident that, in the present climate of heightened awareness and\nrapid and detailed reporting, data useful in understanding SARS and issuing\nsound public health advice are being rapidly collected and rapidly made\navailable.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank subscriber John Herbert\n<j_a_herbert@yahoo.com> for sending information following a radio\nannouncement on this advisory.\nAccording to the very thorough investigation of the cases as presented\nabove, it appears as though the transmission would still qualify as \"close\ncontact\" with the chain of transmission being sitting close to an infected\nindividual on a plane, and then being a member of a tour group that spends\nhours together on a daily basis for multiple days. We await further\ninformation from the investigation of this event. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSARS - Worldwide (03): cases 20030324.0735\nSARS - worldwide (02): cases 20030324.0734\nSARS - worldwide (11) 20030320.0698\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (10) 20030319.0689\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (09) 20030319.0688\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (08) 20030318.0679\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (07) 20030318.0678\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - worldwide (06) 20030318.0677\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (05) 20030317.0669\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (04):comment 20030317.0664\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide: alert (03) 20030316.0660\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome - Worldwide (02):alert 20030315.0649\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Worldwide 20030315.0637\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Canada (Ontario) 20030314.0631\nAcute respiratory syndrome - Vietnam (Hanoi): RFI 20030311.0595\nInfluenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (05) 20030228.0500\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (07) 20030221.0452\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (06) 20030220.0447\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (05) 20030220.0446\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (04) 20030219.0427\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (03) 20030214.0390\nPneumonia - China (Guangdong) (02) 20030211.0369\nPneumonia - Investigation of these cases, including tentative\nidentification of the index case, has progressed rapidly. The Hong Kong\ndepartment of health is tracing, for surveillance purposes, the crew\nmembers and passengers who had taken 2 flights. The general public has been\ninformed and a hot-line has been set up.\nWHO epidemiologists in Geneva, together with experts tracking outbreaks in\naffected countries, have decided today that, based on the information\navailable at present, there is no need to change previous WHO advice.\nWHO continues to recommend no travel restrictions to any destination. WHO\nadvises travellers to remain alert to the symptoms of SARS. These include\nhigh fever, respiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath, and\ndifficulty breathing, and should report these symptoms promptly.\nAs of today, 487 SARS cases have been reported from 12 countries.\nA number of persons with SARS have taken long distance flights after\nbecoming ill. Thousands of passengers who travelled in the same flights\nhave been traced in Germany, Canada, Singapore and the United States. No\ncases have been discovered among these contacts. Today's report of a\npossible transmission of SARS on board a flight is undergoing\ninvestigation. As \"close\" contact is possible during a flight, in\npassengers sitting close to an infected person, such transmission cannot be\nruled out. The evidence to date indicates that in-flight transmission is\nvery unusual.\nHealth authorities and hospital staff the world over are now alert to the\nsymptoms of SARS. Suspect cases are being quickly detected and promptly\nreported. Proper isolation and management of cases has greatly reduced the\nrisk of transmission of newly detected cases to others.\nWHO advice to travellers is being kept under constant review. SARS is an\nemerging disease. Knowledge about is clinical behaviour, response to\ntreatment, and modes and risks of transmission are continually evolving.\nWHO is confident that, in the present climate of heightened awareness and\nrapid and detailed reporting, data useful in understanding SARS and issuing\nsound public health advice are being rapidly collected and rapidly made\navailable.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank subscriber John Herbert\n<j_a_herbert@yahoo.com> for sending information following a radio\nannouncement on this advisory.\nAccording to the very thorough investigation of the cases as presented\nabove, it appears as though the transmission would still qualify as \"close\ncontact\" with the chain of transmission being sitting close to an infected\nindividual on a plane, and then being a member of a tour group that spends\nhours together on a daily basis for multiple days. We await further\ninformation from the investigation of this event. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSARS - Worldwide (03): cases 20030324.0735\nSARS - worldwide (02): cases 20030324.0734\nSARS - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2044-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-18 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "278", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (05): Hong Kong advisory", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=278", "date": "2003-03-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (05): HONG KONG ADVISORY\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: 25 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong Department of Health 25 Mar 2003\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nHealth Surveillance for airline passengers\n-------------------\nA spokesman for the Department of Health (DH) 25 Mar 2003 called on members\nof the public who had travelled from Hong Kong to Beijing in flight CA 112\non 15 Mar 2003 or from Beijing to Hong Kong in flight CA 115 on 19 Mar 2003\nto call DH's hotline 2961 8968 for health advice.\nThe plea follows the detection of 9 atypical pneumonia cases among members\nof a Beijing tour organized by a Hong Kong travel agent.\nThe tour comprised 35 tour members and a staff member of the travel agent.\nThey left for Beijing in flight CA 112 on 15 Mar 2003 and returned to Hong\nKong in flight CA 115 on 19 Mar 2003.\nInvestigation revealed that a couple who joined the tour, both aged 44, had\ndeveloped symptoms during their stay in Beijing on 18 Mar 2003. They were\nadmitted to Tuen Mun Hospital on the evening of 22 Mar 2003 and are now in\nstable condition.\nOn receiving the notification on 23 Mar 2003, DH immediately contacted\nother members of the tour. Among them 3, one man and 2 women aged between\n27 and 50, were also confirmed to have developed atypical pneumonia\nsymptoms. They were admitted to Tuen Mun Hospital and Pamela Youde\nNethersole Eastern Hospital for treatment. They are in stable condition.\n6 other members of the tour who had been reported to have coughs, 3 men and\n3 women aged between 32 and 61, were admitted to hospitals for close\nsurveillance earlier. Four of them, comprising 2 men and 2 women aged\nbetween 32 and 51, were confirmed today to have infected with atypical\npneumonia. They are receiving treatment in Queen Elizabeth Hospital. The\nfifth person, a 61-year-old man, is still under observation in Tuen Mun\nHospital. The sixth person, a 48-year-old woman, was discharged yesterday.\nIt is suspected that the couple contracted the disease from a passenger, a\nman aged 73, who sat close to them on their way to Beijing. The man was\nfeeling unwell after visiting his brother in Ward 8A of Prince of Wales\nHospital earlier this month.\nDH has informed the Airport Authority, the Civil Aviation Department and\nthe airline concerned. Advice was also given to the airline concerned to\ndisinfect the airplanes.\nDH is tracing the crew members and passengers who had taken these two\nflights, for surveillance purposes.\nThe spokesman reminded members of the public who have respiratory symptoms\nincluding fever, chills, malaise and cough to avoid traveling by plane\nbefore recovery.\nIt is prudent for tourists to adopt the following precautionary measures to\nprevent atypical pneumonia:\nBuild up good body immunity by having a proper diet, regular exercise and\nadequate rest, reducing stress and avoiding smoking;\nMaintain good personal hygiene, and wash hands after sneezing, coughing or\ncleaning the nose;\nMaintain good ventilation; avoid visiting crowded places with poor ventilation;\nDo not share towels;\nConsult a doctor promptly if you develop respiratory symptoms and fever.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 25 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS update 25 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_03_25/en/>\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) multi-country outbreak - Update 9\nUpdated travel advice\nOn 15 Mar 2003, WHO issued a travel advisory in response to the growing\ninternational threat posed by Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).\nSince then, WHO has conducted daily teleconferences with health authorities\nand WHO team members on the scene in all areas affected by SARS.\nWHO also receives detailed bulletins from ministries of health in the most\nheavily affected areas reporting on any SARS-related events that might\nalter understanding of the behaviour of this new disease.\nToday's communications included a report, from the Hong Kong department of\nhealth, providing detailed preliminary data on the detection of 9 atypical\npneumonia cases among members of a Beijing tour organized by a Hong Kong\ntravel agent. Investigation of these cases, including tentative\nidentification of the index case, has progressed rapidly. The Hong Kong\ndepartment of health is tracing, for surveillance purposes, the crew\nmembers and passengers who had taken 2 flights. The general public has been\ninformed and a hot-line has been set up.\nWHO epidemiologists in Geneva, together with experts tracking outbreaks in\naffected countries, have decided today that, based on the information\navailable at present, there is no need to change previous WHO advice.\nWHO continues to recommend no travel restrictions to any destination. WHO\nadvises travellers to remain alert to the symptoms of SARS. These include\nhigh fever, respiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath, and\ndifficulty breathing, and should report these symptoms promptly.\nAs of today, 487 SARS cases have been reported from 12 countries.\nA number of persons with SARS have taken long distance flights after\nbecoming ill. Thousands of passengers who travelled in the same flights\nhave been traced in Germany, Canada, Singapore and the United States. No\ncases have been discovered among these contacts. Today's report of a\npossible transmission of SARS on board a flight is undergoing\ninvestigation. As \"close\" contact is possible during a flight, in\npassengers sitting close to an infected person, such transmission cannot be\nruled out. The evidence to date indicates that in-flight transmission is\nvery unusual.\nHealth authorities and hospital staff the world over are now alert to the\nsymptoms of SARS. Suspect cases are being quickly detected and promptly\nreported. Proper isolation and management of cases has greatly reduced the\nrisk of transmission of newly detected cases to others.\nWHO advice to travellers is being kept under constant review. SARS is an\nemerging disease. Knowledge about is clinical behaviour, response to\ntreatment, and modes and risks of transmission are continually evolving.\nWHO is confident that, in the present climate of heightened awareness and\nrapid and detailed reporting, data useful in understanding SARS and issuing\nsound public health advice are being rapidly collected and rapidly made\navailable.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank subscriber John Herbert\n<j_a_herbert@yahoo.com> for sending information following a radio\nannouncement on this advisory.\nAccording to the very thorough investigation of the cases as presented\nabove, it appears as though the transmission would still qualify as \"close\ncontact\" with the chain of transmission being sitting close to an infected\nindividual on a plane, and then being a member of a tour group that spends\nhours together on a daily basis for multiple days. We await further\ninformation from the investigation of this event. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nSARS - worldwide (04): etiology 20030325.0737\nSARS - Worldwide (03): cases 20030324.0735\nSARS - worldwide (02): cases 20030324.0734\nSARS - In this report we are focusing on the numbers of cases\nreported and transmission. Information on the identification of the\netiologic agent and development of specific diagnostic tests will be\ncovered separately as has been done by the issuing of separate \"stand\nalone\" posts in the past week. To allow room for more informative titles,\nwe will now use the generally accepted acronym SARS for severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome and add qualifiers to the subject line. - Mod.MPP]\nIn this update:\n[1] Hong Kong - DOH\n[2] Singapore - MOH\n[3] Hong Kong - newswires\n******\n[1]\nDate: 23 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health 23 Mar 2003\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nLatest admission figures\n------------------------\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs at 1pm today (23 Mar 2003), the admission statistics of patients who\nhave been in close contacts with atypical pneumonia patients are as\nfollows: (numbers in brackets are those with symptoms of pneumonia)\nA. Staff of Hospitals/Clinics\nStaff of Prince of Wales Hospital (PWH) admitted to:\nPWH 62 (62)\nPWH (private doctors) 3 (3)\nKwong Wah Hospital 3 (3)\nPrincess Margaret Hospital (PMH) 4 (4)\nTseung Kwan O Hospital (TKOH) 1 (1)\nStaff of Kwong Wah Hospital (KWH) admitted to:\nKWH 4 (4)\nOne of the health workers was discharged\nStaff of Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital (PYNEH) admitted to:\nPYNEH 7 (7)\nStaff of Queen Elizabeth Hospital (QEH) admitted to:\nQEH 5 (2)\nOne of the health workers was discharged\nStaff of a private clinic in Mong Kok admitted to:\nPMH 4 ( 4)\nTuen Mun Hospital 1 (1)\nStaff of a private hospital on HK Island admitted to:\nPYNEH 3 (3)\nStaff of a private hospital in Kowloon admitted to:\nPMH 7 (7)\nPYNEH 1 (1)\nTotal 105 (102)\n2 of the health workers were discharged\nB. Medical students\nMedical students PWH 17 (17)\nOne of the medical students was discharged\nC. Other patients\nPatients, patient's family members & visitors PWH, PMH, PYNEH, QEH, TKOH,\nQueen Mary Hospital & Tuen Mun Hospital 125 (123)\n4 of the patients were discharged\nTotal admissions (A + B + C) 247 (242)\n7 were discharged\n8 patients with atypical pneumonia died recently in the following public\nhospitals: KWH (2 patients); PMH (1); PYNEH (1); PWH (4).\nThe Department of Health's website on atypical pneumonia provides health\nadvice on the prevention of respiratory tract infection and latest\ninformation on the cases in English and Chinese\n.\n[This represents an increase of 25 cases from yesterday's report. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: 23 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore Ministry of Health 23 Mar 2003\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5600>\nUpdate (10) on SARS cases in Singapore\n--------------------------------------\nAs of 23 Mar 2003, a total of 51 people with SARS have been reported to the\nMinistry of Health. The 7 additional patients reported today comprise 3\nhospital staff and 4 close contacts of patients. 3 patients have been\ndischarged from hospital. The other 48 patients are still in hospital. All\nthe patients are stable except for 9 patients who are in a serious condition.\nTo date, apart from the 3 initial people who had travelled to Hong Kong, a\ntotal of 24 family, friends and those who had close contacts with the\ncases, and 24 hospital staff have been diagnosed with SARS. So far, all the\ncases of SARS have been linked to the initial 3 cases. No new index cases\nhave been reported. In addition, no further cases have occurred among\nhospital staff as a result of infection from known or suspected cases of\nSARS after the implementation of enhanced infection control precautions.\nAll suspected and probable cases, including pediatric cases, will be\nmanaged centrally at Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) and the Centre for\nCommunicable Diseases. This will facilitate the management of these\npatients and reduce the risk of secondary transmission of the disease.\nTo free up TTSH's resources to isolate and treat all SARS cases, TTSH will\nnot admit new patients for the next 2 weeks. As such, ambulance cases will\nbe diverted to other hospitals and the public is advised to seek accident\nand emergency care at other hospitals.\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: 23 Mar 2003 13:30 GMT\nFrom: ProMED-mail\nSource: Reuters UK [edited]\n<http://www.reuters.co.uk/newsPackageArticle.jhtml?type=topNews&storyID=242893>\n\nHONG KONG (Reuters): Hong Kong researchers said on Saturday they had\nisolated the virus, found it was new, and designed the first diagnostic\ntest, meaning patients with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) can be\nidentified, and therefore treated, much faster. On Sunday WHO praised the\nHong Kong's team's findings but sounded a note of caution. \"The race to\nidentify the SARS causative agent is by no means over. Although the virus\nhas now been isolated, its identity remains elusive,\" the global body said.\nThe majority of cases are medical workers who have been in close contact\nwith patients or victims' family members. In Hong Kong health officials\nsaid 2 people who worked in the same office as a patient were infected at\nwork. [Other newswire reports have mentioned 3 cases among office workers.\nWe await official news from the Department of Health on these reports. -\nMod.MPP]\nAuthorities in the territory ordered all schools to be disinfected and\nvowed on Sunday to shut for a week any school with a child or staff member\nill with the disease. Education secretary Arthur Li told a news conference\nhe was ordering about 180 children with infected family members to stop\nattending classes for a week from Monday. Officials say 5 schools have\nalready been ordered shut.\nScientists in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Germany, and Canada identified viruses\ntaken from patients as paramyxoviruses, a large family of microbes that\nincludes germs that cause measles, mumps, and respiratory infections. WHO\nsaid other research groups in the network of collaborating labs were\nproducing hints the virus might belong to another family but also expressed\nhope of bringing the epidemic under control.\nThe University of Hong Kong researchers said on Saturday they had designed\nthe world's first SARS diagnostic test, which detects a patient's\nantibodies, which could confirm the diagnosis between 5 and 14 days after\ninfection. Hong Kong doctors have been treating patients with ribavirin --\nan anti-virus drug -- and corticosteroids. They say the regimen works for\nmost patients if treated early.\nHong Kong Hospital Authority director Ko Wing-man said on Sunday one more\npatient had died in Hong Kong, bringing the death toll in the city to 8.\nThe number of infections in Hong Kong rose to 247 on Sunday, including 242\nsuffering full-blown pneumonia.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[An update on the overall worldwide number of cases officially reported was\nnot available at the time of preparation of this report. - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "mumps", "sars", "acute respiratory syndrome"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong - DOH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hanoi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "PWH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong - Department of Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kowloon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "275", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (03): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=275", "date": "2003-03-23 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE: CASES\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[As the volume of postings on this unfolding outbreak and investigation has\nbeen considerable, we have decided to separate reports into different\nposting threads. In this report we are focusing on the numbers of cases\nreported and transmission. Information on the identification of the\netiologic agent and development of specific diagnostic tests will be\ncovered separately as has been done by the issuing of separate \"stand\nalone\" posts in the past week. To allow room for more informative titles,\nwe will now use the generally accepted acronym SARS for severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome and add qualifiers to the subject line. - Mod.MPP]\nIn this update:\n[1] Hong Kong - DOH\n[2] Singapore - MOH\n[3] Hong Kong - newswires\n******\n[1]\nDate: 23 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health 23 Mar 2003\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nLatest admission figures\n------------------------\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs at 1pm today (23 Mar 2003), the admission statistics of patients who\nhave been in close contacts with atypical pneumonia patients are as\nfollows: (numbers in brackets are those with symptoms of pneumonia)\nA. Staff of Hospitals/Clinics\nStaff of Prince of Wales Hospital (PWH) admitted to:\nPWH 62 (62)\nPWH (private doctors) 3 (3)\nKwong Wah Hospital 3 (3)\nPrincess Margaret Hospital (PMH) 4 (4)\nTseung Kwan O Hospital (TKOH) 1 (1)\nStaff of Kwong Wah Hospital (KWH) admitted to:\nKWH 4 (4)\nOne of the health workers was discharged\nStaff of Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital (PYNEH) admitted to:\nPYNEH 7 (7)\nStaff of Queen Elizabeth Hospital (QEH) admitted to:\nQEH 5 (2)\nOne of the health workers was discharged\nStaff of a private clinic in Mong Kok admitted to:\nPMH 4 ( 4)\nTuen Mun Hospital 1 (1)\nStaff of a private hospital on HK Island admitted to:\nPYNEH 3 (3)\nStaff of a private hospital in Kowloon admitted to:\nPMH 7 (7)\nPYNEH 1 (1)\nTotal 105 (102)\n2 of the health workers were discharged\nB. Medical students\nMedical students PWH 17 (17)\nOne of the medical students was discharged\nC. Other patients\nPatients, patient's family members & visitors PWH, PMH, PYNEH, QEH, TKOH,\nQueen Mary Hospital & Tuen Mun Hospital 125 (123)\n4 of the patients were discharged\nTotal admissions (A + B + C) 247 (242)\n7 were discharged\n8 patients with atypical pneumonia died recently in the following public\nhospitals: KWH (2 patients); PMH (1); PYNEH (1); PWH (4).\nThe Department of Health's website on atypical pneumonia provides health\nadvice on the prevention of respiratory tract infection and latest\ninformation on the cases in English and Chinese\n.\n[This represents an increase of 25 cases from yesterday's report. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: 23 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore Ministry of Health 23 Mar 2003\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5600>\nUpdate (10) on SARS cases in Singapore\n--------------------------------------\nAs of 23 Mar 2003, a total of 51 people with SARS have been reported to the\nMinistry of Health. The 7 additional patients reported today comprise 3\nhospital staff and 4 close contacts of patients. 3 patients have been\ndischarged from hospital. The other 48 patients are still in hospital. All\nthe patients are stable except for 9 patients who are in a serious condition.\nTo date, apart from the 3 initial people who had travelled to Hong Kong, a\ntotal of 24 family, friends and those who had close contacts with the\ncases, and 24 hospital staff have been diagnosed with SARS. So far, all the\ncases of SARS have been linked to the initial 3 cases. No new index cases\nhave been reported. In addition, no further cases have occurred among\nhospital staff as a result of infection from known or suspected cases of\nSARS after the implementation of enhanced infection control precautions.\nAll suspected and probable cases, including pediatric cases, will be\nmanaged centrally at Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) and the Centre for\nCommunicable Diseases. This will facilitate the management of these\npatients and reduce the risk of secondary transmission of the disease.\nTo free up TTSH's resources to isolate and treat all SARS cases, TTSH will\nnot admit new patients for the next 2 weeks. As such, ambulance cases will\nbe diverted to other hospitals and the public is advised to seek accident\nand emergency care at other hospitals.\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: 23 Mar 2003 13:30 GMT\nFrom: ProMED-mail\nSource: Reuters UK [edited]\n<http://www.reuters.co.uk/newsPackageArticle.jhtml?type=topNews&storyID=242893>\n\nHONG KONG (Reuters): Hong Kong researchers said on Saturday they had\nisolated the virus, found it was new, and designed the first diagnostic\ntest, meaning patients with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) can be\nidentified, and therefore treated, much faster. On Sunday WHO praised the\nHong Kong's team's findings but sounded a note of caution. \"The race to\nidentify the SARS causative agent is by no means over. Although the virus\nhas now been isolated, its identity remains elusive,\" the global body said.\nThe majority of cases are medical workers who have been in close contact\nwith patients or victims' family members. In Hong Kong health officials\nsaid 2 people who worked in the same office as a patient were infected at\nwork. [Other newswire reports have mentioned 3 cases among office workers.\nWe await official news from the Department of Health on these reports. -\nMod.MPP]\nAuthorities in the territory ordered all schools to be disinfected and\nvowed on Sunday to shut for a week any school with a child or staff member\nill with the disease. Education secretary Arthur Li told a news conference\nhe was ordering about 180 children with infected family members to stop\nattending classes for a week from Monday. Officials say 5 schools have\nalready been ordered shut.\nScientists in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Germany, and Canada identified viruses\ntaken from patients as paramyxoviruses, a large family of microbes that\nincludes germs that cause measles, mumps, and respiratory infections. WHO\nsaid other research groups in the network of collaborating labs were\nproducing hints the virus might belong to another family but also expressed\nhope of bringing the epidemic under control.\nThe University of Hong Kong researchers said on Saturday they had designed\nthe world's first SARS diagnostic test, which detects a patient's\nantibodies, which could confirm the diagnosis between 5 and 14 days after\ninfection. Hong Kong doctors have been treating patients with ribavirin --\nan anti-virus drug -- and corticosteroids. They say the regimen works for\nmost patients if treated early.\nHong Kong Hospital Authority director Ko Wing-man said on Sunday one more\npatient had died in Hong Kong, bringing the death toll in the city to 8.\nThe number of infections in Hong Kong rose to 247 on Sunday, including 242\nsuffering full-blown pneumonia.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[An update on the overall worldwide number of cases officially reported was\nnot available at the time of preparation of this report. - Other patients\nPatients, patient's family members & visitors PWH, PMH, PYNEH, QEH, TKOH,\nQueen Mary Hospital & Tuen Mun Hospital 125 (123)\n4 of the patients were discharged\nTotal admissions (A + B + C) 247 (242)\n7 were discharged\n8 patients with atypical pneumonia died recently in the following public\nhospitals: KWH (2 patients); PMH (1); PYNEH (1); PWH (4).\nThe Department of Health's website on atypical pneumonia provides health\nadvice on the prevention of respiratory tract infection and latest\ninformation on the cases in English and Chinese\n.\n[This represents an increase of 25 cases from yesterday's report. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: 23 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore Ministry of Health 23 Mar 2003\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5600>\nUpdate (10) on SARS cases in Singapore\n--------------------------------------\nAs of 23 Mar 2003, a total of 51 people with SARS have been reported to the\nMinistry of Health. The 7 additional patients reported today comprise 3\nhospital staff and 4 close contacts of patients. 3 patients have been\ndischarged from hospital. The other 48 patients are still in hospital. All\nthe patients are stable except for 9 patients who are in a serious condition.\nTo date, apart from the 3 initial people who had travelled to Hong Kong, a\ntotal of 24 family, friends and those who had close contacts with the\ncases, and 24 hospital staff have been diagnosed with SARS. So far, all the\ncases of SARS have been linked to the initial 3 cases. No new index cases\nhave been reported. In addition, no further cases have occurred among\nhospital staff as a result of infection from known or suspected cases of\nSARS after the implementation of enhanced infection control precautions.\nAll suspected and probable cases, including pediatric cases, will be\nmanaged centrally at Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) and the Centre for\nCommunicable Diseases. This will facilitate the management of these\npatients and reduce the risk of secondary transmission of the disease.\nTo free up TTSH's resources to isolate and treat all SARS cases, TTSH will\nnot admit new patients for the next 2 weeks. As such, ambulance cases will\nbe diverted to other hospitals and the public is advised to seek accident\nand emergency care at other hospitals.\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: 23 Mar 2003 13:30 GMT\nFrom: ProMED-mail\nSource: Reuters UK [edited]\n<http://www.reuters.co.uk/newsPackageArticle.jhtml?type=topNews&storyID=242893>\n\nHONG KONG (Reuters): Hong Kong researchers said on Saturday they had\nisolated the virus, found it was new, and designed the first diagnostic\ntest, meaning patients with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) can be\nidentified, and therefore treated, much faster. On Sunday WHO praised the\nHong Kong's team's findings but sounded a note of caution. \"The race to\nidentify the SARS causative agent is by no means over. Although the virus\nhas now been isolated, its identity remains elusive,\" the global body said.\nThe majority of cases are medical workers who have been in close contact\nwith patients or victims' family members. In Hong Kong health officials\nsaid 2 people who worked in the same office as a patient were infected at\nwork. [Other newswire reports have mentioned 3 cases among office workers.\nWe await official news from the Department of Health on these reports. -\nMod.MPP]\nAuthorities in the territory ordered all schools to be disinfected and\nvowed on Sunday to shut for a week any school with a child or staff member\nill with the disease. Education secretary Arthur Li told a news conference\nhe was ordering about 180 children with infected family members to stop\nattending classes for a week from Monday. Officials say 5 schools have\nalready been ordered shut.\nScientists in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Germany, and Canada identified viruses\ntaken from patients as paramyxoviruses, a large family of microbes that\nincludes germs that cause measles, mumps, and respiratory infections. WHO\nsaid other research groups in the network of collaborating labs were\nproducing hints the virus might belong to another family but also expressed\nhope of bringing the epidemic under control.\nThe University of Hong Kong researchers said on Saturday they had designed\nthe world's first SARS diagnostic test, which detects a patient's\nantibodies, which could confirm the diagnosis between 5 and 14 days after\ninfection. Hong Kong doctors have been treating patients with ribavirin --\nan anti-virus drug -- and corticosteroids. They say the regimen works for\nmost patients if treated early.\nHong Kong Hospital Authority director Ko Wing-man said on Sunday one more\npatient had died in Hong Kong, bringing the death toll in the city to 8.\nThe number of infections in Hong Kong rose to 247 on Sunday, including 242\nsuffering full-blown pneumonia.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[An update on the overall worldwide number of cases officially reported was\nnot available at the time of preparation of this report. -
